研究工艺

The Craft of Research

第四版

Fourth Edition

韦恩·C·布斯

Wayne C. Booth

格雷戈里·科伦布

Gregory G. Colomb

约瑟夫·威廉姆斯

Joseph M. Williams

约瑟夫·比祖普

Joseph Bizup

威廉·T·菲茨杰拉德

William T. FitzGerald

芝加哥大学出版社

The University of Chicago Press

芝加哥和伦敦

Chicago & London

韦恩·布斯 ( Wayne C. Booth )（1921-2005 年）是芝加哥大学英语语言文学专业的乔治·M·普尔曼 (George M. Pullman) 杰出服务名誉教授。他的著作包括The Rhetoric of Fiction和For the Love of It: Amateuring and Its Rivals，均由芝加哥大学出版社出版。

Wayne C. Booth (1921–2005) was the George M. Pullman Distinguished Service Professor Emeritus in English Language and Literature at the University of Chicago. His books included The Rhetoric of Fiction and For the Love of It: Amateuring and Its Rivals, both published by the University of Chicago Press.

Gregory G. Colomb（1951-2011）是弗吉尼亚大学的英语教授，也是《设计真相：奥古斯都模拟史诗的诗学》一书的作者。

Gregory G. Colomb (1951–2011) was professor of English at the University of Virginia and the author of Designs on Truth: The Poetics of the Augustan Mock-Epic.

约瑟夫·威廉姆斯(1933–2008) 是芝加哥大学英语语言文学系教授，着有《风格：走向清晰与优雅》一书。

Joseph M. Williams (1933–2008) was professor in the Department of English Language and Literature at the University of Chicago and the author of Style: Toward Clarity and Grace.

约瑟夫·比祖普 (Joseph Bizup ) 是波士顿大学英语系副教授，也是文理学院写作项目的助理院长和主任。他是《制造文化：维多利亚早期工业的辩护》一书的作者。

Joseph Bizup is associate professor in the Department of English at Boston University as well as assistant dean and director of the College of Arts and Sciences Writing Program. He is the author of Manufacturing Culture: Vindications of Early Victorian Industry.

William T. FitzGerald是罗格斯大学英语系的副教授。他是《精神形态：作为修辞和表演的祈祷》一书的作者。

William T. FitzGerald is associate professor in the Department of English at Rutgers University. He is the author of Spiritual Modalities: Prayer as Rhetoric and Performance.

芝加哥大学出版社，芝加哥 60637

The University of Chicago Press, Chicago 60637

The University of Chicago Press, Ltd., London

前言

Preface

本版的目标

The Aims of This Edition

《研究的技艺》第四版是该书的三位原作者韦恩·C·布斯、格雷戈里·G·科隆和约瑟夫·威廉姆斯去世后的第一版。在进行这次修订时，我们——约瑟夫·比祖普 (Joseph Bizup) 和威廉·T·菲茨杰拉德 (William T。我们的目标是在不盗用原作者的情况下对其进行更新和完善。

This fourth edition of The Craft of Research is the first to appear since the deaths of the book’s three original authors, Wayne C. Booth, Gregory G. Colomb, and Joseph M. Williams. In undertaking this revision, we—Joseph Bizup and William T. FitzGerald—faced the pleasurable and challenging task of reworking a book we have both long admired. Our goal has been to update and refine it without appropriating it from its original authors.

第四版与前三版具有相同的主要目标：满足所有研究人员的需求，不仅是一年级本科生和高年级研究生，甚至是从事和报告任何主题、学术、政治的，或商业的。这本书是写给

The fourth edition has the same main aim as the first three: to meet the needs of all researchers, not just first-year undergraduates and advanced graduate students, but even those in business and government who do and report research on any topic, academic, political, or commercial. The book was written to

• 指导您完成将一个主题或问题转化为一个研究问题的复杂过程，该问题的重要性与您为解决它所付出的努力相匹配；

• guide you through the complexities of turning a topic or question into a research problem whose significance matches the effort that you put into solving it;

• 帮助您组织和起草一份报告，证明您的努力是正确的；

• help you organize and draft a report that justifies the effort;

• 向您展示如何按照读者的意愿阅读您的报告，以便您可以将其修改为他们将以其应有的理解和尊重阅读的报告。

• show you how to read your report as your readers will so that you can revise it into one that they will read with the understanding and respect it deserves.

其他手册涉及这些问题，但这本有所不同。目前的大多数指南都承认，研究人员很少在寻找主题、陈述论文、填写便条卡、起草和修改之间直线前进。有经验的研究人员来回循环，前进一两步再继续返回以再次前进，改变方向，同时期待尚未开始的阶段。但据我们所知，没有其他指南试图解释过程的每个部分如何影响所有其他部分——开发项目如何让研究人员为起草做好准备，起草如何揭示论点中的问题，写介绍如何提示你做更多的研究。

Other handbooks touch on these matters, but this one is different. Most current guides acknowledge that researchers rarely move in a straight line from finding a topic to stating a thesis to filling in note cards to drafting and revision. Experienced researchers loop back and forth, move forward a step or two before going back in order to move ahead again, change directions, all the while anticipating stages not yet begun. But so far as we know, no other guide tries to explain how each part of the process influences all the others—how developing a project prepares the researcher for drafting, how drafting can reveal problems in an argument, how writing an introduction can prompt you to do more research.

特别是，本书试图明确说明其他指南视为无法分析和解释的神秘创作过程的事项，包括

In particular, the book tries to be explicit about matters that other guides treat as a mysterious creative process beyond analysis and explanation, including

• 如何将模糊的兴趣转化为读者认为值得提出和解决的问题；

• how to turn a vague interest into a problem readers think is worth posing and solving;

• 如何建立一个论点来激励读者认真对待你的主张；

• how to build an argument that motivates readers to take your claim seriously;

• 如何预见深思熟虑但挑剔的读者的保留意见，然后做出适当回应；

• how to anticipate the reservations of thoughtful but critical readers and then respond appropriately;

• 如何创建引言和结论来回答读者最棘手的问题，那又怎样？;

• how to create an introduction and conclusion answering that toughest of questions from readers, So what?;

• 如何按照读者的意愿阅读您自己的作品，从而知道何时以及如何修改它。

• how to read your own writing as readers will, and thereby know when and how to revise it.

每一章的核心都是站在读者一边的建议，想象他们将如何评价你所写的内容。

Central in every chapter is the advice to side with your readers, to imagine how they will judge what you have written.

这本书解决了大多数基于研究的写作类型所共有的形式元素，这不仅是因为作家需要了解它们的表面形状，而且因为它们可以帮助作家思考。这些类型——研究论文、研究报告、白皮书和许多其他类型——不是空洞的模式或形式：它们还体现并实现了特定的工作和争论方式；它们帮助我们所有人开发和完善我们的项目，测试我们的工作，甚至发现新的思路。因此，我们的写作方式会影响我们的论证和研究方式，反之亦然。从这个意义上说，学习一个领域的流派就是学习这个领域本身。

The book addresses the formal elements common to most genres of research-based writing not just because writers need to understand their superficial shape but also because they help writers think. These genres—the research paper, the research report, the white paper, and many others—are not empty patterns or forms: they also embody and enable specific ways of working and arguing; they help us all to develop and refine our projects, test our work, and even discover new lines of thought. How we write thus affects how we argue and research, and vice versa. In this sense, to learn the genres of one’s field is to learn the field itself.

这本书还受到另一个信念的启发：研究和基于研究的写作技能不仅适用于精英，而且每个人都可以学习。高级研究的某些方面只能在特定研究人员社区的背景下学习，但即使您还不属于某个社区，您仍然可以自己创建类似的东西。我们的“教师后记”建议了您（和您的老师）可以做到这一点的方法。

The book is informed by another conviction as well: that the skills of research and research-based writing are not just for the elite but can be learned by everyone. Some aspects of advanced research can be learned only in the context of a specific community of researchers, but even if you don’t yet belong to one, you can still create something like it on your own. Our “Postscript for Teachers” suggests ways you (and your teachers) can do that.

本版未解决的问题

What This Edition Does Not Address

与《研究的技艺》的前几版一样，第 4 版对研究进行了一般性处理。它不讨论如何将叙述、“详细描述”或视听形式的证据纳入你的论点。它们是重要的话题，但太大了，我们无法在这里公正地对待它们。此版本也不涵盖特定领域的研究技术。同样，虽然它讨论了应该指导在线研究的原则，但它并没有试图描述现在在线和通过图书馆提供的大量专业搜索工具和数据库。我们的参考书目建议了这些领域的许多指导来源。

Like the previous editions of The Craft of Research, this fourth edition treats research generally. It does not discuss how to incorporate narratives, “thick descriptions,” or audiovisual forms of evidence into your arguments. They are important topics, but too large for us to do justice to them here. Nor does this edition cover research techniques that are specific to particular fields. Likewise, while it discusses the principles that should guide online research, it does not attempt to describe the vast array of specialized search tools and databases now available online and through the library. Our bibliography suggests a number of sources for guidance in those areas.

此版本的新功能

What’s New in This Edition

在准备第四版时，我们牢记早期版本的积极反响和它们吸引的广泛受众，受众范围从作文课的一年级学生到研究生和其他高级研究人员，甚至是工作的专业人士在商业、医学和法律等领域。事实上，读者是国际读者：这本书已被翻译成俄语、西班牙语、葡萄牙语、韩语、日语和中文。

In preparing this fourth edition, we have kept in mind the positive reception of earlier editions and the wide audience they attracted, an audience that ranges from first-year students in composition classes, to graduate students and other advanced researchers, and even to professionals working in fields such as business, medicine, and law. Indeed, this audience is an international one: the book has been translated into Russian, Spanish, Portuguese, Korean, Japanese, and Chinese.

我们最为关注的是，The Craft of Research是三位才华横溢的教师和学者之间非凡合作的结果，我们很自豪能够追随他们的脚步。在寻求帮助这本书与新一代研究人员交流的同时，我们还努力尊重并保留使《研究的工艺》成为公认经典的观点、内容和声音。熟悉早期版本的人会发现，这一版忠实于本书的愿景和整体结构体。同时，每一章都进行了彻底更新，以反映当代研究的情况。

What we have been most mindful of is that The Craft of Research is the result of an extraordinary collaboration among three gifted teachers and scholars in whose footsteps we are proud to follow. While seeking to help the book speak to new generations of researchers, we have also striven to honor and retain the perspective, content, and voice that have made The Craft of Research a recognized classic. Those who are familiar with earlier editions will discover that this edition is faithful to the book’s vision and overall structure. At the same time, each chapter has been thoroughly updated to reflect the contemporary landscape of research.

具体来说，这是我们所做的：

Here, concretely, is what we’ve done:

• 我们修订了第5章和第6章，以纳入图书馆和互联网研究以及参与源材料方面的最新发展。特别是，我们强调了在线数据库和搜索引擎带来的新研究技术以及在线资源的价值，同时需要评估这些资源的可靠性。

• We revised chapters 5 and 6 to incorporate recent developments in library and Internet research and in engaging source materials. Especially, we emphasized new research techniques made possible by online databases and search engines and the value of online sources, balanced by the need to assess these sources’ reliability.

• 我们再次修改了关于权证的章节（第11 章），这是一个在以前的版本中难以解释的问题。

• We again revised the chapter on warrants (chapter 11), a matter that has been difficult to explain in previous editions.

• 我们将第13章的前两节移到了第12章，现在的标题是“计划和起草”，并调换了第13章和第14章的顺序，现在分别是“组织论点”和“合并资料来源”。

• We moved the first two sections of chapter 13 into chapter 12, which is now titled “Planning and Drafting,” and switched the order of chapters 13 and 14, now titled “Organizing Your Argument” and “Incorporating Sources,” respectively.

• 自始至终，如我们认为有必要，我们澄清了概念并提供了新的示例。

• Throughout, as we thought necessary, we clarified concepts and provided fresh examples.

• 我们区分了相关但不同的研究、论证和写作活动。

• We differentiated the related but distinct activities of research, argument, and writing.

• 在可能的情况下，我们对术语进行了标准化（例如，使用“论文”而不是“报告”）来反映作为研究产品的学术和专业类型的范围。

• Wherever possible, we standardized terms (e.g., using “paper” rather than “report”) to reflect the range of academic and professional genres that are the products of research.

在做这一切的过程中，我们已经尝试——正如布斯、科隆和威廉姆斯在之前的版本中所做的那样——保持和蔼可亲的声音、直率的感觉以及同事们一起工作的立场，许多人认为这对本书的成功至关重要。

In doing all that, we have tried—as Booth, Colomb, and Williams did in prior editions—to preserve the amiable voice, the sense of directness, and the stance of colleagues working together that so many have found crucial to the book’s success.

我们的债务

Our Debts

来自 JB 和 WF：我们要感谢我们的编辑 David Morrow 和他在芝加哥大学出版社的同事们的洞察力和指导，最重要的是，感谢他们对我们的信任，让我们修改了一份无与伦比的文本场。这是一种爱的劳动。

From JB and WF: We wish to thank our editor, David Morrow, and his colleagues at the University of Chicago Press for their insight and guidance and, above all, for the trust they placed in us to revise a text that has no equal in the field. It was a labor of love.

我们与 Booth、Colomb 和 Williams 一起再次感谢许多人，如果没有他们的帮助，以前的版本就不可能实现，尤其是 Jane Andrew、Steve Biegel 和 Donald Freeman。其中包括 Jane Block、Don Brenneis、Sara Bryant、Diane Carothers、Sam Cha、Tina Chrzastowski、John Cox、James Donato、Kristine Fowler、Joe Harmon、Clara Lopez、Bill McClellan、Mark Monmonier、Nancy O'Brien、Kim Steele、大卫·斯特恩、艾伦·萨顿和莱斯利·特劳特曼。

We join Booth, Colomb, and Williams in again thanking the many without whose help the previous editions could never have been realized, especially Jane Andrew, Steve Biegel, and Donald Freeman. These many include Jane Block, Don Brenneis, Sara Bryant, Diane Carothers, Sam Cha, Tina Chrzastowski, John Cox, James Donato, Kristine Fowler, Joe Harmon, Clara Lopez, Bill McClellan, Mark Monmonier, Nancy O’Brien, Kim Steele, David Stern, Ellen Sutton, and Leslie Troutman.

Joe Bizup 感谢他的妻子 Annmarie Caracansi 和女儿 Grace 和 Charlotte；Bill FitzGerald 同样感谢他的妻子 Emilia Lievano 和女儿 Magdalena。我们都感谢各自家人的爱、耐心和支持。

Joe Bizup thanks his wife, Annmarie Caracansi, and daughters, Grace and Charlotte; and Bill FitzGerald likewise thanks his wife, Emilia Lievano, and daughter, Magdalena. We are both grateful for our respective families’ love, patience, and support.

我们允许 Booth、Colomb 和 Williams 再次用他们自己的话表达他们的个人谢意。

We allow Booth, Colomb, and Williams to once again offer their personal acknowledgments in their own words.

来自 WCB（为第二版作曲）：当我回想我 50 多年的教学和研究时，我很惊讶有多少学生和同事可以在这里引用，因为他们减少了我的无知。由于该列表太长，我将主要感谢我的首席评论家、我的妻子 Phyllis，感谢她提供的许多有用的建议和仔细的编辑。她和我的女儿凯瑟琳·史蒂文斯和艾莉森·布斯，以及她们的孩子罗宾、艾米丽和亚伦和所有这些同事一起，帮助我克服了偶尔对负责任调查的未来感到绝望的情绪。

From WCB (composed for the second edition): I am amazed as I think back on my more than fifty years of teaching and research by how many students and colleagues could be cited here as having diminished my ignorance. Since that list would be too long, I’ll thank mainly my chief critic, my wife, Phyllis, for her many useful suggestions and careful editing. She and my daughters, Katherine Stevens and Alison Booth, and their children, Robin, Emily, and Aaron, along with all those colleagues, have helped me combat my occasional despair about the future of responsible inquiry.

来自 GGC：我也很幸运有学生和同事教了我很多东西——首先是数百名研究生，他们与我分享了他们成为教师的经历。最重要的是，他们向我展示了协作探究的可能性。不过，我最依赖的是家和家人：Sandra、Robin、Kikki、Karen 和 Lauren。在动荡和平静的时期，他们为这一切赋予了意义和目的。在他们之前是另一个充满爱的家庭，其中心人物玛丽仍然树立了一个我只能向往的榜样。

From GGC: I, too, have been blessed with students and colleagues who have taught me much—first among them the hundreds of grad students who shared with me their learning to be teachers. They, above all, have shown me the possibilities in collaborative inquiry. What I lean on most, though, are home and family: Sandra, Robin, Kikki, Karen, and Lauren. Through turbulent times and calm, they gave point and purpose to it all. Before them was another loving family, whose center, Mary, still sets an example to which I can only aspire.

来自 JMW：自第一版以来，这个家庭的人数增加了两倍，我更加感谢他们的爱和支持：Ol、Michele 和 Eleanor；克里斯和英格丽德；戴夫、帕蒂、马蒂尔德和欧文；梅根、菲尔、莉莉和卡尔文；乔、克里斯汀、尼古拉斯和凯瑟琳。在开头和结尾，琼，她的耐心、爱心和敏锐的判断力比我应得的还要丰富。

From JMW: The family has tripled in size since the first edition, and I am ever more grateful for their love and support: Ol, Michele, and Eleanor; Chris and Ingrid; Dave, Patty, Matilde, and Owen; Megan, Phil, Lily, and Calvin; Joe, Christine, Nicholas, and Katherine. And at beginning and end, Joan, whose patience, love, and good sense flow still more bountifully than I deserve.

在悼念

In Memoriam

韦恩·C·布斯

Wayne C. Booth

(1921–2005)

(1921–2005)

格雷戈里·科伦布

Gregory G. Colomb

(1951–2011)

(1951–2011)

约瑟夫·威廉姆斯

Joseph M. Williams

(1933–2008)

(1933–2008)

第一部分

Part I

研究、研究人员和读者

Research, Researchers, and Readers

序幕

Prologue

成为一名研究员

Becoming a Researcher

谁需要研究？

WHO NEEDS RESEARCH?

当您想到研究人员时，您会想到什么？穿着实验室外套的人在窥视显微镜？一个在图书馆做笔记的孤独人物？这是大多数人的想象。但您可能还想象过 MSNBC 的 Rachel Maddow、HBO 的 John Oliver 或任何在写作或演讲前进行大量准备的人。就像几乎所有成功人士一样，他们不仅是做研究的专家，而且是利用他人研究成果的专家。事实上，这是他们成功的部分原因。在一个名副其实的“信息时代”，他们不仅学会了如何查找信息，还学会了如何评估信息，然后如何清晰准确地报告信息。（通常，他们会挑战错误信息。）这些技能比以往任何时候都更成为任何职业成功的必要条件。

When you think of a researcher, what do you imagine? Someone in a lab coat peering into a microscope? A solitary figure taking notes in a library? That’s what most people imagine. But you might have also pictured MSNBC’s Rachel Maddow, HBO’s John Oliver, or anyone who prepares extensively before writing or speaking. Like just about every successful person, they are not only experts in doing research, but in using the research of others. In fact, that’s part of what makes them successful. In an aptly named “age of information,” they have learned not only how to find information, but how to evaluate it, then how to report it clearly and accurately. (Often, they challenge misinformation.) More than ever, those skills are essential for success in any profession.

你可能还不是专业人士，但现在学习做研究会在今天帮助你，并为未来做好准备。首先，它将帮助您理解您阅读的内容，这是其他任何东西都做不到的。只有完成了自己的研究，你才能准确判断别人的研究，才能理解教科书或电视上专家如此流畅自信地呈现的东西背后的混乱现实。互联网和有线电视向我们灌输了关于政府、经济、环境和我们购买的产品的“事实”。其中一些事实是合理的，尽管许多事实并非如此。这就是为什么，当你学习做研究时，你也会学会重视清晰准确地报告的可靠研究。

You may not yet be a professional, but learning to do research now will help you today and prepare you for what’s to come. First, it will help you understand what you read as nothing else will. You can accurately judge the research of others only after you’ve done your own and can understand the messy reality behind what is so smoothly and confidently presented in your textbooks or by experts on TV. The Internet and cable TV flood us with “facts” about the government, the economy, the environment, and the products we buy. Some of these facts are sound, though many are not. That’s why, as you learn to do research, you’ll also learn to value reliable research reported clearly and accurately.

您会发现新知识如何取决于您提出的问题以及您思考和交流的方式您的研究塑造了这些问题和您的答案。最重要的是，您将了解我们所依赖的知识如何取决于支持它的研究质量及其报告的准确性。尽管有些人可能认为这是理想主义的，但进行研究的另一个原因是解决难题、发现别人不知道的事情的纯粹乐趣。

You’ll discover both how new knowledge depends on what questions you ask and how the way you think about and communicate your research shapes those questions and your answers. Most important, you’ll come to understand how the knowledge we all rely on depends on the quality of the research that supports it and the accuracy of its reporting. Although some might think it idealistic, another reason for doing research is the sheer pleasure of solving a puzzle, of discovering something that no one else knows.

但是学习做研究不像学习骑自行车，那种你学过一次就永远不会忘记的东西。我们每个人都开始了一些项目，这些项目迫使我们重新思考我们的工作方式。每当我们面对一个新的研究社区时，我们都必须学习它的方法来帮助我们理解其成员认为重要的事情。但即便如此，我们仍然可以依赖所有研究人员遵循的原则，即我们在本书中描述的原则。我们认为，随着您的项目和读者在学校和毕业后的要求越来越高，您会发现它们很有用。

But learning to do research is not like learning to ride a bike, the sort of thing you learn once and never forget. Each of us has started projects that forced us to rethink how we do our work. Whenever we’ve addressed a new research community, we’ve had to learn its ways to help us understand what its members think is important. But even then, we could still rely on principles that all researchers follow, principles that we describe in this book. We think you will find them useful as your projects and readers become more demanding, both in school and after.

不过，我们必须坦率地说：仔细地进行研究并清楚地报告它是一项艰巨的工作，由许多任务组成，通常同时争夺您的注意力。而且，无论您计划得多么周密，研究都会走一条曲折的道路，出现意想不到的转折，有时会走上死胡同，甚至会自行倒退。尽管该过程非常复杂，但我们将逐步完成它，以便您了解其各部分如何协同工作。当您可以管理它的各个部分时，您就可以管理通常令人生畏的整体，并期待以更大的信心进行更多的研究。

We must be candid, though: doing research carefully and reporting it clearly are hard work, consisting of many tasks, often competing for your attention at the same time. And no matter how carefully you plan, research follows a crooked path, taking unexpected turns, sometimes up blind alleys, even looping back on itself. As complex as that process is, we will work through it step-by-step so that you can see how its parts work together. When you can manage its parts, you can manage the often intimidating whole and look forward to doing more research with greater confidence.

开始研究项目

STARTING A RESEARCH PROJECT

如果您正在开始您的第一个项目，任务可能看起来很艰巨：我如何专注于一个主题？我在哪里可以找到有关它的信息？找到后我该怎么办？即使你已经在写作课上完成了一篇“研究论文”，如果这次是真实的，另一个人的想法可能会更加令人生畏。如果是这样，你并不孤单。即使是经验丰富的研究人员在为新受众处理一种新项目时也会感到焦虑。因此，无论您感到什么焦虑，大多数研究人员也都感受到了。不同之处在于，有经验的研究人员知道前方会发生什么——艰苦的工作，但也有乐趣；有些沮丧，但更多的是满足；混乱的时期，但相信最终一切都会走到一起，而且结果是值得付出努力的。最重要的是，经验丰富的研究人员知道如何从头到尾完成，也许并不容易，但在任务的复杂性允许的范围内尽可能高效。这就是本书的目的。

If you are beginning your first project, the task may seem overwhelming: How do I focus on a topic? Where do I find information on it? What do I do when I find it? Even if you’ve done a “research paper” in a writing class, the idea of another may be even more intimidating if this time it’s the real thing. If so, you’re not alone. Even experienced researchers feel anxious when they tackle a new kind of project for a new audience. So whatever anxiety you feel, most researchers have felt it too. The difference is that experienced researchers know what lies ahead—hard work, but also pleasure; some frustration, but more satisfaction; periods of confusion, but confidence that, in the end, it will all come together and that the result is worth the effort. Most of all, experienced researchers know how to get from start to finish not easily, perhaps, but as efficiently as the complexity of their task allows. That’s the aim of this book.

制定计划

WORKING WITH A PLAN

如果您不知道读者在论文中寻找什么或如何帮助他们找到它，您将在项目中遇到困难。经验丰富的研究人员知道，当他们有计划时，他们通常会写出一篇可靠的论文，无论计划多么粗糙，即使只是在他们的脑海中。事实上，他们制定了两种计划：第一种帮助他们准备和进行研究；第二个帮助他们起草论文。

You will struggle with your project if you don’t know what readers look for in a paper or how to help them find it. Experienced researchers know that they most often produce a sound paper when they have a plan, no matter how rough, even if only in their heads. In fact, they create two kinds of plans: the first helps them prepare and conduct their research; the second helps them draft their paper.

他们通常从一个问题和一个计划开始，以指导他们寻找答案。他们可能不确切地知道他们会发现什么，但他们大致知道它会是什么样子，即使这会让他们感到惊讶。他们还知道，一旦有了答案，他们就不会开始写作，就像有经验的木匠只是开始锯木一样。他们起草了第二份计划，即初稿的粗略蓝图——可能只不过是轮廓草图。然而，精明的研究人员不会让这个计划束缚他们：如果他们遇到问题或发现一些可以引导他们走向新方向的东西，他们就会改变它。但在他们开始初稿之前，他们会先制定一些计划，即使他们知道他们几乎肯定会改变它。

They usually begin with a question and a plan to guide their search for an answer. They may not know exactly what they’ll find, but they know generally what it will look like, even if it surprises them. They also know that once they have an answer, they don’t just start writing, any more than an experienced carpenter just starts sawing. They draw up a second plan, a rough blueprint for a first draft—maybe no more than a sketch of an outline. Shrewd researchers, though, don’t let that plan box them in: they change it if they run into a problem or discover something that leads them in a new direction. But before they start a first draft, they begin with some plan, even when they know they’ll almost certainly change it.

草稿计划有助于研究人员写作，但也有助于读者阅读。事实上，各种研究人员都使用标准形式来预测读者寻找什么：

That plan for a draft helps researchers write, but it also helps their readers read. In fact, researchers of all kinds use standard forms to anticipate what readers look for:

• 一位报社记者以传统的“金字塔”形式撰写她的报道，将最重要的信息放在首位，不仅是为了让她的起草工作更容易，也是为了让她的读者能够快速找到新闻的要点，然后决定是否要报道。继续阅读。

• A newspaper reporter writes her story in traditional “pyramid” form, putting the most important information first, not just to make her job of drafting easier, but also so that her readers can find the gist of the news quickly, then decide whether to read on.

• 一名会计师遵循标准格式编写审计报告，不仅是为了组织自己的写作，也是为了让投资者找到他们需要的信息，以决定该公司是另一个安然公司还是下一个苹果公司。

• An accountant follows a standard form for her audit report not just to organize her own writing, but so that investors can find the information they need to decide whether the company is another Enron or the next Apple.

• 美国食品和药物管理局的一位科学家遵循科学报告的可预测形式——介绍、方法和材料、结果、讨论、结论——不仅是为了连贯地整理自己的想法，而且是为了帮助读者找到他们之前必须考虑的具体问题他们接受他的发现。

• A Food and Drug Administration scientist follows the predictable form for a scientific report—introduction, methods and materials, results, discussion, conclusion—not just to order his own thoughts coherently, but to help readers find the specific issues they have to consider before they accept his findings.

在这些形式或流派中，作家可以自由地强调不同的想法，在他们的作品上打上个人烙印。但他们知道计划可以帮助他们高效地写作，同样重要的是，可以帮助他们的读者高效地阅读。

Within these forms, or genres, writers are free to emphasize different ideas, to put a personal stamp on their work. But they know that a plan helps them write efficiently and, no less important, helps their readers read productively.

本书将帮助您制定并执行研究计划和报告计划，不仅鼓励您进行最佳思考，而且帮助您的读者看到其价值。

This book will help you create and execute a plan for doing your research and another for reporting it in ways that not only encourage your best thinking but help your readers see its value.

如何使用本书

HOW TO USE THIS BOOK

处理研究的复杂性（及其焦虑）的最好方法是将这本书读两遍。首先浏览它以了解前面的内容（跳过看起来乏味或令人困惑的内容）。但是当您开始工作时，请仔细阅读与您当前任务相关的章节。如果您是研究新手，请从头开始重读。如果您正在学习中级课程但还不熟悉您的领域，请浏览第一部分，然后专注于其余部分。如果您是一位经验丰富的研究人员，您会发现第 4 章以及第III和IV部分最有用。

The best way to deal with the complexity of research (and its anxieties) is to read this book twice. First skim it to understand what lies ahead (flip past what seems tedious or confusing). But then as you begin your work, carefully read the chapters relevant to your immediate task. If you are new to research, reread from the beginning. If you are in an intermediate course but not yet at home in your field, skim part I, then concentrate on the rest. If you are an experienced researcher, you will find chapter 4 and parts III and IV most useful.

在第一部分中，我们讨论了那些从事第一个项目的人必须有意识地思考的问题：为什么读者希望我们以特定的方式撰写我们的研究（第 1 章），以及为什么你不应该将你的项目视为单独的劳动，而是将其视为一次对话与那些你阅读过他们的作品的人以及那些将反过来阅读你的作品的人（第 2 章）。

In part I, we address what those undertaking their first project must think about deliberately: why readers expect us to write up our research in particular ways (chapter 1), and why you should think of your project not as solitary labor but as a conversation with those whose work you read and with those who will in turn read your work (chapter 2).

在第二部分，我们将讨论如何构建和开发您的项目。我们解释

In part II, we discuss how to frame and develop your project. We explain

• 如何找到感兴趣的话题，然后如何集中注意力并提出问题（第 3 章）；

• how to find a topic in an interest, then how to focus and question it (chapter 3);

• 如何将这些问题转化为研究问题（第 4 章）；

• how to transform those questions into a research problem (chapter 4);

• 如何找到资源来指导您寻找答案（第 5 章）；

• how to find sources to guide your search for answers (chapter 5);

• 如何以鼓励您自己最好的思考的方式来吸引资源（第 6 章）。

• how to engage sources in ways that encourage your own best thinking (chapter 6).

在第 III 部分，我们将讨论如何组合一个合理的案例来支持您的主张。那包括

In part III, we discuss how to assemble a sound case in support of your claim. That includes

• 研究论证概述（第 7 章）；

• an overview of a research argument (chapter 7);

• 如何评估您的观点的重要性（第 8 章）；

• how to evaluate your claim for its significance (chapter 8);

• 如何判断什么才是好的理由和可靠的证据（第 9 章）；

• how to judge what count as good reasons and sound evidence (chapter 9);

• 如何承认和回应问题、异议和其他观点（第 10 章）；

• how to acknowledge and respond to questions, objections, and alternative views (chapter 10);

• 如何使论点的逻辑清晰（第 11 章）。

• how to make the logic of your argument clear (chapter 11).

在第四部分，我们列出了制作论文的步骤：

In part IV, we lay out the steps in producing your paper:

• 如何计划和执行初稿（第 12 章）；

• how to plan and execute a first draft (chapter 12);

• 如何测试和修改它（第 13 章）；

• how to test and revise it (chapter 13);

• 如何合并来源（第 14 章）；

• how to incorporate sources (chapter 14);

• 如何清晰、有针对性地呈现复杂的定量证据（第 15 章）；

• how to present complex quantitative evidence clearly and pointedly (chapter 15);

• 如何撰写引言和结论，让读者相信你的论点值得他们花时间（第 16 章）；

• how to write an introduction and conclusion that convince readers your argument is worth their time (chapter 16);

• 如何编辑您的风格，使其清晰、直接和可读（第 17 章）。

• how to edit your style to make it clear, direct, and readable (chapter 17).

在某些章节之间，您会发现“快速提示”，这些简短的部分通过实用建议对章节进行了补充。

Between some of the chapters you will find “Quick Tips,” brief sections that complement the chapters with practical advice.

在后记“研究伦理”中，我们反思了一个超越专业能力的问题。进行和报告研究是一种具有伦理意义的社会活动。我们经常读到历史学家、科学家、股票分析师和其他人不诚实的研究。我们还看到，从中学生到行业领导者，各个层次的作家都存在剽窃行为。此类事件凸显了以合乎道德的方式进行和使用您的研究的重要性。

In an afterword, “The Ethics of Research,” we reflect on a matter that goes beyond professional competence. Doing and reporting research is a social activity with ethical implications. We often read about the dishonest research of historians, scientists, stock analysts, and others. And we see plagiarism among writers at all levels of achievement, from secondary-school students to leaders of their professions. Such events highlight the importance of doing and using your research ethically.

在结束语中，我们向那些教授研究的人致辞。在本书的末尾是供新手研究人员和特定领域的高级研究人员参考的参考书目。

In a concluding essay, we address those who teach research. At the end of the book is a bibliography of sources for beginning researchers and for advanced researchers in particular fields.

研究是一项艰苦的工作，但就像任何出色完成的具有挑战性的工作一样，它的过程和结果都能带来极大的满足感。这种满足感的很大一部分来自于知道你的工作维持了一个与你有共同兴趣的人的社区结构，尤其是当你发现一些你认为可以通过改变读者的想法和方式来改善他们的生活的东西时。

Research is hard work, but like any challenging job done well, both its process and its results can bring great satisfaction. No small part of that satisfaction comes from knowing that your work sustains the fabric of a community of people who share your interests, especially when you discover something that you believe can improve your readers’ lives by changing what and how they think.

1 印刷思维

1  Thinking in Print

公共和私人研究的用途

The Uses of Research, Public and Private

在本章中，我们定义了研究，然后讨论了如何从学习中受益并做好研究、为什么我们重视它以及为什么我们希望您也能这样做。

In this chapter, we define research, then discuss how you benefit from learning to do it well, why we value it, and why we hope you will too.

每当我们读到科学突破或世界事务危机时，我们都会从报告者的研究中受益，而这些人又从无数其他人的研究中受益。当我们走进图书馆时，我们被超过二十五个世纪的研究所包围。当我们上网时，我们可以阅读数以百万计的研究人员撰写的报告，他们提出了数不清的问题，从他人的研究中收集了大量信息来回答这些问题，然后与我们其他人分享他们的答案，以便我们能够通过提出新问题来继续他们的工作，我们希望能够回答这些问题。

Whenever we read about a scientific breakthrough or a crisis in world affairs, we benefit from the research of those who report it, who in turn benefited from the research of countless others. When we walk into a library, we are surrounded by more than twenty-five centuries of research. When we go on the Internet, we can read millions of reports written by researchers who have posed questions beyond number, gathered untold amounts of information from the research of others to answer them, then shared their answers with the rest of us so that we can carry on their work by asking new questions and, we hope, answering them.

各级教师毕生致力于研究。政府为此花费数十亿美元，企业甚至更多。研究在实验室和图书馆、丛林和海洋深处、洞穴和外层空间、办公室以及信息时代甚至我们自己的家中进行。研究实际上是世界上最大的产业。那些做不好或评价别人的人会发现自己在一个越来越依赖可靠的调查产生的良好信息的基础上提出合理想法的世界中被边缘化，然后清晰准确地呈现出来。

Teachers at all levels devote their lives to research. Governments spend billions on it, businesses even more. Research goes on in laboratories and libraries, in jungles and ocean depths, in caves and in outer space, in offices and, in the information age, even in our own homes. Research is in fact the world’s biggest industry. Those who cannot do it well or evaluate that of others will find themselves sidelined in a world increasingly dependent on sound ideas based on good information produced by trustworthy inquiry and then presented clearly and accurately.

如果没有值得信赖的已发表研究，我们所有人都会被束缚在当下的观点中，成为我们独自经历的囚徒或被告知的一切所蒙骗。当然，我们希望相信我们的意见是正确的。然而，错误的想法，甚至是危险的想法，仍然盛行，因为太多的人接受了基于太少证据的太多观点。正如最近发生的事件所表明的那样，那些根据不可靠的证据采取行动的人可能会让我们——实际上已经把我们——带入灾难。

Without trustworthy published research, we all would be locked in the opinions of the moment, prisoners of what we alone experience or dupes to whatever we’re told. Of course, we want to believe that our opinions are sound. Yet mistaken ideas, even dangerous ones, flourish because too many people accept too many opinions based on too little evidence. And as recent events have shown, those who act on unreliable evidence can lead us—indeed have led us—into disaster.

这就是为什么在这本书中我们会敦促你对你阅读的研究持友好的怀疑态度，即使你意识到你有多么依赖它也要质疑它。

That’s why in this book we will urge you to be amiably skeptical of the research you read, to question it even as you realize how much you depend on it.

1.1 什么是研究？

1.1 WHAT IS RESEARCH?

从最广泛的角度来说，每当我们收集信息以回答解决问题的问题时，我们都会进行研究：

In the broadest terms, we do research whenever we gather information to answer a question that solves a problem:

问题：在哪里可以为我的 '65 Mustang 找到新的气缸垫？

PROBLEM: Where do I find a new head gasket for my ’65 Mustang?

研究：在黄页上查找一家汽车配件商店，然后打电话查看是否有存货。

RESEARCH: Look in the yellow pages for an auto-parts store, then call to see if it has one in stock.

问题：为了打赌，我需要知道迈克尔乔丹的出生时间。

PROBLEM: To settle a bet, I need to know when Michael Jordan was born.

研究：你在谷歌上搜索“迈克尔·乔丹生日”。

RESEARCH: You Google “Michael Jordan birthday.”

问题：我只是对一种新的鱼感到好奇。

PROBLEM: I’m just curious about a new species of fish.

研究：您在互联网上搜索报纸和学术期刊上的文章。

RESEARCH: You search the Internet for articles in newspapers and academic journals.

我们每天都在做这种研究，虽然我们很少把它写下来，但我们依赖于那些写下他们的研究的人：乔丹的传记作者、鱼类发现者、黄页出版商和汽车零部件供应商的目录——他们都写下了他们的研究，因为他们知道总有一天会有人提出他们可以回答的问题。

We all do that kind of research every day, and though we rarely write it up, we rely on those who wrote up theirs: Jordan’s biographers, the fish discoverers, the publishers of the yellow pages and the catalogs of the auto-parts suppliers—they all wrote up their research because they knew that one day someone would have a question that they could answer.

如果你准备做一个研究项目不是因为你想做，而是因为它已经被分配了，你可能会认为它只是临时工，并将其视为空洞的练习。我们希望你不会。做得好，你的项目会让你准备好加入最古老和最受尊敬的人类对话，哲学家、工程师、生物学家、社会科学家、历史学家、文学评论家、语言学家、神学家，更不用说首席执行官、律师、营销人员、投资经理——这个名单是无止境的。

If you’re preparing to do a research project not because you want to but because it’s been assigned, you might think that it is just make-work and treat it as an empty exercise. We hope you won’t. Done well, your project prepares you to join the oldest and most esteemed of human conversations, one conducted for millennia among philosophers, engineers, biologists, social scientists, historians, literary critics, linguists, theologians, not to mention CEOs, lawyers, marketers, investment managers—the list is endless.

现在，如果您是初学者，您可能会觉得谈话是片面的，您必须多听多说，因为您无能为力。如果你是学生，你可以觉得你只有一个读者：你的老师。就目前而言，这一切可能都是真的。但在某个时候，你会加入一场对话，在最好的情况下，它可以帮助你和你的社区摆脱无知、偏见和许多江湖骗子试图强加给我们的半生不熟的想法。可以毫不夸张地说，也许不是今天或明天，而是有一天，你所做的研究和你使用它提出的论点即使不能改善整个世界，也至少可以改善你的角落。

Right now, if you are a beginner, you may feel that the conversation is one-sided, that you have to listen more than you can speak because you have little to contribute. If you are a student, you may feel that you have only one reader: your teacher. All that may be true, for the moment. But at some point, you will join a conversation that, at its best, can help you and your community free us from ignorance, prejudice, and the half-baked ideas that so many charlatans try to impose on us. It is no exaggeration to say that, maybe not today or tomorrow but one day, the research you do and the arguments you make using it can improve if not the whole world, then at least your corner of it.

1.2 为什么要写下来？

1.2 WHY WRITE IT UP?

不过，对于你们中的某些人来说，加入此对话的邀请似乎仍然很容易拒绝。如果你接受了，你就必须找到一个好问题，搜索可靠的数据，制定并支持一个好的答案，然后把它全部写下来。即使你写出了一流的论文，它也可能不会被一个热切的世界阅读，而只会被你的老师阅读。而且，除此之外，你可能会想，我的老师对我的主题了如指掌。除了证明我能做到之外，我从撰写我的研究中得到了什么？

For some of you, though, the invitation to join this conversation may still seem easy to decline. If you accept it, you’ll have to find a good question, search for sound data, formulate and support a good answer, and then write it all up. Even if you turn out a first-rate paper, it may be read not by an eager world but only by your teacher. And, besides, you may think, my teacher knows all about my topic. What do I gain from writing up my research, other than proving I can do it?

一个答案是我们写作不仅仅是为了分享我们的工作，而是为了在我们做之前改进它。

One answer is that we write not just to share our work, but to improve it before we do.

1.2.1写下来记住

1.2.1 Write to Remember

经验丰富的研究人员首先写作只是为了记住他们读过的内容。一些有才华的人可以记住大量信息，但是当我们考虑史密斯根据 Wong 的立场发现了什么，并将两者与布鲁内利的奇数数据进行比较时，我们大多数人都会迷路，尤其是当他们得到博斯科维茨的支持时——但是史密斯说了什么？如果您不对阅读的内容做笔记，您很可能会忘记，或者更糟的是，会记错。

Experienced researchers first write just to remember what they’ve read. A few talented people can hold in mind masses of information, but most of us get lost when we think about what Smith found in light of Wong’s position, and compare both to the odd data in Brunelli, especially as they are supported by Boskowitz—but what was it that Smith said? When you don’t take notes on what you read, you’re likely to forget or, worse, misremember it.

1.2.2为理解而写

1.2.2 Write to Understand

写作的第二个原因是在你阅读的内容中看到更大的模式。当你以新的方式整理和重新整理你的研究结果时，你会发现新的含义、联系和复杂性。即使你能牢记这一切，你也需要帮助来排列不同方向的论点，策划复杂的关系，解决专家之间的分歧。我想使用 Wong 的这些说法，但她的论点被史密斯的数据削弱了。当我将它们并排放置时，我发现史密斯忽略了王的论点的最后一部分。啊哈！如果我从 Brunelli 的这部分介绍它，我可以更清楚地关注 Wong。这就是为什么细心的研究人员在收集到他们需要的所有数据之前从不推迟写作：他们从项目开始就开始写作，以帮助他们以新的方式收集信息。

A second reason for writing is to see larger patterns in what you read. When you arrange and rearrange the results of your research in new ways, you discover new implications, connections, and complications. Even if you could hold it all in mind, you would need help to line up arguments that pull in different directions, plot out complicated relationships, sort out disagreements among experts. I want to use these claims from Wong, but her argument is undercut by Smith’s data. When I put them side by side, I see that Smith ignores this last part of Wong’s argument. Aha! If I introduce it with this part from Brunelli, I can focus on Wong more clearly. That’s why careful researchers never put off writing until they’ve gathered all the data they need: they write from the start of their projects to help them assemble their information in new ways.

1.2.3写作来测试你的想法

1.2.3 Write to Test Your Thinking

写作的第三个原因是把你的想法从头脑中转移到纸上，在那里你会看到你真正能想到的。几乎我们所有人，无论是学生还是专业人士，都相信我们的想法在我们头脑的黑暗中比在冷淡的印刷品中更引人注目。你无法知道你的想法有多好，除非你将它们从快速而混乱的思潮中分离出来，并将它们整理成一种你和你的读者可以研究的有组织的形式。

A third reason to write is to get your thoughts out of your head and onto paper, where you’ll see what you really can think. Just about all of us, students and professionals alike, believe our ideas are more compelling in the dark of our minds than they turn out to be in the cold light of print. You can’t know how good your ideas are until you separate them from the swift and muddy flow of thought and fix them in an organized form that you—and your readers—can study.

简而言之，我们写作是为了更准确地记住、更好地理解、更客观地评价我们的想法。（你会发现，写得越多，读得越好。）

In short, we write to remember more accurately, understand better, and evaluate what we think more objectively. (And as you will discover, the more you write, the better you read.)

1.3 为什么要写正式论文？

1.3 WHY A FORMAL PAPER?

但即使他们同意写作是学习、思考和理解的重要组成部分，一些人仍然想知道为什么他们不能以自己的方式撰写他们的研究，为什么他们必须满足社区强加的要求，而他们却没有加入（甚至想要）并遵守他们没有做任何事情来创建的约定。我为什么要采用不属于我的语言和形式？你不就是想把我变成像你一样的学者吗？如果我按照您的期望写作，我就有失去身份的风险。

But even when they agree that writing is an important part of learning, thinking, and understanding, some still wonder why they can’t write up their research in their own way, why they have to satisfy demands imposed by a community that they have not joined (or even want to) and conform to conventions they did nothing to create. Why should I adopt language and forms that are not mine? Aren’t you just trying to turn me into an academic like yourself? If I write as you expect me to, I risk losing my identity.

这种担忧是合理的（大多数教师希望学生能更频繁地提出这些问题）。但这将是一种根本没有改变你的微弱教育，你的教育越深入，它就越能改变你现在或想成为的“你”。这就是为什么仔细选择你学习的内容和使用的内容如此重要的原因。谁。但如果认为学习报告可靠的研究一定会威胁到你的真实身份，那就错了。它会改变你的思维方式，但前提是给你更多的思维方式。通过更自由地选择你想成为什么样的人以及你想在你的生活中做什么，你会与众不同。

Such concerns are legitimate (most teachers wish students would raise them more often). But it would be a feeble education that did not change you at all, and the deeper your education, the more it will change the “you” that you are or want to be. That’s why it is so important to choose carefully what you study and with whom. But it would be a mistake to think that learning to report sound research must threaten your true identity. It will change the way you think, but only by giving you more ways of thinking. You will be different by being freer to choose whom you want to be and what you want to do with your life.

但学习以读者期望的方式写作的最重要原因是，当你为别人写作时，你对自己的要求比为自己单独写作时更高。当你把你的想法写下来时，它们对你来说已经很熟悉了，你需要帮助才能看到它们不是你想要的样子，而是它们的真实面目。当您尝试预测读者不可避免的关键问题时，您将更好地理解您自己的工作：您如何评估您的证据？为什么你认为它是相关的？你考虑过哪些想法但拒绝了？

But the most important reason for learning to write in ways readers expect is that when you write for others, you demand more of yourself than when you write for yourself alone. By the time you fix your ideas in writing, they are so familiar to you that you need help to see them not for what you want them to be but for what they really are. You will understand your own work better when you try to anticipate your readers’ inevitable and critical questions: How have you evaluated your evidence? Why do you think it’s relevant? What ideas have you considered but rejected?

所有的研究人员，包括我们，都可以回忆起在为满足读者的期望而写作时，他们发现了自己思维中的缺陷或错误，甚至发现了他们在为自己写的初稿中遗漏的新见解。只有当您想象并满足消息灵通且细心的读者的需求和期望时，您才能做到这一点。当你这样做时，你就创建了我们所说的共享价值观的修辞社区。

All researchers, including us, can recall moments when in writing to meet their readers’ expectations, they found a flaw or blunder in their thinking or even discovered a new insight that escaped them in a first draft written for themselves. You can do that only once you imagine and then meet the needs and expectations of informed and careful readers. When you do that, you create what we call a rhetorical community of shared values.

你可能会想，好吧，我会为读者写作，但为什么不用我自己的方式呢？读者期望的传统形式不仅仅是空容器，您必须向其中倾注您的想法。它们还帮助作家以其他方式可能无法做到的方式思考和交流，并且体现了研究社区的共同价值观。无论您加入哪个社区，您都应该通过以标准形式或类型展示您的研究来表明您了解其实践，社区使用这些形式或类型来表示它知道什么以及如何它知道。基于研究的写作的各种类型——研究论文、学术文章、研究报告、会议论文、法律摘要和许多其他类型——已经发展以满足使用它们的社区的需求。它们相对稳定，允许社区的新成员和长期成员通过共同的实践和期望走到一起。一旦你知道属于并定义你的流派特定的研究社区，您将能够更好地回答社区的可预测问题并了解其成员关心的内容和原因。当你学习写作一个领域或专业的体裁时，你就会成为该研究团体的一员。

You might think, OK, I’ll write for readers, but why not in my own way? The traditional forms that readers expect are more than just empty vessels into which you must pour your ideas. They also help writers think and communicate in ways they might not otherwise, and they embody the shared values of a research community. Whatever community you join, you’ll be expected to show that you understand its practices by presenting your research in the standard forms, or genres, that a community uses to represent what it knows and how it knows. The various genres of research-based writing—the research paper, the scholarly article, the research report, the conference paper, the legal brief, and a great many others—have evolved to meet the needs of the communities that use them. Relatively stable, they allow both newcomers and longtime members of a community to come together through shared practices and expectations. Once you know the genres that belong to and define your particular research community, you’ll be better able to answer your community’s predictable questions and understand what its members care about and why. As you learn to write the genres of a field or profession, you become a member of that research community.

但是，尽管研究团体各不相同，但无论是在学术界还是在政府、商业或技术领域，什么才算是好工作都是一样的。如果你现在学会做好研究，无论你在哪里做，你都会在以后的研究中获得巨大的优势。

But as different as research communities are, what counts as good work is the same, whether it’s in the academic world or the world of government, commerce, or technology. If you learn to do research well now, you gain an immense advantage in the kind of research you will do later, no matter where you do it.

1.4 写作即思考

1.4 WRITING IS THINKING

最后，撰写您的研究是与您的读者一起思考并为他们着想。当您为他人写作时，您会将自己的想法与您的记忆和愿望分离开来，以便您和其他人可以更充分地探索、扩展、组合和理解它们。为他人着想比任何其他类型的思考都更谨慎、更持久、更有洞察力——简而言之，更深思熟虑。

Writing up your research is, finally, thinking with and for your readers. When you write for others, you disentangle your ideas from your memories and wishes, so that you—and others—can explore, expand, combine, and understand them more fully. Thinking for others is more careful, more sustained, more insightful—in short, more thoughtful—than just about any other kind of thinking.

当然，你可以采取简单的方法：做足以让你的老师满意的事情。这本书将帮助你做到这一点，但如果你只做这些，你就会亏本。相反，如果你找到一个你关心的话题，提出一个你想回答的问题，然后尽你所能去寻找那个答案，你的项目就会具有神秘的魅力，它的解决方案会给你的努力带来丰厚的回报。没有什么比您对研究的承诺更能促进成功的研究它，没有什么比使用它进行成功（甚至不成功）的论证更能教会你如何思考了。

You can, of course, take the easy way: do just enough to satisfy your teacher. This book will help you do that, but you’ll shortchange yourself if that’s all you do. If instead you find a topic that you care about, ask a question that you want to answer, then pursue that answer as best you can, your project can have the fascination of a mystery whose solution richly rewards your efforts. Nothing contributes more to successful research than your commitment to it, and nothing teaches you more about how to think than making a successful (or even unsuccessful) argument using it.

一些世界上最重要的研究是由那些在冷漠甚至敌意面前坚持不懈的人完成的，因为他们从未对自己的愿景失去信心。遗传学家芭芭拉·麦克林托克 (Barbara McClintock) 多年来一直在努力奋斗，但没有受到赏识，因为她的研究团体认为她的工作乏味。但她相信并坚持下去。当她的同事们终于意识到她已经回答了他们刚刚开始提出的问题时，她获得了科学界的最高荣誉——诺贝尔奖。

Some of the world’s most important research has been done by those who persevered in the face of indifference or even hostility, because they never lost faith in their vision. The geneticist Barbara McClintock struggled for years unappreciated because her research community considered her work uninteresting. But she believed in it and pressed on. When her colleagues finally realized that she had already answered questions that they were just starting to ask, she won science’s highest honor, the Nobel Prize.

我们希望我们可以告诉您如何平衡您对项目价值的信念与满足教师和同事需求的需要，但我们不能。如果您相信自己正在做的事情，但找不到其他人与您有相同的信念，那么您所能做的就是低下头继续前进。带着我们的敬佩。

We wish we could tell you how to balance your belief in the worth of your project with the need to accommodate the demands of teachers and colleagues, but we cannot. If you believe in what you’re doing and cannot find anyone else who shares your beliefs, all you can do is put your head down and press on. With our admiration.

2 与您的读者建立联系

2  Connecting with Your Reader

为你自己和你的读者创造一个角色

Creating a Role for Yourself and Your Readers

如果很少有人阅读，研究就没有多大意义。然而，即使是经验丰富的研究人员有时也会忘记在计划和起草时将读者放在心上。在本章中，我们将向您展示如何在开始项目之前就考虑读者。

Research counts for little if few read it. Yet even experienced researchers sometimes forget to keep their readers in mind as they plan and draft. In this chapter, we show you how to think about readers even before you begin your project.

我们所做的大多数重要事情都是与他人一起做的。一些学生认为研究是不同的。他们想象一个安静的图书馆里孤独的学者。但没有比图书馆或实验室更充满想象声音的地方了。您在这些网站上看到的研究视图只是故事的一部分。当你阅读一本书或一篇科学论文时，你会默默地与作者交谈——并通过他们与他们读过的其他人交谈。事实上，每次你去书面来源寻找信息，你就加入了一场始于五千年前的作家和读者之间的对话。当你报告你自己的研究时，你加入了你的声音，并希望其他声音会回应你，这样你就可以反过来回应他们。事情就是这样，我们希望，这种情况会持续很长时间。

Most of the important things we do, we do with others. Some students think research is different. They imagine the lone scholar in a hushed library. But no place is more filled with imagined voices than a library or lab. The view of research you see walking by these sites is only part of the story. When you read a book or a scientific paper, you silently converse with its writers—and through them with everyone else they have read. In fact, every time you go to a written source for information, you join a conversation between writers and readers that began more than five thousand years ago. And when you report your own research, you add your voice and can hope that other voices will respond to you, so that you can in turn respond to them. So it goes and, we hope, will continue for a long time to come.

2.1 与您的读者交谈

2.1 CONVERSING WITH YOUR READERS

对话是社会活动，我们希望在其中发挥自己的作用。面对面时，我们可以通过感知对话的进展情况来判断我们和其他人的表现如何。我们是否平等相待，礼貌地交谈和倾听，直接回答对方的问题？还是我们中的一个人似乎在扮演专家的角色，而让其他人扮演观众的角色？我们可以根据自己的情况判断对话的进展情况，我们可以调整自己的角色和行为，以在出现错误和误解时进行修复。但写作是一种想象的对话。一旦我们决定扮演什么角色以及分配给读者什么角色，这些角色就固定了。如果我们在阅读时认为，好吧，艾布拉姆斯承认 Stanik 的证据，但他在批评它时过于武断并且忽略了明显的反例，艾布拉姆斯无法改变我们接下来阅读的内容以从我们的判断中恢复过来。

Conversations are social activities in which we are expected to play our parts. Face-to-face, we can judge how well we and others do that by sensing how a conversation is going. Do we treat each other as equals, speaking and listening civilly, answering each other’s questions directly? Or does one of us seem to be playing the role of expert, assigning others the role of audience? We can judge how well a conversation is going as we have it, and we can adjust our roles and behavior to repair mistakes and misunderstandings as they occur. But writing is an imagined conversation. Once we decide what role to play and what role to assign our readers, those roles are fixed. If as we read we think, Well, Abrams acknowledges Stanik’s evidence, but he’s dogmatic in criticizing it and ignores obvious counterexamples, Abrams can’t change what we read next to recover from our judgment.

当然，评判是双向的：就像读者评判作家一样，作家也评判读者，但他们在写作之前就评判了读者。考虑以下两个句子：

Of course, judgments go both ways: just as readers judge writers, so writers also judge readers, but they do so before they write. Consider these two sentences:

REM 睡眠的中断已被证明不仅会抑制记忆巩固，特别是对于陈述性记忆，而且还会显着损害依赖于工作记忆功能的认知过程。

Interruption of REM sleep has been shown not only to inhibit memory consolidation, especially for declarative memories, but also to significantly impair cognitive processes dependent on working memory function.

如果睡眠不足，您不仅难以记住事实和概念，而且您的工作记忆功能也会受损，使您难以记住信息，从而难以理解、思考和学习。

If you don’t get enough sleep, not only will you struggle to retain facts and concepts, but your working memory function will also be impaired, making it difficult for you to hold information in mind and consequently to understand, think, and learn.

两位作者都对读者的需求和目标做出了判断。第一个是针对有兴趣了解睡眠和记忆心理学的知识渊博的同事。因此，她专注于抽象概念并自由使用专业术语。第二个以专家的身份出现，耐心地向对此知之甚少的读者解释复杂的问题，因此他在很大程度上避免使用技术词汇。他还假设他的读者需要实用的建议，所以他直接称呼他们为“你”，并向他们展示他的信息对他们意味着什么。

Both writers make judgments about their readers’ needs and goals. The first addresses herself to knowledgeable colleagues interested in learning about the psychology of sleep and memory. She therefore focuses on abstract concepts and freely uses technical terms. The second presents himself as an expert patiently explaining a complicated matter to readers who know little about it, and so he largely avoids technical vocabulary. He also assumes that his readers want practical advice, and so he addresses them directly as “you” and shows them what his information means to them.

这两句话截然不同：第一句读起来像是高级教科书的节选；第二，就像它来自关于良好学习习惯的指南。但如果他们的作者正确地判断了他们的读者，那么两者都会有效。

The two sentences are very different: the first reads like an excerpt from an advanced textbook; the second, like it comes from a guide on good study habits. But both would be effective if their writers judged their readers correctly.

但是假设作者换了段落。不了解认知心理学并寻求实用建议的读者会认为第一本书的作者对他们的需求漠不关心；了解睡眠和记忆的读者会认为第二篇文章的作者是在贬低他们。当作家以这种方式误判他们的读者时，他们就有可能失去他们。

But suppose the writers switched passages. Readers ignorant of cognitive psychology looking for practical advice would think that the writer of the first was indifferent to their needs; readers knowledgeable about sleep and memory would think that the writer of the second was talking down to them. When writers misjudge their readers in this way, they risk losing them.

事实上，作家无法避免为自己创造一些角色，他们的读者，计划与否。因此，在您写一个字之前，从一开始就值得考虑这些角色。如果你忽视或误导了你的读者，你会在你的早期草稿中留下如此多的错误痕迹，以至于你不会轻易地在最终草稿中修复它们。

In fact, writers can’t avoid creating some role for themselves and their readers, planned or not. So those roles are worth thinking about from the beginning, before you write a word. If you ignore or miscast your readers, you’ll leave so many traces of that mistake in your early drafts that you won’t easily fix them in the final one.

在写这本书的过程中，我们试图想象你——你是什么样的人，你对研究了解多少，你是否关心它。我们为您设想了一个人物角色，一个我们希望您担任的角色：对学习如何进行和报告研究感兴趣并且与我们一样相信其重要性的人（或者至少愿意被说服）。然后我们想象了一个我们自己的角色：致力于研究价值的作家，有兴趣分享它是如何运作的，不是像讲师那样对你说话，也不是像书呆子一样对你低声下气，而是我们希望您成为的“您”。我们试图与那些开始第一个项目的人和那些从事高级工作的人一样轻松地交谈。我们希望新研究人员在讨论他们尚未遇到的问题时不会感到沮丧，并且希望更有经验的读者在我们讨论熟悉的领域时耐心等待。只有您可以判断我们的成功程度。

In writing this book, we tried to imagine you—what you’re like, what you know about research, whether you even care about it. We imagined a persona for you, a role we hoped you would adopt: someone who is interested in learning how to do and report research and who shares our belief in its importance (or at least is open to being persuaded). Then we imagined a persona of our own: writers committed to the value of research, interested in sharing how it works, talking not at you like a lecturer or down to you like a pedant, but with the “you” we hoped you want to become. We tried to speak as easily to those of you starting your first project as to those of you doing advanced work. We hoped that new researchers would not be frustrated when we discussed issues they haven’t yet faced and that more experienced readers would be patient as we covered familiar ground. Only you can judge how well we’ve succeeded.

2.2 了解您的角色

2.2 UNDERSTANDING YOUR ROLE

由于很少有人为了娱乐而阅读正式的研究论文，因此您必须建立一种关系，鼓励他们了解为什么阅读您的论文符合他们的兴趣。这并不容易。太多刚起步的研究人员向读者提供了一种讽刺糟糕课堂的关系：老师，我知道的比你少。所以我的作用是向您展示我可以挖掘出多少事实。你的意思是说我是否找到足够的东西给我一个好成绩。那样做，你就会把你的项目变成一个毫无意义的练习，贬低你和你的老师。更糟糕的是，你将自己置于一个与真正的研究人员完全相反的角色中。

Since few people read formal research papers for entertainment, you have to create a relationship that encourages them to see why it’s in their interest to read yours. That’s not easy. Too many beginning researchers offer readers a relationship that caricatures a bad classroom: Teacher, I know less than you. So my role is to show you how many facts I can dig up. Yours is to say whether I’ve found enough to give me a good grade. Do that and you turn your project into a pointless drill that demeans both you and your teacher. Worse, you cast yourself in a role exactly opposite to that of a true researcher.

在真正的研究中，你必须转换学生和老师的角色。当你做研究时，你会学到一些别人不知道的东西。所以当你报道它时，你必须把你的读者想象成一个不知道但需要知道的人，而你自己则是一个会给她理由想要知道它的人。你必须想象超越的关系以下是我挖掘出的关于 14 世纪西藏编织的一些事实。他们足够合适吗？

In true research, you must switch the roles of student and teacher. When you do research, you learn something that others don’t know. So when you report it, you must think of your reader as someone who doesn’t know it but needs to and yourself as someone who will give her reason to want to know it. You must imagine a relationship that goes beyond Here are some facts I’ve dug up about fourteenth-century Tibetan weaving. Are they enough of the right ones?

提供这些事实有三个更好的理由；第三种在学术研究中最为常见。

There are three better reasons for offering those facts; the third is most common in academic research.

2.2.1我发现了一些有趣的新信息

2.2.1 I’ve Found Some New and Interesting Information

当你对你的读者说，你迈出了真正研究的第一步，这里有一些你不知道但可能会感兴趣的关于 14 世纪西藏编织的事实。当然，此提议假设您的读者想知道。但即使没有，你仍然必须扮演一个已经发现了你的读者会感兴趣的东西的人的角色，而你的读者是一个想知道她是否真的愿意知道的人. 今后，您将有望找到（或创建）一个读者社区，他们不仅对您的主题感兴趣（或被说服），而且还会有您可以回答的问题。但即使你现在没有那么多观众，你也必须像有观众一样写作。你必须表现出对分享新事物感兴趣，甚至热情，因为你对你的工作表现出的兴趣大致预示着你的读者会对它产生兴趣。

You take the first step toward true research when you say to your reader, Here are some facts about fourteenth-century Tibetan weaving that you do not know and may find interesting. This offer assumes, of course, that your reader wants to know. But even if not, you must still cast yourself in the role of someone who has found something your reader will find interesting and your reader as someone who wants to know, whether she really will or not. Down the road, you’ll be expected to find (or create) a community of readers who not only share an interest in your topic (or can be convinced to), but also have questions about it that you can answer. But even if you don’t have that audience right now, you must write as if you do. You must present yourself as interested in, even enthusiastic about, wanting to share something new, because the interest you show in your work roughly predicts the interest your reader will take in it.

2.2.2我找到了一个重要实际问题的解决方案

2.2.2 I’ve Found a Solution to an Important Practical Problem

当您不仅可以对读者说这些是您应该感兴趣的事实，而且这些事实将帮助您解决您关心的问题时，您就向更重要的研究迈出了一步。这就是人们每天在商业、政府和专业领域所做的研究。他们面对实际问题，解决这些问题需要研究事实，首先了解问题，然后找出解决方法——从失眠到利润下降再到恐怖主义。

You take a step toward more significant research when you can say to readers not just Here are some facts that should interest you, but These facts will help you do something to solve a problem you care about. That is the kind of research that people do every day in business, government, and the professions. They confront practical problems whose solutions require research into the facts of the matter, first to understand the problem, then to figure out how to solve it—problems ranging from insomnia to falling profits to terrorism.

为了帮助新研究人员了解这一角色，教师有时会发明“真实世界”场景：一位环境科学教授可能会指派你为国家环境保护局局长写一份关于如何清理当地湖泊的报告。在在这种情况下，您扮演的角色不是学生向老师提供数据，而是专业人士向需要的人提供实用建议。然而，为了使您的报告可信，您必须使用正确的术语，引用正确的来源，找到并提供正确的证据，所有这些都以正确的格式进行。但最重要的是，您必须围绕定义您的角色的特定意图设计您的报告：就如何解决问题向决策者提供建议。这种研究在世界范围内很典型，但在学术研究中不如下一种研究普遍。

To help new researchers learn that role, teachers sometimes invent “real world” scenarios: an environmental science professor might assign you to write a report for the director of the state Environmental Protection Agency on how to clean up a local lake. In this scenario you are playing the role not of a student delivering data to a teacher, but of a professional giving practical advice to someone who needs it. To make your report credible, however, you must use the right terminology, cite the right sources, find and present the right evidence, all in the right format. But most important, you have to design your report around a specific intention that defines your role: to advise a decision maker on what to do to solve a problem. That kind of research is typical in the world at large but is less common in academic research than the next one.

2.2.3我找到了一个重要问题的答案

2.2.3 I’ve Found an Answer to an Important Question

尽管学术研究人员有时会建议 EPA 主管做什么，但他们更常见的角色是帮助他们的研究团体更好地理解某些事情的学者。其他人可能会利用他们的发现来解决实际问题——例如，关于素数分布的发现帮助密码学家设计了一种牢不可破的密码。但该研究本身旨在解决的不是保守秘密的实际问题，而是未完全理解素数的概念问题。一些研究人员称这种研究为“纯”而不是“应用”。

Although academic researchers sometimes advise EPA directors on what to do, their more common role is that of scholars who help their research community simply understand something better. Others might use their findings to solve a practical problem—a discovery about the distribution of prime numbers, for example, helped cryptologists design an unbreakable code. But that research itself was aimed at solving not the practical problem of keeping secrets, but the conceptual problem of not entirely understanding prime numbers. Some researchers call this kind of research “pure” as opposed to “applied.”

教师偶尔会发明涉及概念问题的“真实世界”场景：政治学教授要求您扮演参议员实习生的角色，研究州外大学生的投票习惯。但更典型的是，他们希望您将自己想象成您正在学习成为的样子：一名研究人员向一群对他们想更好地理解的问题感兴趣的其他研究人员发表讲话。例如，您关于 14 世纪西藏编织的报告可能会帮助地毯设计师销售更多地毯，但其主要目的是帮助学者更好地了解西藏艺术，例如14 世纪西藏地毯如何影响现代艺术中国？

Teachers occasionally invent “real world” scenarios involving conceptual problems: a political science professor asks you to play the role of a senator’s intern researching the voting habits of out-of-state college students. But more typically they expect you to imagine yourself as what you are learning to be: a researcher addressing a community of other researchers interested in issues that they want to understand better. Your report on fourteenth-century Tibetan weaving, for example, could possibly help rug designers sell more rugs, but its main aim is to help scholars better understand something about Tibetan art, such as How did fourteenth-century Tibetan rugs influence the art of modern China?

2.3 想象读者的角色

2.3 IMAGINING YOUR READERS’ ROLE

当你扮演这三个角色之一时，你就建立了你与读者的关系——我有信息给你；我 可以帮助您解决问题；我可以帮助你更好地理解一些东西。然而，你必须通过向他们提供社会契约来让你的读者扮演一个互补的角色：如果你扮演你的角色，我会扮演我的角色。但这意味着你必须了​​解他们的角色。如果你让他们扮演一个他们不会接受的角色，你很可能会完全失去他们。在这种情况下，“考虑你的听众”的旧建议意味着你必须以一种能激励你的读者扮演你为他们想象的角色的方式报告你的研究。

You establish your side of the relationship with your readers when you adopt one of those three roles—I have information for you; I can help you fix a problem; I can help you understand something better. You must, however, cast your readers in a complementary role by offering them a social contract: I’ll play my part if you play yours. But that means you have to understand their role. If you cast them in a role they won’t accept, you’re likely to lose them entirely. In this case, the old advice to “consider your audience” means that you must report your research in a way that motivates your readers to play the role you have imagined for them.

例如，假设您是飞艇和齐柏林飞艇方面的专家。您被要求与三个不同的小组分享您的研究，并出于三个不同的原因希望了解它。他们如何接受你将取决于你对每个人打算扮演的角色的想象有多准确，以及你将自己的角色与他们的角色相匹配的程度。为此，您必须了解他们想要什么以及他们愿意并能够为您做些什么作为回报。

For example, suppose you’re an expert on blimps and zeppelins. You’ve been asked to share your research with three different groups with three different reasons for wanting to hear about it. How they receive you will depend on how accurately you imagine the role each intends to play and how well you match your role to theirs. For that, you must understand what they want and what they are in return willing and able to do for you.

2.3.1娱乐我

2.3.1 Entertain Me

想象一下，第一个邀请您发言的团体是当地的 Zeppelin 俱乐部。它的成员不是专家，但他们对齐柏林飞艇了解很多。他们阅读有关它们的资料，参观历史遗迹，并收集飞艇纪念品。您决定分享您在奥托叔祖父的一封信中发现的一些新事实，信中描述了他 1936 年的跨大西洋齐柏林飞艇飞行，以及他保存的一些照片和菜单。他的信评论了他晚餐吃的烤牡蛎，并讲述了一个有趣的故事，讲述了他最初为什么碰巧去旅行。

Imagine the first group that invited you to speak is the local Zeppelin Club. Its members are not experts, but they know a lot about zeppelins. They read about them, visit historic sites, and collect zeppelin memorabilia. You decide to share some new facts you’ve found in a letter from your Great-Uncle Otto describing his transatlantic zeppelin flight in 1936, along with some photographs and a menu he saved. His letter comments on the grilled oysters he had for dinner and tells a funny story about why he happened to take the trip in the first place.

在计划你的演讲时，你判断关键在于飞艇琐事的消遣时间。当您分享您认为他们可能感兴趣的任何内容时，您就满足了交易的要求——直觉、猜测，甚至是未经证实的谣言。您不会展示 PowerPoint 幻灯片、展示数据或引用学术资源来证实您的主张。您的听众将通过饶有兴趣地倾听、提出问题或分享他们自己的轶事来扮演自己的角色。你不会指望他们质疑奥托叔祖父的信的真实性，或者质疑这些照片与齐柏林飞艇的社会历史有什么关系，更不用说比-一般航空旅行。您的工作是进行引人入胜的演讲；他们的任务是和蔼可亲地订婚。

In planning your talk, you judge that what’s at stake is just a diverting hour of zeppelin trivia. You meet your side of the bargain when you share whatever you think might interest them—hunches, speculation, even unsubstantiated rumors. You won’t show PowerPoint slides, present data, or cite scholarly sources to substantiate your claims. Your audience will play its role by listening with interest, asking questions, maybe sharing their own anecdotes. You don’t expect them to challenge the authenticity of the letter from Great-Uncle Otto or question how the photos are relevant to the social history of zeppelins, much less of lighter-than-air travel in general. Your job is to give an engaging talk; theirs is to be amiably engaged.

一些新手研究人员想象他们的读者属于齐柏林飞艇俱乐部，已经对他们的主题着迷并渴望听到任何关于它的新消息。虽然这有时适用于有合适听众的专家（见第 24 页的方框），但它很少适用于学习做和报告认真研究的学生。你的老师希望你不仅要报告你发现了什么，还要报告你可以用它做什么。

Some beginning researchers imagine their readers belong to a Zeppelin Club, already fascinated by their topic and eager to hear anything new about it. While that sometimes works for experts with the right audience (see the box on page 24), it rarely works for students learning to do and report serious research. Your teachers expect you to report not just what you find, but what you can do with it.

2.3.2帮我解决实际问题

2.3.2 Help Me Solve My Practical Problem

想象一下，您的下一次会议是使用 True-to-Life Films。他们计划制作一部关于 1936 年齐柏林飞艇飞行的电影，并希望您帮助他们弄清历史细节，包括餐厅的场景。他们想知道机舱是如何布置的，人们吃什么，菜单是什么样的，等等。他们不在乎你的事实是否新，只在乎是否正确，这样他们才能把现场拍得真实。你给他们看你的照片和菜单，描述奥托叔祖父吃的牡蛎，但你不会理会他为什么要去旅行。要想胜任这个角色，你必须帮助他们解决一个实际问题，你的解决方案不是基于你能找到的所有数据，无论数据有多新，而是仅仅基于那些特定的数据与真实性问题相关的事实，并且您可以证明其来源是可靠的。你的听众会专心而批判地倾听，因为他们想要了解正确的细节。

Imagine that your next meeting is with True-to-Life Films. They plan to make a movie about a zeppelin flight in 1936 and want you to help them get the historical details right, including a scene in the dining cabin. They want to know how the cabin was furnished, what people ate, what the menus looked like, and so on. They don’t care whether your facts are new, only whether they are right, so that they can make the scene authentic. You show them your photos and the menu and describe the oysters Great-Uncle Otto ate, but you don’t bother with why he took the trip. To succeed in this role, you must help them solve a practical problem whose solution you base not on all the data you can find, no matter how new, but on just those particular facts that are relevant to the problem of authenticity and whose sources you can show are reliable. Your audience will listen intently and critically, because they want to get the details right.

如果您的老师发明了一项“真实世界”作业，那么您可能会面临这样的任务——写信给需要对受污染的湖泊采取措施的 EPA 官员。学术研究人员有时会解决此类实际问题，但对他们而言，另一种问题更为常见。因此，只有当你的老师创造了一个实际问题时才提出一个实际问题；否则，请先与她确认。（我们将在第 4 章更详细地讨论实际问题。）

That’s the kind of task you’re likely to face if your teacher invents a “real world” assignment—write to an EPA official who needs to do something about a polluted lake. Academic researchers sometimes address practical problems like these, but for them another kind of problem is far more common. So pose a practical problem only if your teacher creates one; otherwise, check with her first. (We’ll discuss practical problems in more detail in chapter 4.)

2.3.3帮助我更好地理解某些东西

2.3.3 Help Me Understand Something Better

现在假设您的听众是 Zeppo 大学比空气还轻的研究系的教员。他们研究各个方面飞艇和齐柏林飞艇，研究它们的经济学和空气动力学，并参与关于它们的历史和社会意义的全球对话。他们与其他研究轻于空气的学者竞争，以产生新的轻于空气的知识和理论，并发表在轻于空气的期刊和书籍中，供其轻于空气领域的每个人阅读。

Now imagine that your audience is the faculty of Zeppo University’s Department of Lighter-than-Air Studies. They study all aspects of blimps and zeppelins, do research on their economics and aerodynamics, and participate in a worldwide conversation about their history and social significance. They compete with other lighter-than-air scholars to produce new lighter-than-air knowledge and theories that they publish in lighter-than-air journals and books read by everyone in their lighter-than-air field.

这些学者邀请您谈谈您的专业：20 世纪 30 年代飞艇旅行的社会历史。他们不希望您只是用新的事实逗他们开心（尽管如果您这样做他们会很高兴）或帮助他们做某事（尽管如果您让他们咨询 True-to-Life Films 的工作他们会很高兴). 他们希望您使用任何新的事实来帮助他们更好地了解齐柏林飞艇旅行的社会历史，或者更好的是，了解一般的轻于空气的文化。

These scholars have invited you to talk about your specialty: the social history of zeppelin travel in the 1930s. They don’t want you just to amuse them with new facts (though they’ll be happy if you do) or to help them do something (though they’d be pleased if you got them consulting work with True-to-Life Films). They want you to use whatever new facts you have to help them better understand the social history of zeppelin travel or, better still, of lighter-than-air culture in general.

因为这些比空气还轻的学者都非常致力于寻找齐柏林飞艇的真相，你知道他们希望你客观、逻辑严密，并且能够从各个方面审视每一个问题。你也知道，如果你不明确你的事实，他们会在提问期间敲打你，如果你没有很好的答案，然后在葡萄酒和奶酪上把你切成薄片，不仅仅是为了争论甚至讨厌（尽管有些人会讨厌），但要尽可能接近 1930 年代齐柏林飞艇的真相。如果您提供新数据，例如奥托叔祖父的照片、信件和菜单，他们会很高兴看到它们，但他们会想知道它们为何重要，甚至可能质疑它们的真实性。

Because these lighter-than-air scholars are intensely committed to finding the Truth about zeppelins, you know they expect you to be objective, rigorously logical, and able to examine every issue from all sides. You also know that if you don’t nail down your facts, they’ll hammer you during the question period and if you don’t have good answers, slice you up afterward over the wine and cheese, not just to be contentious or even nasty (though some will be), but to get as close as they can to the Truth about zeppelins in the 1930s. If you offer new data, like Great-Uncle Otto’s photos, letter, and menu, they’ll be glad to see them, but they’ll want to know why they matter and might even question their authenticity.

最重要的是，只有当你能证明它们如何作为证据帮助你回答一个对理解飞艇比你叔叔的旅行更重要的问题很重要的问题时，他们才会关心你的文件。如果你能让他们相信他们并不像他们认为的那样了解齐柏林飞艇的社会历史，并且你的新数据将改善他们有缺陷的理解，他们就会特别好地接受你。如果你做不到，他们的回答不会是“我不同意”——我们都学会了忍受这一点；我们中的一些人甚至以此为生——但回应却更具破坏性：我不在乎。

Above all, they will care about your documents only if you can show how they serve as evidence that helps you answer a question important to understanding something about zeppelins that is more important than your uncle’s trip. They will receive you especially well if you can convince them that they do not understand the social history of zeppelins as well as they thought and that your new data will improve their flawed understanding. If you can’t do that, they’ll respond not with I don’t agree—we all learn to live with that; some of us even thrive on it—but with a response far more devastating: I don’t care.

所以你开始你的演讲：

So you begin your talk:

对 1930 年代跨大西洋齐柏林飞艇的餐饮服务进行的多项研究（尤其是 Schmidt 1986 和 Kloepfer 1998）使我们所有人都相信，由于爆炸的危险，食物从未在明火上烹饪过。然而，我最近发现了一份 1936 年 7 月 12 日穿越兴登堡的菜单，上面写着用木炭烤的牡蛎。. . . [然后你继续说明为什么新知识很重要。]

We all have been led to believe by a number of studies on the food service on transatlantic zeppelin flights in the 1930s (especially Schmidt 1986 and Kloepfer 1998) that items were never cooked over an open flame because of the danger of explosions. However, I have recently discovered a menu from the July 12, 1936, crossing of the Hindenburg indicating that oysters grilled over charcoal were served. . . . [You then go on to show why that new knowledge matters.]

当您向学者社区报告研究时，这就是您加入的对话。你必须想象他们在想象与你的对话：不要在意你的风格是否优雅（尽管如果是，我会更欣赏你的作品）；不要用关于你的叔祖父 Otto 的有趣轶事来打扰我（尽管我喜欢听他们讲，如果它们能帮助我更好地理解你的想法）； 忽略你所知道的是否会让我变得富有（尽管如果是这样我会很高兴）。告诉我一些我不知道的事情，以便我更好地了解我们的共同利益。

That is the kind of conversation you join when you report research to a community of scholars. You must imagine them imagining this conversation with you: Never mind whether your style is graceful (though I will admire your work more if it is); don’t bother me with amusing anecdotes about your Great-Uncle Otto (though I like hearing them if they help me understand your ideas better); ignore whether what you know will make me rich (though I would be happy if it did). Just tell me something I don’t know so that I can better understand our common interest.

谁在乎那个？

Who Cares about That?

学术研究人员经常因为研究只对他们自己重要的深奥主题而受到嘲笑。这种指控通常是不公平的，但一些研究人员确实对看似无关紧要的事情着迷。威廉姆斯曾经参加过一位博士生的论文答辩，这位博士生发现了二十世纪初欧洲人类学家在非洲和亚洲拍摄的一卷又一卷胶片。这段以前不为人知的镜头让委员会的电影学者着迷。但当威廉姆斯问候选人时，“这些新电影如何提高我们当时或现在对电影的理解？” 她只能回答说“以前没有人看过这段录像。” 威廉姆斯以不同的方式提出他的问题，但从未得到更好的答案。另一方面，电影学者们并不担心（并且发现威廉姆斯的问题很天真），因为他们已经在想象这些镜头会如何改变他们对早期电影的看法。无论如何，他们都喜欢老电影本身。因此，有时仅新数据就足以引起合适读者的兴趣。但是，如果那位候选人希望写出任何人都感兴趣的东西，除了一小部分专家，她将不得不提出比这里有一些新东西。

Academic researchers are often scoffed at for studying esoteric topics that matter to no one but themselves. The charge is usually unfair, but some researchers do become fascinated with matters that seem to have little significance. Williams once attended the dissertation defense of a PhD candidate who had discovered reels and reels of film shot by European anthropologists in Africa and Asia in the early twentieth century. This previously unknown footage fascinated the film scholars on the committee. But when Williams asked the candidate, “How do these new films improve our understanding of movies then or now?” she could answer only that “no one has ever seen this footage before.” Williams put his question in different ways but never got a better answer. The film scholars, on the other hand, were untroubled (and found Williams’s questions naive), because they were already imagining how the footage might change their thinking about early film. And in any event, they all loved old film for its own sake. So sometimes new data alone are enough to interest the right readers. But if that candidate hopes to write anything that interests anyone but a tiny coterie of specialists, she will have to make an offer better than Here’s some new stuff.

您的学术读者几乎总是扮演第三种角色。只有当你按照他们认为的那样对待他们时，他们才会认为你已经履行了社会契约的那一边：对更多知识和更好理解感兴趣的学者。可以肯定的是，化学或哲学系的教员很少关心齐柏林飞艇，更不用说他们的餐饮服务了。（你能相信他们在 Helium Hall 研究的琐事吗？）但是你也不太关心他们的问题。您关心您的特定读者群体，关心他们的兴趣和期望，并根据您能找到的最佳证据提高他们的理解力。这是所有研究人员必须与读者建立的社会契约。

Your academic readers will almost always adopt this third role. They will think you’ve fulfilled your side of the social contract only when you treat them as who they think they are: scholars interested in greater knowledge and better understanding. To be sure, the faculty over in chemistry or philosophy care little about zeppelins, much less their meal service. (Can you believe the trivia they study over in Helium Hall?) But then you don’t much care about their issues, either. You are concerned with your particular community of readers, with their interests and expectations, with improving their understanding, based on the best evidence you can find. That’s the social contract that all researchers must establish with their readers.

快速提示：了解读者的清单

Quick Tip: A Checklist for Understanding Your Readers

从一开始就为您的读者着想，知道您会在完成项目时更好地理解他们。尽早回答这些问题，然后在您开始计划时重新审视它们，并在您修改时再次审视它们。

Think about your readers from the start, knowing that you’ll understand them better as you work through your project. Answer these questions early on, then revisit them when you start planning and again when you revise.

1. 谁会看我的论文？

1. Who will read my paper?

• 希望我遵守所有学术惯例并使用标准格式的专业人士？

• Professionals who expect me to follow every academic convention and use a standard format?

• 消息灵通的普通读者？

• Well-informed general readers?

• 对主题知之甚少的普通读者？

• General readers who know little about the topic?

2. 他们希望我做什么？我是不是该

2. What do they expect me to do? Should I

• 招待他们？

• entertain them?

• 提供新的事实知识？

• provide new factual knowledge?

• 帮助他们更好地理解某些东西？

• help them understand something better?

• 帮助他们解决世界上的一个实际问题？

• help them do something to solve a practical problem in the world?

3. 我能期望他们知道多少？

3. How much can I expect them to know already?

• 他们对我的主题了解多少？

• What do they know about my topic?

• 问题是他们已经认识到的吗？

• Is the problem one that they already recognize?

• 是他们已经认识但还没有认识的吗？

• Is it one that they have but haven’t yet recognized?

• 问题不是他们的，而是我的？

• Is the problem not theirs, but only mine?

• 他们会认真对待这个问题，还是我必须说服他们这很重要？

• Will they take the problem seriously, or must I convince them that it matters?

4.读者将如何回应我的主要主张中的解决方案/答案？

4. How will readers respond to the solution/answer in my main claim?

• 这会与他们已经相信的相矛盾吗？如何？

• Will it contradict what they already believe? How?

• 他们会针对我的解决方案提出标准论据吗？

• Will they make standard arguments against my solution?

• 他们是否希望看到引导我找到解决方案的步骤？

• Will they want to see the steps that led me to the solution?

第二部分

PART II

提出问题，寻找答案

Asking Questions, Finding Answers

序幕

Prologue

计划您的项目——概述

Planning Your Project—An Overview

如果你浏览过这本书一次，你就可以开始你的项目了。如果你有一个研究问题并且知道如何寻找答案，请快速复习接下来的两章；然后仔细阅读其余的，因为它们与您的任务相关。但是，如果您是从头开始，甚至没有主题可以指导您，您可能会感到困惑。但是，如果您有计划并且一次迈出一步，您就可以管理。

If you’ve skimmed this book once, you’re ready to begin your project. If you have a research question and know how to look for its answer, review the next two chapters quickly; then read the remaining ones carefully as they become relevant to your task. You may, however, feel bewildered if you’re starting from scratch, without even a topic to guide you. But you can manage if you have a plan and take one step at a time.

如果你是从头开始，你的首要任务是找到一个值得研究的研究问题，这将导致一个值得解决的研究问题。为此，有四个步骤：

If you are starting from scratch, your first task is to find a research question worth investigating that will lead to a research problem worth solving. Here are four steps to that end:

1. 找到一个足够具体的主题，让你在有时间的情况下掌握合理数量的信息：例如，不是科学写作的历史，而是皇家学会学报（1675-1750）中的论文作为前身到现代科学文章；不是17 世纪戏剧中的医生，而是莫里哀在早期三部戏剧中对医生的嘲弄。

1. Find a topic specific enough to let you master a reasonable amount of information on it in the time you have: not, for example, the history of scientific writing but essays in the Proceedings of the Royal Society (1675–1750) as precursors to the modern scientific article; not doctors in seventeenth-century drama but Molière’s mockery of doctors in three early plays.

2. 质疑该主题，直到找到引起您兴趣的问题。例如，早期的皇家学会作者如何证明他们的证据是可靠的？或者，为什么莫里哀嘲笑医生？

2. Question that topic until you find questions that catch your interest. For example, How did early Royal Society authors demonstrate that their evidence was reliable? Or, Why did Molière mock doctors?

3. 确定读者希望您提供哪些证据来支持您的回答。他们会接受来自第二手资源的事实报告，还是希望您咨询第一手资源（参见 5.1.1）？他们会期待定量数据、权威引述或第一手观察吗？

3. Determine the kinds of evidence your readers will expect you to offer in support of your answer. Will they accept reports of facts from secondary sources, or will they expect you to consult primary sources (see 5.1.1)? Will they expect quantitative data, quotations from authorities, or firsthand observations?

4.确定你是否能找到这个证据。除非你很有可能找到正确的证据，否则研究一个主题是没有意义的。

4. Determine whether you can find this evidence. There’s no point researching a topic unless you have a good chance of finding the right kind of evidence.

一旦您认为您有足够的数据来支持对您的问题的至少一个似是而非的答案，您将准备好组织一个论证来证明您的论点（见第三部分），然后计划、起草和修改它（见第四部分） ).

Once you think you have enough data to support at least a plausible answer to your question, you’ll be ready to assemble an argument that makes your case (see part III), then to plan, draft, and revise it (see part IV).

然而，您会发现您无法按照我们提供的整齐顺序完成这些步骤。在您拥有支持它所需的所有证据之前，您会想到您的研究问题的暂定答案。当你认为你有一个值得提出的论点时，你可能会发现你需要更多来自新来源的可能不同的证据。您甚至可以修改您的主题。做研究不像沿着一条容易的、标记清晰的小路漫步到一个熟悉的目的地；这更像是在杂草丛生的树林中曲折地在岩石山上上下曲折，有时在雾中，寻找直到你看到它才会认出的东西。但无论你的道路多么迂回，如果你在每一步都计划好可预见的弯路（甚至可能避免其中的一些弯路），你就可以取得进步。

You’ll discover, however, that you can’t march through those steps in the neat order we present them. You’ll think of a tentative answer to your research question before you have all the evidence you need to support it. And when you think you have an argument worth making, you may discover that you need more and maybe different evidence from new sources. You may even modify your topic. Doing research is not like strolling along an easy, well-marked path to a familiar destination; it’s more like zigzagging up and down a rocky hill through overgrown woods, sometimes in a fog, searching for something you won’t recognize until you see it. But no matter how indirect your path, you can make progress if at each step of the way you plan for predictable detours (and maybe even avoid some of them).

你的证据是什么？

What Is Your Evidence?

无论他们的领域如何，研究人员都会收集信息作为证据来支持他们的主张。但不同领域的研究人员用不同的名字称呼这些信息。我们称之为数据。所谓数据，我们指的不仅是自然科学家和社会科学家收集的数字，还包括您“在那里”发现的与回答您的研究问题相关的任何数据。人文学科的研究人员较少使用该术语，但他们也以引文、历史事实等形式收集数据。然而，数据是惰性的，直到您使用它们来支持回答您的研究问题的观点。届时，您的数据将成为证据。如果您没有比可以用作证据更多的数据，那么您收集的还不够。（顺便说一句，数据是复数；一位数据就是一个数据。)

No matter their field, researchers collect information to use as evidence to support their claims. But researchers in different fields call that information by different names. We call it data. By data we mean not just the numbers that natural and social scientists collect, but anything you find “out there” relevant to answering your research question. The term is used less often by researchers in the humanities, but they, too, gather data in the form of quotations, historical facts, and so on. Data are inert, however, until you use them to support a claim that answers your research question. At that point, your data become evidence. If you don’t have more data than you can use as evidence, you haven’t collected enough. (Incidentally, data is plural; a single bit of data is a datum.)

下定决心一路写很多东西。其中大部分将是例行的笔记，但你也应该反思性地写作，以理解：制定大纲；解释为什么你不同意一个消息来源；绘制图表以连接不同的事实；总结来源、职位和学校；记录甚至随机的想法。许多研究人员发现，将预感、新想法、随机想法、问题等记录下来很有用。你可能不会在你的最终草案中包含很多这种为了发现和理解而写作的内容。但是，当你每天边写边写时，你会鼓励自己最好的批判性思维，更好地了解你的资料来源，并且在时机成熟时，更有成效地起草。

Resolve to do lots of writing along the way. Much of it will be routine note-taking, but you should also write reflectively, to understand: make outlines; explain why you disagree with a source; draw diagrams to connect disparate facts; summarize sources, positions, and schools; record even random thoughts. Many researchers find it useful to keep a journal for hunches, new ideas, random thoughts, problems, and so on. You might not include much of this writing-to-discover-and-understand in your final draft. But when you write as you go, every day, you encourage your own best critical thinking, understand your sources better, and, when the time comes, draft more productively.

快速提示：创建写作小组

Quick Tip: Creating a Writing Group

学术研究的一个缺点是它的孤立性。除了小组项目，你大部分时间都是一个人阅读和写作。但它不一定是那样的。寻找除你的导师或顾问之外的其他人，他们会与你谈论你的进步，审阅你的草稿，甚至纠缠你写了多少。那可能是一位慷慨的朋友，但更好的是另一位作家，这样你们就可以评论彼此的想法和草稿。

A downside of academic research is its isolation. Except for group projects, you’ll read and write mostly alone. But it doesn’t have to be that way. Look for someone other than your instructor or adviser who will talk with you about your progress, review your drafts, even pester you about how much you’ve written. That might be a generous friend, but even better is another writer so that you can comment on each other’s ideas and drafts.

最好的是四五个人组成的小组，他们从事自己的项目，定期开会阅读和讨论彼此的工作。在早期，每次会议都应该以这个由三部分组成的句子总结每个人的项目开始：我正在研究 X，因为我想找出 Y，这样我（和你）就能更好地理解 Z（更多关于这个在 3.4) 中。随着你的项目的推进，开发一个开场的“电梯故事”，这是你的项目的简短总结，你可以在去会议的路上给别人。它应该包括你的研究问题、你对答案的最佳猜测，以及你希望用来支持它的证据类型。然后小组可以提出问题、回应和建议。

Best of all is a group of four or five people working on their own projects who meet regularly to read and discuss one another’s work. Early on, each meeting should start with a summary of each person’s project in this three-part sentence: I’m working on X because I want to find out Y, so that I (and you) can better understand Z (more about this in 3.4). As your projects advance, develop an opening “elevator story,” a short summary of your project that you could give someone on the way to a meeting.
