The body of secondary sources in a field is sometimes called that field’s “literature.” The best secondary sources are books from reputable university presses and articles or reports that have been “peer-reviewed,” meaning that they were vetted by experts in the field before they were published. Researchers read secondary sources to keep up with developments in their fields and, in this way, to stimulate their own thinking. The standard way of framing new research problems is to challenge or build on the conclusions or methods of others, as presented in secondary sources they have written. You can also borrow evidence from secondary sources to use in your own arguments, but you should do so only if you do not have access to the primary sources from which that evidence was originally taken. Otherwise you risk appearing careless or lazy.

5.1.3第三来源

5.1.3 Tertiary Sources

这些是为一般读者综合和报告二手资料的书籍和文章，例如教科书、百科全书中的文章（包括维基百科），以及《今日心理学》等大众发行出版物中的文章。在研究的早期阶段，您可以使用第三资源来了解主题。但是，如果您要进行学术论证，则应依赖二手资料，因为这些资料构成了您寻求参与的“对话”。如果你在学术论证中引用第三资源，你会把自己标记为新手或局外人，而且许多读者不会认真对待你或你的论点。

These are books and articles that synthesize and report on secondary sources for general readers, such as textbooks, articles in encyclopedias (including Wikipedia), and articles in mass-circulation publications like Psychology Today. In the early stages of research, you can use tertiary sources to get a feel for a topic. But if you are making a scholarly argument, you should rely on secondary sources, because these make up the “conversation” in which you are seeking to participate. If you cite tertiary sources in a scholarly argument, you will mark yourself as either a novice or an outsider, and many readers won’t take you—or your argument—seriously.

这种回应可能看起来不公平，但事实并非如此。第三来源不一定是错误的——许多实际上是由杰出学者撰写的——但它们是有限的。因为它们是为不熟悉它们所讨论的主题的广泛受众而设计的，所以它们有时会过度简化它们所基于的研究，并且它们很容易变得过时。但是，如果您牢记这些局限性，第三资源可能是宝贵的资源：它们可以告知您新的主题，如果它们有参考书目，有时它们可​​以引导您找到有价值的第二资源。

This response may seem unfair, but it’s not. Tertiary sources aren’t necessarily wrong—many are in fact written by distinguished scholars—but they are limited. Because they are intended for broad audiences who are unfamiliar with the topics that they address, they can sometimes oversimplify the research on which they are based, and they are susceptible to becoming outdated. But if you keep these limitations in mind, tertiary sources can be valuable resources: they can inform you about topics that are new to you, and if they have bibliographies, they can sometimes lead you to valuable secondary sources.

5.1.4区分主要来源、次要来源和第三来源

5.1.4 Differentiating Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary Sources

研究人员并不总是将他们的来源分为这三类。一手资料和二手资料的区分起源于十九世纪的历史学家，然后传播到其他领域。第三来源的类别是后来添加的。虽然这个方案现在是教授学生对来源进行分类的标准方法，但它比其他学科更适合某些学科：它非常适用于历史，其中主要来源是与历史事件或时刻直接相关的材料，以及批评，其中主要来源是您正在解读的艺术、音乐或文学作品的原创作品。但它对哲学、化学或护理等领域的影响不大。

Researchers haven’t always divided their sources into these three categories. The distinction between primary and secondary sources originated with historians in the nineteenth century and then spread to other fields. The category of tertiary sources was added later. Although this scheme is now the standard way that students are taught to classify sources, it fits some disciplines better than others: it works very well for history, in which primary sources are materials directly connected to a historical event or moment, and for criticism, in which primary sources are the original works of art, music, or literature that you are interpreting. But it works less well for, say, philosophy, chemistry, or nursing.

同样重要的是要了解初级、二级和三级的分类不是绝对的，而是相对于研究人员的项目。在大多数情况下，学术期刊上的文章通常被视为次要来源。但如果你的研究问题与其相关，它将成为主要来源作者或领域本身：例如，如果您正在撰写作者的传记或试图弄清楚爱国历史学家是否歪曲了阿拉莫的故事。同样，百科全书上的文章通常被认为是第三来源，但如果你正在研究百科全书处理性别问题的方式，它就会成为主要来源。如果您正在研究艾略特，TS 艾略特的文章“哈姆雷特和他的问题”将是主要来源，但如果您正在研究莎士比亚，则将是次要来源。改变你的关注点，你就改变了你的来源的分类。

It is also important to understand that the classifications of primary, secondary, and tertiary are not absolute but relative to a researcher’s project. In most instances, an article in a scholarly journal would generally be considered a secondary source. But it would become a primary source if your research problem concerned its author or the field itself: if, for example, you are writing the author’s biography or trying to figure out whether patriotic historians have distorted stories of the Alamo. Likewise, an encyclopedia article would usually be considered a tertiary source, but it would become a primary source if you were studying the way encyclopedias deal with gender issues. T. S. Eliot’s essay “Hamlet and His Problems” would be a primary source if you were studying Eliot but a secondary source if you were studying Shakespeare. Change your focus and you change the classification of your sources.

如果这令人困惑，则不必如此。请记住，这些分类只是达到目的的一种手段。归根结底，重要的不是你如何称呼你的资源，而是你如何很好地利用它们来解决你的研究问题、发展新想法并提出有趣的论点。在下一章中，我们将更多地讨论如何在写作中使用资源。

If this is confusing, it need not be. Remember that these classifications are just a means to an end. The important thing, ultimately, is not what you call your sources but how well you use them to address your research problems, develop new ideas, and make interesting arguments. In the next chapter, we will talk more about how you can use sources in your writing.

5.2 浏览二十一世纪的图书馆

5.2 NAVIGATING THE TWENTY-FIRST-CENTURY LIBRARY

今天走进大学图书馆，你可能会想，“书在哪里？” （答案：它们仍然存在，尽管许多已经转移到异地存储。）卡片目录早已被电子搜索引擎和印刷材料——书籍、期刊、照片、电影、视频和录音——所取代——越来越多地被数字化。今天，您甚至无需进入图书馆即可使用其中的许多资源。但无论您是亲自访问还是通过网站访问，图书馆都是不可或缺的研究工具。

Walk into a university library today and you might wonder, “Where are the books?” (Answer: they are still there, though many have been moved to off-site storage.) The card catalog has long since been replaced by electronic search engines, and print materials—books, journals, photographs, films, video and audio recordings—are increasingly being digitized. Today you don’t even need to enter the library to use many of its resources. But whether you visit in person or through a website, the library is an indispensable tool for research.

考虑到 Internet 上可用的数据量，您可能认为不再需要图书馆——除非是高度专业化的研究。我们认为事实恰恰相反。由于现在有如此多的信息触手可及，因此在进行研究时图书馆比以往任何时候都更加重要。图书馆不仅让我们获取信息，而且确保我们的来源可靠。即使您的公共或学术图书馆相对较小，它也可以作为访问范围更广的资源（研究指南、参考书和在线数据库）的门户，从而扩展图书馆的抵达。当然，要从这些资源中受益，您必须学会浏览 21 世纪的图书馆。

Given the volume of data available on the Internet, you might think that libraries are no longer necessary—except, perhaps, for highly specialized research. We believe the opposite is true. Because so much information is now at our fingertips, libraries are more essential than ever when conducting research. Libraries not only let us access information but also ensure that our sources are reliable. Even if your public or academic library is comparatively small, it can serve as a portal to a much broader range of resources—research guides, reference works, and online databases—that extends the library’s reach. Of course, to benefit from these resources, you must learn to navigate the twenty-first-century library.

5.2.1计划您的图书馆检索

5.2.1 Planning Your Library Search

在使用资源之前，您必须首先找到并评估它们。一些最终将作为来源的材料将实际位于您的图书馆中，但其他材料可能位于其他地方，无论是在线还是在另一个图书馆。为了利用图书馆提供的资源，您必须计划您的搜索。幸运的是，这是图书馆和图书馆员最有用的地方。

Before you can use sources, you must first find and evaluate them. Some materials that will eventually serve as sources will be physically located in your library, but others are likely to be located elsewhere, whether online or at another library. To take advantage of what libraries have to offer, then, you must plan your search. Fortunately, this is where libraries—and librarians—are most useful.

一开始要知道从哪里开始搜索可能会让人不知所措。简单地搜索几个术语并查看出现的结果是很诱人的。我们也这样做，但我们也知道图书馆提供了更系统和更有效的方法来发现有用和可靠的资源。使用图书馆来了解更多关于您的主题以及探索您的研究问题的有前途的途径。

Knowing where to begin your search can be overwhelming at first. It is tempting to simply search a few terms and see what comes up. We do this too, but we also know that the library offers more systematic and productive methods for discovering useful and credible sources. Use the library to learn more about your topic and about promising avenues for exploring your research question.

询问图书管理员。也许我们能提供的最好建议是依靠图书馆员的研究专业知识。一般参考图书馆员和（在较大的图书馆中）学科领域专家都可以帮助您优化搜索参数并指导您使用适合您的特定研究问题的正确工具。他们可以帮助您使用目录查找您的图书馆或其他图书馆（并可通过馆际互借获得）持有的资料。这些相同的图书馆员通常会设计研究指南，以识别特定领域的参考作品和在线数据库。

Ask a Librarian. Perhaps the best advice we can offer is to rely on the research expertise of librarians. Both general reference librarians and (in larger libraries) subject area specialists can help you refine your search parameters and direct you to the right tools for your specific research question. They can help you use the catalog to locate materials held by your library or by other libraries (and obtainable through interlibrary loan). These same librarians typically design research guides that identify reference works and online databases for specific fields.

不要害羞。图书馆员喜欢在研究过程的各个阶段协助各级研究人员。他们可以帮助您制定研究问题和计划、开发搜索词并清点您的结果，以确保您没有遗漏一些有价值的东西。唯一令人尴尬的问题是你没有问但应该问的问题。当然，提前做好准备，中途遇到忙碌的图书管理员是值得的。如果你有一个发达的研究问题准备好分享，您的图书管理员将能够给您更好的建议。您可以使用第 3章中的三步规则来描述您的项目：

And don’t be shy. Librarians love to assist researchers of all levels and at all stages of the research process. They can help you formulate your research question and plan, develop search terms, and inventory your results to ensure you haven’t overlooked something of value. The only embarrassing question is the one you failed to ask but should have. Of course, it pays to meet busy librarians halfway by preparing in advance. If you have a well-developed research question ready to share, your librarian will be able to give you better advice. You might describe your project using the three-step rubric from chapter 3:

1. 我正在研究 80 年代的教育政策

1. I am working on educational policy in the 1980s

2. 了解中西部的学校董事会如何处理废除种族隔离问题，

2. to find out how school boards in the Midwest dealt with desegregation,

3.因为我想了解种族关系的地域差异。

3. because I want to understand regional differences in race relations.

查阅参考著作。如果您已经对您的主题了解很多，您可能也知道如何找到相关资料。但是，如果您是某个主题的新手，请抵制直接进入您认为相关的主要或次要资源的诱惑。这种方法不可靠且不可预测，可能不会为您节省任何时间。一个更成功的策略是让参考书影响您的搜索工作。由专家编写，既有一般参考书，如大英百科全书，也有更专业的著作，如哲学百科全书将为您提供土地布局，以便以后更容易看到您的来源如何适应更大的图景。此外，参考书通常包括引文或参考书目，可以引导您找到您可能会忽略的来源。

Consult Reference Works. If you already know a lot about your topic, you probably also know how to find sources on it. But if you are new to a topic, resist the temptation to go straight to primary or secondary sources that strike you as relevant. This approach is unreliable and unpredictable and probably won’t save you any time. A more successful strategy is to allow reference works to shape your search efforts. Compiled by experts, both general reference works such as the Encyclopaedia Britannica and more specialized works such as the Encyclopedia of Philosophy will give you the lay of the land, so that later it will be easier to see how your sources fit within the bigger picture. In addition, reference works often include citations or bibliographies that can lead you to sources you might otherwise overlook.

在研究的早期阶段特别有价值的是书目作品，其中许多提供摘要，总结了关于某个主题的重要文章或书籍。尤其要注意总结近期书籍或文章的带注释的参考书目或年度文献评论；这些为您的研究提供了最有希望的线索。

Especially valuable at early stages of research are bibliographic works, many of which provide abstracts summarizing significant articles or books on a topic. Look, especially, for annotated bibliographies or annual literature reviews that sum up recent books or articles; these offer the most promising leads for your research.

探索在线数据库。图书馆与互联网的区别在于它们对索引和数据库的订阅。在书籍之后，这些可以说是图书馆最有价值的资产，因为它们使研究人员能够访问他们无法通过其他方式获得的资料。每个图书馆的订阅都不同，主要的研究图书馆提供最全面的专业索引和数据库。然而，每个学术图书馆和许多公共图书馆图书馆提供了一套功能强大的在线工具，可以极大地扩展其实际馆藏。您肯定会希望在您的研究中利用这些通用和专业资源。至少熟悉您的图书馆订阅的主要数据库，例如 Academic Search Premier、MLA International Bibliography 或 PubMed。许多学术数据库要么提供摘要，要么将您引导至包含摘要的文章。查看这些可以帮助您确定一篇文章本身是否值得仔细阅读。一些数据库允许您访问全文文章甚至书籍。但请注意：如果您的图书馆没有订阅数据库中包含的特定期刊，您可能需要付费才能访问全文文章。在这样做之前，总是与图书管理员讨论其他访问方式。

Explore Online Databases. What sets libraries apart from the Internet are their subscriptions to indexes and databases. After books, these are arguably a library’s most valuable assets, since they give researchers access to materials they could not obtain otherwise. Each library’s subscriptions will differ, with major research libraries offering the most comprehensive access to specialized indexes and databases. However, every academic library and many public libraries offer a powerful set of online tools that greatly extend their actual collections. You will certainly want to make use of these general and specialized resources in your research. At least become familiar with the major databases to which your library subscribes, such as Academic Search Premier, MLA International Bibliography, or PubMed. Many academic databases either provide abstracts or direct you to articles that include abstracts. Looking at these can help you decide if an article itself is worth reading carefully. Some databases allow you to access full-text articles and even books. But be aware: If your library does not subscribe to a particular journal included in a database, you might be asked to pay a fee to access a full-text article. Before doing so, always speak with a librarian about other means of access.

5.2.2寻找特定来源

5.2.2 Finding Specific Sources

确定了一系列搜索策略和资源后，您现在可以在图书馆内外寻找特定资源。当然，这个过程并不是严格线性的。单一来源可以引向其他来源，并使您返回到您已经访问过的目录和数据库，只是这次使用了新的搜索词。新手研究人员往往过分依赖少数几个术语，或者过于宽泛（或狭义）的术语而无法调用相关资源。成功的研究人员知道他们必须灵活：搜索通常需要反复试验才能发现那些将产生最相关来源的术语。

Having identified a range of search strategies and resources, you are now in a position to look for specific sources in and beyond the library. Of course, this process is not strictly linear. A single source can lead to others and return you to catalogs and databases you have already visited, only this time with new search terms. Novice researchers often rely too heavily on only a few terms or on terms that prove to be too broad—or narrow—to call up relevant sources. Successful researchers know they have to be flexible: searches typically involve trial and error to discover those terms that will yield the most relevant sources.

搜索您的图书馆目录。在您的研究中，您可能需要以两种互补的方式使用图书馆的目录：关键字搜索和浏览。当您检查了一些来源并确定了与您的主题相关的关键字列表后，您就可以使用这些术语来搜索目录了。在大多数图书馆中，您必须选择要用于搜索的类别（书籍、文章、期刊等）。

Search Your Library Catalog. In your research, you will probably need to use your library’s catalog in two complementary ways: keyword searching and browsing. When you have examined some sources to identify a list of keywords associated with your topic, you are ready to use these terms to search the catalog. In most libraries, you must choose the category (books, articles, journals, etc.) you wish to use for your search.

如果您的来源包括书籍，您可以使用国会图书馆的主题标题，可以在标题页的背面或他们在在线目录中的“详细信息”页面，以搜索相关资料。本书扉页的背面是术语

If your sources include books, you can use Library of Congress subject headings, found either on the back of their title page or on their “details” page in the online catalog, to search for related materials. On the back of this book’s title page are the terms

1. 研究——方法论。2.技术写作。

1. Research—Methodology. 2. Technical writing.

如果您在在线目录中搜索这些术语，您会在该图书馆中找到关于这些主题的所有书籍。一本书可以在多个主题标题下交叉列出。在这种情况下，也请快速查看这些标题下列出的标题。您可能会找到您可能会错过的有用资源。您还可以浏览目录以查找具有相似索书号的书籍。一旦你找到一本看起来符合目标的书，就可以使用它的索书号找到其他与它一起被搁置的书。在您图书的目录条目中查找浏览链接。此列表的重点不如关键字列表，但它也可能包含意想不到的宝石。因此，不要将自己局限于最接近目标的书籍。花时间广泛浏览。

If you search an online catalog for those terms, you will find all the books on those subjects in that library. A book may be cross-listed under multiple subject headings. In that case, take a quick look at the titles listed under those headings as well. You may find useful sources you would have missed otherwise. You can also browse the catalog for books with similar call numbers. Once you identify a book that seems on target, use its call number to find others shelved along with it. Look for the browse link in your book’s catalog entry. This list will be less focused than a keyword list, but it may also contain unexpected gems. So don’t restrict yourself to books nearest your target. Invest the time to browse widely.

任何在线搜索的问题在于它可能会产生大量的标题。芝加哥大学图书馆拥有三百多本关于拿破仑的书籍，还有数千本书名中带有“环境”一词。如果您的搜索出现太多来源，请缩小范围。今天的在线目录允许您以多种方式限制搜索：按出版日期、语言、主题、资源类型（书籍、文章、数据库等），以及可能的其他方式，具体取决于目录。如果您无法决定如何缩小搜索范围，请从发布日期开始。将其限制在过去十五年内发布的那些来源；如果这仍然太多，切到最近十年。

The problem with any online search is that it may produce an overwhelming number of titles. The University of Chicago library has more than three hundred books on Napoleon and thousands with the word environment in their titles. If your search turns up too many sources, narrow it down. Today’s online catalogs let you limit searches in many ways: by date of publication, language, subject, resource type (books, articles, databases, etc.), and possibly others depending on the catalog. If you can’t decide how to narrow your search, start with the date of publication. Restrict it to those sources published in the last fifteen years; if that still turns up too many, cut to the last ten years.

在您搜索国会图书馆或大型大学目录后，您可能会发现您自己的图书馆只拥有您所找到内容的一小部分，但它可以借出您需要的大部分内容。对于太新而无法列入图书馆目录但对您的研究至关重要的书籍，请寻找在线书商。这些图书可能会出现在您图书馆的新馆藏书架上，您可以随时向图书馆推荐图书以供馆藏。但是，如果您很快需要这些书，您可能不得不购买它们。

After you search the Library of Congress or a large university catalog, you may discover that your own library holds only a fraction of what you found, but that it can borrow most of what you need. For books too new to be in a library catalog but crucial to your research, find an online bookseller. Those books might turn up on your library’s new acquisitions shelf, and you can always recommend books to your library for acquisition. But if you need those books quickly, you’ll probably have to buy them.

另一方面，如果您一无所获，则您的主题可能太狭窄或太偏离常规，无法快速产生结果。但你也可能会遇到一个其他人没有考虑过的重要问题，至少暂时没有考虑过。例如，“友谊”曾经是哲学家的重要话题，但几个世纪以来一直被各大百科全书所忽视。不过最近，它又重新成为严肃研究的话题。只有通过自己的认真思考，您才有可能成为一个被忽视的话题。从长远来看，这项研究可能会让你出名，但它可能不适用于几周后到期的论文。

On the other hand, if you find nothing, your topic may be too narrow or too far off the beaten track to yield quick results. But you could also be on to an important question that nobody else has thought about, at least not for a while. For example, “friendship” was once an important topic for philosophers, but it was then ignored by major encyclopedias for centuries. Recently, though, it has reemerged as a topic of serious research. Chances are you’ll make something of a neglected topic only through your own hard thinking. In the long run, that research might make you famous, but it probably won’t work for a paper due in a few weeks.

在堆栈中徘徊。在线研究比步行更快，但如果您从不进入图书馆的书架（假设您被允许），您可能会错过只能在那里找到的重要资源。更重要的是，您会错过偶然发现的好处——只有当标题恰好吸引您的眼球时才会偶然遇到有价值的资源。（我们所有人都通过这种方式找到了重要的资源。）

Prowl the Stacks. Doing research online is faster than on foot, but if you never go into the stacks of your library (assuming you’re allowed to), you may miss crucial sources that you’ll find only there. More important, you’ll miss the benefits of serendipity—a chance encounter with a valuable source that occurs only when a title happens to catch your eye. (All of us have found important sources in this way.)

如果你能进入书架，找到与你的主题相关的书架，然后扫描那个书架上的书名，然后扫描上面、下面和两侧的书名，尤其是大学出版社出版的新装订书籍。然后转身浏览身后的标题；你永远不会知道。当您发现一个有前途的标题时，请浏览其目录和索引以查找与您的问题和答案相关的关键字。然后浏览它的参考书目，寻找看起来相关的标题。与在线相比，您手中的一本书可以更快地完成所有这些工作。怀疑一本没有索引或参考书目的书。（有关系统略读的更多信息，请参见 5.4。）

If you can get into the stacks, find the shelf with books on your topic, then scan the titles on that shelf, then on the ones above, below, and on either side, especially for books with new bindings published by university presses. Then turn around and skim titles behind you; you never know. When you spot a promising title, skim its table of contents and index for keywords related to your question and answer. Then skim its bibliography for titles that look relevant. You can do all that faster with a book in your hand than you can online. Be suspicious of a book with no index or bibliography. (See 5.4 for more on systematic skimming.)

您可以在线查看大多数期刊的目录，但浏览已搁置的期刊会更有效率。一旦您在网上或参考书目中找到有前途的期刊，就可以在书架上找到它们。浏览过去十年的合订本（大多数前面都有年度目录）。然后快速浏览一下附近搁置的期刊。您会惊奇地发现您会在网上错过的相关文章的频率。

You can check tables of contents for most journals online, but browsing among shelved journals can be more productive. Once you identify promising journals online or in bibliographies, find them on the shelf. Skim the bound volumes for the last ten years (most have an annual table of contents in front). Then take a quick look at journals shelved nearby. You’ll be surprised how often you find a relevant article that you would have missed online.

遵循书目路径。大多数资源都会为您提供书目搜索的线索。当你发现一本看起来有用的书时，浏览其参考书目或引用的作品。它的索引将列出被引用次数最多的作者（通常，被引用次数越多，作者越重要）。期刊文章通常以对先前研究的回顾开始，所有研究均被引用。通过遵循此书目路径，您可以浏览最困难的研究领域，因为一个来源总是导致其他来源，导致其他来源，导致其他来源。. .

Follow Bibliographic Trails. Most sources will give you trailheads for bibliographical searches. When you find a book that seems useful, skim its bibliography or works cited. Its index will list the authors cited most often (generally, the more citations, the more important an author is). Journal articles usually begin with a review of previous research, all cited. By following this bibliographic trail, you can navigate the most difficult research territory, because one source always leads to others, which lead to others, which lead to . . .

使用引文索引。许多在线目录和数据库可以让您查找引用您已知的来源的其他来源。这种称为引文索引的技术就像沿着书目路径前进或后退。您可以搜索引用给定来源或前向引用的来源，而不是搜索给定来源引用的来源，反向引用。因此，一个来源的可信度可以通过它引用的来源和引用它的来源来衡量。一个给定的来源后来被引用的次数越多，它的声誉和影响因子就越大。

Use Citation Indexing. Many online catalogs and databases let you look up other sources that cite one that you already know. This technique, called citation indexing, is like following a bibliographic trail, forward or backward. Instead of searching for sources that a given source cites, backward citation, you can search for sources that cite a given source, or forward citation. A source’s credibility can thus be gauged both by the sources it cites and by the sources that cite it. The more a given source is later cited, the greater its reputation and its impact factor.

为了进行此类研究，研究人员过去不得不查阅印刷的引文索引，这个过程可能需要数小时甚至数天。但是今天的在线目录和数据库使这一切变得容易。通过跟踪书目路径并结合使用引文索引，您可以建立一个丰富的资源网络来支持您自己的研究。

To do this kind of research, researchers used to have to consult printed citation indexes, a process that could take hours or even days. But today’s online catalogs and databases make it easy. By following bibliographic trails and using citation indexing in tandem, you can build up a rich network of sources to support your own research.

5.3 在 Internet 上定位资源

5.3 LOCATING SOURCES ON THE INTERNET

您可能已经知道如何搜索公共可用的 Internet：在 Google 等公共搜索引擎的文本框中键入几个词，链接页面（以 URL 或统一资源定位符的形式提供）就会出现在您的屏幕上。我们一直使用这种技术来查找电影放映时间、餐厅评论、股票价格、新闻项目等等。它在我们日常生活中无处不在，反映在我们的语言中。我们将一家公司的名称变成了一个动词：用日常用语来说，“谷歌”就是搜索它。

You probably already know how to search the publicly available Internet: type a few words into the text box of a public search engine like Google, and pages of links—delivered as URLs, or uniform resource locators—arrive on your screen. We use this technique all the time, to find movie times, restaurant reviews, stock prices, news items, and so on. Its ubiquity in our everyday lives is reflected in our language. We’ve turned the name of a company into a verb: in everyday parlance, to “Google” something is to search for it.

您在此类日常研究中的实践经验可能会让您认为互联网是全面可靠的。（你用它来为智能手机或牛仔裤定价，那么为什么不用于你的学术或专业研究呢？）但那将是一个错误。再次提醒您，图书馆的目录和数据库可以让您访问大量您无法通过搜索引擎获得的信息。使用 Internet 进行研究时，请保持健康的怀疑态度：我们使用 Google 或其他搜索引擎检索到的大部分内容都是完全可靠的，但并非所有内容都是如此。与图书馆的目录和数据库相比，互联网基本上不受监控。没有人可以保证无数网站发布和发送的材料的可信度。最后，请记住，提供免费搜索引擎的公司通过获取有关您的在线行为的数据和销售广告来赚钱，并且网站管理员会定期修改他们的网站，使它们在搜索结果中显示得更靠前。这些做法不一定是邪恶的，

Your practical experience with such everyday research might lead you to regard the Internet as comprehensive and reliable. (You use it to price a smartphone or pair of jeans, so why not for your academic or professional research?) But that would be a mistake. Again, remember that your library’s catalogs and databases will allow you to access a great deal of information that you cannot get through a search engine. When using the Internet for research, maintain a healthy skepticism: most of what we retrieve using Google or some other search engine is perfectly reliable, but not everything is. In contrast to your library’s catalogs and databases, the Internet is essentially unmonitored. There is no one to vouch for the credibility of materials posted to, and sent from, countless websites. And finally, keep in mind that companies offering free search engines make their money by acquiring data about you through your online behavior and by selling advertising, and that webmasters routinely modify their sites to make them appear higher in search results. These practices are not necessarily nefarious, but you should remember that search engine companies and websites themselves have an interest in where you go and what you see online.

但是，如果您牢记这些限制，那么使用 Internet 可以成为您研究计划的重要组成部分。以下是我们在自己的研究中使用互联网的一些方式：

But if you keep these limitations in mind, using the Internet can be a valuable component of your research plan. Here are some ways in which we use the Internet in our own research:

• 了解我们对新主题的态度——将我们在这个阶段学到的一切都视为临时的

• To get our bearings with respect to a new topic—regarding everything we learn at this stage as provisional

• 探索潜在关键字以用于更系统的搜索

• To explore potential keywords to use in a more systematic search

• 提醒自己日期或事实——再次记住对照更可靠的来源核对这些

• To remind ourselves of dates or facts—again remembering to check these against more reliable sources

• 找到我们可能希望联系的来源的作者：许多学者和研究人员的资料可在学院和大学网站上找到

• To locate the authors of sources whom we might wish to contact: profiles of many scholars and researchers are available on college and university websites

• 使用谷歌学术搜索快速搜索专业数据库，大致了解我们可能找到的内容

• To get a “ballpark” sense of what we are likely to find through a search of specialized databases by a quick search using Google Scholar

公共可用的一般第三资源（如维基百科）和专业资源（如维多利亚网络）通常非常可靠。但是你仍然应该怀疑地看待它们。一般来说，不要使用 Internet 寻找二手资源，因为它们的可信度取决于学术出版中固有的检查系统，尤其是同行评审系统。但是，您可以免费使用 Internet 作为主要来源。例如，如果您研究肥皂剧故事情节如何回应粉丝的反应，粉丝博客将是很好的主要来源。（我们将在下一节讨论评估来源。）

Publicly available general tertiary sources such as Wikipedia and specialized ones such as the Victorian Web are often quite reliable. But you should still view them skeptically. In general, don’t use the Internet to find secondary sources, as these depend for their credibility on the checks inherent in the academic publishing system, especially that of peer review. You can, however, use the Internet freely as a primary source. For example, if you study how soap opera story lines respond to their fans’ reactions, fan blogs would be fine primary sources. (We discuss evaluating sources in the next section.)

尊重作者的权利。古腾堡计划和谷歌图书等网站可以提供不再受版权保护的旧文本的可靠在线副本。但是发布更新的文本（在美国，是 1923 年或之后出版的文本）可能会侵犯作者的版权。细心的读者不喜欢看到引用未经授权的副本，不仅因为这违反了法律，而且因为此类文本经常被不准确地复制。因此，除非最近的文本是在作者明确许可的情况下发布的（如在数据库中），否则请使用其印刷版而不是电子版。

Respecting Authors’ Rights. Sites such as Project Gutenberg and Google Books can provide reliable online copies of older texts no longer in copyright. But postings of more recent texts (in the United States, those published in 1923 or later) may violate the author’s copyright. Careful readers dislike seeing unauthorized copies cited not only because that breaks the law but also because such texts are often inaccurately reproduced. So unless a recent text is posted with the author’s clear permission (as in a database), use its print rather than its e-version.

5.4 评估相关性和可靠性的来源

5.4 EVALUATING SOURCES FOR RELEVANCE AND RELIABILITY

当您开始寻找资源时，您会发现资源超出您的使用范围，因此您必须快速评估它们的用处。为此，请使用两个标准：相关性和可靠性。

When you start looking for sources, you’ll find more than you can use, so you must quickly evaluate their usefulness. To do so use two criteria: relevance and reliability.

5.4.1评估相关性来源

5.4.1 Evaluating Sources for Relevance

如果您的来源是一本书，请执行以下操作：

If your source is a book, do this:

• 浏览关键字索引，然后浏览出现这些词的页面。

• Skim its index for your keywords, then skim the pages on which those words occur.

• 浏览大量使用关键词的章节的第一段和最后一段。

• Skim the first and last paragraphs in chapters that use a lot of your keywords.

• 略读序言、介绍、章节摘要等。

• Skim prologues, introductions, summary chapters, and so on.

• 浏览最后一章，尤其是第一页和最后两页或最后两页。

• Skim the last chapter, especially the first and last two or three pages.

• 如果来源是文章集，请浏览编辑的介绍。

• If the source is a collection of articles, skim the editor’s introduction.

• 检查参考书目中与您的主题相关的标题。

• Check the bibliography for titles relevant to your topic.

如果您的来源是电子书，您仍然应该按照这些步骤操作，但您也可以在整个文本中搜索您的关键字。

If your source is an e-book, you should still follow these steps, but you can also search the whole text for your keywords.

如果您的来源是一篇文章，请执行以下操作：

If your source is an article, do this:

• 阅读摘要（如果有的话）。

• Read the abstract, if it has one.

• 略读引言和结论；或者，如果它们没有标题，则浏览前六或七段和后四或五段。

• Skim the introduction and conclusion; or if they are not marked off by headings, skim the first six or seven paragraphs and the last four or five.

• 浏览章节标题，阅读这些章节的第一段和最后一段。

• Skim for section headings, and read the first and last paragraphs of those sections.

• 检查参考书目中与您的主题相关的标题。

• Check the bibliography for titles relevant to your topic.

如果您的来源在线，请执行以下操作：

If your source is online, do this:

• 如果它看起来像一篇印刷文章，请按照期刊文章的步骤进行操作，并搜索您的关键字。

• If it looks like a printed article, follow the steps for a journal article, and also search on your keywords.

• 浏览标有“介绍”、“概述”、“总结”等的部分。如果没有，请查找标有“关于网站”或类似内容的链接。

• Skim sections labeled “introduction,” “overview,” “summary,” or the like. If there are none, look for a link labeled “About the Site” or something similar.

• 如果该站点有一个标有“站点地图”或“索引”的链接，请检查它的关键字并浏览参考页面。

• If the site has a link labeled “Site Map” or “Index,” check it for your keywords and skim the referenced pages.

• 如果站点有“搜索”资源，请输入您的关键字。

• If the site has a “search” resource, type in your keywords.

这种速读可以指导自己的写作和修改。如果你的论文结构不便于读者快速浏览并看到你的论点大纲，那么你的论文就有问题，我们将在第12章和第13章讨论这个问题。

This kind of speedy reading can guide your own writing and revision. If you do not structure your paper so your readers can skim it quickly and see the outlines of your argument, your paper has a problem, an issue we discuss in chapters 12 and 13.

5.4.2评估来源的可靠性

5.4.2 Evaluating Sources for Reliability

在阅读之前您无法判断来源，但有迹象表明其可靠性：

You can’t judge a source until you read it, but there are signs of its reliability:

1. 来源是否由知名媒体发布或在线发布？大多数大学出版社都是可靠的，特别是如果你知道大学的名字。一些与大学无关的商业出版社在某些领域是可靠的，例如文学领域的 Norton、科学领域的 Ablex 或法律领域的 West。对一本耸人听闻的商业书籍持怀疑态度，即使其作者的名字后面有博士学位。尤其要注意关于干细胞等激烈争论的社会问题的消息来源研究、枪支管制和全球变暖。许多书籍和文章都是由意识形态驱动的个人或组织出版的。图书馆通常为了覆盖范围而收录它们，但不要假设它们是可靠的。

1. Is the source published or posted online by a reputable press? Most university presses are reliable, especially if you recognize the name of the university. Some commercial presses, which are presses not associated with a university, are reliable in some fields, such as Norton in literature, Ablex in sciences, or West in law. Be skeptical of a commercial book that makes sensational claims, even if its author has a PhD after his name. Be especially careful about sources on hotly contested social issues such as stem-cell research, gun control, and global warming. Many books and articles are published by individuals or organizations driven by ideology. Libraries often include them for the sake of coverage, but don’t assume they are reliable.

2. 这本书或文章是否经过同行评审？大多数著名的出版社和期刊都会在一本书或一篇文章出版前请专家对其进行审阅；这称为同行评审。大学出版社出版的论文集经常但不总是经过同行评审；有时它们仅由指定的编辑或编辑审阅。很少有商业杂志使用同行评审。如果出版物尚未经过同行评审，请保持怀疑。

2. Was the book or article peer-reviewed? Most reputable presses and journals ask experts to review a book or article before it is published; this is called peer review. Essay collections published by university presses are often but not always peer-reviewed; sometimes they are reviewed only by the named editor or editors. Few commercial magazines use peer review. If a publication hasn’t been peer-reviewed, be suspicious.

3.作者是知名学者吗？如果您是一个领域的新手，这很难回答。大多数出版物都会引用作者的学历；您可以使用搜索引擎找到更多信息。大多数知名学者都是可靠的，但如果话题是枪支管制或堕胎等有争议的社会问题，则要谨慎。即使是声名显赫的学者也会有磨刀霍霍的余地，尤其是当他们的研究得到了特殊利益集团的资助时。上网查看作者感谢支持的任何人，包括支持她工作的基金会。

3. Is the author a reputable scholar? This is hard to answer if you are new to a field. Most publications cite an author’s academic credentials; you can find more with a search engine. Most established scholars are reliable, but be cautious if the topic is a contested social issue such as gun control or abortion. Even reputable scholars can have axes to grind, especially if their research is financially supported by a special interest group. Go online to check out anyone an author thanks for support, including foundations that supported her work.

4. 如果来源只能在线获得，是否由知名组织赞助？网站仅与其赞助商一样可靠。您通常可以信任由信誉良好的组织赞助和维护的网站。但如果该网站最近没有更新，它可能已经被废弃，可能不再得到其赞助商的认可。个人支持的一些站点是可靠的；大多数不是。在网络上搜索赞助商的名称以了解更多信息。

4. If the source is available only online, is it sponsored by a reputable organization? A website is only as reliable as its sponsor. You can usually trust one that is sponsored and maintained by a reputable organization. But if the site has not been updated recently, it may have been abandoned and may no longer be endorsed by its sponsor. Some sites supported by individuals are reliable; most are not. Do a web search for the name of the sponsor to find out more about it.

5、源电流是多少？您必须使用最新的资源，但什么才算是最新的取决于领域。在计算机科学领域，一篇期刊文章可能几个月就过时了；在社会科学领域，十年是突破极限。人文学科的出版物保质期更长：例如，文学或艺术评论可以保持数十年甚至数百年的相关性。一般来说，其他研究人员接受的主要立场或理论的来源将比回应的来源保持更长时间去或发展它。假设大多数教科书都不是最新的。如果您不确定来源是否被认为是最新的，请借鉴该领域知名研究人员的实践。查看该领域最近的一些书籍或文章的作品引用列表中的文章日期：一个好的经验法则是您可以引用与该列表中较早的作品一样古老的作品（但为了安全起见，也许不是和最老的一样大）。尝试找到小说、戏剧、信件等主要作品的标准版本：它通常不是最新的。请务必查阅最新版本的二级或三级来源：研究人员经常改变他们的观点，甚至拒绝他们在早期版本中支持的观点。

5. Is the source current? You must use up-to-date sources, but what counts as current depends on the field. In computer science, a journal article can be out-of-date in months; in the social sciences, ten years pushes the limit. Publications have a longer shelf life in the humanities: literary or art criticism, for example, can remain relevant for decades and even centuries. In general, a source that sets out a major position or theory that other researchers accept will stay current longer than those that respond to or develop it. Assume that most textbooks are not current. If you are unsure whether a source will be considered current, take your lead from the practice of established researchers in the field. Look at the dates of articles in the works cited lists of a few recent books or articles in the field: a good rule of thumb is that you can cite works as old as the older ones in that list (but to be safe, perhaps not as old as the oldest). Try to find a standard edition of primary works such as novels, plays, letters, and so on: it is usually not the most recent. Be sure that you consult the most recent edition of a secondary or tertiary source: researchers often change their views, even rejecting ones they espoused in earlier editions.

6. 如果来源是一本书，它有注释和参考书目吗？如果不是，请保持怀疑，因为您无法跟进消息来源声称的任何内容。

6. If the source is a book, does it have notes and a bibliography? If not, be suspicious, because you have no way to follow up on anything that the source claims.

7. 如果来源是网站，它是否包括书目数据？您无法判断一个网站的可靠性，因为它没有标明谁赞助和维护它、谁写了在那里发布的内容以及发布或最后更新的时间。

7. If the source is a website, does it include bibliographical data? You cannot judge the reliability of a site that does not indicate who sponsors and maintains it, who wrote what’s posted there, and when it was posted or last updated.

8. 如果来源是一个网站，它是否明智地处理了它的主题？您的读者不太可能信任从事激烈宣传、攻击不同意者、提出荒唐主张、使用辱骂性语言或犯拼写、标点符号和语法错误的网站。

8. If the source is a website, does it approach its topic judiciously? Your readers are unlikely to trust a site that engages in heated advocacy, attacks those who disagree, makes wild claims, uses abusive language, or makes errors of spelling, punctuation, and grammar.

以下标准对于高年级学生尤为重要：

The following criteria are particularly important for advanced students:

9. 如果来源是一本书，它是否经过了很好的评论？许多领域都有已发表评论的索引，可以告诉您其他人如何评价来源（请参阅我们的“附录：书目资源”）。

9. If the source is a book, has it been well reviewed? Many fields have indexes to published reviews that tell you how others evaluate a source (see our “Appendix: Bibliographic Resources”).

10. 来源是否经常被其他人引用？您可以通过其他人引用它的频率来粗略估计该来源的影响力。引文索引使这很容易做到（见 5.2.2）。如果您发现某个来源被其他学者反复引用，您可以推断该领域的专家认为它是可靠且重要的。据说此类来源具有很高的“影响因子”。你应该保持一个留意这些资源，并利用它们来定位自己的研究领域。

10. Has the source been frequently cited by others? You can roughly estimate how influential a source is by how often others cite it. Citation indexing makes this easy to do (see 5.2.2). If you find that a source is cited repeatedly by other scholars, you can infer that experts in the field regard it as reliable and significant. Such sources are said to have a high “impact factor.” You should keep an eye out for such sources and use them to orient yourself in your field of research.

您可以信任谁？

Whom Can You Trust?

备受推崇的美国医学会杂志任命了一个委员会来审查知名期刊发表的文章的可靠性。尽管这些论文得到了该领域专家的认可，但审稿人报告说“统计和方法错误很常见”（“当同行评审产生不可靠的科学时，”纽约时报， 2002 年 6 月 11 日，第 D6 页）。面对这样的爆料，一些人干脆不理会科学家发表的言论：如果科学文章的审稿人都不能保证数据可靠，外行又何必呢？你做我们都做的——尽你所能：批判性地阅读，当你报告数据时，尽可能准确地做到这一点。我们将在第 8 章回到这个问题。

The highly respected Journal of the American Medical Association appointed a committee to review articles published by reputable journals for reliability. Even though those papers had been approved by experts in the field, the reviewers reported that “statistical and methodological errors were common” (“When Peer Review Produces Unsound Science,” New York Times, June 11, 2002, p. D6). In the face of such revelations, some just dismiss what scientists publish: if the reviewers of scientific articles can’t guarantee reliable data, what is a mere layperson to do? You do what we all do—the best you can: read critically, and when you report data, do so as accurately as you can. We’ll return to this question in chapter 8.

错误很糟糕，但不诚实更糟糕。Booth 的一名学生在一家制药公司找到了一份暑期工作，他被指派检查成堆的医生对问卷的回答，并撕碎某些答案，直到十分之九的人都认可该公司的产品。这些虚假数据随后被用来“证明”该产品有效。这个学生厌恶地退出了，毫无疑问，他被一个不那么道德的人取代了。

Error is bad, but dishonesty is worse. One of Booth’s students got a summer job with a drug company and was assigned to go through stacks of doctors’ answers to questionnaires and shred certain ones until nine out of ten of those left endorsed the company’s product. These bogus data were then used to “prove” that the product worked. The student quit in disgust and was, no doubt, replaced by someone less ethical.

这些指标不保证可靠性。审稿人有时会建议知名媒体发表一些论据薄弱或数据薄弱的文章，因为其论点的其他方面太重要了，不容错过——我们每个人都这样做过。因此，不要仅仅因为一份报告是由知名研究人员撰写并由知名媒体出版，就认为您可以不加批判地阅读。

These indicators do not guarantee reliability. Reviewers sometimes recommend that a reputable press publish something weakly argued or with thin data because other aspects of its argument are too important to miss—we have each done so. So don’t assume that you can read uncritically just because a report is written by a reputable researcher and published by a reputable press.

5.5 超越可预测的来源

5.5 LOOKING BEYOND PREDICTABLE SOURCES

对于课堂论文，您可能会使用您所在领域的典型资源。但是，如果你正在做一个高级项目、一篇硕士论文或一篇博士论文，那就超越它们进行搜索。例如，如果您的项目是关于晚些时候农业变化的经济影响在 16 世纪的英国，你可能会读到涉及乡村人物的伊丽莎白时代的戏剧，看看农业生活的木版画，找到宗教人物对农村社会行为的评论。相反，如果你正在研究伦敦日常生活的视觉表现，你可能会研究时间和地点的经济史。当你超越与你的问题相关的标准参考文献时，你不仅丰富了你的分析，而且丰富了你的知识参考范围和你综合各种数据的能力，这是一个探究性思维的关键能力。不要忽略与您的主题相关但在您最相关来源的参考书目中未提及的著作——如果您找到其他人忽略的良好来源，您将获得原创性的荣誉。

For a class paper, you’ll probably use the sources typical in your field. But if you are doing an advanced project, an MA thesis, or a PhD dissertation, search beyond them. If, for example, your project were on the economic effects of agricultural changes in late sixteenth-century England, you might read Elizabethan plays involving country characters, look at wood prints of agricultural life, find commentary by religious figures on rural social behavior. Conversely, if you were working on visual representations of daily life in London, you might research the economic history of the time and place. When you look beyond the standard kinds of references relevant to your question, you enrich not only your analysis but your range of intellectual reference and your ability to synthesize diverse kinds of data, a crucial competence of an inquiring mind. Don’t ignore a work on your topic that is not mentioned in the bibliographies of your most relevant sources—you will get credit for originality if you turn up a good source that others have ignored.

当他们打败你时

When They Beat You to the Punch

如果您找到一个似乎能准确解决您的问题的资源，请不要惊慌：“改变阿拉莫传奇：为政治服务的历史。” 那一刻你可能会想，我死了。没有什么新鲜事可说。（这发生在 Williams 写博士论文的时候，也发生在 Colomb 的第一本书出版之前。）你可能是对的，但也可能不是。如果消息来源确实解决了您的确切问题，则您必须制定一个新问题。但是你的消息来源问的问题可能并不像你最初担心的那样接近你的问题。而且您可能会发现您可以更好地完成源代码：如果作者未能完全正确地解决问题，那么您在制定问题时就会有一个不知情的盟友。

Don’t panic if you find a source that seems to pose and solve precisely your problem: “Transforming the Alamo Legend: History in the Service of Politics.” At that moment you might think, I’m dead. Nothing new to say. (It happened to Williams when he was writing his doctoral dissertation and to Colomb just before his first book came out.) You may be right, but probably not. If the source does in fact settle your exact question, you have to formulate a new one. But the question your source asked is probably not as close to yours as you first feared. And you may find that you can do the source one better: if the author failed to get things entirely right, you have an unwitting ally in formulating your problem.

5.6 利用人来推进你的研究

5.6 USING PEOPLE TO FURTHER YOUR RESEARCH

21 世纪研究的悖论之一是，即使新技术使我们能够以前所未有的轻松方式获取前所未有的丰富材料，研究也变得更加个人化。因此，在开展项目时，不要忘记人为因素。

One of the paradoxes of twenty-first-century research is that even as new technologies allow us to access an unprecedented wealth of materials with unprecedented ease, research has also become more personal. So as you undertake your project, don’t forget about the human element.

最明显的是，人可以成为主要数据的来源，通过观察、调查或访谈收集。使用时要有创意主要研究人员：不要忽视当地企业、政府或民间组织的人员。例如，如果你正在研究你所在城镇的学校取消种族隔离，你可能会超越文件，询问当地学区是否有人有可以分享的回忆。我们无法解释面试的复杂性（有很多关于该过程的指南），但请记住，您越是通过准确确定你想知道什么，你就会更有效地得到你需要的东西。您不需要围绕一系列问题编写访谈脚本——事实上，如果它让受访者呆住了，那可能不是一个好主意。但是请做好准备，以免您漫无目的地质疑您的消息来源。您总是可以为错过的内容重读一本书，但是您不能继续回到人们身边，因为您没有做好足够的准备来第一次获得您需要的东西。永远记住，在进行涉及人的初步研究时，您必须遵守严格的道德标准（请参阅本章末尾的快速提示）。

Most obviously, people can be sources of primary data, collected through observation, surveys, or interviews. Be creative when using people for primary research: don’t ignore people in local business, government, or civic organizations. For example, if you were researching school desegregation in your town, you might go beyond the documents to ask the local school district whether anyone there has memories to share. We can’t explain the complexities of interviewing (there are many guides to that process), but remember that the more you plan by determining exactly what you want to know, the more efficiently you will get what you need. You don’t need to script an interview around a set list of questions—in fact, that can be a bad idea if it makes the interviewee freeze up. But prepare so that you don’t question your source aimlessly. You can always reread a book for what you missed, but you can’t keep going back to people because you didn’t prepare well enough to get what you needed the first time. And always remember that when conducting primary research that involves people, you must adhere to rigorous ethical standards (see the Quick Tip at the end of this chapter).

人们还可以将您引向良好的二手资料来源或自己充当此类资料来源。我们之前注意到，关于某个主题的二手资料主体构成了关于该主题的学术“对话”。那是一个比喻。但是你也可以而且应该就你的研究进行真正的对话。上面我们鼓励您与一种专家讨论您的研究：您的参考图书管理员。您的图书管理员是图书馆研究过程方面的专家。您还可以直接与专家就您的主题进行交谈，从而从中受益。向他们询问该领域中重要的开放性问题。询问他们对您的项目或临时论文的看法。请他们推荐二手资料供您阅读。这种个人指导对新手研究人员来说是无价的，

People can also lead you to good secondary sources or serve as such sources themselves. We noted earlier that the body of secondary sources on a topic constitutes the scholarly “conversation” about it. That was a metaphor. But you can and should have real conversations about your research as well. Above we encouraged you to discuss your research with one kind of expert: your reference librarian. Your librarian is an expert on the processes of library research. You can also benefit from talking directly with experts on your topic. Ask them about the important open questions in the field. Ask them what they think of your project or provisional thesis. Ask them to suggest secondary sources for you to read. This kind of personal guidance can be invaluable to a novice researcher, and many experts will be happy to talk with you (or at least engage in a little e-mail correspondence).

我们所有人都在自己的研究中提出了这些问题并取得了巨大成功，我们所有人都通过帮助那些与我们联系的人来回应这些问题。我们中的一个人曾经邀请一位知名学者向一群人讲述他的研究过程大学一年级学生。他以这样的方式开始他的演讲：“我真的没有研究过程；我只是问我聪明的朋友我应该读什么。” 这位学者至少有点开玩笑，但我们都可以做得更好，而不是依赖这些聪明的朋友，至少让我们开始。

All of us have made these kinds of queries with great success in our own research, and all of us have responded to them in turn, by helping those who have contacted us. One of us once invited an eminent scholar to talk about his research process to a group of first-year college students. He began his talk by saying, “I don’t really have a research process; I just ask my smart friends what I should read.” This scholar was being at least a bit tongue in cheek, but we could all do worse than to rely on such smart friends, at least to get us started.

快速提示：使用人作为数据源的伦理

Quick Tip: The Ethics of Using People as Sources of Data

近年来，我们越来越意识到使用人进行的研究可能会无意中伤害他们——不仅仅是身体上的伤害，还有让他们难堪、侵犯他们的隐私等等。所以每所学院或大学现在都有一个委员会来审查所有直接或间接涉及人的研究，无论是由学生还是专业研究人员完成的。这些委员会有不同的名称——人类受试者委员会、机构审查委员会、伦理研究委员会等等——但它们都旨在确保研究人员遵循管理研究的格言，就像管理医学一样：不伤害。如果您使用人作为数据来源，请咨询该委员会——无论是通过访谈、调查，甚至可能只是观察他们。跳过这些障碍可能感觉像是官僚作风，但如果你不这样做，你可能会伤害那些帮助你的人，甚至可能会损害你的机构。

In recent years we have become increasingly aware that research using people may inadvertently harm them—not just physically but by embarrassing them, violating their privacy, and so on. So every college or university now has a committee that reviews all research directly or indirectly involving people, whether done by students or professional researchers. These committees go by different names—Human Subjects Committee, Institutional Review Board, Ethics Research Board, and so on—but they all aim to ensure that researchers follow the maxim that should govern research as it does medicine: Do no harm. Consult with that committee if you use people as sources of data—whether by interviewing, surveying, perhaps even just observing them. Jumping through these hoops may feel like bureaucratic make-work, but if you don’t, you could harm those who help you and may even damage your institution.

6 引人入胜的资源

6  Engaging Sources

为了使您的研究可靠，您必须公平准确地使用您的资源。在本章中，我们将解释如何有效地利用您的资源以及如何做笔记，以便在您依赖或批评资源时读者可以信任您。

To make your research reliable, you must use your sources fairly and accurately. In this chapter, we explain how to engage your sources productively and how to take notes so that readers can trust you when you rely on or critique a source.

在本章中，我们将向您展示如何充分利用您的资源，尤其是您的二手资源。我们选择该重点的原因很简单：这是一个我们可以提供有用的一般建议的主题。研究人员查找或创建数据的方式，以及读者期望作为证据的数据类型，因领域而异。历史学家和文学评论家通常会梳理主要来源，寻找可以用作证据的段落。然而，其他研究人员根本不使用主要资源：根据他们的领域，他们可能会在实验室分析土壤样本，或进行调查，或建立计算机模型。但是每个领域都有自己的二手资料，有时称为文献，记录了该领域的对话。所有领域的研究人员都以类似的方式利用这些资源。

In this chapter, we show you how to get the most out of your sources, especially your secondary sources. We’ve chosen that focus for a simple reason: it’s a topic on which we can offer useful, general advice. The ways that researchers find or create their data, and the kinds of data readers expect as evidence, vary wildly from field to field. Historians and literary critics typically comb primary sources for passages they can use as evidence. Other researchers, however, don’t use primary sources at all: depending on their fields, they might analyze soil samples in a lab, or conduct a survey, or build a computer model. But every field has its body of secondary sources, sometimes called its literature, that document the field’s conversation. And researchers in all fields engage these sources in similar ways.

您如何使用二手资源取决于您在搜索项目时的立场。经验丰富的研究人员会定期阅读二手资料以跟上他们领域的工作，因此他们通常在开始他们的项目时会想到一个问题。但是，如果您是一个主题的新手，或者您仍然只有一个主题，您可能需要阅读大量资料才能找到要解决的问题，然后甚至更多才能弄清楚如何解决它。在本章中，我们将向您展示如何像经验丰富的研究人员那样阅读二手资料：不仅是为了您可以在自己的论点中使用的数据，更重要的是对于激发您自己思考的问题、问题和论点。

How you use your secondary sources depends on where you stand in your search for a project. Experienced researchers read secondary sources regularly to keep up with work in their fields, and so they usually begin their projects with a question or problem in mind. But if you are new to a subject or you still have only a topic, you may have to read a lot of sources to find a problem to pursue, and then even more to figure out how to solve it. In this chapter, we show you how to read secondary sources as experienced researchers do: not just for data you can use in your own argument but more importantly for questions, problems, and arguments that spur your own thinking.

6.1 记录完整的书目信息

6.1 RECORDING COMPLETE BIBLIOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION

首先要做的事情是：一旦你决定一个来源值得一读，记录它的所有书目信息。在你做任何其他事情之前先做这件事：这只需要一点时间，我们保证没有任何习惯会在你余下的职业生涯中更好地为你服务。

First things first: once you decide a source is worth reading, record all of its bibliographical information. Do this before you do anything else: it only takes a moment, and we promise that no habit will serve you better for the rest of your career.

你需要你的来源的书目信息，不仅这样你可以回忆你读过的内容，而且还可以在你写作时注明你的来源。在你自己的笔记中，你可以用你喜欢的任何格式记录书目数据——只要你的记录是完整的；当你在你的写作中引用资源时，你应该遵循你所在领域的引用风格（见 14.5）。

You need the bibliographic information for your sources not only so that you can recall what you have read, but also so that you can credit your sources when you write. In your own notes, you can record bibliographic data in whatever format you like—so long as your records are complete; when you cite sources in your writing, you should follow the citation style of your field (see 14.5).

对于印刷书籍，记录

For printed books, record

• 作者

• author(s)

• 标题（包括副标题）

• title (including subtitle)

• 编辑和翻译（如果有的话）

• editor(s) and translator(s) (if any)

• 版本

• edition

• 体积

• volume

• 发布地点（如果列出多个城市，则仅列出第一个城市）

• place published (only the first city if more than one is listed)

• 出版商

• publisher

• 发布日期

• date published

• 查阅的文章或章节的页码

• page numbers of articles or chapters consulted

• 图书馆索书号（如果有的话）

• library call number (if any)

• 国际标准书号

• ISBN

对于电子书，记录您为印刷书记录的所有内容以及

For electronic books, record everything you would record for a printed book plus

• 网址（如果有）

• URL (if any)

• 数据库名称（如果有）

• name of database (if any)

• 访问日期

• date of access

• 本书的电子版

• electronic format of the book

对于期刊文章，记录

For journal articles, record

• 作者

• author(s)

• 文章标题（包括副标题）

• title (including subtitle) of article

• 期刊名称

• title of journal

• 卷号和期号

• volume and issue number

• 日期

• date

• 文章页码

• page numbers of article

• 图书馆索书号（如果有的话）

• library call number (if any)

对于在线资源，请尽可能多地记录上述内容。也记录

For online sources, record as much of the above as applies. Also record

• 网址

• URL

• 数据库名称（如果有）

• name of database (if any)

• 访问日期

• date of access

• 网站管理员（如果确定）

• Webmaster (if identified)

如果您在线访问印刷文本，请记录原始印刷的书目数据以及您的在线访问来源。

If you access a printed text online, record bibliographical data from the original printing as well as your source of online access.

如果您扫描或复印一本书中的一段话，请同时扫描或复印其扉页和反面的书目信息。然后添加图书馆索书号（如果您知道）。引用来源时不需要包括索书号，但知道它可以让您在需要时轻松再次找到来源。

If you scan or photocopy a passage from a book, also scan or photocopy its title page and the bibliographic information on the reverse side. Then add the library call number if you know it. You won’t need to include the call number when you cite the source, but knowing it will allow you to find the source again easily if you need it.

您可能认为此建议过于谨慎，但事实并非如此。没有什么比在你的笔记中有完美的引文或数据但无法在你的写作中使用它更令人沮丧的了，因为你没有完整地记录你的来源并且无法再次找到它。

You may think this advice is overly cautious, but it isn’t. Nothing is more frustrating than having the perfect quotation or bit of data in your notes and being unable to use it in your writing, because you didn’t completely document your source and can’t find it again.

威廉姆斯曾经不得不将有关伊丽莎白时代社会历史的出版物搁置一年多，因为他未能完整记录消息来源。多年前，他看到了一些数据——一份 1638 年伦敦租房者的名单——他认为他总有一天会发现有用的。但他没能在源头上记录完整的信息，所以当那一天到来时，他无法使用它的数据。他在芝加哥大学的图书馆里找了好几个小时，直到有一天晚上他从床上坐起来，才意识到来源在另一个图书馆！

Williams once had to withhold a publication on Elizabethan social history for more than a year because he failed to document a source fully. Years earlier he had come across some data—a list of renters in London in 1638—he thought he would someday find useful. But he had failed to record complete information on his source, so when that day came, he could not use its data. He searched the library at the University of Chicago for hours, until one night he sat up in bed, realizing that the source was in a different library!

6.2 积极吸引资源

6.2 ENGAGING SOURCES ACTIVELY

有经验的研究人员不会被动阅读；他们积极接触消息来源，与他们进行对话。如果可以，请将重要资料阅读两遍。首先，慷慨地阅读。注意什么能激发你的兴趣。重读让你困惑或困惑的段落。不要立即寻找分歧，而是以有助于理解来源的方式阅读。否则，如果它提出的论点与您的论点相抗衡，您会很想强调它的弱点。至少在一开始要抵制这种诱惑。

Experienced researchers don’t read passively; they engage their sources actively, entering into conversation with them. If you can, read important sources twice. First, read generously. Pay attention to what sparks your interest. Reread passages that puzzle or confuse you. Don’t look for disagreements right away, but read in ways that help the source make sense. Otherwise, you’ll be tempted to emphasize its weaknesses if it presents an argument that rivals yours. Resist that temptation, at least at first.

然后，如果您的来源看起来很重要或似乎挑战了您自己的立场，请慢慢地、更批判地再读一遍。当你阅读一篇文章时，不仅要考虑它说的是什么，还要考虑你会如何回应。将这些回复记录在你的笔记中，或者——如果你拥有源代码或正在使用副本——在源代码本身的页边空白处。通过总结来测试你的理解力：如果你不能在脑海中总结一段话，你对它的理解程度还不够高，无法提出异议。

Then, if your source seems important or seems to challenge your own position, read it a second time slowly and more critically. When you read a passage, think not only about what it says but about how you would respond. Record those responses in your notes or—if you own the source or are working from a copy—in the margins of the source itself. Test your understanding by summarizing: if you can’t sum up a passage in your mind, you don’t understand it well enough to disagree.

不要仅仅因为权威断言就接受观点。几十年来，研究人员引用了一个“事实”，即北极的因纽特人对雪的类型有很多术语。但另一位研究人员发现他们只有三个（她声称如此）。并了解专家们经常不同意。如果专家 A 说一件事，B 会断言相反，C 会声称自己是专家，但事实并非如此。当一些学生听到专家不同意时，他们变得愤世嫉俗并将专家知识视为只是意见。但是，不要将对合法争议问题的知情和深思熟虑的辩论误认为仅仅是意见。事实上，它是一个活跃领域的标志。

Don’t accept a claim just because an authority asserts it. For decades, researchers cited the “fact” that the Inuit people of the Arctic had many terms for types of snow. But another researcher found that they have just three (or so she claims). And understand that experts frequently disagree. If Expert A says one thing, B will assert the opposite, and C will claim to be an expert but is not. When some students hear experts disagree, they become cynical and dismiss expert knowledge as just opinion. But don’t mistake informed and thoughtful debate over legitimately contested issues for mere opinion. In fact, it’s the mark of an active field.

如果你是一名高级研究人员，请检查对你的论点重要的一切的准确性。研究成果被其他人使用过的研究人员通常会告诉你，他们的报告不准确，总结不当，或者被无知地批评。作家们定期给纽约书评和纽约时报的“书评”写信，指出评论家如何歪曲他们的观点或做出事实性错误来批评他们。

If you are an advanced researcher, check the accuracy of everything important to your argument. Researchers whose work has been used by others will tell you, as often as not, that it was reported inaccurately, summarized carelessly, or criticized ignorantly. Writers regularly write to the New York Review of Books and the “Book Review” of the New York Times, pointing out how reviewers distorted their ideas or made factual errors criticizing them.

检查——再检查

Check—and Check Again

研究人员很少故意歪曲来源，但他们偶尔会粗心或懒惰。Colomb 听到一位著名的研究人员在她的演讲后承认她从未读过她刚刚讨论的作品。布斯的一本书被一位评论家“反驳”，他显然只读了一个章节的标题，“小说必须是现实的”。由于未能阅读更多内容，他不知道布斯本人正在攻击标题中的主张，以及其他对小说的误解。威廉姆斯的一本书的一位评论家错误地引用了他的话，然后认为他不同意他的观点，为威廉姆斯首先提出的观点争论不休！

Researchers rarely misrepresent sources deliberately, but they are occasionally careless or intellectually lazy. Colomb heard a prominent researcher confess after her talk that she had never read the work she had just discussed. One of Booth’s books was “refuted” by a critic who apparently read only the title of a section, “Novels Must Be Realistic.” Failing to read beyond it, he didn’t know that Booth himself was attacking the claim in the title, along with other misconceptions about fiction. One reviewer of a book by Williams misquoted him and then, thinking he was disagreeing with him, argued for the point Williams made in the first place!

6.3 阅读问题

6.3 READING FOR A PROBLEM

一旦你有了一个研究问题，就用它来指导你寻找证据、模型和论据来回应。但是，如果您还没有，您将不知道哪些数据、模型或论点可能是相关的。所以阅读资源不是随机的，而是有意地发现问题。寻找看起来令人费解、不准确或简单化的说法——任何你可以不同意的。当您不同意某个来源时，您更有可能找到一个研究问题，但您也可以在您同意的来源中找到一个。

Once you have a research problem, use it to guide your search for evidence, models, and arguments to respond to. But if you don’t yet have one, you won’t know which data, models, or arguments might be relevant. So read sources not randomly but deliberately to find a problem. Look for claims that seem puzzling, inaccurate, or simplistic—anything you can disagree with. You’re more likely to find a research problem when you disagree with a source, but you can also find one in sources you agree with.

6.3.1寻找创意协议

6.3.1 Look for Creative Agreement

如果您相信消息来源的说法，请尝试扩展该说法：它可能涵盖哪些新案例？它能提供什么新的见解？是否有消息来源没有考虑的确凿证据？这里有一些通过创造性协议发现问题的方法。

If you believe what a source claims, try to extend that claim: What new cases might it cover? What new insights can it provide? Is there confirming evidence the source hasn’t considered? Here are some ways to find a problem through creative agreement.

1. 提供额外支持。您可以提供新的证据来支持消息来源的观点。

1. Offer additional support. You can offer new evidence to support a source’s claim.

史密斯用轶事表明阿拉莫的故事在得克萨斯州以外具有神话般的地位，但大城市报纸的社论提供了更好的证据。

Smith uses anecdotes to show that the Alamo story had mythic status beyond Texas, but editorials in big-city newspapers offer better evidence.

• 消息来源支持旧证据的观点，但您提供了新证据。

• Source supports a claim with old evidence, but you offer new evidence.

• 消息来源支持证据不足的说法，但您提供了更有力的证据。

• Source supports a claim with weak evidence, but you offer stronger evidence.

2. 确认无根据的观点。您可以证明消息来源仅假设或推测的事情。

2. Confirm unsupported claims. You can prove something that a source only assumes or speculates about.

史密斯建议可视化以提高运动成绩，但对运动员心理活动的 MRI 研究提供的证据表明为什么这是个好建议。

Smith recommends visualization to improve sports performance, but MRI studies of the mental activities of athletes offer evidence that shows why that is good advice.

• 消息来源推测________ 可能是真实的，但您提供证据证明它是真实的。

• Source speculates ________ might be true, but you offer evidence to show that it is.

• 资料来源假设________ 是真实的，但您可以证明这一点。

• Source assumes ________ is true, but you can prove it.

3. 更广泛地应用观点。您可以延长头寸。

3. Apply a claim more widely. You can extend a position.

史密斯认为，当医学生用许多比喻而不是一个比喻来解释生理过程时，他们会更好地学习生理过程。工程和法律专业的学生似乎也是如此。

Smith argues that medical students learn physiological processes better when they are explained with many metaphors rather than with just one. The same seems true for engineering and law students.

• 来源正确地将 ________ 应用于一种情况，但您将其应用于新情况。

• Source correctly applies ________ to one situation, but you apply it to new ones.

• 消息来源声称________ 在特定情况下是正确的，但您证明它在一般情况下是正确的。

• Source claims that ________ is true in a specific situation, but you show it’s true in general.

6.3.2寻找创意分歧

6.3.2 Look for Creative Disagreement

如果您积极阅读，您将不可避免地发现自己不同意您的资料来源。不要将这些分歧置之不理，因为它们通常指向新的研究问题。寻找这些类型（列表并不详尽，有些类型重叠）：

If you read actively, you’ll inevitably find yourself disagreeing with your sources. Don’t brush those disagreements aside, because they often point to new research problems. Look for these types (the list is not exhaustive, and some kinds overlap):

1. 种类的矛盾。一位消息人士说，某事是一回事，但又是另一回事。

1. Contradictions of kind. A source says something is one kind of thing, but it’s another.

史密斯说，涂鸦只是故意破坏，但最好将其理解为一种公共艺术形式。

Smith says that graffiti is merely vandalism, but it is better understood as a form of public art.

• 消息来源声称__________ 是一种__________，但事实并非如此。

• Source claims that __________ is a kind of __________, but it’s not.

• 消息来源声称__________ 始终具有__________ 作为其特征或品质之一，但事实并非如此。

• Source claims that __________ always has __________ as one of its features or qualities, but it doesn’t.

• 消息来源声称__________ 是正常的/好的/重要的/有用的/道德的/有趣的，但事实并非如此。

• Source claims that _________ is normal/good/significant/useful/moral/interesting, but it’s not.

您可以颠倒这些观点和随后的观点以相反：

You can reverse those claims and the ones that follow to state the opposite:

• 尽管消息来源说_________不是一种_________，但您可以证明它是。

• Though a source says _________ is not a kind of _________, you can show that it is.

2.部分与整体的矛盾。你可以证明一个来源错误了某物的各个部分是如何相关的。

2. Part-whole contradictions. You can show that a source mistakes how the parts of something are related.

史密斯认为编码与自由教育无关，但事实上，它是必不可少的。

Smith has argued that coding is irrelevant to a liberal education, but in fact, it is essential.

• 来源声称__________ 是__________ 的一部分，但事实并非如此。

• Source claims that __________ is a part of __________, but it’s not.

• 消息来源声称__________ 的一部分以某种方式与另一部分相关，但事实并非如此。

• Source claims that one part of __________ relates to another in a certain way, but it doesn’t.

• 消息来源声称每个__________ 都有__________ 作为它的一部分，但事实并非如此。

• Source claims that every __________ has __________ as one of its parts, but it doesn’t.

3.发展或历史矛盾。您可以表明消息来源错误地描述了主题的起源或发展。

3. Developmental or historical contradictions. You can show that a source mistakes the origin or development of a topic.

史密斯认为世界人口将会增加，但事实不会。

Smith argues that the world population will rise, but it won’t.

• 来源声称__________ 正在改变，但事实并非如此。

• Source claims that __________ is changing, but it’s not.

• 来源声称__________起源于__________，但事实并非如此。

• Source claims that __________ originated in __________, but it didn’t.

• 消息来源声称__________ 以某种方式发展，但事实并非如此。

• Source claims that __________ develops in a certain way, but it doesn’t.

4.外部因果矛盾。你可以证明来源错误的因果关系。

4. External cause-effect contradictions. You can show that a source mistakes a causal relationship.

史密斯声称大麻合法化会增加青少年对大麻的使用，但证据表明事实并非如此。

Smith claims that legalizing marijuana will increase its use among teenagers, but evidence shows that it doesn’t.

• 消息来源声称__________ 导致__________，但事实并非如此/它们都是由__________ 引起的。

• Source claims that __________ causes __________, but it doesn’t/they are both caused by __________.

• 消息来源声称__________ 足以引起__________，但事实并非如此。

• Source claims that __________ is sufficient to cause __________, but it’s not.

• 来源声称 __________ 仅导致 __________，但它也会导致 __________。

• Source claims that __________ causes only __________, but it also causes __________.

5. 观点的矛盾。大多数矛盾不会改变概念框架，但是当你与事物的“标准”观点相矛盾时，你会促使其他人以新的方式思考。

5. Contradictions of perspective. Most contradictions don’t change a conceptual framework, but when you contradict a “standard” view of things, you urge others to think in a new way.

史密斯假设广告只有经济功能，但它也充当新艺术形式的实验室。

Smith assumes that advertising has only an economic function, but it also serves as a laboratory for new art forms.

• 消息来源从 __________ 的角度讨论 __________，但新的背景或观点揭示了新的真相 [新的或旧的背景可以是社会、政治、哲学、历史、经济、伦理、性别特定等] .

• Source discusses __________ from the point of view of __________, but a new context or point of view reveals a new truth [the new or old context can be social, political, philosophical, historical, economic, ethical, gender specific, etc.].

• Source 使用理论/价值体系__________ 分析__________，但您可以从新的角度分析它并以新的方式看待它。

• Source analyzes __________ using theory/value system __________, but you can analyze it from a new point of view and see it in a new way.

6.4 阅读论证

6.4 READING FOR ARGUMENTS

6.4.1阅读要响应的参数

6.4.1 Read for Arguments to Respond To

在承认并回应读者可预见的问题和分歧之前，任何论点都是不完整的。您可以在二手资料中找到其中一些相互竞争的观点。他们提供了哪些替代您的主张的选择？他们引用了哪些你必须承认的证据？一些新的研究人员认为，如果他们提到任何反对他们自己的观点，他们就会削弱他们的论点。反之亦然。当你承认他人的观点时，你就表明你不仅知道这些观点，而且已经仔细考虑过并且可以自信地回应它们（有关更多信息，请参阅第 10 章）。

No argument is complete until it acknowledges and responds to its readers’ predictable questions and disagreements. You can find some of those competing views in secondary sources. What alternatives to your claims do they offer? What evidence do they cite that you must acknowledge? Some new researchers think that they weaken their case if they mention any views opposing their own. The opposite is true. When you acknowledge the views of others, you show that you not only know those views, but have carefully considered and can confidently respond to them (for more on this, see chapter 10).

经验丰富的研究人员也会利用这些相互竞争的观点来改进自己的观点。除非你明白为什么一个理性的人可能会有不同的想法，否则你无法真正理解你的想法。因此，当您寻找来源时，不要只寻找那些支持您的主张的来源。警惕与它们相矛盾的来源，因为它们是您的读者可能知道的来源。

Experienced researchers also use those competing views to improve their own. You can’t really understand what you think until you understand why a rational person might think differently. So as you look for sources, don’t look just for those that support your claims. Be alert for sources that contradict them, because they are sources that your readers are likely to know.

6.4.2阅读推理和分析模型

6.4.2 Read for Models of Reasoning and Analysis

您也可以以另一种方式使用二手资料：作为推理和分析的模型。如果你从来没有像你计划的那样提出论点，你可能会遵循你在二手资料中找到的其他论点的模式。你不能使用特定的想法（那将是剽窃），但当你借用其争论或分析数据的方式时，你并没有剽窃一个来源。（不要担心使用来源作为模型会使你的研究看起来没有原创性。研究论证在他们的方法和推理方式上通常是非原创的。读者会在你的问题、主张和证据中寻找原创性。）

You can use secondary sources in another way as well: as models of reasoning and analysis. If you have never made an argument like the one you plan to, you might follow the pattern of other arguments that you find in your secondary sources. You can’t use specific ideas (that would be plagiarism), but you do not plagiarize a source when you borrow its ways of arguing or of analyzing data. (Don’t worry that using a source as a model will make your research seem unoriginal. Research arguments are often unoriginal in their methods and ways of reasoning. Readers will look for originality in your problem, claim, and evidence.)

假设你想争辩说，阿拉莫传奇的兴盛是因为它服务于创造它的人的政治利益，并满足了重复它的人的情感需求。您将需要针对您的主张的独特理由和证据，但您可以提出读者在关于其他真实或虚构的其他传说的类似论证中看到的各种问题。例如，如果有资料显示亚瑟王传奇如何帮助塑造英国社会和政治，你可能会对阿拉莫和德克萨斯共和国提出类似的论点。您没有义务引用您的模型，但为了获得可信度，您可能会注意到它提出了与您的相似的论点：

Suppose you want to argue that the Alamo legend thrived because it served the political interests of those who created it and satisfied the emotional needs of those who repeated it. You will need reasons and evidence unique to your claim, but you can raise the kinds of issues that readers see in similar arguments about other legends, real or fictional. If, for example, a source shows how the King Arthur legend helped to shape English society and politics, you might make a similar argument about the Alamo and the Republic of Texas. You are not obliged to cite your model, but to gain credibility, you might note that it makes an argument similar to yours:

正如亚瑟王的传说帮助建立了明确的英国社会和政治身份（Weiman 1998），阿拉莫的传说也是如此。. .

Just as the Arthurian legends helped to forge a definitively English social and political identity (Weiman 1998), so the legend of the Alamo . . .

6.5 阅读数据和支持

6.5 READING FOR DATA AND SUPPORT

6.5.1阅读数据作为证据

6.5.1 Read for Data to Use as Evidence

新的研究人员会定期挖掘二手数据来源，但如果可以的话，请检查主要来源。如果重要的引文以其原始形式和上下文可用，那么不查找它是有风险的，也是智力上的懒惰。您无需同意来源即可使用其数据；事实上，它的论点甚至不必与你的问题相关，只要它的数据是相关的。但是，仅当您可以自行判断统计数据是否被收集时才使用统计数据并进行了适当的分析。（如果你修过一两门统计学和概率课程，你会很好地为自己服务，这是大多数美国人可耻地无知的领域。）

New researchers regularly mine secondary sources for data, but if you can, check the primary source. If an important quotation is available in its original form and context, it is risky and intellectually lazy not to look it up. You don’t have to agree with a source to use its data; in fact, its argument does not even have to be relevant to your question, so long as its data are. However, use statistical data only if you can judge for yourself whether they were collected and analyzed appropriately. (You serve yourself well if you take a course or two in statistics and probability, an area where most Americans are shamefully ignorant.)

6.5.2阅读观点以用作支持

6.5.2 Read for Claims to Use as Support

研究人员经常使用他们在二手资料中找到的结果来支持他们自己的论点。如果您发现一个有用的主张，您可以引用它来支持您自己的主张，尤其是当它得到很好的支持和广泛接受的时候。但许多说法只不过表明另一位研究人员同意你的观点。要将此类观点用作证据，您不仅必须报告消息来源的结论，还必须报告其推理和支持证据。

Researchers often use the results they find in secondary sources to bolster their own arguments. If you find a useful claim, you can cite it to support your own, especially if it has been well supported and widely accepted. But many claims show nothing more than that another researcher agrees with you. To use such claims as evidence, you have to report not only the conclusion of the source but its reasoning and supporting evidence as well.

6.6 做笔记

6.6 TAKING NOTES

一旦找到您认为可以使用的来源，您必须有目的地仔细阅读它。但是，如果您不能再次找到它或不能很好地记住它以供使用，那对您没什么好处。因此，在您做任何其他事情之前，请再次记录来源的完整书目信息。然后记笔记的方式不仅可以帮助您记住和使用您所阅读的内容，还可以帮助您进一步思考。

Once you find a source that you think you can use, you must read it purposefully and carefully. But that will do you little good if you can’t locate it again or remember it well enough to use. So again, before you do anything else, record the source’s full bibliographic information. Then take notes in a way that will help you not only to remember and use what you have read but also to further your own thinking.

您可以在索引卡或笔记本上做笔记，也可以使用计算机或手持设备。您甚至可以使用多种基于 Web 的解决方案（从文字处理器到精心设计的参考管理系统）在线做笔记。这些方法中的每一种都有其优点和缺点。您需要了解它们并选择最适合您的方法。

You can take notes on index cards or in a notebook, or you can use your computer or handheld device. You can even take notes online, using any number of web-based solutions, from word processors to elaborate reference-management systems. Each of these approaches has its advantages and disadvantages. You need to understand them and pick the approach that will work best for you.

6.6.1在纸上做笔记

6.6.1 Taking Notes on Paper

多年前，在来源上做笔记的标准方法是创建一个索引卡文件：

Years ago, the standard way to take notes on sources was to create a file of index cards:

左上角是作者、短标题和页码。右上角是关键字，让研究人员可以将笔记分类和重新分类为不同的类别和顺序。卡片的正文总结了来源，记录了直接引述，并包括与引述明确区分的进一步研究的评论或想法。左下方是来源的电话号码。

At the top left is the author, short title, and page number. At the top right are keywords that let the researcher sort and re-sort notes into different categories and orders. The body of the card summarizes the source, records a direct quotation, and includes a comment or thought about further research that is clearly distinguished from the quotation. At bottom left is the call number of the source.

虽然今天很少有研究人员广泛使用这种方法，但我们仍然可以从中学到重要的原则：

Although few researchers use this method extensively today, we can still learn important principles from it:

• 记录每个来源的完整书目信息，以便您可以正确引用并轻松再次找到它。

• Record complete bibliographic information for each source so that you can cite it properly and find it again easily.

• 不同主题的单独笔记：不要将不同主题的笔记混在一起，即使它们来自同一来源。

• Separate notes on different topics: don’t jumble together your notes on different topics, even if they come from the same source.

• 确保您的笔记准确无误，因为您以后需要能够依赖它们。（如果你想引用不止几行，可以考虑影印、扫描或剪切和粘贴段落，或者简单地保存整个文档。）

• Make sure your notes are accurate, because you need to be able to rely on them later. (If you want to quote more than a few lines, consider photocopying, scanning, or cutting-and-pasting the passage, or simply saving the whole document.)

• 或许最重要的是：清楚地区分（1）你从来源引用的内容，（2）你从来源转述或总结的内容，以及（3）你自己的想法。如果您在纸上书写，请使用标题或括号或不同颜色的墨水来区分这些不同类型的笔记。如果您使用计算机或在线做笔记，请使用不同的字体或不同颜色的字体。我们强调，您必须明确地区分您自己的话和来源的话，因为很容易混淆两者。

• Perhaps most important: clearly distinguish (1) what you quote from a source, (2) what you paraphrase or summarize from a source, and (3) your own thoughts. If you are writing on paper, use headings or brackets or different colors of ink to differentiate these different kinds of note. If you are using a computer or taking notes online, use different fonts or different colors of type. We stress that you must unambiguously distinguish your own words from those of your sources because it is so easy to confuse the two.

与计算机文件相比，纸质笔记在存储、备份、索引和访问方面可能很麻烦，并且容易出现转录错误：在手抄引文时，更改措辞出奇地容易，即使您认为自己是小心。尽管如此，纸质笔记还是有其用途的。例如，笔记本或一包索引卡既便宜又便携，纸有时可以用在技术无法做到的地方——一些档案馆仍然需要顾客用纸和笔做笔记。一些研究人员仍然依赖纸质笔记的主要原因是它们有助于思考。由于您无法写出所有内容，因此使用纸张会迫使您思考最重要的内容。同样，如果您的笔记写在卡片或纸上，您可以将它们分组、洗牌，或者将它们放在书桌、桌子甚至地板上。而这个行为写下你的笔记不仅可以帮助你记住其中的内容，还可以帮助你看到联系并发展你自己的想法。

Compared to computer files, paper notes can be cumbersome to store, back up, index, and access, and they are susceptible to transcription errors: when hand-copying quotations, it is surprisingly easy to alter their wording, even when you think you are being careful. Still, paper notes have their uses. For example, a notebook or pack of index cards is cheap and portable, and paper can sometimes go where technology cannot—some archives still require patrons to take notes with paper and pencil. The main reason some researchers still rely on paper notes is that they help with thinking. Since you can’t write out everything, using paper forces you to think about what’s most important. Likewise, if your notes are on cards or sheets of paper, you can group them, shuffle them, or lay them out on a desk, a table, or even the floor. And the very act of writing out your notes can help you not only remember what’s in them but also see connections and develop your own ideas.

尽管如此，如今很少有研究人员仅依赖纸质笔记。大多数人使用他们的电脑。

Still, few researchers today rely on paper notes alone. Most use their computers.

6.6.2在电脑上做笔记

6.6.2 Taking Notes on a Computer

当您使用计算机做笔记时，您有多种选择：

When you take notes using a computer, you have several options:

• 最简单的是，您可以使用文字处理器。为每个来源创建一个单独的文件（或至少一个单独的页面），并确保明确地区分您自己的文字与来源的文字。文字处理器易于使用，但它们也限制了您索引、组织、排序和搜索笔记的能力。因此，特别是对于长期或复杂的项目，您可能需要考虑其他选择。

• Most simply, you can use a word processor. Create a separate file (or at least a separate page) for each source, and be sure to unambiguously distinguish your own words from those of your source. Word processors are easy to use, but they also limit your ability to index, organize, sort, and search your notes. So for long or complex projects especially, you may want to consider other options.

• 您可以使用专用的笔记应用程序来创建和组织您的项目笔记。此类应用程序可以帮助您索引、排序和访问您的笔记，但由于它们有时使用专有格式，因此它们会使您难以共享笔记或将它们与其他程序一起使用。

• You can use a dedicated note-taking application to create and organize your notes for a project. Such applications can help you to index, sort, and access your notes, but since they sometimes use proprietary formats, they can make it difficult for you to share your notes or use them with other programs.

• 您可以使用完整的参考管理系统。这样的系统不仅仅可以帮助您组织和访问您的笔记。他们通常可以直接从在线图书馆目录和数据库中提取信息，并且可以在您写作时格式化和更新您的引文和参考书目。有些甚至会在参考管理系统中存储您的资源的完整电子副本，帮助您建立和维护您的个人资源库。但与笔记程序一样，这些系统有时会使用专有格式，您必须学会使用它们。

• You can use a full reference-management system. Such systems do much more than help you organize and access your notes. They can often pull information directly from online library catalogs and databases, and they can format and update your citations and bibliographies when you write. Some will even store full electronic copies of your sources within the reference management system, helping you build and maintain your personal library of sources. But like note-taking programs, these systems sometimes use proprietary formats, and you have to learn to use them.

所有三种类型的应用程序也都提供基于 Web 的版本，这意味着应用程序和您的笔记不在您自己的计算机上，而是在“云”中。这可以保护您的数据免于意外丢失或损坏（您不必担心硬盘驱动器崩溃）并且可以帮助您共享信息并与其他研究人员协作。

All three types of application are also available in web-based versions, meaning that the application and your notes reside not on your own computer but in the “cloud.” This protects your data from inadvertent loss or corruption (you don’t have to worry about your hard drive crashing) and can help you share information and collaborate with other researchers.

但无论您使用何种技术，您都必须考虑一些基本问题：

But whatever technology you use, you have to consider some basic questions:

• 你将如何保持井井有条？例如，如果您计划为每个来源创建一个单独的文字处理文档，那么您需要一个系统来命名和存储您的文件。如果没有这样的系统，您的硬盘上的笔记很容易“丢失”。

• How will you stay organized? For example, if you plan to create a separate word-processing document for each source, you then need a system for naming and storing your files. Without such a system, it is very easy to “lose” your notes on your hard drive.

• 你将如何使用你的笔记？您可能会决定以不同方式存储您的笔记，用于小型项目和大型项目、离散项目和正在进行的项目、单个项目和协作项目。

• How will you use your notes? You may decide to store your notes differently for small projects and large ones, for discrete projects and ongoing ones, for individual projects and collaborative ones.

• 您的学校或图书馆提供哪些应用程序？许多学校为教师和学生提供笔记或参考管理系统，有时将这些工具与他们的目录集成。如果您的学校提供​​此类资源，请考虑使用它们。

• What applications are available through your school or library? Many schools offer note-taking or reference-management systems to faculty and students, sometimes integrating these tools with their catalogs. If your school offers such resources, consider using them.

• 最重要的是：哪种方法最适合您自己的写作、思考和工作方式？随着您成长为一名作家和研究人员，您将开发出适合您的工作方式。其他人可能会觉得它们很麻烦或令人困惑，甚至难以理解。不管。请记住，您的目标不是创建一套精心制作的笔记，但要有能力和聪明地研究和写作。如果一款软件不能帮助您做到这一点，那么它对您来说就没有用。

• Most important: what approach best suits your own ways of writing, thinking, and working? As you grow as a writer and researcher, you will develop ways of working that are particular to you. Others may find them cumbersome or confusing or even incomprehensible. No matter. Remember that your goal is not to create an elaborate set of notes but to research and write capably and intelligently. If a piece of software doesn’t help you do that, it isn’t useful—to you.

6.6.3决定是引用、释义还是总结

6.6.3 Decide Whether to Quote, Paraphrase, or Summarize

如果你可以影印、扫描或下载你的源代码，或者你知道你可以在写作时在线访问它，那么你就可以更少地关注保留它的确切文字，而更多地关注你自己的参与。这是一个很大的优势。总结来源，这也将帮助您理解它，并注意您在写作时可能想要引用或释义的段落。另请注意您自己对来源的回应。你在哪里发现自己同意它？不同意？想说，是的，但是。. . ？

If you can photocopy, scan, or download your source, or you know that you can access it online when you write, you can focus less on preserving its exact words than on your own engagement with it. That’s a great advantage. Summarize the source, which will also help you understand it, and note passages you may want to quote or paraphrase when you write. Note also your own responses to the source. Where did you find yourself agreeing with it? Disagreeing? Wanting to say, Yes, but . . . ?

如果您无法保留您的来源并且您不知道您以后是否能够访问它，您将面临更艰难的选择。转录每个有趣或可能有用的段落的确切单词需要很长时间，但是当您后来意识到您只想引用您总结的内容时，这会很麻烦。所以在做笔记的时候，你必须边做边选择是引用、释义还是总结。一般来说，人文学科的研究人员最常引用；社会和自然科学家通常会进行释义和总结。但是每个选择都取决于您打算如何使用您的来源：

If you can’t preserve your source and you don’t know whether you will be able to access it later, you have a tougher choice. It takes too long to transcribe the exact words of every passage that’s interesting or potentially useful, but it’s a nuisance when you realize later that you want to quote something you only summarized. So when taking notes, you must choose as you go whether to quote, paraphrase, or summarize. In general, researchers in the humanities quote most often; social and natural scientists usually paraphrase and summarize. But every choice depends on how you plan to use your source:

• 当您只需要段落、章节甚至整篇文章或书籍的要点时进行总结。摘要对于相关但不特别相关的上下文或视图很有用。来源的摘要永远不能作为很好的证据。

• Summarize when you need only the point of a passage, section, or even whole article or book. Summary is useful for context or views that are related but not specifically relevant. A summary of a source never serves as good evidence.

• 当段落中的特定词语不如其含义重要时，改述。释义并不意味着只改变一两个词。你必须用你自己的替换原来的大部分单词和措辞。释义永远不如直接引用那么好。

• Paraphrase when the specific words of a passage are less important than its meaning. Paraphrasing doesn’t mean changing just a word or two. You must replace most of the words and phrasing of the original with your own. A paraphrase is never as good evidence as a direct quotation.

• 为这些目的记录准确的报价：

• Record exact quotations for these purposes:

——引用的话是支持你的理由的证据。例如，如果您声称不同的地区对这场战役有反应以不同的方式描述阿拉莫，您会引用不同报纸上的确切词语。如果你只需要他们的一般情绪，你会解释他们。

—The quoted words are evidence that backs up your reasons. If, for example, you claimed that different regions responded to the Battle of the Alamo differently, you would quote exact words from different newspapers. You would paraphrase them if you needed only their general sentiments.

——这些话来自你计划依赖或挑战的权威。

—The words are from an authority you plan to rely on or challenge.

——这些词是惊人的原创或如此引人注目，以至于引文可以构成你其余讨论的框架。

—The words are strikingly original or so compelling that the quotation can frame the rest of your discussion.

— 消息来源提出了您不同意的说法，并且为了公平起见，您希望准确地陈述该说法。

—The source makes a claim that you disagree with, and to be fair you want to state that claim exactly.

永远不要缩写引文，以为以后可以准确地重构它。你不能。如果你错误引用，你会破坏你的信誉。

Never abbreviate a quotation thinking you can accurately reconstruct it later. You can’t. And if you misquote, you’ll undermine your credibility.

6.6.4获得正确的上下文

6.6.4 Get the Context Right

你不能记录一切，但你必须记录足够多以确保你准确地捕捉到源的含义。当你使用来自你的来源的材料时，不仅要记录他们说了什么，还要记录他们如何使用这些信息。

You can’t record everything, but you have to record enough to ensure that you accurately capture the source’s meaning. As you use material from your sources, record not just what they say but how they use the information.

1. 当你引用、释义或总结时，注意上下文。你不能完全避免断章取义，因为你不能引用原文的全部内容。因此，当您起草释义或摘要或复制引文时，请在最重要的上下文中进行——您自己对原文的理解。当你记录一个论点的一部分时，请注意作者所追求的推理路线：
