1. When you quote, paraphrase, or summarize, be careful about context. You cannot entirely avoid quoting out of context, because you cannot quote all of an original. So when you draft a paraphrase or summary or copy a quotation, do so within the context that matters most—that of your own grasp of the original. When you record a part of an argument, note the line of reasoning that the author was pursuing:

NOT： Bartolli（第 123 页）：战争是由 Z 引起的。

NOT: Bartolli (p. 123): The war was caused by Z.

NOT： Bartolli（第 123 页）：战争是由 X、Y 和 Z 引起的。

NOT: Bartolli (p. 123): The war was caused by X, Y, and Z.

但是： Bartolli：战争是由 X、Y 和 Z 引起的（第 123 页）。但最重要的原因是 Z（第 123 页），原因有以下三个：原因 1（第 124-26 页）；原因 2（第 126 页）；原因 3（第 127-28 页）。

BUT: Bartolli: The war was caused by X, Y, and Z (p. 123). But the most important cause was Z (p. 123), for three reasons: reason 1 (pp. 124–26); reason 2 (p. 126); reason 3 (pp. 127–28).

有时你只关心结论，但读者通常想看看结论是如何从支持它的论证中得出的。所以当你做笔记时，不仅要记录结论，还要记录支持结论的论据。

Sometimes you will care only about the conclusion, but readers usually want to see how a conclusion emerges from the argument supporting it. So when you take notes, record not only conclusions but also the arguments that support them.

2. 记录观点时，请注意其在原件中的作用。是重点吗？一个小问题？资格还是让步？通过注意这些区别，您可以避免此类错误：

2. When you record a claim, note its role in the original. Is it a main point? A minor point? A qualification or concession? By noting these distinctions you avoid this kind of mistake:

原文 由 JONES 提供： “研究人员认识到肺癌有多种原因，包括遗传倾向和暴露于石棉、氡和细颗粒物等环境因素。但研究过这些数据的人都不会怀疑肺癌的主要原因是吸烟。”

ORIGINAL BY JONES: “Researchers recognize that lung cancer has a number of causes, including genetic predisposition and exposure to environmental factors such as asbestos, radon, and fine particulates. But no one who has studied the data doubts that lung cancer’s leading cause is smoking.”

关于琼斯的误导性报告 ：吸烟只是导致肺癌的众多原因之一。例如，琼斯声称“肺癌有多种原因，包括遗传易感性和接触石棉、氡和细颗粒物等环境因素。”

MISLEADING REPORT ABOUT JONES: Smoking is just one cause of lung cancer among many. Jones, for example, claims that “lung cancer has a number of causes, including genetic predisposition and exposure to environmental factors such as asbestos, radon, and fine particulates.”

琼斯根本没有提出这一点。他承认了一个观点来确立他想表达的观点。任何以这种方式故意误报的人都违反了基本的真实标准。但是如果你只注意消息来源的话而不是他们在争论中的作用，你可能会不经意地犯这样的错误。

Jones did not make that point at all. He conceded a point to set up the point he wanted to make. Anyone who deliberately misreports in this way violates basic standards of truth. But you can make such a mistake inadvertently if you note only a source’s words and not their role in an argument.

为避免此类错误，请将论点的核心陈述与作者承认但轻描淡写的限制或让步区分开来。除非你是在“违背”作者的意图阅读——例如，揭露隐藏的倾向——不要报告来源的次要方面，就好像它们是主要的，或者更糟的是，就好像它们是来源的全部要点一样。

To avoid such mistakes, distinguish statements that are central to an argument from qualifications or concessions that the author acknowledges but downplays. Unless you are reading “against the grain” of the writer’s intention—to expose hidden tendencies, for example—do not report minor aspects of a source as though they were major or, worse, as if they were the source’s whole point.

3. 记录观点的范围和置信度。这些是不一样的：

3. Record the scope and confidence of a claim. These are not the same:

炸薯条中的化学物质会致癌。

Chemicals in french fries cause cancer.

炸薯条中的化学物质可能是致癌因素。

Chemicals in french fries may be a factor in causing cancer.

炸薯条中的某些化学物质与某些癌症的高发病率相关。

Some chemicals in french fries correlate with a higher incidence of some cancers.

4. 不要将对其他作者观点的总结误认为是对其他作者观点的总结。有些作家没有明确指出当他们总结另一个人的论点时，很容易引用他们所说的他们打算反驳的内容，而不是他们实际上相信的内容。

4. Don’t mistake a summary of another writer’s views for those of an author summarizing them. Some writers do not clearly indicate when they summarize another’s argument, so it is easy to quote them as saying what they set out to disprove rather than what they in fact believe.

5. 注意消息来源同意和不同意的原因。两位社会科学家可能会声称社会问题是由个人因素造成的，而不是环境力量造成的，但一位可能会引用基因遗传的证据，而另一位则指向宗教信仰。消息来源同意的方式和原因与他们同意的事实一样重要。同样，消息来源可能不同意，因为他们对相同证据的解释不同或对问题采取不同的方法。

5. Note why sources agree and disagree. Two social scientists might claim that a social problem is caused by personal factors, not by environmental forces, but one might cite evidence from genetic inheritance while the other points to religious beliefs. How and why sources agree is as important as the fact that they do. In the same way, sources might disagree because they interpret the same evidence differently or take different approaches to the problem.

将自己依附于任何一位研究人员对某个问题所说的话是有风险的。当您不加批判地总结他人的工作时，这不是“研究”。即使您的消息来源受到普遍信任，也要小心。如果你依赖至少两个来源，你通常会发现他们并不完全一致，这就是你自己的研究可以开始的地方。哪个有更好的论据？哪个更尊重证据？事实上，你有一个研究问题——我们应该相信谁？

It is risky to attach yourself to what any one researcher says about an issue. It is not “research” when you uncritically summarize another’s work. Even if your source is universally trusted, be careful. If you rely on at least two sources, you’ll usually find that they do not agree entirely, and that’s where your own research can begin. Which has the better argument? Which better respects the evidence? In fact, you have a research problem right there—whom should we believe?

6.7 注释你的来源

6.7 Annotating Your Sources

6.7.1边缘注释

6.7.1 Marginal Annotations

作为在纸上或计算机上做笔记的替代方法，您可以直接以印刷或数字形式对许多来源进行注释。注释是一种通过评论、问题和对其他文本的交叉引用来标记文本的技术。在空白处进行注释通常比简单地突出显示更有成效，因为它可以凸显来源与项目的相关性。

As an alternative to taking notes on paper or a computer, you can directly annotate many sources in print or digital form. Annotation is a technique of marking up a text through comments, questions, and cross-references to other texts. Annotating in the margins is generally more productive than simply highlighting because it brings into relief the relevance of a source to your project.

在注释中，您记录了本章讨论的主动阅读实践。您可以使用注释来识别来源的主张和关键词，或者通过质疑（或扩展）来源的理由、证据和保证（参见第三部分）与来源“争论”。随着项目的发展，您可以返回到带注释的文本以查看您之前的想法。

In annotating, you document the active reading practices discussed in this chapter. You can use annotations to identify a source’s claims and keywords or “argue” with a source by questioning (or extending) its reasons, evidence, and warrants (see part III). As your project develops, you can return to an annotated text to see what you were thinking earlier.

当然，并非每个文本都同样可用于注释。您不能在图书馆书籍或您不拥有的其他文本的页边空白处书写。许多文本只能（或最方便地）以数字形式访问。然而，幸运的是，有一些数字注释工具可以让您在数字环境中记录您的阅读。您可以使用这些工具来注释范围广泛的文本，包括图像，并链接您对各种文本的阅读以创建可搜索的数据库以供以后检索。

Of course, not every text is equally available for annotation. You can’t write in the margins of library books or other texts you do not own. Many texts are accessible only (or most conveniently) in digital form. Fortunately, however, there are digital annotation tools that let you document your reading in digital environments. You can use these tools to annotate a wide range of texts, including images, and to link your readings of various texts to create a searchable database for later retrieval.

广泛阅读的价值

The Value of Reading Widely

我们已经强调了有一个好的问题来集中你的研究是多么重要。但是，不要认为您是在浪费时间阅读后来证明无关紧要的资源。事实上，当你阅读和记录的内容多于你使用的内容时，你就建立了一个对良好思考至关重要的知识基础。良好的思维是一种可以学习的技能，但只有当你拥有深厚而广泛的知识基础时，你才能运用它。因此，阅读资料不仅是为了回答您今天提出的问题，而且是为了帮助您更好地思考您在余下的研究生涯中会提出的每一个问题。为此，您阅读的所有内容都是相关的。

We have emphasized how important it is to have a good question to focus your research. Don’t think, however, that you waste time reading sources that turn out to be irrelevant. In fact, when you read and record more than you use, you build up a base of knowledge crucial to the exercise of good thinking. Good thinking is a skill that you can learn, but you can exercise it only when you have a deep and wide base of knowledge to work on. So read sources not just to answer the question you ask today, but to help you think better about every question you’ll ask for the rest of your research career. To that end, everything you read is relevant.

6.7.2注释书目

6.7.2 Annotated Bibliography

一种吸引来源的方法是带注释的参考书目——一个可能的来源列表，其中包含每个来源的引文和简短的描述性摘要。（关于引用的更多信息，请参见 14.5。）根据创建它们的动机，有多种类型的注释。对于研究项目，带注释的参考书目提供了一系列来源的鸟瞰图以及它们在您的论文中可能扮演的角色。通常，带注释的参考书目的汇编是研究过程中的一个独特阶段，一个让你（和你的老师）反思你收集的资源的阶段。每个注释都是评估来源可信度、总结其论点并解释其与您的项目的相关性的机会。

One approach to engaging sources is an annotated bibliography—a list of possible sources featuring both a citation and a brief descriptive summary of each source. (For more on citations, see 14.5.) There are multiple types of annotations based on the motive for creating them. For a research project, an annotated bibliography offers a bird’s-eye view of a range of sources and the roles they might play in your paper. Often the assembling of an annotated bibliography is a distinct stage in a research process, one that allows you (and your teacher) to reflect on the sources you have collected. Each annotation is an opportunity to evaluate the credibility of a source, summarize its argument, and explain its relevance to your project.

编制带注释的参考书目可以作为检查点，以衡量您进行研究的彻底程度以及您对所收集资源的参与程度。如果你不能总结你的资料来源或解释它们的相关性，你可能还没有准备好写你的论文。

Compiling an annotated bibliography can serve as a checkpoint to gauge how thoroughly you have conducted your research and how deeply you have engaged the sources you have collected. If you can’t summarize your sources or explain their relevance, you are likely not ready to write your paper.

快速提示：管理正常焦虑的时刻

Quick Tip: Manage Moments of Normal Anxiety

当你深入你的项目时，你可能会遇到一个时刻，一切似乎都陷入了无望的混乱之中。当您积累笔记的速度快于整理笔记的速度时，通常会发生这种情况。这样的时刻可能会给您带来压力，但它们也可能表明您即将获得新的见解或发现。

As you get deeper into your project, you may experience a moment when everything seems to run together into a hopeless muddle. That usually happens when you accumulate notes faster than you can sort them. Such moments can be stressful, but they can also be a sign that you are on the verge of a new insight or discovery.

你可以利用一切机会组织和总结你收集到的东西，边写边写，并回到中心问题：我在问什么问题？我有什么问题？继续排练该公式，我正在研究 X 以更多地了解 Y，以便我的读者可以更好地理解 Z。它还可以帮助您思考。

You can minimize the panic by taking every opportunity to organize and summarize what you have gathered by writing as you go and by returning to the central questions: What question am I asking? What problem am I posing? Keep rehearsing that formula, I am working on X to learn more about Y, so that my readers can better understand Z. Writing regularly about these questions does more than help you stay focused; it also helps you think.

你也可以求助于朋友、同学、老师——任何愿意作为富有同情心但又挑剔的听众的人。解释您所学到的知识如何解决您的问题并帮助您解决问题。问他们，这有意义吗？我错过了什么重要的东西吗？你还想知道什么？你会从他们的反应中获益，但更多的是仅仅从向非专家解释你的想法的行为中获益。

You can also turn to friends, classmates, teachers—anyone who will serve as a sympathetic but critical audience. Explain how what you have learned bears on your question and helps you resolve your problem. Ask them, Does this make sense? Am I missing anything important? What else would you like to know? You will profit from their reactions, but even more from the mere act of explaining your ideas to non-specialists.

第三部分

PART III

提出论点

Making an Argument

序幕

Prologue

组装研究论证

Assembling a Research Argument

你迫不及待地计划你的论点，直到你收集了最后一点数据并找到了所有最后的相关来源。首先，你永远不可能全部得到。在第二种情况下，你最终会机械地或漫无目的地进行研究，积累越来越多的东西，却不知道你将用它做什么，或者跟随面包屑的踪迹，但谁知道在哪里。当然，您必须进行一些研究才能掌握您的项目。但是，一旦您了解了您的问题及其可能的解决方案，您就应该开始计划您的论点。你的计划会随着你的研究进展而改变——如果没有，你可能没有尽你最大的努力——但是尽早制定计划并在你进行的时候修改它会帮助你更好地掌握你的材料并更有目的地进行研究：只有当你试图提出一个研究论点回答了读者可预见的问题，你能看到你还没有做哪些研究吗？

You can’t wait to plan your argument until after you’ve gathered every last bit of data and found every last relevant source. In the first place, you’ll never get them all. In the second, you’ll end up researching mechanically or aimlessly, accumulating more and more stuff with no sense of what you’ll do with it or following trails of bread crumbs who knows where. Of course, you have to do some research to get a handle on your project. But as soon as you have a sense of your problem and its likely solution, you should begin planning your argument. Your plan will change as your research progresses—if it doesn’t, you probably aren’t doing your best thinking—but making a plan early and modifying it as you go will help you grasp your material better and research more purposefully: only when you try to make a research argument that answers your readers’ predictable questions can you see what research you have yet to do.

研究争论不像我们每天听到的激烈交流。这些争论通常涉及争执：孩子们为玩具争吵，室友为播放什么音乐争吵，司机为谁拥有先行权争吵。这样的争论可以是礼貌的，也可以是下流的，但大多数都涉及冲突，有赢家也有输家。可以肯定的是，研究人员有时会就彼此的推理和证据争论不休，偶尔会爆发出粗心大意、无能甚至欺诈的指控。但这种论点并不是让他们成为研究人员的首要原因。

A research argument is not like the heated exchanges we hear every day. Those arguments usually involve a dispute: children argue over a toy, roommates over what music to play, drivers over who had the right-of-way. Such arguments can be polite or nasty, but most involve conflict, with winners and losers. To be sure, researchers sometimes wrangle over each other’s reasoning and evidence and occasionally erupt into charges of carelessness, incompetence, and even fraud. But that kind of argument is not what made them researchers in the first place.

在接下来的五章中，我们将考察一种论证，即与其说是赢家和输家之间的尖锐争论，不如说是与和蔼可亲、时而持怀疑态度的同事进行的热烈交谈。这是一种对话，在这种对话中，你和你想象中的读者合作探讨一个你们都认为需要解决的问题，这种对话的目的不是强迫对方进入同意，而是合作寻找一个重要但具有挑战性的问题的最佳答案。

In the next five chapters, we examine a kind of argument that is less like a prickly dispute with winners and losers and more like a lively conversation with amiable and sometimes skeptical colleagues. It is a conversation in which you and your imagined readers cooperatively explore an issue that you both think is important to resolve, a conversation that aims not at coercing each other into agreement, but at cooperatively finding the best answer to an important but challenging question.

开始了解你

Getting to Know You

你一直被告知要为你的听众着想，但没有什么比想象来自你不认识的人的问题更难的了。经验丰富的研究人员具有认识许多读者的优势。他们与他们谈论研究项目，在写下之前尝试想法。如果您是刚起步的研究人员或学生，您可能还没有以这种个人方式了解您的读者。但是你可以做一些功课来了解他们是如何写作、争论和思考的：

You’ve been told endlessly to think about your audience, but nothing is harder than imagining questions from someone you don’t know. Experienced researchers have the advantage of knowing many of their readers personally. They talk with them about research projects, trying out ideas before writing them up. If you are a beginning researcher or a student, you may not yet know your readers in this personal way. But you can do some homework to understand how they write, argue, and think:

• 阅读发表与您类似研究的期刊。注意文章承认和回应的问题类型。

• Read journals that publish research like yours. Notice the kinds of questions the articles acknowledge and respond to.

• 与更有经验的研究人员或老师排练你的论点。在你有了计划之后但在起草之前，谈谈你的想法，询问是否有任何疑点或令人困惑的地方。

• Rehearse your argument with a more experienced researcher or a teacher. After you have a plan but before you draft, talk over your ideas, asking whether any seem doubtful or confusing.

• 请一些您信任的人阅读您的草稿并指出他们有问题或查看替代方案的地方。尽可能找到与您的目标读者相似的人。

• Ask a few people you trust to read your drafts and indicate where they have questions or see alternatives. Find people as much like your intended readers as possible.

您甚至可以尝试结识一些真正的读者。例如，一群物理学家曾经希望生物学家注意到他们的研究，但当他们发送给生物学期刊的第一篇手稿被拒绝时，他们很不高兴。所以他们开始参加生物学会议，阅读生物学期刊，甚至在生物学系的教员休息室闲逛。在弄清楚生物学家的想法后，他们改写了论点并发表了影响该领域的论文。您可能无法前往参加会议或在教职员工休息室闲逛，但您仍然可以结识校园内从事您所在领域工作的教职员工和学生。你越了解他们，你就越能想象他们可能会问你的问题。

You can even try to get to know some actual readers. For example, a group of physicists once wanted biologists to notice their research but were unhappy when the first manuscript they sent to a biology journal was rejected. So they started attending biology conferences, reading biology journals, even hanging around the biology department’s faculty lounge. After they figured out how biologists think, they rewrote their arguments and published papers that influenced the field. You may not be able to travel to conferences or hang out in a faculty lounge, but you can still get to know faculty and students on your campus working in your field. The better you know them, the better you will be able to imagine questions they might ask you.

不过，在那次谈话中，你们所做的不仅仅是礼貌地交换意见。我们都有权发表自己的意见，没有法律要求我们解释或捍卫这些意见。但在研究论证中，我们应该向读者展示为什么我们的主张很重要，然后用充分的理由和证据来支持我们的主张，就好像我们的读者很合理地问我们，我为什么要相信那个？

In that conversation, though, you do more than politely trade opinions. We are all entitled to our opinions, and no law requires us to explain or defend them. But in a research argument, we are expected to show readers why our claims are important and then to support our claims with good reasons and evidence, as if our readers were asking us, quite reasonably, Why should I believe that?

事实上，虽然我们更容易注意到激烈的争执，但我们每天都会进行这些合作争论，每次我们都交换充分的理由来决定做什么——当和朋友讨论买什么手机、读什么书，甚至是否去买披萨或中国菜。就像那些友好的讨论一样，研究论证不会强迫读者提出要求。相反，你从你的读者开始做起，带着他们可以预见的问题，为什么他们应该接受你的主张，他们问的问题不是为了破坏你的论点，而是为了检验它，帮助你们找到并理解一个值得分享的真理。当然，当你写一场争论，没有人会亲自问你这些问题。所以你必须代表你的读者想象它们。正是这些想象中的问题和你的答案使你的论点成为正在进行的对话的一部分。在第 7 章中，我们考察了构成研究论证的要素。在第 8-11 章中，我们详细解释了每个元素。在第四部分，我们将向您展示如何将论点写成文字。

In fact, although we more easily notice the heated disputes, we have these collaborative arguments every day, each time we trade good reasons for deciding what to do—when discussing with a friend what cell phone to buy, what books to read, even whether to get pizza or Chinese food. Like those friendly discussions, a research argument doesn’t force a claim on readers. Instead, you start where your readers do, with their predictable questions about why they should accept your claim, questions they ask not to sabotage your argument but to test it, to help both of you find and understand a truth worth sharing. Of course, when you write an argument, no one is there to ask you those questions in person. So you must imagine them on your readers’ behalf. It’s those imagined questions and your answers that make your argument part of an ongoing conversation. In chapter 7 we survey the elements that constitute a research argument. In chapters 8–11 we explain each element in detail. In part IV, we show you how to put that argument into writing.

7 提出好的论点

7  Making Good Arguments

概述

An Overview

在本章中，我们将解释什么是研究论证，以及构成一个论证的五个问题。

In this chapter, we explain what a research argument is and the five questions whose answers constitute one.

在第二部分中，我们认为真正的研究不仅仅涉及收集关于某个主题的信息；我们认为这意味着为您和您的读者关心的问题制定解决方案。同样，分享你的研究结果不仅仅是给你的读者一个“数据转储”，上面写着，这是关于我的主题的一些事实；这意味着在研究论证中解释您的问题并证明您的解决方案。

In part II, we argued that real research involves more than just amassing information on a topic; we argued that it means developing solutions to problems you and your readers care about. Likewise, sharing the results of your research involves more than just giving your readers a “data dump” that says, Here are some facts about my topic; it means explaining your problem and justifying your solution in a research argument.

7.1 论证与读者的对话

7.1 ARGUMENT AS A CONVERSATION WITH READERS

在研究论证中，您提出一个主张，用有证据支持的理由支持它，承认并回应其他观点，有时还要解释您的推理原则。这些事情没有什么神秘的：你在每一次深思熟虑地询问一个未解决的问题的谈话中都这样做：

In a research argument, you make a claim, back it with reasons supported by evidence, acknowledge and respond to other views, and sometimes explain your principles of reasoning. There’s nothing arcane about these things: you do them in every conversation that inquires thoughtfully into an unsettled issue:

艾比：我听说上学期有点不稳定。你认为这个学期会怎样？[ Abby 提出一个她感兴趣的问题，以问题的形式提出。]

Abby: I hear last semester was a little rocky. How do you think this term will go? [Abby poses a problem that interests her, put in the form of a question.]

布雷特：更好，我希望。[布雷特提出了一个回答问题的说法。]

Brett: Better, I hope. [Brett makes a claim that answers the question.]

艾比：这是为什么呢？[ Abby 要求有理由相信 Brett 的说法。]

Abby: Why is that? [Abby asks for a reason to believe Brett’s claim.]

布雷特：我终于要上我的专业课程了。[布雷特提供了一个理由。]

Brett: I’ll finally be taking courses in my major. [Brett offers a reason.]

艾比：为什么会有不同？[ Abby 不明白 Brett 的理由与他声称自己会做得更好有何关联。]

Abby: Why will that make a difference? [Abby doesn’t see how Brett’s reason is relevant to his claim that he will do better.]

布雷特：当我选修我感兴趣的课程时，我会更加努力。[布雷特提供了一个将他的理由与他的主张联系起来的一般原则。]

Brett: When I take courses I’m interested in, I work harder. [Brett offers a general principle that relates his reason to his claim.]

艾比：什么课程？[ Abby 要求提供证据来支持 Brett 的理由。]

Abby: What courses? [Abby asks for evidence to back up Brett’s reason.]

布雷特：建筑史，设计导论。[布雷特提供了他的理由所依据的具体实例。]

Brett: History of architecture, introduction to design. [Brett offers specific instances on which he based his reason.]

艾比：但是你必须重修的那门微积分课程呢？[ Abby 提出了一个与 Brett 的理由相矛盾的观点。]

Abby: But what about that calculus course you have to take again? [Abby offers a point that contradicts Brett’s reason.]

布雷特：我知道我上次不得不放弃它，但我找到了一位非常好的导师。【Brett认可Abby的反对并做出回应。]

Brett: I know I had to drop it last time, but I found a really good tutor. [Brett acknowledges Abby’s objection and responds to it.]

艾比：但是你不会选修五门课程吗？[艾比提出另一个保留意见。]

Abby: But won’t you be taking five courses? [Abby raises another reservation.]

布雷特：我知道。这并不容易。[布雷特承认了一个他无法反驳的观点。]

Brett: I know. It won’t be easy. [Brett concedes a point he cannot refute.]

艾比：你会提高你的 GPA 吗？[艾比询问布雷特观点的限度。]

Abby: Will you pull up your GPA? [Abby asks about the limits of Brett’s claim.]

布雷特：我应该。我希望 3.0，只要我不必找兼职工作。[布雷特限制了他的权利要求的范围并增加了一个条件。]

Brett: I should. I’m hoping for a 3.0, as long as I don’t have to get a part-time job. [Brett limits the scope of his claim and adds a condition.]

如果你能想象自己在那个对话中，你会发现组织一个研究论证并没有什么奇怪的。那是因为任何论点的五个要素只是对艾比问布雷特的各种问题的回答——而你必须代表你的读者问你自己：

If you can imagine yourself in that conversation, you’ll find nothing strange about assembling a research argument. That’s because the five elements of any argument are just answers to the kinds of questions Abby asks Brett—and that you must ask yourself on your reader’s behalf:

1. 主张：你想让我相信什么？你想说什么？

1. Claim: What do you want me to believe? What’s your point?

2. Reasons：为什么这么说？我为什么要同意？

2. Reasons: Why do you say that? Why should I agree?

3.证据：你怎么知道的？你能备份吗？

3. Evidence: How do you know? Can you back it up?

4. 确认和回应：但是呢。. . ？

4. Acknowledgment and Response: But what about . . . ?

5. Warrant：这是怎么回事？你的逻辑是什么？你能解释一下你的推理吗？

5. Warrant: How does that follow? What’s your logic? Can you explain your reasoning?

事实上，您可以将您的研究视为找出这些问题答案的过程。

In fact, you can think of your research as the process of figuring out answers to these questions.

7.2 支持您的观点

7.2 SUPPORTING YOUR CLAIM

每个研究论点的核心都是你的研究问题的答案，你的问题的解决方案——你的主要主张。您必须使用两种支持来支持该观点：原因和证据。

At the core of every research argument is the answer to your research question, the solution to your problem—your main claim. You have to back up that claim with two kinds of support: reasons and evidence.

7.2.1支持观点的理由

7.2.1 Support Claims with Reasons

第一种支持，即理由，是一种引导读者接受你的主张的陈述。我们经常将一个原因加入一个观点中，因为：

The first kind of support, a reason, is a statement that leads readers to accept your claim. We often join a reason to a claim with because:

小学应该把教授外语作为优先事项，因为我们在年轻的时候学得语言最好也最容易。原因

Elementary schools should make teaching foreign languages a priorityclaim because we acquire languages best and most easily when we are young.reason

澄清一些术语

Clarifying Some Terms

到目前为止，我们已经使用两个术语来命名总结您的研究结果的陈述。在问题的上下文中，我们称之为您的答案。在问题的上下文中，我们称之为您的解决方案。现在在争论的背景下，我们称它为你的主张。

So far, we’ve used two terms to name the statement that sums up the results of your research. In the context of questions, we called it your answer. In the context of problems, we called it your solution. Now in the context of an argument, we’ll call it your claim.

•观点是一种需要支持的断言（可以是一句话或多句）：气候变化正在威胁沿海城市；托妮·莫里森 (Toni Morrison) 最重要的小说是《宠儿》( Beloved)。你的主要主张是你的整个研究论证所支持的断言。有些人将此断言称为您的论文。

• A claim is an assertion (which can be a single sentence or more) that demands support: Climate change is threatening coastal cities; Toni Morrison’s most important novel is Beloved. Your main claim is the assertion your whole research argument supports. Some call this assertion your thesis.

•原因是支持观点的断言：[因为]气候变化导致海平面上升；[因为]在《宠儿》中，莫里森的主要主题得到了最充分的发展。

• A reason is an assertion that supports a claim: [Because] climate change is causing ocean levels to rise; [Because] in Beloved, Morrison’s major themes find their fullest development.

•证据是用来支持理由的数据。与主张或理由不同，证据并不总是被框定为断言：记录过去十年海平面上升的数据表或Beloved中说明莫里森主要主题的引文都是证据形式。

• Evidence is data deployed to support a reason. Unlike a claim or a reason, evidence is not always framed as an assertion: a data table documenting rising ocean levels over the past decade or quotations from Beloved illustrating Morrison’s major themes would be forms of evidence.

这些术语可能会造成混淆，因为一个原因也是一个可以由更多原因支持的从属观点，因为原因和证据都是一种支持。但如果您坚持使用我们，您就会明白为什么这些区别很重要。

These terms can be confusing, because a reason is also a subclaim that can be supported by more reasons and because both reasons and evidence are kinds of support. But if you stick with us, you’ll see why these distinctions are important.

你通常需要不止一个理由来支持一个主张，在一个复杂的论证中，你的理由本身通常需要进一步的支持：

You often need more than one reason to support a claim, and in a complex argument, your reasons themselves will usually require further support:

小学应该把教授外语作为优先事项1因为我们在年轻的时候学得语言最好也最容易。reason 1 supporting claim 1/claim 2事实上，那些从第二个开始的人成人的语言很少能达到儿童时期学习语言的人的流利程度。理由 2 支持理由 1 和主张 2/主张 3在小学阶段教授外语也有助于儿童的道德发展，理由 3 支持主张 1/主张 4，因为它培养了对超越自己的文化和社会的认识。理由 4 支持理由 3 和权利要求 4/权利要求 5。

Elementary schools should make teaching foreign languages a priorityclaim 1 because we acquire languages best and most easily when we are young.reason 1 supporting claim 1/claim 2 In fact, those who begin second languages as adults rarely attain the level of fluency of those who learn them as children.reason 2 supporting reason 1 and claim 2/claim 3 Teaching foreign languages at the elementary-school level also contributes to children’s ethical development,reason 3 supporting claim 1/claim 4 because it fosters an awareness of cultures and societies beyond their own.reason 4 supporting reason 3 and claim 4/claim 5.

7.2.2证据基础

7.2.2 Base Reasons on Evidence

第二种支持是你提出理由的证据。我们说过，更多的理由可以支持理由，但这些链条不会永远持续下去。最终你必须展示一些数据。那是你的证据。原因和证据之间的区别似乎只是语义问题，在某些情况下，这两个词似乎可以互换：

The second kind of support is the evidence on which you base your reasons. We’ve said that reasons can be supported by still more reasons, but these chains don’t go on forever. Eventually you have to show some data. That’s your evidence. This distinction between reasons and evidence can seem just a matter of semantics, and in some contexts the words do seem interchangeable:

您必须基于充分的理由提出观点。

You have to base your claim on good reasons.

你必须将你的主张建立在良好的证据之上。

You have to base your claim on good evidence.

但它们不是同义词，区分它们对于提出合理的论点至关重要。比较这两个句子：

But they are not synonyms, and distinguishing them is crucial in making sound arguments. Compare these two sentences:

你的理由基于什么证据？

What evidence do you base your reason on?

你的证据基于什么原因？

What reason do you base your evidence on?

第二句话似乎很奇怪：我们不根据原因提供证据；我们以证据为依据。

That second sentence seems odd: we don’t base evidence on reasons; we base reasons on evidence.

还有其他区别：

There are other differences:

• 我们用头脑想出理由。

• We use our minds to think up reasons.

• 我们必须在世界“外面”寻找证据，然后让每个人都能看到。

• We have to search for evidence “out there” in the world, then make it available for everyone to see.

问，我去哪里看你的理由是没有意义的？问，我去哪里看你的证据是有道理的？

It makes no sense to ask, Where do I go to see your reasons? It does make sense to ask, Where do I go to see your evidence?

在随意的谈话中，我们通常只用一个理由来支持一个主张：

In casual conversation, we usually support a claim with just a reason:

我们应该离开了。claim看起来像下雨。原因

We should leave.claim It looks like rain.reason

很少有人问，你有什么证据表明它看起来像下雨？但是当你解决严肃的问题时，读者希望你将每个理由都建立在证据的基础上，因为细心的读者不会接受表面价值的理由。他们要求你提供这些理由所依据的证据、数据和事实：

Few ask, What’s your evidence that it looks like rain? But when you address serious issues, readers expect you to base each reason on its own foundation of evidence, because careful readers don’t accept reasons at face value. They ask for the evidence, the data, the facts on which you base those reasons:

小学应该把教授外语作为优先事项1因为我们在年轻的时候学得语言最好也最容易。支持主张 1/主张 2 的理由 1事实上，那些从成人开始学习第二语言的人很少能达到儿童时期学习第二语言的人的流利程度。原因 2 支持原因 1/主张 3在一项针对一百多名第二语言学习者的研究中，Jones (2013) 发现第二语言熟练程度与 . . . （见表 1）。支持理由2的证据

Elementary schools should make teaching foreign languages a priorityclaim 1 because we acquire languages best and most easily when we are young.reason 1 supporting claim 1/claim 2 In fact, those who begin second languages as adults rarely attain the level of fluency of those who learn them as children.reason 2 supporting reason 1/claim 3 In a study of over one hundred second-language learners, Jones (2013) identified an inverse correlation between second-language proficiency and . . . (see table 1).evidence supporting reason 2

有了理由和证据，我们就有了研究论点的核心：

With reasons and evidence, we have the core of a research argument:

但在大多数情况下，仅有这个核心是不够的：你还必须通过承认和回应其他观点来充实你的研究论点，有时，通过提供证明理由与主张的相关性。

But in most cases, this core alone isn’t enough: you also have to flesh out your research argument by acknowledging and responding to other points of view and, sometimes, by offering warrants that show how a reason is relevant to a claim.

7.3 承认并回应预期的问题和异议

7.3 ACKNOWLEDGING AND RESPONDING TO ANTICIPATED QUESTIONS AND OBJECTIONS

细心的读者会质疑你论点的每一部分，所以你必须尽可能多地预料到他们的问题，然后承认并回答最重要的问题。例如，当读者考虑学校应该优先考虑外语教学的说法时，他们可能想知道这样做是否会影响其他科目的教学。如果您认为读者可能会问这个问题，您最好承认并做出回应：

Careful readers will question every part of your argument, so you must anticipate as many of their questions as you can, and then acknowledge and respond to the most important ones. For example, when readers consider the claim that schools should make foreign-language instruction a priority, they may wonder if doing that might detract from the teaching of other subjects. If you think readers might ask that question, you would be wise to acknowledge and respond to it:

小学应该优先考虑外语1因为我们在学习语言时最好也最容易年轻。原因 1 支持 claim 1/claim 2  。. . 当然，如果学校更加重视外语，其他科目的教学质量可能会下降。承认但几乎没有证据支持这种恐惧，而有很多证据可以消除它。. . . 回复

Elementary schools should make foreign languages a priorityclaim 1 because we acquire languages best and most easily when we are young.reason 1 supporting claim 1/claim 2 . . . Of course, if schools increase the attention they give to foreign languages, quality of instruction in other subjects might decline.acknowledgment But little evidence exists to support that fear and much dispels it. . . .response

然而，所有研究人员面临的挑战不仅仅是回应读者的问题、备选方案和反对意见，而是首先要想象它们。（我们将在第 10 章解决这个问题。）

The challenge all researchers face, however, is not just responding to readers’ questions, alternatives, and objections, but imagining them in the first place. (We’ll address that issue in chapter 10.)

由于没有致谢和回应，任何研究论证都是不完整的，我们将它们添加到图表中以显示它们与论证的所有其他部分的关系：

Since no research argument is complete without acknowledgments and responses, we add them to our diagram to show how they relate to all the other parts of an argument:

7.4 将观点和理由与保证联系起来

7.4 CONNECTING CLAIMS AND REASONS WITH WARRANTS

即使您的读者同意某个理由是真实的，他们仍可能反对它与您的主张无关。考虑这个论点：

Even when your readers agree that a reason is true, they may still object that it’s not relevant to your claim. Consider this argument:

我们在欧洲和北美面临着更高的医疗保健成本，因为气候变化正在将延长的硬冻线稳步向北移动。原因

We are facing significantly higher health care costs in Europe and North Americaclaim because climate change is moving the line of extended hard freezes steadily northward.reason

读者可能会接受这个原因的真实性，但质疑它与观点的相关性，并问：更高的健康成本与硬冷冻有什么关系？我没有看到连接。要回答，您必须提供一个一般原则来证明将您的特定原因与您的特定主张相关联：

Readers might accept the truth of that reason but question its relevance to the claim, asking: What do higher health costs have to do with hard freezes? I don’t see the connection. To answer, you must offer a general principle that justifies relating your particular reason to your particular claim:

当一个地区的严寒较少时，它必须支付更多费用来对抗不再被严寒杀死的亚热带昆虫携带的新疾病。

When an area has fewer hard freezes, it must pay more to combat new diseases carried by subtropical insects no longer killed by those freezes.

像所有认股权证一样，这个认股权证说如果存在一般情况（一个地区的硬冻较少），那么我们可以推断出一个一般后果（该地区将有更高的成本来对抗新疾病）。所有保证背后的逻辑是，如果概括是真实的或合理的，那么它的具体实例也必须如此。

Like all warrants, this one says that if a general circumstance exists (an area has fewer hard freezes), then we can infer a general consequence (that area will have higher costs to combat new diseases). The logic behind all warrants is that if a generalization is true or reasonable, then so must be specific instances of it.

但要使这种逻辑起作用，读者必须同意四件事。两个很容易理解：

But for that logic to work, readers must agree with four things. Two are easy to understand:

1. 保证书是真实的或合理的：更少的硬冻实际上意味着更高的医疗费用。

1. The warrant is true or reasonable: fewer hard freezes in fact mean higher medical costs.

2. 理由真实或合理：严寒实际上正在向北移动。

2. The reason is true or reasonable: hard freezes in fact are moving north.

接下来的两个更难：

The next two are more difficult:

3. 理由中的具体情况可以作为逮捕令中一般情况的合理实例。

3. The specific circumstance in the reason qualifies as a plausible instance of the general circumstance in the warrant.

4. 观点中的具体后果可以作为授权令中一般后果的合理实例。

4. The specific consequence in the claim qualifies as a plausible instance of the general consequence in the warrant.

我们可以这样说明这个逻辑：

We can illustrate that logic like this:

正如我们将要看到的，要决定什么时候需要搜查令并不容易。经验丰富的研究人员通常只在两种情况下陈述它们：当他们认为他们所在领域的读者可能会问一个原因如何与一个主张相关时，或者当他们向普通读者解释他们领域的推理方式时。如果您认为您的读者可能看不到观点和理由之间的联系，您必须添加保证来证明它：

As we’ll see, it’s not easy to decide when you even need a warrant. Experienced researchers usually state them on only two occasions: when they think readers in their fields might ask how a reason is relevant to a claim or when they are explaining their fields’ ways of reasoning to general readers. If you think your readers might not see the connection between a claim and reason, you must add a warrant to justify it:

当一个地区的严寒较少时，它可以预期更高的医疗费用来应对无法在冰冻中存活的亚热带昆虫携带的疾病。保证欧洲和北美因此必须预期更高的医疗保健成本是主要主张，因为气候变化正在将延长的硬冻结线稳步向北移动。原因在过去的一百年里，持续超过两周的严寒线以大约 .的速度向北移动。. . 证据

When an area has fewer hard freezes, it can expect higher medical costs to cope with diseases carried by subtropical insects that do not survive freezes.warrant Europe and North America must thus expect higher health care costsmain claim because climate change is moving the line of extended hard freezes steadily north.reason In the last one hundred years, the line of hard freezes lasting more than two weeks has moved north at the rate of roughly . . .evidence

我们可以在图表中添加保证，以表明它们将观点及其支持理由联系起来：

We can add warrants to our diagram to show that they connect a claim and its supporting reason:

（我们知道认股权证这个问题不容易理解；我们将在第 11 章中再次更详细地解释它。）

(We know this matter of warrants is not easy to grasp; we explain it again in more detail in chapter 11.)

7.5 从简单的论证中构建复杂的论证

7.5 BUILDING A COMPLEX ARGUMENT OUT OF SIMPLE ONES

这五个要素构成了一个“基本”论点，但研究论点更为复杂。

Those five elements constitute a “basic” argument, but research arguments are more complex.

• 我们几乎总是用两个或多个理由来支持一个主张，每个理由都必须有自己的额外理由和证据来支持，并且可能有自己的理由来证明。

• We almost always support a claim with two or more reasons, each of which must be supported by its own additional reasons and evidence and perhaps justified by its own warrant.

• 由于读者对任何复杂的论点都有很多选择和反对意见，因此细心的研究人员通常不得不对其中的一些做出回应。

• Since readers think of many alternatives and objections to any complex argument, careful researchers typically have to respond to a number of them.

此外，每个理由、保证或对异议的回应（所有这些都是陈述或断言）本身可能必须被处理作为从属观点并由其自己的论点支持。只有证据“独立”，但即便如此，您可能还必须解释您从哪里得到它、为什么您认为它是可靠的以及它如何支持您的理由——这可能还需要另一个论证。

Moreover, each reason, warrant, or response to an objection (all of which are statements or assertions) may itself have to be treated as a subclaim and supported by its own argument. Only the evidence “stands alone,” but even then you may have to explain where you got it, why you think it’s reliable, and how it supports your reason—and that may require yet another argument.

认知超载：一些令人安心的话

Cognitive Overload: Some Reassuring Words

正是在这一点上，许多刚接触研究的学生开始感到不知所措。如果是这样，那么你的焦虑与其说是与你的智力有关，不如说是与缺乏经验有关。我们中的一个人正在向法律写作老师解释作为新手如何让许多一年级法律学生觉得自己是无能的作家。谈话结束时，一位女士报告说，她曾是一名人类学教授，她发表的作品因文笔清晰而受到称赞。然后她转行去了法学院。她说，在头六个月里，她的写作语无伦次，以至于她担心自己患上了退行性脑病。当然，她不是：她正在经历我们大多数人都经历过的痛苦转变，当我们试图为我们更不了解的观众写一些我们不完全理解的事情时。

It’s at about this point that many students new to research begin to feel overwhelmed. If so, your anxieties have less to do with your intelligence than with inexperience. One of us was explaining to teachers of legal writing how being a novice makes many first-year law students feel like incompetent writers. At the end of the talk, one woman reported that she had been a professor of anthropology whose published work was praised for the clarity of her writing. Then she switched careers and went to law school. She said that during her first six months, she wrote so incoherently that she feared she was suffering from a degenerative brain disease. Of course, she was not: she was going through the painful transition most of us experience when we try to write about matters we do not entirely understand for an audience we understand even less. She was relieved to find that the better she understood the law, the better she wrote about it.

如果你感到不知所措，你可以从这个故事中得到安慰，就像一位给我们发电子邮件的读者一样：

If you feel overwhelmed, you can take comfort in that story, as did one reader who e-mailed us this:

在研究工艺中，你写了一个从人类学转向法律的女人，突然发现自己无法清晰地写作。当了五年的平面设计助理教授后，我最近转向人类学，突然发现写人类学论文就像拔牙一样。我心想我可能得了退化性脑病！当我读到有关转行法律的人类学家时，我大笑起来。这让我感觉好多了。

In Craft of Research you write about a woman who switched from anthropology to law and suddenly found herself unable to write clearly. After being an assistant professor of graphic design for five years, I recently switched to anthropology and suddenly found that writing anthropology papers is like pulling teeth. I thought to myself that I might have a degenerative brain disorder! I laughed out loud when I read about the anthropologist who switched to law. It made me feel a bit better.

最后，大多数论点还包括背景、定义、对读者可能不理解的问题的解释等。例如，如果你要向不熟悉经济理论的读者就通货膨胀和货币供应量之间的关系进行辩论，你就必须解释经济学家是如何理解这些概念的。严肃的论点是复杂的结构。（第 8 章到第 11 章详细解释了它们。）

And finally, most arguments also include background, definitions, explanations of issues that readers might not understand, and so on. If, for example, you were making an argument about the relationship between inflation and money supply to readers not familiar with economic theory, you would have to explain how economists understand those concepts. Serious arguments are complex constructions. (Chapters 8–11 explain them in detail.)

7.6 通过丰富你的论点来创造一种精神

7.6 CREATING AN ETHOS BY THICKENING YOUR ARGUMENT

读者不仅根据你提供的理由和证据来判断你的论点，还根据你对他们的问题和疑虑的预期和解决程度来判断。通过以这种方式“丰富”你的论点，你赢得了读者的信任，建立了传统上所谓的你的气质：你在论点中表现出来的性格。你看起来是那种会从各个方面考虑问题，用读者接受的证据来支持主张，并且深思熟虑地考虑其他观点的人吗？还是你看起来是一个只看到一种观点而对其他人的观点不屑一顾甚至无视的人？

Readers judge your arguments not just by the reasons and evidence you offer but also by how well you anticipate and address their questions and concerns. By “thickening” your argument in this way, you earn the confidence of your readers, building up what is traditionally called your ethos: the character you project in your argument. Do you seem to be the sort of person who considers issues from all sides, who supports claims with evidence that readers accept, and who thoughtfully considers other points of view? Or do you seem to be someone who sees only one point of view and dismisses or even ignores the views of others?

当您承认其他观点并在保证中解释您的推理原则时，您就给了读者充分的理由与您一起开发和测试新想法。从长远来看，你在个人论证中表现出的气质会强化你的声誉，这是每个研究人员都必须关心的事情，因为你的声誉是你撰写的每个论证中默认的第六要素。它回答了未说出口的问题，我可以信任你吗？这个答案必须是肯定的。

When you acknowledge other views and explain your principles of reasoning in warrants, you give readers good reason to work with you in developing and testing new ideas. In the long run, the ethos you project in individual arguments hardens into your reputation, something every researcher must care about, because your reputation is the tacit sixth element in every argument you write. It answers the unspoken question, Can I trust you? That answer must be Yes.

快速提示：一个常见的错误——回到你所知道的

Quick Tip: A Common Mistake—Falling Back on What You Know

如果您是一名缺乏经验的研究人员，您可能会过于依赖感觉熟悉的事物。例如，你可能过早地接受了一个主张，甚至可能在你做很多研究之前，因为你“知道”你可以证明它。但是退回到那种确定性只会让你无法做出最好的思考。作为一名研究人员意味着让自己对自己的发现和见解感到惊讶。因此，当您开始一个项目时，不要从您知道可以证明的主张开始，而要从您想要探索和解决的问题开始。

If you are an inexperienced researcher, you may be tempted to rely too heavily on what feels familiar. For example, you might embrace a claim too early, perhaps even before you have done much research, because you “know” you can prove it. But falling back on that kind of certainty will just keep you from doing your best thinking. Being a researcher means allowing yourself to be surprised by your discoveries and insights. So when you start a project, begin not with a claim you know you can prove but with a problem you want to explore and solve.

同样，当你刚接触一个领域时，你可能会倾向于依赖你从教育或经验中熟悉的争论方式。例如，如果你在文学课上学会了如何呈现和分析引文，不要以为你可以在强调“客观数据”的领域做同样的事情，比如生物学或实验心理学。另一方面，如果你作为生物学或心理学专业的学生学会了收集硬数据和进行统计分析，不要以为你可以在艺术史中做同样的事情。这并不意味着您在一堂课上学到的东西在另一堂课上毫无用处。所有领域都共享我们在此描述的参数元素。但是你必须了解一个领域处理这些元素的方式的独特之处，并且足够灵活以适应，相信你学到的技能。

Likewise, when you are new to a field, you may be tempted to rely on ways of arguing that are familiar to you from your education or experience. If, for example, you learned in a literature class how to present and analyze quotations, do not assume that you can do the same in fields that emphasize “objective data,” such as biology or experimental psychology. On the other hand, if as a biology or psychology major you learned to gather hard data and perform statistical analyses, do not assume that you can do the same in art history. This does not mean that what you learn in one class is useless in another. All fields share the elements of argument we describe here. But you have to learn what’s distinctive in the way a field handles those elements and be flexible enough to adapt, trusting the skills you’ve learned.

当您熟悉自己的领域时，您可能会想以不同的方式过度简化。当一些刚起步的研究人员成功地提出一种论点时，他们只是一遍又一遍地重复。他们对一种复杂性的掌握使他们对另一种复杂性视而不见：他们看不到他们的领域，如果它是一个活跃的领域，则以相互竞争的方法论、相互竞争的解决方案、相互竞争的目标和目的为标志。不要落入这个陷阱。如果您已经掌握了一种类型的论证，请尝试其他类型的论证：寻找替代方法，不仅制定多种解决方案，而且制定多种支持它们的方法，询问其他人是否会以不同的方式处理您的问题。

And when you become familiar with your field, you may be tempted to oversimplify in a different way. When some beginning researchers succeed at making one kind of argument, they just keep making it over and over. Their mastery of one kind of complexity blinds them to another: they fail to see that their field, if it is an active one, is marked by competing methodologies, competing solutions, competing goals and objectives. Don’t fall into this trap. If you’ve mastered one type of argument, try others: seek out alternative methods, formulate not only multiple solutions but multiple ways of supporting them, ask whether others would approach your problem differently.

当您不熟悉某个主题或领域时，您需要一些方法来管理新想法和新思维方式的复杂性。但要谨防不加批判地将熟悉的方法强加于新问题。随着您了解更多，您会认识到事情既不像您最初担心的那样复杂得让人眼花缭乱，也不像您当时希望的那样简单。

When you are new to a topic or a field, you need ways to manage the complexity of new ideas and new ways of thinking. But guard against uncritically imposing familiar methods on new problems. As you learn more, you’ll recognize that things are neither as blindingly complex as you first feared nor as simple as you then hoped.

8 提出观点

8  Making Claims

在本章中，我们将讨论如何识别能够回答您的研究问题的论点类型，以及如何判断您的论点是否足够具体和重要，足以作为论点的要点。

In this chapter, we discuss how to recognize the kind of claim that answers your research question and how to tell if your claim is specific and significant enough to serve as the main point of your argument.

您需要对您的研究问题有一个暂定的答案，以便将您的搜索重点放在将测试和支持其答案的证据上。当你测试它时，你可能会修改它，但当你整理你的论点时，你必须理解你所提出的主张的种类。您还必须确保您的主张不仅合理，而且重要到需要首先进行论证。问自己三个问题：

You need a tentative answer to your research question to focus your search for evidence that will test and support its answer. As you test it, you will likely revise it, but as you assemble your argument, you must understand the kind of claim you are making. You must also be sure that your claim is not just sound, but significant enough to need an argument in the first place. Ask yourself three questions:

1. 我应该提出什么样的观点？

1. What kind of claim should I make?

2、够具体吗？

2. Is it specific enough?

3. 我的读者会认为它足够重要以至于需要一个论据来支持它吗？

3. Will my readers think it is significant enough to need an argument supporting it?

当你能回答这三个问题时，你就可以准备好你的论点了。

When you can answer those three questions, you’re ready to assemble your argument.

8.1 确定您应该提出的观点类型

8.1 DETERMINING THE KIND OF CLAIM YOU SHOULD MAKE

你提出的问题类型决定了你提出的主张类型以及你需要支持它的论据类型。正如我们在第 4 章中看到的，学术研究人员通常提出的不是实际问题，而是概念性问题，其解决方案要求读者不要采取行动，而是要理解：

The kind of problem you pose determines the kind of claim you make and the kind of argument you need to support it. As we saw in chapter 4, academic researchers usually pose not practical problems but conceptual ones, the kind whose solution asks readers not to act but to understand:

2008-2011 年的大衰退主要是由于疏忽的金融监管导致银行承担过多风险。

The Great Recession of 2008–2011 was caused largely by negligent financial regulation that let banks take on too much risk.

8.1.1做出概念性观点

8.1.1 Making Conceptual Claims

除了区分实际主张和概念主张之外，认识到主张解决了一系列问题也很有用：事物或情况是否存在？如果是这样，我们应该如何表征它？它是怎么变成这样的？是好还是坏？对此可以或应该做些什么？根据观点中隐含的一个或多个问题，将需要不同种类的证据来支持它。您对某个主题所做的观点将属于以下一类（或多类）：

Beyond distinguishing between practical and conceptual claims, it is useful to recognize that claims address a range of questions: Does a thing or a situation exist? If so, how should we characterize it? How did it get this way? Is it good or bad? What can or should be done about it? Depending on the question or questions implicit in a claim, different kinds of evidence will be required to support it. The claims you make on a topic will fall into one (or more) of the following classes:

• 事实或存在的观点：

• Claims of fact or existence:

在过去十年中，全球平均气温上升到前所未有的水平。

Average global temperatures have risen to unprecedented levels within the past decade.

• 定义和分类观点：

• Claims of definition and classification:

鸟类，而不是爬行动物，是恐龙的直系后裔。

Birds, not reptiles, are the direct descendants of dinosaurs.

• 因果观点：

• Claims of cause and consequence:

接触石棉是导致肺癌的主要原因。

Exposure to asbestos is a leading contributor to lung cancer.

• 评估或估价观点：

• Claims of evaluation or appraisal:

莎士比亚最伟大的喜剧是《皆大欢喜》。

Shakespeare’s greatest comedy is As You Like It.

• 行动或政策观点：

• Claims of action or policy:

宾夕法尼亚州应该提高天然气钻探的开采费以资助教育。

Pennsylvania should increase extraction fees on natural gas drilling to fund education.

前四类——事实、定义、原因和价值——涉及概念性主张。对于事实或存在的主张，您必须提供证据证明情况确实如您描述的那样。定义或分类的观点取决于对相似点或不同点的推理，这些相似点或不同点将一个实体分配到更广泛的类别或将其与其他实体区分开来。评估或评估的有效主张取决于判断标准，以证明为什么某事是好的或坏的（或比其他事物更好或更坏）。最后，因果关系的主张将一系列事实联系起来，以表明某些情况确实（或不）遵循或导致另一种情况。

The first four classes—fact, definition, cause, and value—concern conceptual claims. For claims of fact or existence, you must provide evidence that a situation is, in fact, as you characterize it. Claims of definition or classification depend on reasoning about similarities or differences that assigns an entity to some broader class or distinguishes it from other entities. Effective claims of evaluation or appraisal depend on criteria of judgment to justify why something is good or bad (or better or worse than something else). Finally, claims of cause or consequence connect sets of facts to show that some situation does (or doesn’t) follow from or lead to another.

8.1.2提出实际要求

8.1.2 Making Practical Claims

实际主张是支持（或反对）某些行动或政策的主张。它通常由一系列概念性主张构成：一个证明存在问题，另一个表明问题的原因，还有一个解释如何按照你的建议去做来解决问题。读者可能还希望您解释以下内容：

A practical claim is one that argues for (or against) some action or policy. It is usually built from a chain of conceptual claims: one that demonstrates that a problem exists, another that shows what causes the problem, and still another that explains how doing what you propose will fix it. Readers may also expect you to explain the following:

• 为什么你的解决方案是可行的；如何在合理的时间和精力下实施。

• Why your solution is feasible; how it can be implemented with reasonable time and effort.

• 为什么实施成本低于问题成本。

• Why it will cost less to implement than the cost of the problem.

• 为什么它不会产生比它解决的问题更大的问题。

• Why it will not create a bigger problem than the one it solves.

• 为什么它比替代解决方案更便宜或更快——这种说法通常很难得到支持。

• Why it is cheaper or faster than alternative solutions—a claim often difficult to support.

如果你提出一个实际的主张但不提出这四个子论点，你的读者可能会拒绝你的整个论点。

If you advance a practical claim but don’t make those four sub-arguments, your readers may reject your whole argument.

因此，当你整理你的论点时，要清楚你所提出的主张的种类，无论是概念上的还是实践上的。不要通过强调实际行动来夸大概念主张的重要性，至少不要在论文的早期。如果你想建议你的概念主张的实际应用，请在你的结论中这样做。在那里，你可以将它作为一个值得考虑的行动来提供，而不必为它开发一个案例（我们将在第 16 章中回到这一点）。

So as you assemble your argument, be clear about the kinds of claims you are making, whether conceptual or practical. Don’t inflate the importance of a conceptual claim by tacking on a practical action, at least not early in your paper. If you want to suggest a practical application of your conceptual claim, do so in your conclusion. There, you can offer it as an action worth considering without having to develop a case for it (we return to this in chapter 16).

8.2 评估您的观点

8.2 EVALUATING YOUR CLAIM

我们无法告诉您如何找到好的观点，但我们可以向您展示如何从读者的角度评估您的观点。最重要的是，他们希望您的观点既具体又重要。

We can’t tell you how to find a good claim, but we can show you how to evaluate the one you have from the point of view of your readers. Above all, they expect your claim to be both specific and significant.

8.2.1使您的观点具体化

8.2.1 Make Your Claim Specific

模糊的主张导致模糊的争论。你的主张越具体，就越能帮助你计划你的论点并让你的读者在阅读时保持正轨。您通过精确的语言和明确的逻辑使观点更加具体。

Vague claims lead to vague arguments. The more specific your claim, the more it helps you plan your argument and keep your readers on track as they read it. You make a claim more specific through precise language and explicit logic.

精确的语言。比较这两个观点：

Precise Language. Compare these two claims:

电视夸大了对犯罪率的估计。

TV inflates estimates of crime rates.

当地电视新闻中对暴力的生动报道导致普通观众高估了他们社区的犯罪率以及他们自己和家人面临的人身危险高达 150%。

Graphic reports of violence on local TV news lead regular viewers to overestimate by as much as 150 percent both the rate of crime in their neighborhood and the personal danger to themselves and their families.

第一个说法非常含糊，以至于我们对接下来会发生什么一无所知。第二个有更具体的概念，不仅可以帮助读者更清楚地理解该主张，还可以为作者提供一组更丰富的概念，以便在下文中展开。事实上，观点的精确性表明了论证可能如何进行。

The first claim is so vague that we have little idea about what’s to come. The second has more specific concepts that not only help readers understand the claim more clearly, but also give the writer a richer set of concepts to develop in what follows. Indeed, the precision of the claim signals how the argument is likely to proceed.

我们不建议为了自己的利益而冗长、冗长的观点。但是，当您在观点的早期版本中包含比您最终可能使用的更多的条款时，您会受益。最后的观点应该只根据你的读者需要的那样具体，并且应该只包括你在你的论点中作为主题发展的那些概念。

We do not recommend long, wordy claims for their own sake. But you benefit when you include in early versions of your claim more terms than you might ultimately use. That final claim should be only as specific as your readers need and should include only those concepts that you develop as themes in your argument.

明确的逻辑。您也可以明确观点的逻辑。即使使用相对精确的语言，该主张也仅提供了一个命题：

Explicit Logic. You can also be explicit in the logic of your claim. Even with its relatively precise language, this claim offers only a single proposition:

经常看电视的人高估了他们社区的犯罪率以及对他们自己和家人的人身危险。

Regular TV viewers overestimate both the rate of crime in their neighborhood and the personal danger to themselves and their families.

在自然科学和社会科学中，这样的主张很常见，甚至更受欢迎。但在人文学科中，这样的说法似乎有点单薄。当你起草你的工作主张时，尝试用两种方式阐述它的逻辑：

In the natural and social sciences, claims like that are common, even preferred. But in the humanities, such a claim might seem a bit thin. As you draft your working claim, try elaborating its logic in two ways:

• 引入一个以although或even though开头的限定子句。

• Introduce it with a qualifying clause beginning with although or even though.

• 用以because 开头的原因从句结束。

• Conclude it with a reason-clause beginning with because.

例如：

For example:

尽管暴力犯罪实际上在减少，但普通的电视观众高估了他们所在社区的犯罪率 150%，因此错误判断对自己和家人的人身危险，因为当地电视晚间新闻经常以图形报道熟悉地点的混乱和谋杀，这让许多人相信犯罪每晚都发生在他们的前门外。

Although violent crime is actually decreasing, regular TV viewers overestimate their neighborhood crime rate by 150 percent and therefore misjudge personal danger to themselves and their families because local TV evening news regularly opens with graphic reports of mayhem and murder in familiar locations, making many believe that crime happens nightly outside their front door.

虽然该观点似乎被覆盖了，但它预示了完整论证所需的五个要素中的三个：（1）虽然我承认 X，（2）我主张 Y（3）是因为理由 Z。

While that claim may seem overwritten, it foreshadows three of the five elements that you need for a full argument: (1) Although I acknowledge X, (2) I claim Y (3) because of reason Z.

您可以使用介绍性的虽然子句来承认三种不同的观点：

You can use an introductory although clause to acknowledge three kinds of alternative views:

• 您的读者相信但您的观点质疑的东西：

• Something that your readers believe but your claim challenges:

尽管大多数人认为他们能很好地判断自己的安全性，但普通的电视观众却高估了。. .

Although most people believe they are good judges of their security, regular TV viewers overestimate . . .

• 与您的观点相冲突的观点：

• A point of view that conflicts with yours:

尽管许多安全专家将恐惧视为采取安全预防措施的最佳动机，但普通电视观众却高估了。. .

Although many security professionals see fear as the best motivation for safety precautions, regular TV viewers overestimate . . .

• 限制您的观点范围或信心的条件：

• A condition that limits the scope or confidence of your claim:

虽然很难衡量他们对人身安全的真实感受，但普通电视观众高估了。. .

Although it is difficult to gauge their real feelings about personal security, regular TV viewers overestimate . . .

如果读者可能会想到这些资格，请先承认它们。你不仅暗示你理解他们的观点，而且承诺在你的论证过程中回应他们。

If readers might think of those qualifications, acknowledge them first. You not only imply that you understand their views, but commit yourself to responding to them in the course of your argument.

当你添加一个最终的因为子句时，你预测了一些支持你的主张的原因：

When you add a final because clause, you forecast some of the reasons that support your claim:

尽管许多人认为校服有助于降低公立学校的暴力事件发生率，但证据充其量只是微弱的证据，因为研究 人员没有控制与校服原因 1同时制定的其他措施， 而且报告的数据是统计怀疑。原因2

Although many believe that school uniforms help lower the incidence of violence in public schools,qualification the evidence is at best weakclaim because researchers have not controlled for other measures that have been instituted at the same time as uniformsreason 1 and because the data reported are statistically suspect.reason 2

同样，我们不建议您的最终草案提供像这些一样臃肿的观点。但是你的工作主张越丰富，你的论点就越令人满意。

Again, we don’t suggest that your final draft should offer a claim as bloated as these. But the richer your working claim, the more satisfying your argument is likely to be.

8.2.2让你的观点有意义

8.2.2 Make Your Claim Significant

在一个观点的特殊性之后，读者最仔细地关注它的重要性，他们衡量的质量是它要求他们改变他们的想法的程度。虽然我们无法量化重要性，但我们可以粗略估计：如果读者接受一个主张，他们必须改变多少其他信念？最重要的主张要求研究团体改变其最深的信念（并且它将相应地抵制此类主张）。

After the specificity of a claim, readers look most closely at its significance, a quality they measure by how much it asks them to change what they think. While we can’t quantify significance, we can roughly estimate it: if readers accept a claim, how many other beliefs must they change? The most significant claims ask a research community to change its deepest beliefs (and it will resist such claims accordingly).

如果某些研究团体只要求他们接受关于共同感兴趣的主题的新证据，那么一些研究团体认为该主张足够重要：

Some research communities consider a claim significant enough if it asks them only to accept new evidence on a topic of common interest:

我在这里描述了 6 种 13 世纪的威尔士语拉丁语法。最近才发现，这些语法是同类中唯一的例子。它们帮助我们更好地理解中世纪时期编写的语法范围。

I describe here six thirteenth-century Latin grammars of the Welsh language. Found just recently, these grammars are the only examples of their kind. They help us better appreciate the range of grammars written in the medieval period.

（回想一下 2.3.3 中那些新发现的胶卷。）

(Recall those reels of newly discovered film in 2.3.3.)

当研究不仅提供新数据而且使用这些数据来解决看似令人费解、不一致或有其他问题的问题时，读者会更加重视研究：

Readers value research more highly when it not only offers new data but uses those data to settle what seems puzzling, inconsistent, or otherwise problematic:

关于消费者信心波动如何影响股市的争论由来已久，但新的统计工具表明两者之间关系不大。. .

There has been a long debate about how fluctuations in consumer confidence affect the stock market, but new statistical tools suggest little relationship between . . .

但是，当新的事实或猜想打破似乎早已确定的事实时，读者最看重的是：

But readers value most highly when new facts or conjectures upset what seems long settled:

长期以来，现代物理学一直坚信光速在任何地方、任何时间、任何条件下都是恒定的，但新数据表明它可能并非如此。

It has long been an article of faith in modern physics that the speed of light is constant everywhere at all times, under all conditions, but new data suggest it might not be.

像这样的说法会受到大批物理学家的质疑，因为如果属实，这将意味着物理学家不仅要改变对光速的看法，还要改变许多其他事情的看法。

A claim like that would be contested by legions of physicists because if true, it would mean that physicists would have to change their minds not just about the speed of light but about lots of other things as well.

在你职业生涯的早期，你不会被期望知道一个领域的人认为应该（甚至可以）修改什么。但你仍然可以通过询问读者对它的反对程度来衡量你的主张的重要性。一种方法是考虑相反的主张：

Early in your career, you won’t be expected to know what those in a field think should (or even could) be revised. But you can still gauge the significance of your claim by asking how strongly readers might contest it. One way to do that is by considering opposite claims:

哈姆雷特不是一个肤浅的人物。

Hamlet is not a superficial character.

这份报告总结了最近关于蜜蜂消失的研究。

This report summarizes recent research on the disappearance of bees.

要评估任一主张在多大程度上值得争论，请将肯定的主张更改为否定的主张，反之亦然：

To assess how much either claim is worth contesting, change an affirmative claim into a negative one and vice versa:

哈姆雷特是一个肤浅的人物。

Hamlet is a superficial character.

这份报告没有总结最近关于蜜蜂消失的研究。

This report does not summarize recent research on the disappearance of bees.

如果观点的反面看起来明显错误（如第一个）或微不足道（如第二个），那么读者可能会认为原始观点不值得争论。（当然，一些伟大的思想家已经成功地反驳了明显不言自明的主张，就像哥白尼所做的那样，他愚蠢地断言——或者在当时看来是这样——太阳不会绕地球转。）

If the reverse of a claim seems obviously false (like the first one) or trivial (like the second), then readers are likely to think the original claim is not worth an argument. (Of course, some great thinkers have successfully contradicted apparently self-evident claims, as Copernicus did when he asserted foolishly—or so it seemed at the time—that the sun does not go around the earth.)

如果你是一名高级研究人员，你可以通过它改变你的社区的想法和它的研究方式来衡量你的主张的重要性。很少有发现像克里克和沃森的 DNA 结构一样重要。它不仅让生物学家以不同的方式思考遗传学，而且开辟了新的研究方向。

If you are an advanced researcher, you measure the significance of your claim by how much it changes what your community thinks and how it does its research. Few discoveries have been as significant as Crick and Watson’s structure of DNA. Not only did it make biologists think about genetics differently, but it opened up new lines of research.

但是您不必大声疾呼才能做出有用的贡献：小的发现可以开辟新的思路。例如，如果您发现亚伯拉罕·林肯读过一些鲜为人知的哲学家，历史学家就会梳理林肯的文本以寻找这种影响的痕迹。

But you don’t have to make big claims to make a useful contribution: small findings can open up new lines of thinking. If, for example, you discovered that Abraham Lincoln read some obscure philosopher, historians would comb Lincoln’s texts for traces of that influence.

如果你刚接触研究，当然，你的主张不必挑战专家，给你的老师留下深刻印象即可。如果您无法预测它是否会发生，请将您的读者想象成和您一样的人。在开始研究之前，您是怎么想的？你的主张在多大程度上改变了你现在的想法？您现在了解哪些以前不了解的内容？这是为读者准备的最佳方式有一天会问你任何研究人员可能面临的最具破坏性的问题：我为什么要相信这个？但我为什么要关心呢？

If you are new to research, of course, your claim doesn’t have to challenge the experts, just impress your teacher. If you can’t predict whether it will, imagine your reader is someone like yourself. What did you think before you began your research? How much has your claim changed what you now think? What do you understand now that you didn’t before? That’s the best way to prepare for readers who will someday ask you the most devastating question any researcher can face: not Why should I believe this? but Why should I care?

8.3 提高可信度的合格观点

8.3 QUALIFYING CLAIMS TO ENHANCE YOUR CREDIBILITY

一些新的研究人员认为，当他们的主张被最有力地陈述时，他们的主张是最可信的。但没有什么比傲慢的确定性更能损害你的气质。尽管看起来很矛盾，但通过谦虚地承认论点的局限性，您可以使论点更有力、更可信。当您承认并回应他们的观点时，您就赢得了读者的信任，这表明您不仅理解而且考虑了他们的立场（更多信息，请参见第 10 章）。但是，如果您随后做出过分的观点，您可能会失去这种信任。通过限定范围和确定性，将你的主张限制在你的论点可以实际支持的范围内。

Some new researchers think their claims are most credible when they are stated most forcefully. But nothing damages your ethos more than arrogant certainty. As paradoxical as it seems, you make your argument stronger and more credible by modestly acknowledging its limits. You gain the trust of your readers when you acknowledge and respond to their views, showing that you have not only understood but considered their position (for more, see chapter 10). But you can lose that trust if you then make claims that overreach. Limit your claims to what your argument can actually support by qualifying their scope and certainty.

8.3.1确认限制条件

8.3.1 Acknowledge Limiting Conditions

每项观点都有限制条件：

Every claim has limiting conditions:

假设仪器经过精确校准，我们得出结论认为地震的震中位于东京西南 50 英里处。

We conclude that the epicenter of the earthquake was fifty miles southwest of Tokyo, assuming the instrumentation was accurately calibrated.

我们认为，除非新的全球冲突增加军费开支，否则航空制造业将无法达到 20 世纪后期的水平。

We believe that aviation manufacturing will not match its late twentieth-century levels, unless new global conflicts increase military spending.

但每项观点都受制于无数条件，因此请仅提及读者可能合理想到的条件。科学家们很少承认他们的主张取决于他们仪器的准确性，因为每个人都希望他们能够确保他们是。但经济学家通常承认他们的主张存在局限性，这既是因为他们的预测会受到不断变化的条件的影响，也是因为读者想知道需要关注哪些条件。

But every claim is subject to countless conditions, so mention only those that readers might plausibly think of. Scientists rarely acknowledge that their claims depend on the accuracy of their instruments, because everyone expects them to ensure that they are. But economists often acknowledge limits on their claims, both because their predictions are subject to changing conditions and because readers want to know which conditions to watch for.

考虑提及重要的限制条件，即使您认为读者不会想到它们。例如，在下一个示例中，作者不仅表明她很谨慎，而且对观点进行了更全面、更准确的陈述：

Consider mentioning important limiting conditions even if you feel readers would not think of them. For example, in this next example, the writer not only shows that she was careful but gives a fuller and more accurate statement of the claim:

今天，富兰克林·罗斯福 (Franklin D. Roosevelt) 被尊为我们最受尊敬的历史人物之一，但在他的第二个任期即将结束时，他非常不受欢迎，至少在美国社会的某些阶层中是这样。例如，报纸攻击他提倡社会主义，这是现代政府陷入困境的迹象。1938 年，70% 的中西部报纸指责他希望政府管理银行系统。. . . 有些人持不同意见，包括 Nicholson (1983, 1992) 和 Wiggins (1973)，他们都提供了轶事报道，罗斯福一直受到高度重视，承认，但这些报道仅得到那些有兴趣神化的人的记忆的支持罗斯福。回应 除非能够证明批评罗斯福的报纸受到特殊利益集团的控制，否则限制观点他们的攻击表明了民众对罗斯福总统任期的强烈不满。申索重述

Today Franklin D. Roosevelt is revered as one of our most admired historical figures, but toward the end of his second term, he was quite unpopular, at least among certain segments of American society.claim Newspapers, for example, attacked him for promoting socialism, a sign that a modern administration is in trouble. In 1938, 70 percent of Midwest newspapers accused him of wanting the government to manage the banking system. . . . Some have argued otherwise, including Nicholson (1983, 1992) and Wiggins (1973), both of whom offer anecdotal reports that Roosevelt was always in high regard,acknowledgment but these reports are supported only by the memories of those who had an interest in deifying FDR.response Unless it can be shown that the newspapers critical of Roosevelt were controlled by special interests,limitation on claim their attacks demonstrate significant popular dissatisfaction with Roosevelt’s presidency.restatement of claim

8.3.2使用套期保值来限制确定性

8.3.2 Use Hedges to Limit Certainty

我们很少能凭良心说我们 100% 肯定我们的主张是绝对真实的。细心的作家用称为对冲的词和短语来限定他们的确定性。例如，如果有人有权自信的话，那就是 DNA 螺旋结构的发现者克里克和沃森。但是当他们宣布他们的发现时，他们对他们的主张的确定性进行了对冲（对冲是粗体的；介绍是浓缩的）：

Only rarely can we state in good conscience that we are 100 percent certain that our claims are unqualifiedly true. Careful writers qualify their certainty with words and phrases called hedges. For example, if anyone was entitled to be assertive, it was Crick and Watson, the discoverers of the helical structure of DNA. But when they announced their discovery, they hedged the certainty of their claims (hedges are boldfaced; the introduction is condensed):

我们希望为脱氧核糖核酸 (DNA) 的盐提出[注意：未说明] 结构。. . . Pauling 和 Corey 已经提出了核酸的结构。. . . 我们认为，这种结构不令人满意，原因有二：(1)我们认为给出 X 射线图的物质是盐，而不是游离酸。. . . (2)一些范德瓦尔斯距离看起来太小了。（JD Watson 和 FHC Crick，“核酸的分子结构”）

We wish to suggest a [note: not state the] structure for the salt of deoxyribose nucleic acid (D.N.A.). . . . A structure for nucleic acid has already been proposed by Pauling and Corey. . . . In our opinion, this structure is unsatisfactory for two reasons: (1) We believe that the material which gives the X-ray diagrams is the salt, not the free acid. . . . (2) Some of the van der Waals distances appear to be too small. (J. D. Watson and F. H. C. Crick, “Molecular Structure of Nucleic Acids”)

没有对冲，克里克和沃森会更简洁但更激进。比较那个谨慎的段落和这个更有力的版本（很多激进的语气来自缺乏资格）：

Without the hedges, Crick and Watson would be more concise but more aggressive. Compare that cautious passage with this more forceful version (much of the aggressive tone comes from the lack of qualification):

我们在此公布脱氧核糖核酸 (DNA) 盐的结构。. . . 核酸的结构已经被提出鲍林和科里。. . . 它们的结构不令人满意有两个原因：(1)给出它们的X-射线图的材料是盐，而不是游离酸。. . . (2) 它们的范德瓦尔斯距离太小。

We announce here the structure for the salt of deoxyribose nucleic acid (D.N.A.). . . . A structure for nucleic acid has already been proposed by Pauling and Corey. . . . Their structure is unsatisfactory for two reasons: (1) The material which gives their X-ray diagrams is the salt, not the free acid. . . . (2) Their van der Waals distances are too small.

当然，如果你对冲太多，你会显得胆小或不确定。但在大多数领域，读者不信任用诸如all、no one、every、always、never等词语表达的措手不及的确定性。一些老师说他们反对所有的对冲，但他们中的大多数人真正拒绝的是对每一个微不足道的主张进行限定的对冲。有些领域确实比其他领域使用更少的对冲。这需要灵巧的触摸。对冲太多，你会显得口齿不清；对冲太少，你会显得过于自信。不幸的是，两者之间的界限很细。因此，请观察您所在领域的人如何管理不确定性并照此去做。

Of course, if you hedge too much, you will seem timid or uncertain. But in most fields, readers distrust flatfooted certainty expressed in words like all, no one, every, always, never, and so on. Some teachers say they object to all hedging, but what most of them really reject are hedges that qualify every trivial claim. And some fields do tend to use fewer hedges than others. It takes a deft touch. Hedge too much and you seem mealy-mouthed; hedge too little and you can seem overconfident. Unfortunately, the line between the two is thin. So watch how those in your field manage uncertainty and do likewise.

9 收集理由和证据

9  Assembling Reasons and Evidence

在本章中，我们将讨论两种对主张的支持：理由和证据。我们向您展示如何区分两者，如何使用理由来组织您的论点，以及如何评估证据的质量。

In this chapter, we discuss two kinds of support for a claim: reasons and evidence. We show you how to distinguish between the two, how to use reasons to organize your argument, and how to evaluate the quality of your evidence.

读者首先寻找论点的核心、主张及其支持。他们特别关注判断其合理性的一系列理由，以及判断其逻辑的顺序。如果他们认为这些理由有道理，他们就会查看你提供的证据，这是每一个论点的基石。如果他们不相信证据，他们会拒绝理由，并拒绝接受您的主张。

Readers look first for the core of an argument, a claim and its support. They look particularly at its set of reasons to judge its plausibility and their order to judge its logic. If they think those reasons make sense, they will look at the evidence you present, the bedrock of every argument. If they don’t believe the evidence, they’ll reject the reasons and, with them, your claim.

因此，当你整理你的论点时，你必须根据他们会接受的证据，以清晰、合乎逻辑的顺序向读者提供一套合理的理由。本章将向您展示如何做到这一点。

So as you assemble your argument, you must offer readers a plausible set of reasons, in a clear, logical order, based on evidence they will accept. This chapter shows you how to do that.

9.1 用理由来计划你的论点

9.1 USING REASONS TO PLAN YOUR ARGUMENT

当你整理你的理由时，你就为你的论点建立了一个逻辑结构。要测试该结构，您可以制作传统的大纲或以其他方式可视化您的计划。您可能会发现创建称为“故事板”的类似图表的大纲很有用。要开始制作故事板，请在单独的索引卡或页面的顶部写下您的主要主张和每个原因（和子原因）。然后在每个原因（或子原因）下方，列出支持它的证据。如果您还没有证据，请记下您需要的证据类型。最后，将页面或索引卡排列在桌子或墙上，使它们的逻辑关系一目了然。

When you order your reasons, you build a logical structure for your argument. To test that structure, you can make a traditional outline or visualize your plan in other ways. You might find it useful to create a chart-like outline known as a “storyboard.” To start a storyboard, write your main claim and each reason (and subreasons) at the top of separate index cards or pages. Then below each reason (or subreason), list the evidence that supports it. If you don’t have the evidence yet, note the kind of evidence you’ll need. Finally, arrange the pages or index cards on a table or wall to make their logical relationships visible at a glance.

只阅读原因，而不是细节，看看这个顺序是否有意义。如果没有，请尝试不同的顺序，直到成功为止。在这一点上，你只是在概述你的论点，而不是你的论文。当你转向初稿时，你将根据你的读者（和你的）的理解重新考虑你的理由，并可能安排一个新的顺序（关于订购部件的更多信息，请参见 12.1.3）。

Read just the reasons, not the details, to see if that order makes sense. If it doesn’t, try out different orders until it does. At this point, you are outlining only your argument, not your paper. When you turn to a first draft, you will reconsider your reasons in light of your readers’ understanding (and yours) and perhaps arrange a new order (for more on ordering parts, see 12.1.3).

9.2 区分证据和原因

9.2 DISTINGUISHING EVIDENCE FROM REASONS

一旦你以合理的顺序排列了你的理由，请确保你有足够的证据来支持每一个理由。读者不会接受一个理由，除非他们看到一个理由植根于他们认为是既定事实的基石。问题是，你不能决定那个；你的读者做。要算作证据，陈述必须报告读者同意不质疑的内容，至少为了论证的目的。但如果他们真的质疑它，你认为确凿的事实证据对他们来说只是一个理由，你还没有达到你的论点必须依赖的证据基础。

Once you’ve arranged your reasons in a plausible order, be sure you have sufficient evidence to support each one. Readers will not accept a reason until they see it anchored in what they consider to be a bedrock of established fact. The problem is, you don’t get to decide that; your readers do. To count as evidence, a statement must report something that readers agree not to question, at least for the purposes of the argument. But if they do question it, what you think is hard factual evidence is for them only a reason, and you have not yet reached that bedrock of evidence on which your argument must rest.

考虑这个论点：

Consider this argument:

美国高等教育必须遏制不断上涨的学费，因为大学学费正在成为实现美国梦的障碍。原因 如今，大多数学生离开大学时都背负着沉重的债务负担。证据

American higher education must curb escalating tuition costs,claim because the price of college is becoming an impediment to realizing the American dream.reason Today a majority of students leave college with a crushing debt burden.evidence

在最后一句话中，作者提供了她认为是一个“事实”，足以作为支持她的理由的证据。

In that last sentence, the writer offers what she believes is a “fact” hard enough to serve as evidence to support her reason.

但是持怀疑态度的读者可能会问，这只是一个概括。你有什么硬数据来支持“大多数学生”或“沉重的债务负担”？这样的读者不会将该陈述视为无可置疑的事实，而是将其视为仍然需要确凿证据的软理由。作者必须添加如下内容：

But a skeptical reader might ask, That’s just a generalization. What hard numbers do you have to back up “a majority of students” or “crushing debt burden”? Such a reader treats that statement not as an unquestioned fact but as a soft reason still in need of hard evidence. The writer would have to add something like this:

2013 年，近 70% 的学生借钱上大学，平均贷款额为 30,000 美元，这笔债务使许多人无法买房、组建家庭或攻读更高学位。证据

In 2013, nearly 70 percent of students borrowed money for college with loans averaging $30,000, a debt that prevents many from buying a home, beginning a family, or pursuing a higher degree.evidence

当然，真正持怀疑态度的读者可能会再次问，是什么支持这些数字？是什么证明这种情况是一场危机？如果是这样，作者将不得不提供更严格的数据，分解这些数字以记录债务对应届毕业生的影响。如果她自己做研究，她可以展示她的原始数据。如果她在二手资料中找到了她的数据，她可以引用它，但她可能会被要求证明她的资料来源是可靠的。真正持怀疑态度的读者永远不会放弃。

Of course a really skeptical reader could again ask, What backs up those numbers? What justifies the claim that this situation is a crisis? If so, the writer would have to provide still harder data, breaking down those numbers to document the consequences of debt for recent graduates. If she did her own research, she could show her raw data. If she found her data in a secondary source, she could cite it, but she might then be asked to prove that her source is reliable. Really skeptical readers just never give up.

如果你能想象读者振振有词地问，不是一次而是很多次，你怎么知道的？什么事实证明它是真的？, 你还没有达到读者想要的——无可争议证据的基石。在所谓的专家迅速告诉我们的时候根据我们从未见过数据的研究做什么和思考什么，细心的读者已经学会怀疑地查看证据报告。即使您认为自己有充分的证据，也要清楚它是如何收集的以及由谁收集的。如果它是由其他人收集的，请找到并引用尽可能接近证据的来源。

If you can imagine readers plausibly asking, not once but many times, How do you know that? What facts make it true?, you have not yet reached what readers want—a bedrock of uncontested evidence. And at a time when so-called experts are quick to tell us what to do and think based on studies whose data we never see, careful readers have learned to view reports of evidence skeptically. Even when you think you have good evidence, be clear how it was collected and by whom. If it was collected by others, find and cite a source as close to the evidence as you can get.

我们的证据基础隐喻

Our Foundational Metaphors for Evidence

当我们谈论证据时，我们通常使用基础隐喻：好的证据是坚实的、坚硬的，是我们建立论点的基石，是我们可以亲眼看到的东西。不好的证据是站不住脚的、薄弱的或薄弱的。这样的语言鼓励读者将证据视为独立于任何人的解释和判断的现实。但数据总是由收集数据并将其用作证据的人构建和塑造的。当你建立你的论点时，请记住，只有当你的读者毫无疑问地接受它时，你的证据才算作证据，至少目前是这样。

When we talk about evidence, we typically use foundational metaphors: good evidence is solid, hard, the bedrock foundation on which we build arguments, something we can see for ourselves. Bad evidence is flimsy, weak, or thin. Language like that encourages readers to think of evidence as a reality independent of anyone’s interpretation and judgment. But data are always constructed and shaped by those who collect and use them as evidence. As you build your argument, keep in mind that your evidence will count as evidence only if your readers accept it without question, at least for the moment.

9.3 从 IT 报告中区分证据

9.3 DISTINGUISHING EVIDENCE FROM REPORTS OF IT

现在有一个并发症：研究人员很少在任何报告中包括证据本身。即使你自己收集数据，在田野里数兔子或采访失业者，你的论文也只能用文字、数字、表格、图表、图片等来引用或代表那些兔子和失业者。例如，检察官在法庭上说，琼斯是毒贩，这里有证据可以证明，他可以举起一袋可卡因，甚至让陪审员自己拿着。（当然，他和陪审员都必须相信那个说这是他从琼斯那里拿走的同一个袋子的警官和那个说白色东西真的是可卡因的化学家。）但是当他写道案情简报，他不能把那个袋子钉在书页上；他只能参考或描述它。

Now a complication: researchers rarely include in any report the evidence itself. Even if you collect your own data, counting rabbits in a field or interviewing the unemployed, your paper can only refer to or represent those rabbits and unemployed in words, numbers, tables, graphs, pictures, and so on. For example, when a prosecutor says in court, Jones was a drug dealer, and here is the evidence to prove it, he can hold up a bag of cocaine, even let jurors hold it in their own hands. (Of course, both he and the jurors must believe the officer who says it’s the same bag he took from Jones and the chemist who says that the white stuff really is cocaine.) But when he writes a brief on the case, he cannot staple that bag to the page; he can only refer to or describe it.

同样，研究人员不能与读者分享“证据本身”。例如：

In the same way, researchers cannot share with their readers “the evidence itself.” For example:

情绪在理性中发挥的作用比许多人想象的要大。声称事实上，如果没有大脑的情感中心，我们就无法做出理性的决定。理由 1 支持主张大脑的情感中心受到物理损伤的人无法做出最简单的决定。原因 2 支持原因 1例如，考虑 Y 先生的情况，他 。. . 证据报告

Emotions play a larger role in rationality than many think.claim In fact, without the emotional centers of the brain, we could not make rational decisions.reason 1 supporting claim Persons whose brains have suffered physical damage to their emotional centers cannot make the simplest decisions.reason 2 supporting reason 1 For example, consider the case of Mr. Y, who . . .report of evidence

该论点并没有提供大脑受损的真实人的证据；它只能报告对他们行为的观察、大脑扫描的副本、反应时间表等。（事实上​​ ，我们更喜欢阅读他人的报告，而不是必须自己测试大脑和阅读 MRI 扫描。）

That argument doesn’t offer as evidence real people with damaged brains; it can only report observations of their behavior, copies of their brain scans, tables of their reaction times, and so on. (In fact, we prefer to read reports of others than to have to test brains and read MRI scans ourselves.)

我们知道，证据和证据报告之间的这种区分似乎很好，但它强调了两个重要问题。首先，您从来源获取的数据总是由该来源塑造，不是为了歪曲它们，而是将它们置于服务于该来源目的的形式中。例如，假设你想证明名人崇拜扭曲了合理的报酬，你需要证据证明运动员和演艺人员的报酬远远高于顶级医生、将军和政府官员。您可以在官方报告中找到政府工资。但是除非你能偷看奥普拉和泰格伍兹的纳税申报表（谁知道它们有多可靠），否则你将不得不依赖那些可能或可能没有系统地从更远的地方收集和编制的收入报告报道。除非您可以与那些计算、组织和报告原始数据的人交谈，否则在将其用于您自己的目的之前，您将与证据本身相差三四步。

We know this distinction between evidence and reports of evidence must seem like a fine one, but it emphasizes two important issues. First, data you take from a source have invariably been shaped by that source, not to misrepresent them, but to put them in a form that serves that source’s ends. For example, suppose you want to show that the cult of celebrity distorts rational compensation, and you need evidence that athletes and entertainers are paid far more than top doctors, generals, and government officials. You could find government salaries in official reports. But unless you can peek at the tax returns of Oprah and Tiger Woods (and who knows how reliable they would be), you would have to depend on reports of those incomes that may or may not have been systematically collected and compiled from still more distant reports. Unless you can talk to those who counted, organized, and reported the original data, you’ll be at three or four removes from the evidence itself before you use it for your own purposes. (And at least one reporter in that chain of reports almost certainly miscopied some of the data.)

其次，当你反过来报告这些数据作为你自己的证据时，你无法避免再次操纵它们，至少将它们置于新的背景下。即使你自己收集数据，你也会整理它们，使它们看起来比你在笔记中实际看到、计算和记录的更连贯。事实上，甚至在你开始收集任何事实之前，你就必须决定要计算什么，如何对数字进行分类，如何排列它们，是否以表格、条形图或图形的形式呈现它们。甚至照片和录像也反映了特定的观点。简而言之，事实是由收集它们的人和使用它们的人的意图塑造的。

Second, when you in turn report those data as your own evidence, you cannot avoid manipulating them once again, at least by putting them in a new context. Even if you collected the data yourself, you tidied them up, making them seem more coherent than what you actually saw, counted, and recorded in your notes. In fact, even before you started collecting any facts at all, you had to decide what to count, how to categorize the numbers, how to order them, whether to present them in the form of a table, bar chart, or graph. Even photographs and video recordings reflect a particular point of view. In short, facts are shaped by those who collect them and again by the intentions of those who use them.

Reports of reports（of reports of reports）的质量通常很差，这就是为什么阅读大量研究的人对证据的可靠性如此苛刻的原因。如果您自己收集数据，他们会想知道您是如何收集数据的。如果您依赖来源，他们会希望您使用主要来源，如果您不使用，则尽可能接近主要来源。他们想要完整的引文和参考书目，这样如果他们愿意，他们就可以自己查看您的资料来源。简而言之，他们想知道他们可以信任“外面”的内容和他们正在阅读的内容之间的完整报告链。

This often squishy quality of reports of reports (of reports of reports) is why people who read lots of research are so demanding about the reliability of evidence. If you collect data yourself, they’ll want to know how you did it. If you depend on sources, they’ll expect you to use primary sources, and if you didn’t, to get as close to primary sources as you can. And they want complete citations and a bibliography so that they could, if they wanted to, look at your sources themselves. In short, they want to know that they can trust the complete chain of reports between what’s “out there” and what they are reading.

相信三百年前和现在的证据

Trusting Evidence Three Hundred Years Ago and Now

在实验科学的早期，研究人员在他们所谓的“目击者”面前进行实验，“目击者”是观察实验的著名科学家，以便他们能够证明报告证据的准确性。研究人员不再依赖目击者。相反，每个研究领域都对其收集和报告证据的方法进行了标准化，以确保证据的可靠性（尽管一些研究人员仍能逃脱欺诈）。当您遵守您所在领域的标准程序时，您鼓励读者按照您的话接受您的证据，而不需要他们自己去看。所以当你阅读二手资料时，注意他们引用的证据类型，他们是如何引用的，然后照做。在社会学领域，像社会学家那样做。

In the early days of experimental science, researchers conducted experiments before what they called “witnesses,” reputable scientists who observed the experiments so that they could attest to the accuracy of the reported evidence. Researchers don’t rely on witnesses anymore. Instead, each area of study has standardized its methodologies for collecting and reporting evidence to ensure that it is reliable (though some researchers still get away with fraud). When you observe the standard procedures in your field, you encourage readers to accept your evidence at your word, without their needing to see it themselves. So as you read secondary sources, note the kind of evidence they cite, how they cite it, then do likewise. When in sociology, do as sociologists do.

我们生活在这样一个时代，我们都受到研究报告和民意调查的影响，这些报告和民意调查充其量是可疑的，最坏的情况是伪造的，因此您必须向读者保证他们可以信任您的数据。信誉链中的最后一环是您，因此请仔细考虑您使用谁的数据以及如何使用它们。

We live in an age where we are all subjected to research reports and opinion surveys that are at best dubious and at worst faked, so you have to assure your readers that they can trust your data. The last link in that chain of credibility is you, so be thoughtful about whose data you use and how you use them.

9.4 评估你的证据

9.4 EVALUATING YOUR EVIDENCE

一旦您了解了读者期望的证据类型，您就必须测试您的证据的可靠性：它是否充分且具有代表性，是否准确准确地报告，是否来自权威来源？这些并不是学术研究独有的奇特标准。我们都将它们应用到我们最普通的对话中，即使是与孩子。在下文中，“父母”在所有这些标准上都对“孩子”造成了错误：

Once you know the kind of evidence your readers expect, you must test the reliability of yours: is it sufficient and representative, reported accurately and precisely, and taken from an authoritative source? These are not exotic criteria unique to academic research. We all apply them in our most ordinary conversations, even with children. In the following, “Parent” faults “Child” on all those criteria:

孩子：我需要一双新运动鞋。声称看。这些太小。证据

Child: I need new sneakers.claim Look. These are too small.evidence

家长：你的脚一个月没长那么大，而且它们似乎对你的伤害不大[也就是说，你的证据可能是相关的，但我拒绝它，因为它不准确，因为即使它是准确的， “太小”不够精确]。

Parent: Your feet haven’t grown that much in a month, and they don’t seem to hurt you much [i.e., your evidence could be relevant, but I reject it because it is not accurate and because even if it were accurate, “too small” is not sufficiently precise].

孩子：但是他们太邋遢了，不适合上学。原因看看这些污垢和这些破烂的鞋带。证据

Child: But they’re too grungy for school.reason Look at this dirt and these raggedy laces.evidence

家长：污垢会洗掉，鞋带可以更换。这还不足以购买新运动鞋 [也就是说，你可能在事实上是正确的，但光是脏兮兮的和破旧的鞋带并不足以证明它们不适合上学]。
