Parent: The dirt will wash off and the laces can be replaced. That’s not enough to buy new sneakers [i.e., you may be factually correct, but dirt and raggedy laces alone are not sufficient evidence that they are unfit for school].

孩子：他们受伤了。原因看我跛行的样子。证据

Child: They hurt.reason Look at how I limp.evidence

家长：你一分钟前还好好走路【即你的证据不具有代表性】。

Parent: You were walking fine a minute ago [i.e., your evidence is not representative].

孩子：每个人都认为我应该买新运动鞋。哈利这么说的原因。证据

Child: Everybody thinks I should get new sneakers.reason Harry said so.evidence

家长： Harry 的意见在这个房子里并不重要[即，Harry 可能已经说过，但他的意见并不具有权威性]。

Parent: Harry’s opinion doesn’t matter in this house [i.e., Harry may have said that, but his opinions are not authoritative].

读者根据父母对孩子使用的相同标准来判断证据报告。他们希望证据准确、准确、充分、具有代表性和权威性。（读者也希望证据具有相关性，但我们将在第 11 章中讨论这一点。）在收集证据时，在将其添加到故事板之前，根据这些标准对其进行筛选。

Readers judge reports of evidence by the same criteria a parent uses with a child. They want evidence to be accurate, precise, sufficient, representative, and authoritative. (Readers also expect evidence to be relevant, but we’ll discuss that in chapter 11.) As you assemble your evidence, screen it for those criteria before you add it to your storyboard.

9.4.1准确报告证据

9.4.1 Report Evidence Accurately

细心的读者倾向于怀疑，所以他们会抓住你证据中最微不足道的错误，作为你在其他一切方面都不可靠的标志。无论你的研究论点是基于实验室、实地、图书馆还是在线收集的数据，都要完整清楚地记录这些数据，然后在你写下之前、之时和之后仔细检查它们。把简单的事情做对是对读者的尊重，也是处理困难事情的最好训练。如果您承认其质量可疑，有时甚至可以使用有问题的证据。事实上，如果你指出似乎支持你的主张的证据，但随后又认为它不可靠而拒绝，你就表明自己是谨慎的、自我批评的，因此是值得信赖的。

Careful readers are predisposed to be skeptical, so they will seize on the most trivial mistake in your evidence as a sign of your unreliability in everything else. Whether your research argument depends on data collected in a lab, in the field, in the library, or online, record those data completely and clearly, then double-check them before, as, and after you write them up. Getting the easy things right shows respect for your readers and is the best training for dealing with the hard things. You can sometimes use even questionable evidence, if you acknowledge its dubious quality. In fact, if you point to evidence that seems to support your claim but then reject it as unreliable, you show yourself to be cautious, self-critical, and thus trustworthy.

9.4.2适当精确

9.4.2 Be Appropriately Precise

你的读者希望你准确地陈述你的证据。他们听到警钟，用他们无法评估其实质的方式对冲您的主张：

Your readers want you to state your evidence precisely. They hear warning bells in words that hedge your claim in such a way that they cannot assess its substance:

林务局已经花费了大量资金来防止森林火灾，但仍然很有可能发生大而昂贵的火灾。

The Forest Service has spent a great deal of money to prevent forest fires, but there is still a high probability of large, costly ones.

多少钱很划算？高概率是多少——30%？80%？什么算大而贵？注意诸如some、most、many、almost、often、usually、frequently、general等词。这样的词可以适当地限制观点的范围（见 8.3），但如果研究人员没有足够努力地工作来获得精确的数字，它们也可以捏造它。

How much money is a great deal? How probable is a high probability—30 percent? 80 percent? What counts as large and costly? Watch for words like some, most, many, almost, often, usually, frequently, generally, and so on. Such words can appropriately limit the breadth of a claim (see 8.3), but they can also fudge it if the researcher didn’t work hard enough to get the precise numbers.

然而，什么才算是精确，因领域而异。物理学家以纳秒的几分之一来测量夸克的寿命，因此可容忍的误差范围小得几乎可以忽略不计。衡量苏联何时处于崩溃点的历史学家会估计它在几个月内。古生物学家可能会确定一个新物种的年代，前后数万年。按照各自领域的标准，三者都恰到好处。（证据也可能过于精确。只有鲁莽的历史学家才会断言苏联在 1987 年 8 月 18 日下午 2 点 13 分达到了不可避免的崩溃点。）

What counts as precise, however, differs by field. A physicist measures the life of quarks in fractions of a nanosecond, so the tolerable margin of error is vanishingly small. A historian gauging when the Soviet Union was at the point of collapse would estimate it in months. A paleontologist might date a new species give or take tens of thousands of years. According to the standards of their fields, all three are appropriately precise. (Evidence can also be too precise. Only a foolhardy historian would assert that the Soviet Union reached its point of inevitable collapse at 2:13 p.m. on August 18, 1987.)

9.4.3提供充分的、有代表性的证据

9.4.3 Provide Sufficient, Representative Evidence

初学者通常提供的证据太少。他们认为他们用一句话、一个数字、一个个人经历来证明一个主张（尽管有时只有一点证据就足以反驳它）。例如：

Beginners typically offer too little evidence. They think they prove a claim with one quotation, one number, one personal experience (though sometimes only one bit of evidence is sufficient to disprove it). For example:

莎士比亚一定讨厌女人，因为哈姆雷特和麦克白中的女人是邪恶的或软弱的。

Shakespeare must have hated women because those in Hamlet and Macbeth are evil or weak.

读者需要的不仅仅是这些才能接受如此重要的观点。

Readers need more than that to accept such a significant claim.

即使您提供了大量证据，您的读者仍然希望它能够代表可用内容的全部变化。一两部莎士比亚戏剧中的女性并不代表他所有的女性，正如莎士比亚代表所有伊丽莎白时代的戏剧一样。当您的证据是大量数据中的小样本时，例如在调查中，读者会特别警惕。无论何时使用抽样数据，您的数据不仅必须具有代表性，而且还必须证明它具有代表性。

Even if you offer lots of evidence, your readers still expect it to be representative of the full range of variation in what’s available. The women in one or two Shakespearean plays do not represent all his women, any more than Shakespeare represents all Elizabethan drama. Readers are especially wary when your evidence is a small sample from a large body of data, as in surveys. Whenever you use sampled data, not only must your data be representative, but you must show that it is.

与您的证据不具代表性的说法相关的一项指控是，它是轶事。它可能具有代表性，但也可能不具有代表性。如果您的主张取决于一两个例子，无论选择多么具有代表性，您的证据都有可能被视为一种挑选樱桃的形式而被驳回。当然，轶事证据可以以数据的统计表示所没有的方式具有说服力。有说服力的例子、案例研究或证明规则的例外情况非常有说服力，这使得通过轶事进行的论证具有吸引力，但也具有风险，因为论证的说服力取决于其证据。

A charge related to the claim that your evidence is unrepresentative is that it is anecdotal. It might be representative but, then again, it might not. If your claim depends on one or two examples, however well-chosen to be representative, there is a risk that your evidence will be dismissed as a form of cherry-picking. Of course, anecdotal evidence can be persuasive in ways that statistical representations of data are not. The very persuasiveness of the telling example, the case study, or the exception that proves the rule makes argument by anecdote attractive but also risky because an argument is only as strong as its evidence.

9.4.4考虑权威的权重

9.4.4 Consider the Weight of Authority

不同的领域对证据的定义和评估不同。如果您是初学者，则需要时间来了解您所在领域的读者接受和拒绝的证据类型。获得这种体验最痛苦的方式就是成为他们批评的对象。不那么痛苦的是寻找因为证据被判定为不可靠而失败的论证的例子。听讲座和课堂讨论，了解您的导师批评的各种论点，因为他们认为证据不足。失败的论证比成功的论证更能帮助你理解什么才是可靠的。

Different fields define and evaluate evidence differently. If you’re a beginner, you’ll need time to learn the kinds of evidence that readers in your field accept and reject. The most painful way to gain that experience is to be the object of their criticism. Less painful is to seek examples of arguments that failed because their evidence was judged unreliable. Listen to lectures and class discussions for the kinds of arguments that your instructors criticize because they think that the evidence is weak. Failed arguments help you understand what counts as reliable better than do successful ones.

一种特殊的弱证据来自读者认为不权威的来源。二十世纪初，纽约人接受了一份当地报纸的话：“如果你在太阳下看到它，就是这样。” 一般而言，读者根据其严谨和客观的声誉为来源分配权威程度。例如，大多数人会接受研究人员从美国疾病控制中心获得的有关病毒传播的数据作为可信的证据，即使考虑到错误的可能性。然而，来自维基百科的证据在许多圈子中不会被接受，因为维基百科不被认为是权威的。“考虑来源”是怀疑论者对因缺乏权威而被驳回的证据的反驳。

A particular kind of weak evidence comes from sources that readers do not consider authoritative. Early in the twentieth century, New Yorkers accepted the word of a local newspaper: “If you see it in the Sun, it’s so.” In general, readers assign degrees of authority to sources based on their reputation for rigor and objectivity. For example, most people will accept data on the transmission of viruses that a researcher obtains from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control as credible evidence, even allowing for the possibility of error. However, evidence from Wikipedia will not be accepted in many circles because Wikipedia is not regarded as authoritative. “Consider the source” is the skeptic’s rebuttal to evidence dismissed for lack of authority.

10 致谢和回应

10  Acknowledgments and Responses

如果一个论点不能承认其他观点，那么这个论点就不完整。本章展示了如何通过承认和回应读者可能提出的问题、异议和备选方案来使你的论点更有说服力。

An argument is not complete if it fails to recognize other points of view. This chapter shows how you can make your argument more convincing by acknowledging and responding to questions, objections, and alternatives your readers might raise.

你的论点的核心是基于证据的理由支持的主张。你用更多的理由来加厚它，也许用额外的子理由和证据来支持每个理由。但是，如果您只向读者提供主张、理由和证据——无论这些对您来说多么有说服力——他们可能仍然会觉得您的论点单薄，或者更糟的是，他们对他们的观点一无所知或不屑一顾。要打造一个成功的论证，你必须做的不仅仅是组装一个由主张、理由和证据组成的健全的大厦；你还必须将这些观点定位为对正在进行的对话的贡献，而你的读者也参与其中（见第 7 章）。

The core of your argument is a claim backed by reasons based on evidence. You thicken it with more reasons, perhaps supporting each with additional subreasons and evidence. But if you give your readers only claims, reasons, and evidence—no matter how compelling these are to you—they may still find your argument thin or, worse, ignorant or dismissive of their views. To craft a successful argument, you must do more than assemble a sound edifice of claims, reasons, and evidence; you must also position those claims as contributions to an ongoing conversation in which your readers are invested (see chapter 7).

你可以在介绍中做到这一点，将你的主要主张作为读者关心的问题的解决方案来展示（我们将在第 16 章详细讨论介绍）。但你也可以在整个论证过程中做到这一点，方法是预测、承认和回应读者可能在此过程中提出的问题、异议和替代方案。当你计划和起草你的论文时，你的读者不会在那里质疑你或提出他们自己的观点。所以你必须想象他们的问题和观点并考虑他们。通过想象自己与读者交谈，这就是您与读者建立合作关系的方式。

You can do this in your introduction by presenting your main claim as a solution to a problem your readers care about (we’ll talk more about introductions in chapter 16). But you can do it throughout your argument as well by anticipating, acknowledging, and responding to questions, objections, and alternatives that your readers are likely to raise along the way. As you plan and draft your paper, your readers won’t be there to question you or to offer their own views. So you have to imagine their questions and views and take them into account. That’s how you establish a cooperative relationship with readers, by imagining yourself conversing with them.

在本章中，我们将向您展示如何想象和解决读者可能会就您的论点提出的两类问题：

In this chapter, we show you how to imagine and address two kinds of questions that readers may ask about your argument:

• 他们可能会通过质疑您的主张的清晰度、您的理由的相关性或您的证据质量来质疑其内在的可靠性。

• They may question its intrinsic soundness by challenging the clarity of your claim, the relevance of your reasons, or the quality of your evidence.

• 他们可能会通过要求您考虑替代方案来质疑它的外在可靠性——构建问题的不同方式、您忽略的证据或其他人就您的主题所写的内容。

• They may question its extrinsic soundness by asking you to consider alternatives—different ways of framing the problem, evidence you’ve overlooked, or what others have written on your topic.

当您预期、承认并回答这两种问题时，您就创建了一个读者更有可能信任和接受的论点。

When you anticipate, acknowledge, and respond to both kinds of questions, you create an argument that readers are more likely to trust and accept.

10.1 按照读者的意愿质疑你的论点

10.1 QUESTIONING YOUR ARGUMENT AS YOUR READERS WILL

在计划和起草你的论点时，如果你从一开始就尝试想象对它的每一种可能反应，你可能会停滞不前。因此，首先关注你自己想说的话，关注构成你论点核心的主张、理由和证据。一旦你有了这个核心，试着想象读者对它的反应。这样做可能很难，因为您太了解自己的论点，并且可能过于相信它而无法认真挑战它。如果您可以与您信任的朋友、导师或同事分享您论点的核心，那就去做吧。这将帮助您确定其他读者可能提出的问题、异议和替代方案。如果你不能，那么想象一群特别怀疑的假设读者比你希望你的实际读者更尖锐地质疑你的论点。

When planning and drafting your argument, you may freeze up if you try from the outset to imagine every possible reaction to it. Therefore, focus first on what you yourself want to say, on the claims, reasons, and evidence that make up your argument’s core. Once you have that core, try to imagine readers’ responses to it. Doing this may be hard, because you know your own argument too well and may believe in it too much to seriously challenge it. If you can share the core of your argument with a friend, mentor, or colleague you trust, do it. That will help you identify questions, objections, and alternatives that other readers might raise. If you can’t, then imagine a group of particularly skeptical hypothetical readers questioning your argument more sharply than you hope your actual readers will.

在这个练习中，你可能会暂停将争论视为协作探究的概念，而不是将其想象成战争，而是接近于一场热烈的辩论。通过与不同结果有利害关系的人、希望你错的人的眼光来看待你的论点。

For this exercise, you might suspend your conception of argument as collaborative inquiry and imagine it not quite as warfare, but as something close to a warm debate. View your argument through the eyes of someone who has a stake in a different outcome, someone who wants you to be wrong.

首先，检查你的问题。以下是一些想象中的读者可能会回答的问题：

First, examine your problem. Here are some questions with possible answers from an imagined reader:

1.为什么你认为有问题？“你正在应对的情况的成本或后果似乎并不那么重要。”

1. Why do you think there’s a problem at all? “The costs or consequences of the situation you are responding to don’t seem that significant.”

2.您是否正确定义了问题？它是实用的还是概念性的？“也许问题不涉及你提出的问题，而是另一个问题。”

2. Have you properly defined the problem? Is it practical or conceptual? “Maybe the problem involves not the issue you raise but another one.”

然后考虑您的解决方案：

Then consider your solution:

3.你的解决方案是实用的还是概念性的？也就是说，它是否要求读者做某事或理解某事？它是否与问题匹配（实际问题需要实际解决方案；概念问题需要概念问题）？“你解释出了什么问题，但你没有说我们如何改变它。” “你断言我们目前的理解是不够的，但你没有提供一种看待这个问题的新方法。”

3. Is your solution practical or conceptual? That is, does it ask readers to do something or to understand something? And does it match the problem (practical problems demand practical solutions; conceptual problems conceptual ones)? “You explain what’s wrong, but you don’t say how we can change it.” “You assert that our current understanding falls short, but you don’t offer a new way of looking at the issue.”

4.你的主张是否过于强烈？“我能想到例外和限制。”

4. Have you stated your claim too strongly? “I can think of exceptions and limitations.”

5a. 为什么你的实际解决方案比其他人更好？“我认为你提出的方案成本太高，还会产生新的问题。”

5a. Why is your practical solution better than others? “I think that what you propose will cost too much and create new problems.”

5b. 为什么你的概念性解决方案比别人好？“它似乎与所有这些其他公认的知识不符。”

5b. Why is your conceptual solution better than others? “It doesn’t seem to fit with all this other well-established knowledge.”

如果你想出了一个你无法回答的问题，在继续之前决定你是否能找到答案。在这个问题上不要对自己太过宽容：解决你的论点问题的时候就是你发现它的时候。

If you come up with a question that you can’t answer, decide whether you can find the answer before you go on. Don’t go easy on yourself with this one: the time to fix a problem with your argument is when you find it.

请注意您的论点在哪里可能看起来很薄弱但实际上并非如此。例如，如果您预计读者会认为您的解决方案有成本，而实际上没有，您可以通过承认和回应来消除这种担忧：

Note where your argument might seem weak but actually isn’t. If, for example, you anticipate that readers will think your solution has costs that it does not, you can defuse that concern by acknowledging and responding to it:

看起来，通过关注特定银行的行为，我们正在最大限度地减少导致金融危机的系统性力量，但实际上，我们的案例研究将表明。. .

It might seem that by focusing on the actions of specific banks, we are minimizing the systemic forces that contributed to the financial crisis, but, in fact, our case studies will show . . .

接下来，质疑你的支持。想象一个读者质疑你的证据。读者可能会质疑其性质：

Next, question your support. Imagine a reader challenging your evidence. A reader might question its nature:

1. “我想看到不同类型的证据——确凿的数字，而不是轶事（或者关于真人的故事，而不是冰冷的数字）。”

1. “I want to see a different sort of evidence—hard numbers, not anecdotes (or stories about real people, not cold numbers).”

如果您提供正确的证据，读者可能仍会质疑其质量：

If you present the right kind of evidence, a reader might still question its quality:

2. “这不准确。这些数字不相加。”

2. “It isn’t accurate. The numbers don’t add up.”

3. “不够精确。你说的‘很多’是什么意思？”

3. “It isn’t precise enough. What do you mean by ‘many’?”

4. “它不是最新的。还有比这更新的研究。”

4. “It isn’t current. There’s newer research than this.”

5. “这不具有代表性。你没有得到所有组的数据。”

5. “It isn’t representative. You didn’t get data on all the groups.”

6. “它不具有权威性。史密斯不是这方面的专家。”

6. “It isn’t authoritative. Smith is no expert on this matter.”

然而，最严厉的反对意见通常是这个：

The toughest objection, however, is usually this one:

7. “你需要更多证据。一个数据点（引文/数字/轶事）是不够的。”

7. “You need more evidence. One data point (quotation/number/anecdote) is not sufficient.”

大多数研究人员都难以找到足够好的证据来提出可靠的论据，尤其是那些工作期限很短的研究人员。但是老师抱怨最多的学生似乎认为他们首先找到的证据就是他们所需要的。

Most researchers have difficulty finding enough good evidence to make a solid case, especially those working on short deadlines. But teachers grumble most about students who seem to think that the evidence they find first is all they need.

当读者对与您不同的解决方案有利害关系时，他们可能会特别怀疑。因此，如果您觉得您的证据并非无懈可击，您可能想坦率地承认其局限性，以免读者因为您夸大其词而拒绝您的论点。

Readers can be particularly skeptical when they have a stake in a solution that differs from yours. So if you feel your evidence is less than unassailable, you may want to admit its limitations candidly, before readers reject your argument because you overstated it.

最后，读者可能看不到你的理由如何支持你的主张，或者你的主张如何从你的理由中得出。我们用第 11 章的全部篇幅来解决这个问题。

Finally, readers may not see how your reasons support your claims, or how your claim follows from your reasons. We devote all of chapter 11 to this problem.

总之，在整理你的论点时，要像你最持怀疑态度的读者那样检验你的主张、理由和证据——甚至以他们可能不会采用的方式。然后，您至少可以解决您认为他们会提出的最重要的反对意见。向读者表明，在他们通过他们的论点之前，您已经通过了自己的观点。

In sum, when assembling your argument, test your claims, reasons, and evidence as your most skeptical readers will—and even in ways they might not. You can then address at least the most important objections that you can imagine them raising. Show readers that you put your argument through your own wringer before they put it through theirs.

10.2 想象你的论点的替代方案

10.2 IMAGINING ALTERNATIVES TO YOUR ARGUMENT

当您认识到自己论点的局限性时，您就可以通过向读者表明您是在诚实地论证并公平对待他们来建立可信度。但这只是一种防御措施。如果你不仅表明你理解自己论点的优势和局限性，而且表明您也了解并考虑过替代方案。为此，您必须通过承认和回应这些替代观点来将其纳入您的论点。

When you recognize your own argument’s limitations, you build credibility by showing readers that you are making an honest case and dealing with them fairly. But that’s just a defensive move. You will seem even more credible if you show not just that you understand the strengths and limitations of your own argument, but that you also understand and have thought about the alternatives to it. To do that, you have to bring those alternative views into your argument by acknowledging and responding to them.

如果您非常了解您的主题和读者，您可以尝试自己想象这些替代方案。但通常识别替代观点的最佳方法是查看您的来源。在第 6 章中，我们鼓励您在研究过程中积极利用您的资源，不仅要将它们用于数据，还要激发您自己的思考。您的消息来源还提供了可供选择的观点，您可以在自己的论点中回应这些观点。

If you know your subject and readers very well, you can try to imagine those alternatives yourself. But usually the best way to identify alternative views is to look to your sources. In chapter 6, we encouraged you to actively engage your sources during your research, to use them not just for data but to stimulate your own thinking. Your sources also offer a ready supply of alternative views that you can respond to in your own argument.

您可以将您的二手资料视为关于您的主题、问题或问题的对话的书面记录。了解该对话可以让您为之做出贡献。当你阅读你的资料时，注意他们提出与你不同的主张的地方，采取不同的方法，关注问题的不同方面，等等。请特别注意您和您的消息来源不同意的地方和原因。还要注意一个来源与另一个来源不一致的地方。所有这些分歧都可以帮助您确定在您自己的论点中承认的替代方案。如果您知道您将如何回应特定来源，请在阅读时将该回应添加到您的笔记中。

You can think of your secondary sources as a written record of the conversation about your topic, question, or problem. Knowing that conversation allows you to contribute to it. When you read your sources, note where they advance claims different from yours, take different approaches, focus on different aspects of the problem, and so on. Note especially where—and why—you and your sources disagree. Also note where one source disagrees with another. All those disagreements can help you identify alternatives to acknowledge in your own argument. If you know how you would respond to a particular source, add that response to your notes as you read.

您不仅可以回应消息来源的主张，还可以回应他们的证据。如果您发现来源的证据不可靠或不相关，请不要简单地忽略它。如果你的读者可能会认真对待它，你可以承认它但解释为什么你没有使用它。

You can respond not only to your sources’ claims but also to their evidence. If you find a source’s evidence unreliable or irrelevant, don’t simply ignore it. If your readers might take it seriously, you can acknowledge it but explain why you didn’t use it.

最后，您的消息来源还可以帮助您想象您的读者并预测他们对您的论点的反应。通常，您的读者会像您资料来源的作者一样；有时他们甚至可能包括他们。

Finally, your sources also help you imagine your readers and anticipate their reactions to your argument. Often your readers will be like your sources’ authors; sometimes they may even include them.

10.3 决定承认什么

10.3 DECIDING WHAT TO ACKNOWLEDGE

如果你能想象出你的读者可能有的几个问题、选择和反对意见，你将面临一个金发姑娘时刻：承认太多，你会分散读者对你论点核心的注意力；承认太少，你似乎对他们的观点漠不关心，甚至一无所知。您需要弄清楚有多少致谢会让人感觉“恰到好处”。

If you can imagine just a few of the questions, alternatives, and objections that your readers might have, you’ll face a Goldilocks moment: acknowledge too many and you distract readers from the core of your argument; acknowledge too few and you seem indifferent to or even ignorant of their views. You need to figure out how many acknowledgments will feel “just right.”

10.3.1选择回应什么

10.3.1 Choosing What to Respond To

要缩小备选方案或反对的范围，请考虑以下优先事项：

To narrow your list of alternatives or objections, consider these priorities:

• 你可以反驳的合理的弱点指控

• plausible charges of weaknesses that you can rebut

• 在您的领域中重要的替代论据

• alternative lines of argument important in your field

• 读者希望真实的替代结论

• alternative conclusions that readers want to be true

• 读者知道的替代证据

• alternative evidence that readers know

• 你必须解决的重要反例

• important counterexamples that you have to address

寻找可以让您重复部分论点的替代方案。例如，如果读者可能会想到实际上并非如此的定义的例外情况，请承认它们并使用响应来强化您的观点：

Look for alternatives that let you repeat a part of your argument. For example, if readers might think of exceptions to a definition that in fact are not, acknowledge them and use the response to reinforce your point:

有些人争辩说，即使是食物也会让人上瘾，但请记住，我们在这里只关心那些通常会让人上瘾的物质，而不是那些……。. .

Some have argued that even food can be addictive, but remember we are concerned here only with substances for which addiction is the norm, not those . . .

或者，如果读者可能想到与您的方案接近的替代解决方案，请用它来重申您的解决方案的优点：

Or if readers might think of an alternative solution close to yours, use it to reiterate the virtues of your solution:

大多数研究人员认为，规则和其他形式的正式写作建议会降低而不是提高表现，因为写作“是一种无意识的创造意义的行为，而不是有意识地遵守规则的过程。” 部分过程确实如此：作者在起草句子时不应参考规则。但写作不仅涉及起草，还涉及许多有意识的过程。我们在这里展示的是，什么样的正式建议对写作的有意识方面有效和无效。. . .

Most researchers argue that rules and other forms of formal writing advice degrade rather than improve performance because writing “is a non-conscious act of making meaning, not a conscious process of following rules.” That is true for parts of the process: writers should not consult rules as they draft sentences. But writing involves not just drafting but many conscious processes as well. What we show here is what kinds of formal advice do and do not work for conscious aspects of writing. . . .

最后，确认可能对您的读者特别有吸引力的替代方案，但前提是您可以做出回应而不会显得不屑一顾。最好忽略你的读者喜欢的东西而不是贬低它。

Finally, acknowledge alternatives that may particularly appeal to your readers, but only if you can respond without seeming to be dismissive. Better to ignore what your readers like than to disparage it.

10.3.2承认论证中的缺陷

10.3.2 Acknowledging Flaws in Your Argument

如果您发现论点中存在无法修复或无法解释的缺陷，请尝试重新定义您的问题或重建您的论点避免它。但如果你做不到，你将面临一个艰难的决定。您可以忽略该缺陷并希望您的读者不会注意到它。但这是不诚实的。如果他们确实注意到了，他们会怀疑你的能力，如果他们认为你试图隐藏它，他们会质疑你的诚实。我们的建议看似幼稚，但行之有效：坦诚承认问题并做出回应

If you discover a flaw in your argument that you cannot fix or explain away, try to redefine your problem or rebuild your argument to avoid it. But if you cannot, you face a tough decision. You could just ignore the flaw and hope your readers don’t notice it. But that’s dishonest. If they do notice it, they will doubt your competence, and if they think you tried to hide it, they will question your honesty. Our advice may seem naive, but it works: candidly acknowledge the issue and respond that

• 你的其余论点不仅仅弥补了这个缺陷。

• the rest of your argument more than balances the flaw.

• 虽然缺陷很严重，但更多的研究会找到绕过它的方法。

• while the flaw is serious, more research will show a way around it.

• 虽然该缺陷使您无法完全接受您的主张，但您的论点提供了对问题的重要见解，并提出了更好的答案需要什么。

• while the flaw makes it impossible to accept your claim fully, your argument offers important insight into the question and suggests what a better answer would need.

有时，研究人员将他们想要支持但无法支持的主张视为其他人可能认为合理的假设，从而将失败转化为成功。然后他们展示了为什么不是：

Occasionally researchers turn failure into success by treating a claim they wanted to support but couldn’t as a hypothesis that others might find reasonable. Then they show why it isn’t:

看起来，当陪审员以关注受害人并强调她的痛苦的形式听取案件事实时，他们更有可能责备被告。毕竟，这是原告律师的标准做法。但事实上，我们没有发现 之间的相关性。. .

It might seem that when jurors hear the facts of a case in a form that focuses on the victim and emphasizes her suffering, they will be more likely to blame the accused. That is, after all, the standard practice of plaintiffs’ lawyers. But in fact, we found no correlation between . . .

10.3.3承认你无法回答的问题

10.3.3 Acknowledging Questions You Can’t Answer

刚起步的研究人员有时会认为他们的目标是对某个主题拥有最终决定权，也就是说，提出一个只允许完全同意而不需要回应的论点。但这是一个错误。经验丰富的研究人员和教师明白，没有任何论点是完全无懈可击的，而且任何一种版本的真理往往都是复杂的，而且总是有争议的。事实上，最激动人心的研究往往不是为我们已知的问题提供答案，而是为我们尚未考虑提出的新问题提供答案。这对于解决概念问题的研究尤其如此，但对于应用研究也是如此。

Beginning researchers sometimes think that their goal is to have the last word on a topic, that is, to make an argument that allows for no response but total assent. But that’s a mistake. Experienced researchers and teachers understand that no argument is entirely unassailable and that any one version of the truth is often complicated and always contestable. In fact, the most stimulating research is often that which provides not answers to questions we already know, but new sets of questions we haven’t yet thought to ask. This is especially true for research addressing conceptual problems, but it can be true for applied research as well.

知识渊博的读者会更好地考虑你的论点和你，而不是假装你有所有的答案，而是承认你的论点的局限性，尤其是那些挤压你比你喜欢的多。让步通过使读者的观点合法化来邀请他们参与对话，这始终是一种有助于维持研究人员社区的姿态。如果你能给他们提出新的有趣的问题让他们思考，他们会特别感激。这就是让谈话继续下去的原因。

Knowledgeable readers will think better of your argument and of you if, rather than pretending you have all the answers, you acknowledge your argument’s limits, especially those that squeeze you more than you like. Concessions invite readers into the conversation by legitimizing their views, always a gesture that helps sustain a community of researchers. And they will be especially grateful if you can give them new and interesting questions to think about. That’s what keeps the conversation going.

10.4 将你的回答作为次要论点

10.4 FRAMING YOUR RESPONSES AS SUBORDINATE ARGUMENTS

承认备选方案和反对意见让您有机会做出回应。但你不能只提出竞争性主张。即使是最小的回应也会给你一个限制或拒绝你已经承认的东西的理由：

Acknowledging alternatives and objections gives you an opportunity to respond. But you can’t just offer a competing claim. Even a minimal response gives a reason to limit or reject what you have acknowledged:

有些人认为食物会让人上瘾，承认反对意见，但我们在这里只关心那些成瘾是常态的物质。反对无关紧要的原因

Some have argued that food can be addictive,acknowledgment of objection but we are concerned here only with substances for which addiction is the norm.reason why objection is irrelevant

最初的反应可能就足够了，但前提是读者认识到它的基础，要么因为它很明显，要么因为你之前已经提出过论点。否则，使用其他原因和证据解释其基础：

That initial response may be enough, but only if readers recognize the basis for it, either because it’s obvious or because you’ve made the argument before. Otherwise, explain its basis using additional reasons and evidence:

有些人认为食物会让人上瘾，承认反对意见，但我们在这里只关心那些成瘾是常态的物质。反对无关紧要的原因有些人尝过一次巧克力之后可能无法抗拒，但与那些接触过一次可卡因后立即上瘾的人相比，他们的人数只是一小部分。子原因 Chernowitz (1998) 发现只有一次接触会导致 . . . 证据报告

Some have argued that food can be addictive,acknowledgment of objection but we are concerned here only with substances for which addiction is the norm.reason why objection is irrelevant Some who taste chocolate once may be unable to resist it thereafter, but their number is a fraction of those who are immediately addicted to crack cocaine after a single exposure.subreason Chernowitz (1998) found that just one exposure resulted in . . .report of evidence

对于更实质性的回应，你需要一个完整的论点，包括多种原因、证据，甚至可能是保证书和额外的确认和回应。（此时，将致谢和回应添加到论证工作计划中的适当位置。在第 12 章中，我们将讨论将它们放在初稿计划中的什么位置。）同样，在回应备选方案时，你面临金发姑娘的选择：不过多也不过少。只有经验可以教你如何找到这种平衡。所以请注意专家们是如何做到这一点的，并照此去做。

For more substantial responses, you need a full argument, with multiple reasons, evidence, and perhaps even warrants and additional acknowledgments and responses. (At this point, add acknowledgments and responses to the appropriate places in the working plan of your argument. In chapter 12 we’ll discuss where to put them in the plan of your first draft.) Again, when responding to alternatives, you face a Goldilocks choice: not too much, not too little. Only experience can teach you how to find this balance. So notice how experts achieve it and do likewise.

10.5 确认和响应的词汇

10.5 THE VOCABULARY OF ACKNOWLEDGMENT AND RESPONSE

有些作家没有承认替代方案，因为他们想不出任何替代方案。本章中的策略将帮助您克服该问题。其他人可以想出要承认的观点，但担心如果他们这样做，他们会削弱他们的论点。事实上，大多数读者认为这样的承认可以提高作者的可信度。作家也回避承认和回应反对意见和替代方案，因为他们不知道如何在页面或屏幕上以书面形式做这些事情。本节向您展示如何操作。

Some writers fail to acknowledge alternatives because they can’t think of any. The strategies in this chapter will help you overcome that problem. Others can think of views to acknowledge, but fear that if they do, they weaken their argument. In fact, most readers think that such acknowledgments enhance a writer’s credibility. Writers also shy away from acknowledging and responding to objections and alternatives because they don’t know how to do those things in writing, on the page or screen. This section shows you how.

当你想承认并回应反对意见或替代方案时，你必须决定给予它多少信任：选择范围从仅提及反对意见并驳回它到详细解决它。我们大致按照从最不屑一顾到最尊重的顺序提出我们的建议。（括号和斜杠表示替代选择。）

When you want to acknowledge and respond to an objection or alternative, you have to decide how much credence to give it: options range from just mentioning an objection and dismissing it to addressing it at length. We present our advice roughly in that order, from most dismissive to most respectful. (Brackets and slashes indicate alternative choices.)

10.5.1承认异议和备选方案

10.5.1 Acknowledging Objections and Alternatives

承认异议或替代语言表明你给予它多少权重。这里有一些选项。

Acknowledge an objection or alternative in language that shows how much weight you give it. Here are some options.

1. 你可以用despite , regardless of , or notwithstanding来淡化反对或备选方案：

1. You can downplay an objection or alternative by introducing it with despite, regardless of, or notwithstanding:

[ Despite/Regardless of/Notwithstanding ] 国会声称要减税，承认最新的预算提案表明。. . 回复

[Despite/Regardless of/Notwithstanding] Congress’s claims that it wants to cut taxes,acknowledgment the latest budget proposals suggest that . . .response

以相同的方式使用although、while和even though：

Use although, while, and even though in the same way:

[ Although/While/Even though ] 香港正在经历经济问题，承认东南亚仍然很强大。. . 回复

[Although/While/Even though] Hong Kong is experiencing economic problems,acknowledgment Southeast Asia remains a strong . . .response

2. 你可以用seem、appear、may或could，或用副词如plausibly、justifiably、reasonable、surprising或 even certainly间接表示确认：

2. You can signal an acknowledgment indirectly with seem, appear, may, or could, or with an adverb like plausibly, justifiably, reasonably, surprisingly, or even certainly:

林肯在他的信中表达了[似乎/似乎]是抑郁症。致谢而是那些观察他的人。. . 回复

In his letters Lincoln expresses what [seems/appears] to be depression.acknowledgment But those who observed him . . .response

这个建议 [可能有/可能有] 一些优点，感谢我们。. . 回复

This proposal [may have/plausibly has] some merit,acknowledgment but we . . .response

3. 您可以将异议或备选方案归因于未命名的来源，这会给它一点权重：

3. You can attribute an objection or alternative to an unnamed source, which gives it a little weight:

很容易[认为/想象/说/声称/争论]税收应该。. . 致谢但是还有[另一种/替代/可能] [解释/论点/原因/可能性]。回复

It is easy to [think/imagine/say/claim/argue] that taxes should . . .acknowledgment But there is [another/alternative/possible] [explanation/line of argument/account/possibility].response

一些证据[可能/可能/可以/可能/确实] [建议/指示/指向/引导一些人思考] 我们应该。. . ，感谢但是。. . 回复

Some evidence [might/may/can/could/does] [suggest/indicate/point to/lead some to think] that we should . . . ,acknowledgment but . . .response

4. 您可以将异议或备选方案归因于通用对话者，赋予其更多权重：

4. You can attribute an objection or alternative to a generic interlocutor, giving it more weight:

[一些/许多/一些] [可能/可能/可能/会] [说/认为/争论/声称/指责/反对] 古巴不是。. . 致谢但是，事实上， . . . 回复

There are [some/many/a few] who [might/may/could/would] [say/think/argue/claim/charge/object] that Cuba is not . . .acknowledgment But, in fact, . . .response

尽管 [一些研究人员/评论家/学者] 认为 . . . ，感谢我们的研究表明。. .

Although [some researchers/critics/scholars] have argued that . . . ,acknowledgment our research shows . . .

请注意，如果您过早地诋毁那些您不同意的人，您可能会削弱您的论点：

Note that you can weaken your case if you prematurely denigrate those you disagree with:

一些天真的研究人员声称 . . .

Some naive researchers have claimed that . . .

偶尔粗心的历史学家 H 甚至声称。. .

The occasionally careless historian H has even claimed that . . .

保留批评的回应，并将其指向工作而不是人。

Save criticism for the response, and direct it at the work rather than the person.

5. 你可以用I或we、被动动词或诸如admittedly、granted、to be sure等承认其某些有效性的词或短语，用自己的声音承认反对或替代：

5. You can acknowledge an objection or alternative in your own voice, using I or we, a passive verb, or a word or phrase such as admittedly, granted, to be sure, and so on, which concedes it some validity:

我[理解/知道/意识到]自由主义者相信。. . ，感谢但是。. . 回复

I [understand/know/realize] that liberals believe in . . . ,acknowledgment but . . .response

[真实/可能/可能]电子烟比传统香烟致癌性低。致谢但是，。. . 回复

It is [true/possible/likely] that electronic cigarettes are less carcinogenic than conventional cigarettes.acknowledgment However, . . .response

[必须/应该/可以] [承认/承认/注意到/承认]没有好的证据证明。. . 承认尽管如此，. . .

It [must/should/can] be [admitted/acknowledged/noted/conceded] that no good evidence proves that . . .acknowledgment Nevertheless, . . .

[ Granted/Certainly/Admittedly/True/To be sure/Of course ]，亚当斯声称。. . 致谢但是，。. . 回复

[Granted/Certainly/Admittedly/True/To be sure/Of course], Adams has claimed . . .acknowledgment However, . . .response

我们[愿意/可能/能够/可能/可能] [说/争论/主张/认为] 针头交换等公共卫生项目鼓励。. . ，承认，但这些影响被超过。. . 回复

We [would/could/can/might/may] [say/argue/claim/think] that public health programs such as needle exchanges encourage . . . ,acknowledgment but these effects are outweighed by . . .response

10.5.2回应异议和备选方案

10.5.2 Responding to Objections and Alternatives

以表示不同意的术语或短语开始您的回复，例如但是、然而或另一方面。如果读者还不知道该回答的依据，请至少用一个理由或什至用一个完整的从属论据来支持它。

Begin your response with a term or phrase that signals disagreement, such as but, however, or on the other hand. If readers do not already know the basis for that response, support it with at least one reason or even with a complete subordinate argument.

您可以以委婉或直率的方式做出回应。

You can respond in ways that range from tactful to blunt.

1、遗憾的不是出处不明，而是不完全明白：

1. You can regret not that the source is unclear, but that you don’t entirely understand:

但是[我不太明白如何/我发现很难看出如何/我不清楚] X 可以声称，什么时候。. . 回复

But [I do not quite understand how/I find it difficult to see how/It is not clear to me how] X can claim that, when . . .response

2.或者你可以注意到有未解决的问题：

2. Or you can note that there are unsettled issues:

但这里还有其他问题 。. ./ 但是仍然存在 . 的问题 。. . 回复

But there are other issues here . . ./But there remains the problem of . . .response

3. 你可以更有力地回应，声称承认的立场无关紧要或不可靠：

3. You can respond more forcefully, claiming the acknowledged position is irrelevant or unreliable:

但尽管这可能很有见地，但承认它[忽略/不相关/不影响]手头的问题。回复

But as insightful as that may be,acknowledgment it [ignores/is irrelevant to/does not bear on] the issue at hand.response

但是[证据/推理]是[不可靠/不可靠/薄弱]。回复

But the [evidence/reasoning] is [unreliable/shaky/thin].response

但论点是[站不住脚/薄弱/困惑/简单化]。回复

But the argument is [untenable/weak/confused/simplistic].response

但论点 [忽略/忽略/遗漏] 关键因素。回复

But the argument [overlooks/ignores/misses] key factors.response

你必须决定你的反应应该有多直率。如果替代方案看起来明显有缺陷，请直言不讳，但要专注于工作而不是人。

You have to decide how blunt your response should be. If an alternative seems obviously flawed, say so, but focus on the work rather than the person.

4. 当你认为另一位研究人员似乎没有仔细考虑一个问题时，你通常应该礼貌地说出来。这里有几种可能性：

4. When you think another researcher seems to have not thought through an issue carefully, you usually should say so civilly. Here are a few possibilities:

史密斯的证据很重要，承认， 但我们必须查看所有可用的证据。回复

Smith’s evidence is important,acknowledgment but we must look at all the available evidence.response

这解释了一些问题，承认， 但它对于单一解释来说太复杂了。回复

That explains some of the problem,acknowledgment but it is too complex for a single explanation.response

这一原则在许多情况下都适用，但 并非在所有情况下都适用。回复

That principle holds in many cases,acknowledgment but not in all.response

快速提示：三个可预测的分歧

Quick Tip: Three Predictable Disagreements

至少有些读者可能会想到三种替代方案。

There are three kinds of alternatives that at least some readers are likely to think of.

1.除了你声称的原因之外，还有其他原因。如果你的论点是关于因果关系的，请记住没有单一原因的结果，也没有单一结果的原因。如果你争论 X 导致 Y，每个读者都会想到其他原因。欧洲蜜蜂群落可能因使用杀虫剂而崩溃，但知情的读者还可以列出其他可能的因素，包括栖息地丧失、疾病、转基因作物和寄生虫。因此，如果您专注于众多原因中的一个，请承认其他原因。如果你觉得读者可能认为某些原因比你给予的更多关注，请承认这种观点并解释你为什么不强调它。

1. There are causes in addition to the one you claim. If your argument is about cause and effect, remember that no effect has a single cause and no cause has a single effect. If you argue that X causes Y, every reader will think of other causes. European honeybee colonies may be collapsing because of pesticide use, but an informed reader could also list other possible factors, including loss of habitat, disease, genetically modified crops, and parasites. So if you focus on one cause out of many, acknowledge the others. And if you feel readers might think that some cause deserves more attention than you give it, acknowledge that view and explain why you deemphasized it.

2.这些反例呢？无论你的证据多么丰富，读者都可能会想到他们认为会破坏你的论点的例外和反例。所以你必须首先想到它们，承认那些更合理的，特别是如果它们是生动的，然后解释为什么你不认为它们像你的读者那样具有破坏性。当您对变化范围很广的现象（例如气候）发表观点时要特别小心。不了解统计推理的读者会关注一个异常案例，即使它属于正态分布：佛罗里达州寒冷的七月四日并不能反驳全球变暖的说法，就像温暖的新英格兰圣诞节证明这一点一样。

2. What about these counterexamples? No matter how rich your evidence, readers are likely to think of exceptions and counterexamples that they believe undermine your argument. So you must think of them first, acknowledge the more plausible ones, especially if they are vivid, and then explain why you don’t consider them as damaging as your reader might. Be particularly wary when you make claims about a phenomenon with a wide range of variation, such as the climate. Readers who do not understand statistical reasoning will focus on an aberrant case, even though it falls within a normal distribution: a cold Fourth of July in Florida does not disprove a claim about global warming, any more than a warm New England Christmas proves it.

3.我不像你那样定义X。对我来说，X 意味着。. . 要接受你的主张，读者必须接受你的定义，因为定义是至关重要的保证（见下一章）：如果你正在研究尼古丁成瘾，你的读者必须理解你所说的这个术语的意思。它是否意味着只是一种强烈的渴望，一种某些人无法抗拒的渴望，或者一种无人能抗拒的渴望？您可以找到从字典中的几行到医学参考书中的页面的定义。但不管这些来源是什么也就是说，读者倾向于重新定义他们遇到的术语以适应他们自己的观点。香烟制造商长期以来争辩说，香烟不会让人上瘾，因为有些人可以戒烟；他们的批评者认为香烟会让人上瘾，因为更多的人不会。

3. I don’t define X as you do. To me, X means . . . To accept your claim, readers must accept your definitions, because definitions are crucial warrants (see the next chapter): if you are researching nicotine addiction, your readers must understand what you mean by that term. Does it mean just a strong craving, a craving that some people can’t resist, or a craving that no one can? You can find definitions ranging from a few lines in a dictionary to pages in a medical reference work. But regardless of what those sources say, readers tend to redefine terms they encounter to suit their own views. Cigarette manufacturers long argued that cigarettes are not addictive because some people can quit; their critics argued that cigarettes are addictive because more people can’t.

当你的论点取决于一个术语的含义时，定义它以支持你的解决方案，并为你的定义提供一个从属论据。不要将字典定义视为权威（永远不要开始，“根据韦伯斯特的说法，‘成瘾’的意思是……”）。请注意您可能需要承认的合理的替代定义。如果您使用的技术术语也有共同的含义（如社会阶级或理论），请承认该共同含义并解释您采用技术术语的原因。相反，如果您没有像专家读者期望的那样使用技术术语，请承认这一点并解释您选择其他含义的原因。

When your argument hinges on the meaning of a term, define it to support your solution and offer a subordinate argument for your definition. Don’t treat a dictionary definition as authoritative (never begin, “According to Webster’s, ‘addiction’ means . . .”). Be aware of plausible alternative definitions that you may need to acknowledge. If you use a technical term that also has a common meaning (like social class or theory), acknowledge that common meaning and explain why you have adopted the technical one. Conversely, if you do not use a technical term as expert readers expect you to, acknowledge that and explain why you’ve opted for another meaning.

11张权证

11  Warrants

认股权证是将理由与观点联系起来的一般原则。本章解释何时以及如何使用它们。一般来说，只有当你的读者没有他们就无法理解你的论点，或者当你希望你的读者质疑你的推理时，你才应该陈述你的保证。当你为某个领域的专家写作时，你可以不说明你的大部分保证，因为你的读者通常已经知道它们并且认为它们是理所当然的。

Warrants are general principles that connect reasons to claims. This chapter explains when and how to use them. In general, you should state your warrants only when your readers will not understand your argument without them or when you expect your readers to challenge your reasoning. When you write for experts in a field, you can leave most of your warrants unstated, because your readers will usually know them already and take them for granted.

考虑这个论点：

Consider this argument:

俄罗斯联邦面临生活水平下降的问题，声称这是因为其出生率仅为千分之 13.2，男性的预期寿命仅为 63 岁左右。原因

The Russian Federation faces a falling standard of living,claim because its birthrate is only 13.2 per 1,000 and life expectancy for men is only about 63 years.reason

有人回应：

Someone responds:

好吧，关于俄罗斯的出生率和预期寿命，你是对的，但我不明白这与你声称俄罗斯的生活水平会下降有什么关系。有什么关系？

Well, you’re right about Russia’s birthrate and life expectancy, but I don’t see how that’s relevant to your claim that its standard of living will fall. What’s the connection?

提出论点的人会如何回答？更重要的是，如果那个论点是书面的，她怎么知道她必须在问题被问到之前回答这个问题？这些问题涉及论证的第五个也是最复杂的要素：它的保证。保证是将理由与观点联系起来的原则。保证很重要，因为读者可能不仅会质疑理由的有效性，还会质疑其相关性。

How would the person making the argument answer? More important, if that argument were in writing, how would she know that she had to answer that question before it was asked? Such questions address the fifth and most complex element of an argument: its warrants. A warrant is a principle that connects a reason to a claim. Warrants are important because readers may challenge not just the validity of a reason but its relevance as well.

在本章中，我们将解释认股权证如何运作、如何对其进行测试以及何时以及何时不陈述。基本原则是这样的：只有当你的读者没有他们就无法理解你的推理，或者你预计你的推理会受到挑战时，才陈述你的保证。

In this chapter, we explain how warrants work, how to test them, and when and when not to state them. The basic principle is this: state your warrants only if your readers will not be able to understand your reasoning without them, or if you anticipate that your reasoning will be challenged.

但当我们开始时，请注意：每个人都在努力理解认股权证——不时包括我们所有人。因此，如果在本章结束时您仍然有疑问，那么您并不孤单。

But as we get started, a word of caution: everyone struggles to understand warrants—including, from time to time, all of us. So if at the end of this chapter you still have questions, you’re not alone.

11.1 日常推理中的保证

11.1 WARRANTS IN EVERYDAY REASONING

保证很难掌握，但当人们提供谚语来证明他们的推理时，我们很容易理解它们。那是因为谚语是我们都知道的保证。比如有人说：

Warrants are hard to grasp, but we understand them easily enough when people offer proverbs to justify their reasoning. That’s because proverbs are warrants that we all know. For example, someone says:

我听说联邦调查局一直在审问市长的工作人员。原因他一定是卷入了一些不正当的事情。宣称

I hear the FBI has been questioning the mayor’s staff.reason He must be involved in something crooked.claim

另一个人可能会反对，你是对的。联邦调查局一直在盘问他的手下，但为什么这意味着他不诚实呢？为了解释导致该结论的推理，第一个人可能会说一句谚语，嗯，哪里有烟，哪里就有火。也就是说，当我们看到有问题的迹象时，我们可以推断出确实有问题。

Another person might object, You’re right. The FBI has been questioning his staff, but why does that mean he’s crooked? To explain the reasoning that led to that conclusion, the first person might offer the proverb, Well, where there’s smoke, there’s fire. That is, when we see a sign of something wrong, we can infer that something is in fact wrong.

这种推理背后的逻辑是这样的。大多数谚语描述的情况由两个截然不同的部分组成：一个情况（哪里有烟，……）及其后果（ ……哪里有火）。如果情况与后果之间的联系在一般情况下是真实或合理的，那么在特定情况下也必须是真实或合理的。在烟雾、火灾、联邦调查局和市长的情况下，逻辑如下：

The logic behind that reasoning is this. Most proverbs describe a situation made up of two distinct parts: a circumstance (Where there’s smoke, . . .) and its consequence (. . . there’s fire). If the connection between the circumstance and consequence is true or reasonable in general, it must also be true or reasonable in specific instances. In the case of smoke, fire, the FBI, and the mayor, that logic looks like this:

我们用谚语来证明多种日常推理：因果关系（欲速则不达）；行为规则（三思而后行）；可靠的推论（一燕不立夏）。但这样的谚语并不是我们日常保证的唯一例子。我们到处都使用认股权证：在体育运动中（防守赢得冠军）；在烹饪中（仅在几个月内用“r”供应牡蛎）；在定义中（质数只能被自身和一整除）；即使在研究中（当读者发现一点证据中的错误时，他们也不相信其余的）。

We use proverbs to justify many kinds of everyday reasoning: cause and effect (Haste makes waste); rules of behavior (Look before you leap); reliable inference (One swallow does not a summer make). But such proverbs are not our only examples of everyday warrants. We use warrants everywhere: in sports (Defense wins championships); in cooking (Serve oysters only in months with an “r”); in definitions (A prime number can be divided only by itself and one); even in research (When readers find an error in one bit of evidence, they distrust the rest).

11.2 学术论证中的保证

11.2 WARRANTS IN ACADEMIC ARGUMENTS

在学术论证中，认股权证的运作方式完全相同。但与谚语和其他日常保证相比，学术保证可能难以管理——尤其是对于刚接触该领域的研究人员——原因有以下三个。

In academic arguments, warrants work in exactly the same way. But in contrast to proverbs and other everyday warrants, academic warrants can be difficult to manage—especially for researchers new to a field—for three reasons.

首先，学术保证不是我们共有的司空见惯。它们是属于特定研究人员群体的特定推理原则，而且数量不计其数。生活中的事实是新的研究人员需要时间来掌握他们领域的保证。

First, academic warrants aren’t commonplaces we all share. They are specific principles of reasoning that belong to particular communities of researchers, and they are countless. A fact of life is that it just takes time for new researchers to grasp the warrants of their fields.

其次，经验丰富的研究人员在为他们所在领域的专业读者写作时很少明确陈述他们的保证，因为他们可以放心地假设这些读者已经了解他们。（陈述显而易见的事情似乎没有帮助，反而居高临下。）这种做法很适合专业读者。但这对新手提出了挑战，他们必须弄清楚是什么原因使某些原因与观点相关，而另一些则不相关，这是专家们认为理所当然的事情。这就是为什么任何领域的初学者都难以理解为专家编写的论证逻辑。

Second, experienced researchers rarely state their warrants explicitly when they write for specialized readers in their fields because they can safely assume that these readers already know them. (To state the obvious would seem not helpful but condescending.) This practice serves specialized readers well. But it poses a challenge to novices, who have to figure out what makes some reasons relevant to claims and others not, something those experts take for granted. That’s why beginners in any field struggle with the logic of arguments written for specialists.

这是工作中的学术授权的示例。假设现有证据支持这个原因，生物学家会接受这个论点：

Here’s an example of an academic warrant at work. Assuming the available evidence supported the reason, biologists would accept this argument:

鲸鱼与河马的关系比与牛的关系更密切，声称因为它与河马共享更多 DNA。原因

A whale is more closely related to a hippopotamus than to a cow,claim because it shares more DNA with a hippopotamus.reason

没有生物学家会问，是什么让 DNA 与测量关系相关？因此，没有生物学家为她的同事写作会提供回答这个问题的保证。然而，如果一个非生物学家问这个问题，生物学家会用其他生物学家认为理所当然的保证来回答：

No biologist would ask, What makes DNA relevant to measuring relationship? So no biologist writing for her colleagues would offer a warrant answering that question. If, however, a non-biologist asked that question, the biologist would answer with a warrant other biologists take for granted:

当一个物种与一个物种共享的 DNA 多于与另一个物种共享的 DNA 时，我们推断它与第一个物种的关系更密切。结果

When a species shares more DNA with one species than it does with another,circumstance we infer that it is more closely related to the first.consequence

当然，生物学家可能还必须解释该保证。关键是：是否明确陈述保证不仅取决于论点，还取决于听众。只有在与非专家交流或受到挑战时，专家才会陈述对其他专家来说显而易见的原则。

Of course, the biologist would probably then have to explain that warrant as well. The point is this: whether or not a warrant gets stated explicitly depends not only on the argument but also on the audience. Experts state principles that are obvious to other experts only when they communicate with non-experts—or when challenged.

第三，学术保证通常以压缩其情况和后果的方式陈述。在大多数谚语中，这些部分是不同的：哪里有烟，哪里就有火 。结果但我们也可以将这两部分压缩成一个短片观点：烟意味着火。这是我们很少用谚语做的事情，但专家们经常用他们的专业权证做的事情：

Third, academic warrants are often stated in ways that compress their circumstances and consequences. In most proverbs, these parts are distinct: Where there’s smoke,circumstance there’s fire.consequence But we can also compress those two parts into one short statement: Smoke means fire. That’s something we rarely do with proverbs but that experts often do with their specialized warrants:

共享 DNA 是物种间关系的衡量标准。

Shared DNA is the measure of the relationship between species.

换句话说，我们的生物学家的保证没有明确区分情况与其可预测的后果。但是，无论授权令如何压缩，我们总能推断出这两个部分。为清楚起见，我们将以最明确的两部分形式陈述认股权证：当 X，则Y。

Phrased this way, our biologist’s warrant doesn’t explicitly distinguish a circumstance from its predictable consequence. But however compressed a warrant might be, we can always infer those two parts. For purposes of clarity, we’ll state warrants in their most explicit two-part form: When X, then Y.

11.3 理解权证的逻辑

11.3 UNDERSTANDING THE LOGIC OF WARRANTS

这又是关于俄罗斯经济未来的争论：

Here again is that argument about Russia’s economic future:

俄罗斯联邦面临生活水平下降的问题，声称这是因为其出生率仅为千分之 13.2，男性的预期寿命仅为 63 岁左右。原因

The Russian Federation faces a falling standard of living,claim because its birthrate is only 13.2 per 1,000 and life expectancy for men is only about 63 years.reason

如果有人反对理由似乎与观点无关，则提出论点的人必须证明与由两部分组成的保证的联系是正确的：（1）让我们得出结论的一般情况（2）一般后果.

If someone objects that the reason seems irrelevant to the claim, the person making the argument would have to justify the connection with a warrant consisting of two parts: (1) a general circumstance that lets us draw a conclusion about (2) a general consequence.

当一个国家的劳动力萎缩时，其经济前景普遍黯淡。一般后果

When a nation’s labor force shrinks,general circumstance its economic future is grim.general consequence

情况和后果都必须比具体原因和主张更笼统。从视觉上看，该逻辑如下所示：

Both the circumstance and consequence have to be more general than the specific reason and claim. Visually, that logic looks like this:

这与我们在关于烟雾、火灾和不正当市长的争论中看到的模式相同。

That’s the same pattern we saw in the argument about smoke, fire, and the crooked mayor.

11.4 测试保证

11.4 TESTING WARRANTS

读者以可预见的方式挑战认股权证。考虑这个论点：

Readers challenge warrants in predictable ways. Consider this argument:

与流行的看法相反，在 19 世纪上半叶及之前，美国可能并不普遍拥有枪支，因为遗嘱中很少提及枪支。原因对 1750 年至 1850 年在七个州提交的 4,465 份遗嘱的审查表明，只有 11% 的遗嘱提到长枪或手枪。证据报告

Contrary to popular belief, gun ownership in America was probably not widespread in the first half of the nineteenth century and before,claim because guns were rarely mentioned in wills.reason A review of 4,465 wills filed in seven states from 1750 to 1850 shows that only 11 percent mention a long gun or handgun.report of evidence

这种说法可能会遭到那些认为美国的创建者拥有枪支的人的抵制。因此，即使他们承认原因是真实的——遗嘱中实际上很少提及枪支——他们可能仍然会反对：但我不明白这如何成为相信很少有人拥有枪支的理由。这无关紧要。

Such a claim is likely to be resisted by those who believe that those who founded the United States owned guns. So even if they accept that the reason is true—that guns were in fact rarely mentioned in wills—they may still object: But I don’t see how that counts as a reason to believe that few people owned a gun. It’s irrelevant.

如果一位作家预料到读者会提出反对意见，在她陈述具体原因之前，她会提供一份保证书，将具体原因与具体观点联系起来：

If a writer anticipated that readers would raise that objection, she would offer a warrant to link the specific reason to the specific claim before she stated them:

在十八世纪和十九世纪初，贵重物品列在遗嘱中，所以当一个人没有在遗嘱中提及贵重物品时，他就没有拥有。手令由于枪支很有价值，但在 1850 年之前很少在遗嘱中提及，因此枪支拥有率一定不普遍。宣称

In the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, valuable objects were listed in wills, so when someone failed to mention a valuable object in his will, he did not own one.warrant Since guns were valuable but were rarely mentioned in wills before 1850,reason gun ownership must not have been widespread.claim

但如果她想让她的读者接受这个保证，她必须在她的读者做之前问自己五个问题：

But if she wants her readers to accept that warrant, she must ask herself five questions before her readers do:

1. 那个权证合理吗？

1. Is that warrant reasonable?

2. 是否足够有限？

2. Is it sufficiently limited?

3. 它是否优于任何竞争认股权证？

3. Is it superior to any competing warrants?

4.适合这个领域吗？

4. Is it appropriate to this field?

5.是否能涵盖原因和观点？

5. Is it able to cover the reason and claim?

11.4.1你的保证合理吗？

11.4.1 Is Your Warrant Reasonable?

当读者可以接受它的后果来自于它的情况时，保证似乎是合理的。如果读者不接受这一点，您必须首先说服他们接受您的保证，方法是将其视为自己论点中的主张，并有自己的理由和证据支持：

A warrant seems reasonable when readers can accept that its consequence follows from its circumstance. If readers don’t accept that, you must first convince them to accept your warrant by treating it as a claim in its own argument, supported by its own reasons and evidence:

在 18 世纪和 19 世纪初，贵重物品被列在遗嘱中，因此当遗嘱中没有提到这样的贵重物品时，这个人就没有拥有它。保证/观点Watson (1989) 证实了这一点。原因在对 1750 年至 1825 年间在坎伯兰县提交的 1,356 份遗嘱的研究中，他发现。. . 证据

In the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, valuable objects were listed in wills, so when a will failed to mention such a valuable object, the person did not own one.warrant/claim Watson (1989) confirmed that to be the case.reason In a study of 1,356 wills filed in Cumberland County between 1750 and 1825, he found . . .evidence

11.4.2你的授权是否足够有限？

11.4.2 Is Your Warrant Sufficiently Limited?

大多数认股权证仅在一定范围内是合理的。例如，关于枪支所有权的保证似乎不允许有任何例外：

Most warrants are reasonable only within certain limits. For example, that warrant about gun ownership seems to allow no exceptions:

在 18 世纪和 19 世纪初，有价值的物品被列在遗嘱中。

In the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, valuable objects were listed in wills.

那个版本太宽泛了；如果它是合格的，它可能看起来更合理：

That version is too broad; it might seem more plausible if it were qualified:

在 18 世纪和 19 世纪初，大多数被主人认为有价值的家居用品通常都列在遗嘱中。

In the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, most household objects considered valuable by their owners were usually listed in wills.

但是，一旦您开始用诸如most和usually之类的词来限定权证，您就必须证明它的例外情况不排除您的理由和主张：什么频率是most和usually？枪支一直被认为是有价值的吗？

But once you start qualifying a warrant with words like most and usually, you then have to show that its exceptions do not exclude your reason and claim: What frequency are most and usually? Were guns always considered valuable?

11.4.3您的认股权证是否优于任何竞争认股权证？

11.4.3 Is Your Warrant Superior to Any Competing Warrants?

你可能认为你的保证是合理的并且有足够的限制，但其他人可能会反驳它。这里还有两个相互竞争的认股权证，都可以说是合理的：

You may think your warrant is reasonable and sufficiently limited, but others might contradict it. Here are two more competing warrants, both arguably reasonable:

当父母认为医疗程序可能会伤害他们的孩子时，他们有权拒绝。泰勒和克里斯认为麻疹疫苗会导致自闭症，因此他们可以拒绝让女儿接种麻疹疫苗。

When parents believe a medical procedure may harm their children, they have a right to refuse it. Taylor and Chris believe the measles vaccine causes autism, so they can refuse to have it administered to their daughter.

当医疗决定涉及公共卫生问题时，国家有权对其进行监管。当人口中的大多数儿童接种麻疹疫苗时，每个人都会更安全，因此该州可以强制泰勒和克里斯让他们的女儿接种疫苗。

When medical decisions concern matters of public health, the state has a right to regulate them. When most children in a population are vaccinated against measles, everyone is safer, so the state can compel Taylor and Chris to allow their daughter to be vaccinated.

应以哪种手令为准？这是另一个争论的问题。

Which warrant should prevail? That’s a matter for yet another argument.

您有时可以通过限制权证来协调竞争权证：

You can sometimes reconcile competing warrants by limiting them:

当父母认为医疗程序可能会伤害他们的孩子时，他们有权拒绝， 只要这不会危及他人的健康。

When parents believe a medical procedure may harm their children, they have a right to refuse it, so long as that does not jeopardize the health of others.

当医疗决定涉及公共卫生问题时，国家有权对其进行监管， 只要国家尽可能少地侵犯父母为子女做出医疗决定的特权。

When medical decisions concern matters of public health, the state has a right to regulate them, so long as the state encroaches as little as possible on parents’ prerogative to make medical decisions for their children.

找到合适的平衡并不容易。同样，这是一个有争议的问题。

Finding the right balance is not easy. Again, it’s a matter for argument.

11.4.4你的权证适合这个领域吗？

11.4.4 Is Your Warrant Appropriate to This Field?

你的保证可能是合理的、足够有限的并且优于其他的，但如果它不适合他们的特定研究团体，你的读者可能仍然会拒绝它。当法律专业的学生发现许多他们认为理所当然的保证在法律辩论中没有立足之地时，他们在法律上得到了一个痛苦的教训。例如，像我们大多数人一样，他们开始法学院时抱着这样的常识性信念：

Your warrant may be reasonable, sufficiently limited, and superior to others, but your readers might still reject it if it is not appropriate to their particular research community. Law students get a painful lesson in the law when they find that many warrants they take for granted have no place in legal arguments. For example, like most of us, they start law school holding this commonsense belief:

人受了委屈，法律就该纠正。

When a person is wronged, the law should correct it.

但是法律专业的学生必须知道，法律授权书可能胜过这些常识性的想法。例如：

But law students have to learn that legal warrants may trump such commonsense ideas. For example:

当一个人无视法律义务时，即使是无意中，也必须承担后果。

When one ignores legal obligations, even inadvertently, one must suffer the consequences.

所以：

Therefore:

当老年房主忘记缴纳房产税时，其他人可以购买他们的房子来补缴税款并驱逐他们。

When elderly home owners forget to pay real estate taxes, others can buy their houses for back taxes and evict them.

与他们最正派的本能相反，法学院学生必须学会争辩说，正义不是他们认为合乎道德的结果，而是法律和法院支持的结果。

Against their most decent instincts, law students must learn to argue that justice is not the outcome they believe to be ethical but the one that the law and the courts support.

11.4.5您的保证书是否能够涵盖您的理由和观点？

11.4.5 Is Your Warrant Able to Cover Your Reason and Claim?

最后，您必须确保您的理由和主张是您的授权的一般情况和一般后果的良好例证。例如：

Finally, you must be sure that your reason and claim are good instances of your warrant’s general circumstance and general consequence. For example:

艾哈迈德：你应该买枪，因为你一个人住。原因

Ahmed: You should buy a gun,claim because you live alone.reason

贝丝：为什么一个人住就意味着我应该买枪？

Beth: Why does living alone mean I should buy a gun?

艾哈迈德：当你不安全时，一般情况下你应该保护自己。一般后果

Ahmed: When you aren’t safe,general circumstance you should protect yourself.general consequence

贝丝：但是独居并不会让我不安全。

Beth: But living alone doesn’t make me unsafe.

Beth 反对的不是 Ahmed 的理由是错误的，而是这不是他的逮捕令一般情况的有效实例。所以对她来说，艾哈迈德的理由不在他的逮捕令范围内，因此不相关。贝丝也可能回应说拥有枪支会使她的家更不安全（而不是更安全）。在那种情况下，她会反对艾哈迈德的说法不是逮捕令后果的一个很好的例子，也就是说，这不是他的理由：即使她不安全，枪支也不允许她保护自己.

Beth objects not that Ahmed’s reason is false but that it is not a valid instance of his warrant’s general circumstance. So to her, Ahmed’s reason isn’t covered by his warrant and is therefore not relevant. Beth might also have responded that owning a gun would make her home less safe (rather than more). In that case, she would be objecting that Ahmed’s claim isn’t a good instance of the warrant’s consequence, that is, that it doesn’t follow from his reason: even if she was unsafe, a gun would not allow her to protect herself.

如果这一切看起来很复杂，请知道您有很好的伙伴关系：至少从亚里士多德时代起，保证与主张和理由的关系就一直困扰着逻辑学家。但是，只要了解读者通常质疑保证的方式，就可以帮助您写出更好的论据，这就是我们在上面列出这五个问题的原因。

If all this seems complicated, know that you are in good company: the relationship of warrants to claims and reasons has vexed logicians since at least the time of Aristotle. But just knowing the ways that readers typically challenge warrants will help you write better arguments, which is why we’ve listed those five questions above.

11.5 知道何时陈述保证

11.5 KNOWING WHEN TO STATE A WARRANT

任何领域的论证都依赖于无数的推理原则，但这些原则中的大多数深深植根于我们的默会知识中，以至于我们很少陈述它们。但是，在三种情况下，您可能必须：

An argument in any field depends on countless principles of reasoning, but most of these principles are so deeply embedded in our tacit knowledge that we rarely state them. There are three occasions, however, when you may have to:

1.你的读者在你的领域之外。当您以专家身份为非专家读者写作时，您可能需要解释专家如何得出结论并支持他们的主张，尤其是在这些推理方式不寻常的情况下。

1. Your readers are outside your field. When you write as an expert for non-expert readers, you may need to explain how experts draw conclusions and support their claims, especially if these ways of reasoning are unusual.

2.你使用的推理原则在你的领域是新的或有争议的。当您依赖非传统的推理原则时，您可以预料至少有一些读者会持怀疑态度。因此，通过陈述你的保证然后证明它的合理性来化解这种怀疑。参考您所在领域也使用它的其他人。如果你做不到，那就用你自己的论据来捍卫你的推理。

2. You use a principle of reasoning that is new or controversial in your field. When you rely on unconventional principles of reasoning, you can anticipate that at least some of your readers will be skeptical. So defuse that skepticism by stating your warrant and then justifying it. Refer to others in your field who also use it. If you can’t do that, make an argument of your own defending your reasoning.

3.你声称读者会拒绝，因为他们只是不希望它是真的。在这种情况下，一个好的策略是在你列出理由并声称你担心他们会抵制之前，先以你希望读者接受的保证开始。他们可能不喜欢要求更好，但你至少会鼓励他们看到这并非不合理。例如：

3. You make a claim that readers will resist because they just don’t want it to be true. In this case, a good strategy is to start with a warrant that you hope readers will accept before you lay out a reason and claim that you fear they will resist. They may not like the claim any better, but you will at least encourage them to see that it is not unreasonable. For example:

我们应该承认人类行为对气候变化负有主要责任，因为几乎所有气候科学家都持有这种观点。原因

We should accept that human actions are largely responsible for climate change,claim because virtually all climate scientists hold that view.reason

你不说的话说明你是谁

What You Don’t Say Says Who You Are

当您陈述并支持保证来解释他们可能不承认的推理原则时，您是在礼貌地对待读者。但是当你对你应该向不知情的读者陈述的保证保持沉默时，你做出了同样强烈（虽然不那么友好）的姿态。不管怎样，保证会显着影响读者如何看待你通过论点表达的精神。

You treat readers courteously when you state and support warrants to explain principles of reasoning that they may not recognize. But you make an equally strong (though less friendly) gesture when you keep silent about warrants you should state for readers not in the know. One way or the other, warrants significantly affect how readers perceive the ethos you project through your arguments.

一些读者可能会抵制这种说法，因为它威胁到他们持有的其他坚定信念。面对此类读者的作家可能会鼓励他们至少考虑这一主张，方法是给他们一个他们应该能够接受的保证：

Some readers may resist that claim because it threatens other strong convictions they hold. A writer confronting such readers might encourage them at least to consider that claim by giving them a warrant that they should be able to accept:

当绝大多数有能力的专家得出相同的结论时，我们可能可以相信它。因此，我们应该承认人类行为对气候变化负有主要责任，因为几乎所有气候科学家都持有这种观点。原因

When an overwhelming majority of competent experts arrive at the same conclusion, we can probably trust it.warrant We should therefore accept that human actions are largely responsible for climate change,claim because virtually all climate scientists hold that view.reason

当读者接受保证是合理的，理由是真实的，并且理由和主张是保证的一般情况和后果的良好实例时，那么他们在逻辑上至少有义务考虑该主张。如果他们不这样做，任何理性的论证都不可能改变他们的想法。

When readers accept that a warrant is reasonable, that a reason is true, and that the reason and claim are good instances of the warrant’s general circumstance and consequence, then they are logically obliged at least to consider the claim. If they don’t, no rational argument is likely to change their minds.

11.6 使用权证检验你的论点

11.6 USING WARRANTS TO TEST YOUR ARGUMENT

所有论点都基于保证，即使没有明确说明。你可以通过想象一个论证的依据来检验一个论证的合理性。关于暴力视频游戏如何影响儿童，这是一个有缺陷的论点：

All arguments rely on warrants, even if they aren’t stated explicitly. You can test the soundness of an argument by trying to imagine a warrant for it. Here is a flawed argument about how violent video games affect children:

今天 12 至 16 岁的儿童比上一代人的暴力行为要严重得多。原因Brown (2013) 表明 . . . 证据鉴于这些事实，暴力视频游戏似乎极有可能对当今的年轻人产生破坏性影响。宣称

Children aged 12–16 today are significantly more violent than their counterparts from a generation ago.reason Brown (2013) has shown that . . .evidence Given these facts, it seems highly likely that violent video games are exerting a destructive influence on today’s youth.claim

为了理解这里出了什么问题，我们可以想象一个授权令，它可以让我们得出关于电子游戏对儿童影响的结论：

To understand what’s wrong here, we can imagine a warrant that would allow us to draw a conclusion about the effect of video games on children:

当孩子们不断地接触到虐待狂暴力的画面时，他们会受到更坏的影响。保证今天 12-16 岁的儿童比上一代的儿童更暴力。原因Brown (2013) 表明 . . . 证据鉴于这些事实，暴力视频游戏似乎极有可能对当今的年轻人产生破坏性影响。宣称

When children are constantly exposed to images of sadistic violence, they are influenced for the worse.warrant Children aged 12–16 today are significantly more violent than their counterparts from a generation ago.reason Brown (2013) has shown that . . .evidence Given these facts, it seems highly likely that violent video games are exerting a destructive influence on today’s youth.claim

现在我们可以看到问题所在：具体情况——12 至 16 岁儿童中暴力行为的增加——并不是逮捕令一般情况的有效实例：儿童暴露在虐待狂暴力的画面中。

Now we can see the problem: the specific circumstance—rising violence among children aged 12–16—is not a valid instance of the warrant’s general circumstance: children being exposed to images of sadistic violence.

因此，即使关于儿童暴力事件增加的说法是正确的，也不能证明这一说法是正确的。为了解决这个论点，我们必须修改理由，使其成为逮捕令一般情况的一个很好的例子，这也可能意味着产生新的证据来支持这个新理由：

So even if that statement about rising violence among children is true, it can’t justify the claim. To fix that argument, we have to revise the reason to be a good instance of the warrant’s general circumstance, which may also mean producing new evidence to support that new reason:

当孩子们不断地接触到虐待狂暴力的画面时，他们会受到更坏的影响。warrant在过去十年中，视频游戏已成为儿童接触暴力图像的主要来源。Jones (2014) 的新原因表明 . . . 新证据鉴于这些事实，暴力电子游戏似乎极有可能对当今的年轻人产生破坏性影响，使他们比上一代人更加暴力。宣称

When children are constantly exposed to images of sadistic violence, they are influenced for the worse.warrant Over the past decade, video games have become a major source of children’s exposure to violent imagery.new reason Jones (2014) shows that . . .new evidence Given these facts, it seems highly likely that violent video games are exerting a destructive influence on today’s youth, making them significantly more violent than their counterparts from a generation ago.claim

现在，原因和观点似乎更接近逮捕令涵盖或包括的内容：

Now the reason and claim seem closer to what the warrant covers or includes:

但热衷于破坏论点的读者可能仍然反对：

But a reader keen to derail the argument might still object:

等待。所有这些图像都不是“虐待狂”。其中大部分是卡通暴力。孩子们不会经常接触它。

Wait. All those images aren’t “sadistic.” Much of it is cartoon violence. And children aren’t constantly exposed to it.

作为回应，作者将不得不处理这些问题。

In response, the writer would have to deal with those issues.

现在你明白了为什么重要的问题会如此无休止地争论不休，为什么即使你觉得你的案子是无懈可击的，你的读者仍然可以说，等一下。关于什么 。. . ？读者可以通过两种方式质疑理由。他们可以反对您的理由没有可靠的证据，或者它们似乎与观点无关。要回答第一种反对意见，您必须找到更好的证据。要回答第二类问题，您必须提供使您的理由相关的保证。如果你不能，你必须修改你的论点。

Now you understand why important issues are so endlessly contested, why, even when you feel your case is airtight, your readers can still say, Wait a minute. What about . . . ? Readers can challenge reasons in two ways. They can object that your reasons are not grounded on sound evidence or that they seem irrelevant to a claim. To answer the first sort of objection, you must find better evidence. To answer the second sort, you must provide a warrant that makes your reasons relevant. If you can’t, you must revise your argument.

11.7 质疑他人的授权

11.7 CHALLENGING OTHERS’ WARRANTS

最难提出的论点是那些不仅挑战研究团体接受的主张和证据，而且挑战它所拥护的保证的论点。没有比辩论更难的任务了，因为当您挑战社区的保证时，您要求读者不仅改变他们的信仰，而且改变他们的推理方式。要想成功挑战授权令，你必须首先想象那些接受授权令的人会如何捍卫它。认股权证可以基于不同类型的支持论据，因此您必须以不同的方式对它们提出质疑。

The most difficult arguments to make are those that challenge not just the claims and evidence that a research community accepts but also the warrants it embraces. No argumentative task is harder, because when you challenge a community’s warrants, you ask readers to change not just what they believe but how they reason. To challenge a warrant successfully, you must first imagine how those who accept it would defend it. Warrants can be based on different kinds of supporting arguments, so you have to challenge them in different ways.

11.7.1根据经验挑战权证

11.7.1 Challenging Warrants Based on Experience

我们根据我们的经验或其他人的报告做出一些保证。

We base some warrants on our experience or on reports by others.

当人们习惯性地撒谎时，我们就不会相信他们。

When people habitually lie, we don’t trust them.

当杀虫剂渗入生态系统时，野生鸟类的蛋壳变得非常脆弱，孵化的雏鸟减少，鸟类数量下降。

When insecticides leach into the ecosystem, eggshells of wild birds become so weak that fewer chicks hatch and the bird population falls.

要挑战这些保证，您有两种选择，两者都很困难：(1) 挑战体验的可靠性，这很少容易；(2) 找到不能作为特例排除的反例。

To challenge those warrants, you have two choices, both difficult: (1) challenge the reliability of the experience, which is rarely easy; (2) find counterexamples that cannot be dismissed as special cases.

11.7.2基于权限挑战授权

11.7.2 Challenging Warrants Based on Authority

我们相信某些人是因为他们的专业知识、地位或魅力。

We believe some people because of their expertise, position, or charisma.

当权威 X 说 Y 时，Y 必须如此。

When authority X says Y, Y must be so.

挑战权威的最简单和最友好的方式是争辩说，在所讨论的问题上，权威没有所有证据或超出其专业知识范围。最激进的方法是争辩说来源实际上根本不是权威。

The easiest—and friendliest—way to challenge an authority is to argue that, on the matter in question, the authority does not have all the evidence or reaches beyond its expertise. The most aggressive way is to argue that the source is in fact not an authority at all.

11.7.3基于知识系统的挑战权证

11.7.3 Challenging Warrants Based on Systems of Knowledge

这些保证由定义、原则或理论系统支持：

These warrants are backed by systems of definitions, principles, or theories:

来自 数学：当我们将两个奇数相加时，我们得到一个偶数。

FROM MATHEMATICS: When we add two odd numbers, we get an even one.

来自 生物学：当一个有机体进行有性繁殖时，其个体后代会有所不同。

FROM BIOLOGY: When an organism reproduces sexually, its individual offspring differ.

来自 法律：当我们无照驾驶时，我们犯了轻罪。

FROM LAW: When we drive without a license, we commit a misdemeanor.

当您质疑这些认股权证时，“事实”在很大程度上是无关紧要的。您必须要么挑战系统，这总是很困难，要么表明案件不属于搜查令范围。

When you challenge these warrants, “facts” are largely irrelevant. You must either challenge the system, always difficult, or show that the case does not fall under the warrant.

11.7.4挑战一般文化保证

11.7.4 Challenging General Cultural Warrants

这些保证不是基于个人经验，而是基于整个文化的共同经验。对于那种文化的成员来说，他们似乎是无懈可击的“常识”。

These warrants are backed not by individual experience but by the common experience of an entire culture. To members of that culture, they seem unassailable “common sense.”

眼不见，心不烦。

Out of sight, out of mind.

侮辱是报复的理由。

An insult justifies retaliation.

处理蟾蜍会导致疣。

Handling toads causes warts.

像这样的认股权证可能会随着时间的推移而变化，但速度很慢。你可以挑战他们，但读者会抵制，因为你似乎在挑战他们的传统。

Warrants like these may change over time, but slowly. You can challenge them, but readers will resist, because you seem to be challenging their heritage.

11.7.5 具有挑战性的方法论保证

11.7.5 Challenging Methodological Warrants

将这些视为“元保证”，即在应用于特定案例之前没有内容的一般思维模式。我们用它们来解释抽象推理（它们是许多谚语的来源）：

Think of these as “meta-warrants,” general patterns of thought with no content until applied to specific cases. We use them to explain abstract reasoning (they are the source of many proverbs):

泛化：当 X 的每个已知案例都具有质量 Y 时，那么所有 X 可能都具有质量 Y。（看过一个，都看过。）

GENERALIZATION: When every known case of X has quality Y, then all Xs probably have quality Y. (Seen one, seen them all.)

类比：当 X 在大多数方面都像 Y 时，那么 X 在其他方面也会像 Y。（有其父必有其子。）

ANALOGY: When X is like Y in most respects, then X will be like Y in other respects. (Like father, like son.)

符号：当 Y 经常出现在 X 之前、期间或之后时，Y 是 X 的符号。（冷手，暖心。）

SIGN: When Y regularly occurs before, during, or after X, Y is a sign of X. (Cold hands, warm heart.)

哲学家质疑这些保证，但在实际论证的问题上，我们仅质疑它们的应用或指出限制条件：是的，我们可以将 X 类比为 Y，但不能将 . . .

Philosophers have questioned these warrants, but in matters of practical argumentation, we challenge only their application or point out limiting conditions: Yes, we can analogize X to Y, but not if . . .

11.7.6根据信条质疑保证

11.7.6 Challenging Warrants Based on Articles of Faith

有些保证是无可置疑的：杰斐逊在写道时援引了一个保证，我们认为这些真理是不言而喻的，即人人生而平等。. . . 其他包括

Some warrants are beyond challenge: Jefferson invoked one when he wrote, We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal. . . . Others include

当一个观点被体验为揭示的真理时，它必须是真实的。

When a claim is experienced as revealed truth, it must be true.

当一个观点是基于神圣的教义时，它必须是真实的。

When a claim is based on divine teaching, it must be true.

这样的保证不是由证据支持的，而是由拥护它们的人的确定性支持的。挑战它们毫无意义，因为它们是信仰的陈述，不受争论或证据的影响。如果您在收集数据时遇到它们，请忽略它们或不将它们视为研究对象，而是将其视为对生命意义的探究。

Such warrants are backed not by evidence but by the certainty of those who espouse them. It is pointless to challenge them, because they are statements of faith, impervious to argument or evidence. If you encounter them as you gather your data, ignore them or treat them not as a subject for research but as an inquiry into the meaning of life.

快速提示：原因、证据和保证

Quick Tip: Reasons, Evidence, and Warrants

您可以通过两种方式证明您的理由：通过提供证据来支持它们或通过搜查令得出它们。这些方法中的每一种都会导致不同类型的争论。研究人员通常更相信第一种而不是第二种，所以尽可能将你的理由建立在确凿的证据上。比较这两个参数：

You can justify your reasons in two ways: by offering evidence to support them or by deriving them from a warrant. Each of these ways leads to a different kind of argument. Researchers generally trust the first kind more than the second, so base your reasons on solid evidence when you can. Compare these two arguments:

我们应该尽我们所能阻止青少年发短信和开车，因为分心驾驶是青少年死亡的主要原因。原因根据疾病预防控制中心 (CDC) 的数据，机动车事故占 12-19 岁人群死亡人数的三分之一以上，而开车时发短信会成倍增加任何驾驶员卷入其中的可能性。而且， 。. . 证据

We should do what we can to discourage teenagers from texting and driving,claim because distracted driving is a leading cause of teenage deaths.reason According to the CDC, motor vehicle accidents are responsible for over a third of all fatalities among people aged 12–19, and texting while driving exponentially increases the likelihood that any driver will be involved in one. Moreover, . . .evidence

我们应该尽我们所能阻止青少年发短信和开车，因为当他们这样做时，他们发生事故的风险就会增加。原因 1开车很困难，发短信会分散注意力，原因 2 支持原因 1我们知道，当人们在执行复杂任务时分心时，他们的表现会受到影响。保证链接原因 2 和原因 1

We should do what we can to discourage teenagers from texting and driving,claim because when they do, their risk of having an accident increases.reason 1 Driving is difficult and texting a distraction,reason 2 supporting reason 1 and we know that when people are distracted while performing complex tasks, their performance suffers.warrant linking reason 2 and reason 1

如果你像大多数当代读者一样，你可能更喜欢这些论点中的第一个。那是因为它的保证没有争议（因此不言而喻）并且它的主张得到基于确凿证据的理由的支持。第二个论点是有道理的，因为理由 1 和理由 2 是该保证的一般后果和条件的很好的例子。但大多数读者仍然需要证据。

If you are like most contemporary readers, you probably preferred the first of these arguments. That’s because its warrant is not controversial (and therefore goes without saying) and its claim is supported by a reason based on solid evidence. That second argument is plausible because reason 1 and reason 2 are good instances of that warrant’s general consequence and condition. But most readers still want evidence.

特别是，您不能仅凭保证和理由来支持事实主张（请参阅 8.1）：

In particular, you can’t support a claim of fact (see 8.1) with a warrant and reason alone:

发短信和开车是导致青少年死亡的主要原因，这是事实，因为开车时发短信会让人分心。原因当司机分心时，他们会增加发生严重甚至致命事故的风险。保证

Texting and driving is a leading cause of teenage deaths,claim of fact because texting while driving is very distracting.reason When drivers are distracted, they increase their risk of having serious even fatal accidents.warrant

你是不是在想，我可以相信，但我想要一些证据？这种常识性反应很能说明问题。我们不能只是推理我们的方式结论是开车时发短信是导致青少年死亡的主要原因，甚至根本不会导致青少年死亡。除了少数几个领域——数学、哲学、神学的一些分支——证明事实主张的方法是用证据表明你所主张的事实确实如此。

Are you thinking, I could believe that, but I’d like some proof? That commonsense response is telling. We can’t just reason our way to the conclusion that texting while driving is a leading cause of teen fatalities, or even that it causes teen fatalities at all. Except in a few fields—some branches of mathematics, philosophy, theology—the way to demonstrate a claim of fact is to show with evidence that what you are claiming is, in fact, the case.

教训是：只要有可能，不要依靠基于保证的详尽推理，而要依靠确凿的证据。

The lesson is this: whenever you can, rely not on elaborate lines of reasoning based on warrants but on hard evidence.

第四部分

PART IV

写下你的论点

Writing Your Argument

序幕

Prologue

重新规划

Planning Again

没有公式可以告诉您何时开始起草。许多作家开始时没有一个完整的计划，随着事情变得更加清晰，他们不得不丢弃好的但不相关的页面。如果没有多个大纲和摘要，其他人就无法开始。我们中的一些人在转向认真的书面草稿之前就已经在脑海中构思了草稿。你必须找到自己的方式来开始初稿，但如果你从一开始就通过总结、分析和评论的方式继续写论文，你就可以为那一刻做好准备。

No formula can tell you when to start drafting. Many writers begin without a full plan, and as things become clearer, they have to discard good but irrelevant pages. Others can’t get going without multiple outlines and summaries. And some of us compose drafts in our heads well before turning to a serious draft in writing. You have to find your own way to start a first draft, but you can prepare for that moment if you keep writing your way toward the paper from the start through summaries, analyses, and critiques.

以下是您知道何时准备好计划草稿的方式：

Here’s how you know when you’re ready to plan a draft:

• 您知道您的读者是谁，他们知道什么，以及他们为什么要关心您的问题。

• You know who your readers are, what they know, and why they should care about your problem.

• 你知道你想要表现的精神或品格。

• You know the kind of ethos or character you want to project.

• 你可以用两三句话勾勒出你的问题及其答案。

• You can sketch your question and its answer in two or three sentences.

• 您可以勾勒出支持您的主张的理由和证据。

• You can sketch the reasons and evidence supporting your claim.

• 您知道您的读者可能提出的问题、备选方案和异议，并且您可以回应他们。

• You know the questions, alternatives, and objections that your readers are likely to raise, and you can respond to them.

• 您知道您的读者何时可能看不到理由与主张的相关性，并且可以陈述将他们联系起来的保证。

• You know when your readers may not see the relevance of a reason to a claim and can state the warrant that connects them.

然而，即使他们有了计划并准备起草，有经验的作家也知道他们不会直接进入成品。他们知道他们会走入死胡同，但也会有新发现，甚至可能会重新考虑他们的整个项目。他们也知道他们早期的很多草稿不会它进入他们的最终草案，因此他们开始得足够早，以便留出时间进行修改。

Even when they have a plan and are ready to draft, though, experienced writers know that they won’t march straight through to a finished product. They know they’ll go down blind alleys, but also make new discoveries, maybe even rethink their whole project. They also know that a lot of their early drafting will not make it into their final draft, and so they start early enough to leave time for revision.

整理术语：假设、答案、解决方案、主张、观点

Sorting Out Terms: Hypothesis, Answer, Solution, Claim, Point

在第二部分中，我们使用术语answer、hypothesis和solution来命名解决研究中心问题的句子。在第 III 部分中，我们使用术语主要主张来指代构成您的论证其余部分所支持的关键断言的答案、假设或解决方案。在第四部分中，我们使用点来命名论文中陈述主要主张的句子（有些人使用术语thesis）。假设、答案、解决方案、主张和观点——所有这些术语指的是同一个句子。我们使用不同的术语，因为每个术语都从不同的角度定义了该句子的作用。

In part II we used the terms answer, hypothesis, and solution to name the sentence that resolved the central issue of your research. In part III we used the term main claim to refer to the answer, hypothesis, or solution that constitutes the key assertion that the rest of your argument supports. Here in part IV we use point to name the sentence that states the main claim in a paper (some use the term thesis). Hypothesis, answer, solution, claim, and point—all those terms refer to the same sentence. We use different terms because each defines the role of that sentence from a different angle.

第四部分将引导您完成最终论文的创作过程。在第 12 章中，我们将介绍计划和起草，然后在第 13 章中组织你的论点。在第 14 章中，我们讨论了合并和引用来源的艰巨任务。在第 15 章中，我们讨论了如何以视觉形式呈现定量数据，在第 16 章中，我们讨论了如何撰写有效的介绍和结论。最后，在第 17 章中，我们以清晰直接的风格处理写作问题。

Part IV will lead you through the process of creating your final paper. In chapter 12 we walk through planning and drafting, then in chapter 13 organizing your argument. In chapter 14 we discuss the demanding task of incorporating and citing sources. In chapter 15 we discuss how to present quantitative data in visual form, and in chapter 16 how to write effective introductions and conclusions. Finally, in chapter 17 we deal with problems of writing in a clear and direct style.

12 规划与起草

12  Planning and Drafting

一旦你整理好你的论点，你就可以准备好起草它了。但是经验丰富的作家知道，花在计划初稿上的时间比开始写作时得到的回报要多。计划可帮助您将论点的要素组织成一种对读者既连贯又具有说服力的形式。

Once you’ve assembled your argument, you might be ready to draft it. But experienced writers know that time spent planning a first draft more than pays off when they start writing it. A plan helps you organize the elements of your argument into a form that will be both coherent and persuasive to your readers.

有些领域规定了研究报告的计划。例如，在实验科学中，读​​者希望报告遵循这样的计划：

Some fields stipulate the plan of a research report. In the experimental sciences, for example, readers expect reports to follow a plan something like this:

介绍——方法和材料——结果——讨论——结论

Introduction – Methods and Materials – Results – Discussion – Conclusion

如果您的领域要求您遵循常规计划，请向您的老师索取模型或在二手资料中找到一个。然而，在大多数领域，你必须制定自己的计划，但该计划仍必须帮助读者找到他们正在寻找的东西。

If your field requires you to follow a conventional plan, ask your teacher for a model or find one in a secondary source. In most fields, however, you have to create a plan of your own, but that plan must still help readers find what they are looking for.

12.1 计划你的论文

12.1 PLANNING YOUR PAPER

12.1.1草拟工作简介

12.1.1 Sketch a Working Introduction

通常建议作家最后写介绍。一些作家可以等到写完最后一句话再写第一句话，但我们大多数人都需要一个有效的介绍来让我们走上正轨。准备写两次你的介绍，现在为你自己写一个粗略的介绍，然后为你的读者写最后一个。最后的介绍通常分为三个部分（见第 16 章），所以你不妨勾勒出你的工作介绍来预测它们。

Writers are often advised to write their introductions last. A few writers can wait until they’ve written their last words before they write their first ones, but most of us need a working introduction to start us on the right track. Expect to write your introduction twice, a sketchy one for yourself right now, then later a final one for your readers. That final introduction will usually have three parts (see chapter 16), so you might as well sketch your working introduction to anticipate them.

1. 在你的故事板第一页的顶部， 仅对与你的论点最相关的来源中的关键点进行简要 总结。 一个边缘相关的帐户 参考资料在您的介绍中没有位置。仅总结您打算挑战、修改或扩展的来源。然后以对读者有用的方式对这些资源进行排序：按时间顺序、质量、重要性、观点等。在任何情况下都不要按照你碰巧阅读它们的顺序或将它们记录在你的笔记中。如果您确定此摘要中包含哪些内容，只需按有用的顺序列出来源即可。

1. At the top of the first page of your storyboard, sketch a brief summary of only the key points in only those sources most relevant to your argument.
