An account of marginally relevant references has no place in your introduction. Summarize only the sources that you intend to challenge, modify, or expand on. Then order those sources in a way that is useful to your readers: chronologically, by quality, significance, point of view, and so on. Under no circumstances follow the order in which you happened to read them or record them in your notes. If you’re sure what will go into this summary, just list the sources in a useful order.

2. 在对资源进行总结之后，将您的问题改写为关于您在其中看到的缺陷或差距的陈述：

2. After your summary of sources, rephrase your question as a statement about a flaw or gap that you see in them:

为什么阿拉莫的故事在我们的民族神话中如此重要？

Why is the Alamo story so important in our national mythology?

→然而，这些历史学家中很少有人解释为什么阿拉莫的故事在我们的民族神话中变得如此重要。

→ Few of these historians, however, have explained why the Alamo story has become so important in our national mythology.

3. 草拟一个答案 如果我们找不到怎么办？您可能只是在猜测，但请尝试找到一些答案。

3. Sketch an answer to So what if we don’t find out? You may be only guessing but try to find some answer.

如果我们了解这些故事如何成为民族传奇，我们就会更好地理解我们的民族价值观，甚至可能是什么让我们与众不同。

If we understood how such stories become national legends, we would better understand our national values, perhaps even what makes us distinct.

如果你想不出任何答案那又怎样？， 跳过它; 我们将在第 13 章回到它。

If you can’t think of any answer to So what?, skip it; we’ll return to it in chapter 13.

4. 陈述你的问题的答案作为你的观点，或者在出发点承诺一个答案。你在这里有两个选择：

4. State the answer to your question as your point, or promise an answer in a launching point. You have two choices here:

• 在引言的末尾陈述论文的要点，以构架接下来的内容，并在接近结论的开头再次陈述。

• State the point of your paper at the end of your introduction to frame what follows and again near the beginning of your conclusion.

• 只在你的结论中陈述它，作为你推理的高潮。

• State it only in your conclusion, as a climax to your reasoning.

这是一个至关重要的选择，因为它与读者建立了社会契约。如果你在介绍的最后陈述你的主要观点，你就让你的读者负责：读者，你控制如何阅读这篇论文。你知道我的问题及其解决方案，我的观点。您可以决定如何——甚至是否——继续阅读。没有惊喜。另一方面，如果你等到你的结论才陈述你的主要主张，你创造了一种更具控制力的关系：读者，你必须跟随我走过每一个曲折，直到我们到达终点，我将最终揭示我的观点。大多数读者更喜欢在介绍的末尾看到您的主要观点，因为这样他们可以更快地阅读接下来的内容，更好地理解其相关性，并更长久地记住它。尽早陈述你的主张也有助于让你走上正轨。

This is a crucial choice, because it creates your social contract with your readers. If you state your main point toward the end of your introduction, you put your readers in charge: Reader, you control how to read this paper. You know my problem and its solution, my point. You can decide how—even whether—to read on. No surprises. On the other hand, if you wait until your conclusion to state your main claim, you create a more controlling relationship: Reader, you must follow me though every twist and turn until we reach the end, where I will finally reveal my point. Most readers prefer to see your main point at the end of your introduction, because that lets them read what follows faster, understand its relevance better, and remember it all longer. Stating your claim early also helps keep you on track.

一些新的研究人员担心，如果他们过早地揭示他们的主要观点，读者会感到“无聊”并停止阅读。其他人则担心重蹈覆辙。这两种恐惧都是毫无根据的。如果你问了一个有趣的问题，读者会想看看你能回答得如何。

Some new researchers fear that if they reveal their main point too early, readers will be “bored” and stop reading. Others worry about repeating themselves. Both fears are baseless. If you ask an interesting question, readers will want to see how well you can answer it.

如果你决定只在结论中宣布你的主张，你仍然需要在引言末尾用一句话来引导读者进入论文的正文。该句子应包括命名将贯穿您论文的关键概念的术语（参见 6.6.1、8.2.1、12.1.2）。起草最终介绍后，您会更好地准备写启动句。因此，为了计划的目的，将您的主要观点放在故事板介绍页面的底部；你可以稍后移动它。

If you decide to announce your claim only in your conclusion, you still need a sentence at the end of your introduction that launches your reader into the body of your paper. That sentence should include terms that name the key concepts that will run through your paper (see 6.6.1, 8.2.1, 12.1.2). You’ll be better prepared to write that launching sentence after you draft your final introduction. So for purposes of planning, put your main claim at the bottom of your storyboard’s introduction page; you can move it later.

一些作者在介绍的末尾添加了一张“路线图”：

Some writers add a “road map” at the end their introduction:

在第 1 部分中，我讨论了 . . . 第 2 部分地址。. . 第 3 部分检查。. .

In part 1, I discuss the issue of . . . Part 2 addresses . . . Part 3 examines . . .

路线图在社会科学中很常见，但在人文学科中，许多人发现它们很笨拙。您可以在故事板中添加路线图以指导起草，然后将其从最终草稿中删除。如果保留它，请将其缩短。

Road maps are common in the social sciences, but many in the humanities find them clumsy. You can add a road map to your storyboard to guide your drafting, then cut it from your final draft. If you keep it, make it short.

这是故事板第一页现在的样子：

Here is how the first page of your storyboard might now look:

研究表明，十八岁以下的女运动员患脑震荡的风险几乎是从事相同运动的同龄男运动员的两倍。上下文[主要来源摘要如下。]

Research has shown that female athletes under eighteen have almost twice the risk of sustaining concussions as male athletes of the same age who play the same sports.context [Summary of key sources follows.]

但该研究几乎没有揭示造成这种差异的原因。问题改写为研究差距

But that research reveals little about the causes of this discrepancy.question rephrased as gap in research

在我们了解为什么女性运动员比男性运动员遭受脑震荡的比例更高之前，我们无法知道保护她们的最有效方法。问题的后果

Until we understand why female athletes suffer proportionally more concussions than their male counterparts, we can’t know the most effective ways to protect them.consequences of question

这种差异似乎部分是由于男女运动员佩戴的防护装备不同，以及发生伤害时的监测、报告和护理标准不同。你暂定的要点

The discrepancy appears to be due in part to differences in the protective equipment worn by male and female athletes as well as to different standards of monitoring, reporting, and care when injuries occur.your tentative main point

虽然很粗略，但这个介绍足以让您走上正轨。在你的最终草案中，你将修改它以更完整地陈述你的问题（见第 16 章）。

Sketchy as it is, this introduction is enough to start you on track. In your final draft, you’ll revise it to state your problem more completely (see chapter 16).

12.1.2确定贯穿整篇论文的关键概念

12.1.2 Identify Key Concepts That Will Run Through Your Whole Paper

为了使您的论文看起来连贯，读者必须看到贯穿其所有部分的一些关键概念。您可能会在用于对笔记进行分类的术语中找到它们，但它们必须包括来自陈述您的问题和要点的句子中的关键字。在介绍页上，圈出四五个表达这些概念的词。忽略命名您的一般主题的词；专注于与您的特定问题相关的那些：

For your paper to seem coherent, readers must see a few key concepts running through all of its parts. You might find them among the terms you used to categorize your notes, but they must include keywords from the sentences stating your problem and main point. On the introduction page, circle four or five words that express those concepts. Ignore words that name your general topic; focus on those relevant to your specific question:

就业、工作满意度、最近的东南亚移民、跨文化、居住时间、之前的经济水平

employment, job satisfaction, recent SE Asian immigrants, cross-cultural, length of residence, prior economic level

如果你发现几个关键术语，你的主题和观点可能过于笼统（回顾 8.2.1）。在每个故事板页面的顶部列出这些关键术语，并在起草时牢记它们。

If you find few key terms, your topic and point may be too general (review 8.2.1). List those key terms at the top of each storyboard page, and keep them in mind as you draft.

12.1.3计划论文的主体

12.1.3 Plan the Body of Your Paper

1. 勾勒背景并定义术语。在故事板的介绍页之后，添加一个概述必要背景的页面。您可能需要定义术语、阐明您的问题或更详细地审查研究、为您的项目设置限制、在更大的历史或社会背景中定位您的问题等等。保持简短。

1. Sketch background and define terms. After the introduction page of your storyboard, add a page on which you outline necessary background. You may have to define terms, spell out your problem or review research in more detail, set limits on your project, locate your problem in a larger historical or social context, and so on. Keep it short.

2. 为论文的每个主要部分创建一个页面。在每一页的顶部，写下该部分其余部分的要点支持、发展或解释。通常，这将是支持您的主要主张的理由。

2. Create a page for each major section of your paper. At the top of each of these pages, write the point that the rest of that section supports, develops, or explains. Usually, this will be a reason supporting your main claim.

3.找到合适的顺序。当你组装你的论点（见 9.1）时，你以一种你可能已经清楚的方式排列了它的各个部分。但是当你计划一个草稿时，你必须以一种满足读者需求的方式来排列它们。当您不确定该顺序应该是什么时，请考虑这些选项。前两个基于您的主题：

3. Find a suitable order. When you assembled your argument (see 9.1), you ordered its parts in a way that may have been clear to you. But when you plan a draft, you must order them in a way that meets the needs of your readers. When you’re not sure what that order should be, consider these options. The first two are based on your topic:

•逐个部分。如果你能把你的主题分成几个部分，你就可以依次处理每个部分，但你仍然必须按照有助于读者理解的方式对这些部分进行排序——按照它们的功能关系、层次结构等。

• Part-by-part. If you can break your topic into its parts, you can deal with each in turn, but you must still order those parts in a way that helps readers understand them—by their functional relationships, hierarchy, and so on.

•按时间顺序。这是最简单的：从早到晚或因果关系。

• Chronological. This is the simplest: earlier to later or cause to effect.

接下来的六个是基于读者的知识和理解。

These next six are based on your readers’ knowledge and understanding.

•从短到长，从简单到复杂。大多数读者更愿意先处理简单的问题，然后再处理更复杂的问题。

• Short to long, simple to complex. Most readers prefer to deal with simple issues before they work through more complex ones.

•从熟悉到不熟悉。大多数读者在阅读新问题之前更喜欢阅读更熟悉的问题。

• More familiar to less familiar. Most readers prefer to read about more familiar issues before they read about new ones.

•竞争性降低到竞争性增加。大多数读者更容易从他们同意的内容转移到他们不同意的内容。

• Less contestable to more contestable. Most readers move more easily from what they agree with to what they don’t.

•重要到不重要（反之亦然）。读者更喜欢先阅读更重要的原因（但这些原因如果放在最后可能会产生更大的影响）。

• More important to less important (or vice versa). Readers prefer to read more important reasons first (but those reasons may have more impact if they come last).

•为以后的理解做准备的早期理解。读者可能必须先了解一些事件、原理、定义等，然后才能理解其他内容。

• Earlier understanding to prepare for later understanding. Readers may have to understand some events, principles, definitions, and so on before they understand something else.

•一般分析，然后是具体应用。读者可能必须先了解您的总体立场的概要，然后才能了解您如何将其应用于特定的文本、事件、情况等。

• General analysis followed by specific applications. Readers may have to understand the outlines of your overall position before they can follow how you apply it to specific texts, events, situations, and so on.

通常这些原则相互配合：读者同意并容易理解的内容也可能是简短而熟悉的。但这些原则也可能发生冲突：读者可能会拒绝最快的理由这是最重要的。无论您的顺序如何，它都必须反映读者的需求，而不是材料似乎强加给自己的顺序（如在明显的比较对比组织中），尤其是您想到这些原因的顺序。

Often these principles cooperate: what readers agree with and easily understand might also be short and familiar. But these principles may also conflict: readers might reject most quickly reasons that are most important. Whatever your order, it must reflect your readers’ needs, not the order that the material seems to impose on itself (as in an obvious compare-contrast organization), least of all the order in which those reasons occurred to you.

最后，通过在每页顶部草绘显示它的单词来明确您选择的顺序原则：首先 。. . ,第二 。. . ; 后来 。. . ，终于 。. . ; 更重要的是 。. . ; 一个更复杂的问题是 。. . ; 结果 。. . 如果这些术语让人感到尴尬，请不要担心。在这一点上，它们是为了您的利益，而不是您的读者的利益。您可以修改甚至从最终草稿中删除它们。

Finally, make the principle of order you choose clear by sketching at the top of each page words that show it: First . . . , second . . . ; Later . . . , finally . . . ; More important . . . ; A more complex issue is . . . ; As a result . . . Don’t worry if these terms feel awkward. At this point, they’re for your benefit, not your readers’. You can revise or even delete them from your final draft.

12.1.4规划每个部分和子部分

12.1.4 Plan Each Section and Subsection

1. 突出每个部分和小节中的关键术语。正如您的论文需要介绍一样，它的每个部分也需要介绍。早些时候我们告诉您在故事板页面的顶部说明每个部分的要点。现在，正如您选择贯穿整篇论文的关键术语一样，圈出将本节与其他所有部分区分开来的那些；他们应该在陈述该部分要点的句子中。如果找不到区分某个部分的术语，请仔细查看它对整体的贡献。它可能提供很少或没有。

1. Highlight the key terms in each section and subsection. Just as your paper needs an introduction, so does each of its sections. Earlier we told you to state the point of each section at the top of its storyboard page. Now, just as you picked out key terms to run through your whole paper, circle the ones that uniquely distinguish this section from all the others; they should be in the sentence that states the point of that section. If you cannot find terms to distinguish a section, look closely at how it contributes to the whole. It may offer little or nothing.

2. 指出放置证据、确认书、保证书和摘要的位置。将这些部分添加到每个部分的故事板页面。反过来，他们可能需要得到自己论点的支持。

2. Indicate where to put evidence, acknowledgments, warrants, and summaries. Add these parts to the storyboard page for each section. They may, in turn, need to be supported by their own arguments.

•证据。大多数部分都包含支持理由的证据。如果您有不同类型的证据支持相同的原因，请以对读者有意义的方式对它们进行分组和排序。请注意您可能必须在何处解释您的证据——它来自哪里，为什么它是可靠的，它究竟如何支持一个原因。

• Evidence. Most sections consist of evidence supporting a reason. If you have different kinds of evidence supporting the same reason, group and order them in a way that makes sense to readers. Note where you may have to explain your evidence—where it came from, why it’s reliable, exactly how it supports a reason.

•致谢和回应。想象一下读者可能会反对什么，然后概述一个回应。回应可能是带有主张、理由、证据的子论证，甚至是对你的回应的想象回应的另一种回应。

• Acknowledgments and responses. Imagine what readers might object to, then outline a response. Responses may be sub-arguments with a claim, reasons, evidence, and even another response to an imagined response to your response.

•认股权证。一般而言，如果您需要手令，请在提出观点和支持理由之前说明。这以下例如，如果论点是为伊丽莎白时代社会历史方面的非专家准备的，则需要搜查令：

• Warrants. Generally speaking, if you need a warrant, state it before you offer its claim and supporting reason. This following argument, for example, needs a warrant if it’s intended for non-experts in Elizabethan social history:

由于 1580 年牛津大学的大多数学生在文件上签名时只写了名字和姓氏，因此他们中的大多数一定是平民。宣称

Since most students at Oxford University in 1580 signed documents with only their first and last names,reason most of them must have been commoners.claim

当通过逮捕令引入时，每个人（甚至专家）都更清楚这一论点：

That argument is clearer to everyone (even experts) when introduced by a warrant:

在 16 世纪后期的英国，当某人不是绅士而是平民时，他不会加上“先生”。或“Esq”。到他的签名。保证1580 年，牛津大学的大多数学生在签署文件时只留下了他们的名字和姓氏，因此他们中的大多数人一定是平民。宣称

In late sixteenth-century England, when someone was not a gentleman but a commoner, he did not add “Mr.” or “Esq.” to his signature.warrant Most students at Oxford University in 1580 signed documents with only their first and last names,reason so most of them must have been commoners.claim

如果您认为读者可能会质疑您的保证，请提出支持它的论据。

If you think readers might question your warrant, make an argument supporting it.

如果你的论文很长而且“事实很重”，有日期、名字、事件或数字，你可以通过简要总结你的论证进展来结束每个主要部分。你在那个部分建立了什么？到目前为止，你的论点如何形成？如果在您的最终草稿中，这些摘要看起来很笨拙，请将其删除。

If your paper is long and “fact-heavy” with dates, names, events, or numbers, you might end each major section by briefly summarizing the progress of your argument. What have you established in that section? How does your argument shape up so far? If in your final draft those summaries seem clumsy, cut them.

12.1.5 草拟工作结论

12.1.5 Sketch a Working Conclusion

在故事板的结论页顶部再次陈述您的观点。在它之后，如果可以的话，勾勒出它的意义（对那又怎样？的另一个回答）。

State your point again at the top of a conclusion page of your storyboard. After it, if you can, sketch its significance (another answer to So what?).

在做这一切的过程中，您可能会发现您无法使用所有收集的笔记。那并不意味着你浪费了时间。研究就像淘金：挖很多，挑出一点，把剩下的扔掉。欧内斯特·海明威说过，当你丢弃你知道是好的东西时，你就知道你写得很好——但不如你保留的东西好。

In doing all this, you may discover that you can’t use all the notes you collected. That doesn’t mean you wasted time. Research is like gold mining: dig up a lot, pick out a little, toss the rest. Ernest Hemingway said that you know you’re writing well when you discard stuff you know is good—but not as good as what you keep.

12.2 避免三种常见但有缺陷的计划

12.2 AVOIDING THREE COMMON BUT FLAWED PLANS

并非所有计划都同样好。我们最初的努力通常是追踪我们作为研究人员的思考或活动，而不是读者的经历。

Not all plans are equally good. Our first efforts often track our thinking or activities as researchers but not the experiences of readers.

1. 不要把你的论文组织成你思想的叙述。很少有读者想知道你首先发现了什么，然后是你遇到的死胡同，然后是你克服的问题。当他们不得不费力地浏览您的项目历史以达到您为结束而保存的要点时，他们会变得特别恼火。

1. Do not organize your paper as a narrative of your thinking. Few readers want to know what you found first, followed by the dead ends you hit, then the problems you overcame. They become especially annoyed when they have to slog through the history of your project to get to a main point you’ve saved for the end.

要测试你的草稿是否解决了这个问题，请寻找那些不是指你的研究结果而是指你是如何做的或你在想什么的句子。您可以在诸如The first issue was之类的语言中看到这种迹象 。. . ; 然后我比较了 。. . ; 最后，我总结一下。如果你发现了不止几个这样的句子，你可能不是在支持一个主张，而是在讲述你是如何找到它的。如果是这样，围绕你论点的核心要素——你的主张和支持它的理由——重新组织你的论文。

To test your draft for this problem, look for sentences that refer not to the results of your research but to how you did it or to what you were thinking. You see signs of this in language like The first issue was . . . ; Then I compared . . . ; Finally, I conclude. If you discover more than a few such sentences, you may not be supporting a claim but rather telling the story of how you found it. If so, reorganize your paper around the core elements of your argument—your claim and the reasons supporting it.

2. 不要把你的论文拼凑成你的来源。读者需要你的分析，而不是你的来源摘要。新手研究人员将引文、摘要和松散的释义串在一起，拼凑成一个几乎没有反映他们自己想法的拼凑物时，他们就犯了错误。这样的“打补丁”招来罪魁祸首这都是总结，没有分析。如果您在网上进行大部分研究，这是一个特别的风险，因为从您的资源中剪切和粘贴非常容易。有经验的读者会认出补丁编写，而你可能会被指控剽窃（见 14.6）。

2. Do not assemble your paper as a patchwork of your sources. Readers want your analysis, not a summary of your sources. Beginning researchers go wrong when they string together quotations, summaries, and loose paraphrases of sources into a patchwork that reflects little of their own thinking. Such “patch writing” invites the charge This is all summary, no analysis. It is a particular risk if you do most of your research online, because it is so easy to cut-and-paste from your sources. Experienced readers recognize patch writing, and you risk a charge of plagiarism (see 14.6).

高级研究人员很少提供拼凑的摘要，但他们可能会以另一种方式过于密切地关注来源：他们将自己的论文映射到主要来源的组织上，而不是创造一个更好地为他们的论点服务的新来源。如果贯穿你论文的关键术语与一个或多个来源中的相同，请考虑你是在提出自己的论点还是在模仿他们的论点。

Advanced researchers rarely offer patchwork summaries, but they can follow sources too closely in another way: they map their paper on to the organization of a major source rather than create a new one that serves their argument better. If the key terms that run through your paper are the same as those in one or more sources, consider whether you are making your own argument or mimicking theirs.

3. 不要将你的论文直接映射到你作业的语言上。如果你在第一段中重复你作业中的语言，你的老师可能会认为你没有贡献自己的想法，如下例所示：

3. Do not map your paper directly on to the language of your assignment. If you echo the language of your assignment in your first paragraph, your teacher may think that you’ve contributed no ideas of your own, as in this example:

作业：不同的知觉理论在处理感觉输入时给予认知中介不同的权重。一些人声称输入直接到达大脑；其他人认为接受器官受认知影响。比较在这个问题上采取不同立场的两种视觉、听觉或触觉感知理论。

ASSIGNMENT: Different theories of perception give different weight to cognitive mediation in processing sensory input. Some claim that input reaches the brain unmediated; others that receptive organs are subject to cognitive influence. Compare two theories of visual, aural, or tactile perception that take different positions on this matter.

论文 开篇 ：不同的视觉感知理论家对认知中介在处理感官输入中的作用给予不同的重视。在本文中，我将比较两种视觉感知理论，其中之一。. .

PAPER’S OPENING PARAGRAPH: Different theorists of visual perception give different weight to the role of cognitive mediation in processing sensory input. In this paper I will compare two theories of visual perception, one of which . . .

如果您的作业列出了一系列要涵盖的问题，请避免按给定的顺序解决它们。例如，如果你被要求“比较弗洛伊德和荣格在想象和无意识方面的差异”，你就不必将论文分为两部分，第一部分关于弗洛伊德，第二部分关于荣格。这种组织往往会导致一对不相关的摘要。相反，尝试将主题分解为它们的概念部分，例如无意识和想象的元素、它们的定义等；然后以对读者有用的方式对这些部分进行排序。

If your assignment lists a series of issues to cover, avoid addressing them in the order given. If, for example, you were asked to “compare and contrast Freud and Jung on the imagination and unconscious,” you would not have to organize your paper into two parts, the first on Freud and the second on Jung. That kind of organization too often results in a pair of unrelated summaries. Instead, try breaking the topics into their conceptual parts, such as elements of the unconscious and the imagination, their definitions, and so on; then order those parts in a way useful to your readers.

12.3 将你的计划变成草稿

12.3 TURNING YOUR PLAN INTO A DRAFT

一些作家认为，一旦他们有了大纲或故事板，他们就可以磨出句子了。有经验的作家更清楚。他们知道起草可以是一种计划永远无法取代的发现行为，因为那时我们经常会经历研究中最激动人心的时刻之一：我们发现了我们在表达之前没有的想法。但就像流程中的其他步骤一样，有了计划，即使是惊喜也会发生得更好。

Some writers think that once they have an outline or a storyboard, they can just grind out sentences. Experienced writers know better. They know that drafting can be an act of discovery that planning can never replace, because it is then that we often experience one of research’s most exciting moments: we discover ideas that we didn’t have until we expressed them. But like other steps in the process, even surprises happen better with a plan.

12.3.1以舒适的方式起草

12.3.1 Draft in a Way That Feels Comfortable

许多有经验的作家在写完故事板之前很久就开始写作了。他们制定一个粗略的计划，使用早期草稿探索他们的想法，然后根据他们的发现制定最终计划。他们知道早期写作的大部分内容不会生存，所以他们很早就开始了。探索性起草可以帮助你发现你从未想过的想法，但只有当你有一个遥远的截止日期时它才有效。如果您对您的主题不熟悉或截止日期很短，请在您有更清晰的计划时起草。

Many experienced writers begin to write long before they fill up their storyboard. They create a rough plan, use early drafts to explore what they think, then create a final plan based on what they discover. They know that much of that early writing will not survive, so they start early. Exploratory drafting can help you discover ideas you never imagined, but it works only if you have a distant deadline. If you are new to your topic or have a short deadline, draft when you have a clearer plan.

尽快开始起草

Start Drafting as Soon as You Can

截止日期来得太快了：我们渴望再过一个月、一周，再过一天。（我们为本书的每一版都争取到了最后期限。）事实上，一些研究人员似乎永远无法完成，认为他们必须继续工作，直到他们的论文、论文或书籍完美无缺。那篇完美的论文从来没有写过，也永远不会写出来。您所能做的就是在可用的时间内尽可能地做好自己的工作。当你这样做时，你可以对自己说：读者，经过我最大的努力，这就是我所相信的——不是全部或最终的真相，而是对我很重要的真相，我希望对你也很重要。在时间和我的能力允许的情况下，我已经尽可能全面地检验并支持这个真理，因此您可能会发现我的论点足够强大，可以考虑、或许可以接受，甚至可以改变您的信念。

Deadlines come too soon: we long for another month, a week, just one more day. (We fought deadlines for every edition of this book.) In fact, some researchers seem never able to finish, thinking they have to keep working until their paper, dissertation, or book is perfect. That perfect paper has never been written and never will be. All you can do is to make yours as good as you can in the time available. When you’ve done that, you can say to yourself: Reader, after my best efforts, here’s what I believe—not the whole or final truth, but a truth important to me and I hope to you. I have tested and supported that truth as fully as time and my abilities allow, so that you might find my argument strong enough to consider, perhaps to accept, maybe even to change what you believe.

一旦他们有了一个计划，许多作家就会快速起草：他们让文字流畅，省略他们可以稍后插入的引文和数据，当他们被卡住时跳过。如果他们不记得某个细节，他们会插入一个“[?]”并继续写，直到他们没油了，然后再回去查找。但是快速的起草者需要时间来修改，所以如果你起草得很快，那就早点开始吧。

Once they have a plan, many writers draft quickly: they let the words flow, omitting quotations and data that they can plug in later, skipping ahead when they get stuck. If they don’t remember a detail, they insert a “[?]” and keep writing until they run out of gas, then go back to look it up. But quick drafters need time to revise, so if you draft quickly, start early.

其他作家只能慢慢地、小心地工作：他们必须在开始下一个句子之前把每个句子都写对。为此，他们需要一个周密的计划。因此，如果您起草缓慢，请创建详细的大纲或故事板。

Other writers can work only slowly and carefully: they have to get every sentence right before they start the next one. To do that, they need a meticulous plan. So if you draft slowly, create a detailed outline or storyboard.

大多数作家在快速起草、仔细修改并剔除无关紧要的内容时表现最佳。但是以适合您的任何方式起草。

Most writers work best when they draft quickly, revise carefully, and toss what’s irrelevant. But draft in any way that works for you.

12.3.2使用关键词让自己走上正轨

12.3.2 Use Keywords to Keep Yourself on Track

起草的一个问题是保持正轨。故事板会有所帮助，但您也可以将关键概念放在眼前，并时不时地检查一下您使用它们的频率，尤其是那些区分每个部分。但不要让故事板或关键术语扼杀新思维。如果您发现自己在四处游荡，请沿着小路前行，直到您看到它会将您带到何处。你可能正在追踪一个有趣的想法。

One problem with drafting is staying on track. A storyboard helps, but you might also keep your key concepts in front of you and, from time to time, check how often you use them, especially those that distinguish each section. But don’t let your storyboard or key terms stifle fresh thinking. If you find yourself wandering, follow the trail until you see where it takes you. You may be on the track of an interesting idea.

即使您所在领域的论文不使用标题和副标题，我们也建议您在起草时使用。使用其标题的部分或小节所特有的单词创建每个标题：

Even if papers in your field don’t use headings and subheadings, we suggest that you do when you draft. Create each heading out of the words that are unique to the section or subsection it heads:

萨姆·休斯顿 (Sam Houston) 成为德克萨斯州以外报纸上的英雄

Sam Houston as a Hero in Newspapers Outside of Texas

这些标题还可以一目了然地显示您论文的结构（带编号的标题在某些社会科学中很常见，在人文学科中很少见）。如果您的领域不使用标题，请将它们从您的最终草案中删除。

These headings also show the structure of your paper at a glance (numbered headings are common in some social sciences, rare in the humanities). If your field doesn’t use heads, delete them from your final draft.

快速提示：克服拖延症和写作障碍

Quick Tip: Work Through Procrastination and Writer’s Block

如果您不能开始写作，或者连草拟几个字都费劲，您可能遇到了写作障碍。一些案例源于对学校及其压力的焦虑；如果那可能是你，请咨询辅导员。但大多数情况都有您可以解决的原因：

If you can’t start writing or you struggle to draft even a few words, you may have writer’s block. Some cases arise from anxieties about school and its pressures; if that might be you, see a counselor. But most cases have causes you can address:

• 您对这项任务感到非常害怕，以至于您不知道从哪里开始。如果是这样，将流程分成小任务；然后一次专注于一个步骤。

• You feel so intimidated by the task that you don’t know where to begin. If so, divide the process into small tasks; then focus on one step at a time.

• 您没有设定任何目标或设定过高的目标。如果是这样，请创建一个例程来设定您可以实现的目标，然后使用诸如进度表或与写作伙伴定期会面之类的工具。

• You have set no goals or goals that are too high. If so, create a routine that sets goals you can meet, then use devices such as a progress chart or regular meetings with a writing partner.

• 你觉得你必须让每个句子或段落都完美无缺，然后才能继续下一个句子或段落。如果你在写作过程中随意写作，告诉自己你写作只是为了帮助你在纸上思考，你就可以避免对完美的痴迷。无论如何，要知道每个研究人员都会为了完成工作而在完美上做出妥协。

• You feel you must make every sentence or paragraph perfect before you move to the next one. You can avoid some obsession with perfection if you write informally along the way, telling yourself you are writing only to help you think on paper. In any event, know that every researcher compromises on perfection to get the job done.

如果您遇到此类问题，请前往学生学习中心。那里的顾问曾与各种拖延者和受阻的作家一起工作，可以为您提供针对您的问题的建议。

If you have problems like these, go to the student learning center. Advisers there have worked with every kind of procrastinator and blocked writer and can give you advice tailored to your problem.

另一方面，一些写作障碍的案例可能真的是让你的想法在你的潜意识中酝酿的机会，同时它们组合并重新组合成新的和令人惊讶的东西。如果你遇到困难但有时间（这是早点开始的另一个原因），让你的潜意识在解决问题的同时花一两天时间做其他事情。然后返回到任务中，看看是否可以重回正轨。

On the other hand, some cases of writer’s block may really be opportunities to let your ideas simmer in your subconscious while they combine and recombine into something new and surprising. If you’re stuck but have time (another reason to start early), let your unconscious work on the problem while you do something else for a day or two. Then return to the task to see if you can get back on track.

13 组织你的论点

13  Organizing Your Argument

本章介绍了组织和修改草稿的程序，以便您的读者和您一样清楚地了解您的论点。起初，这个过程可能看起来有点机械，但这就是它的优点。如果您一步一个脚印，您就可以高效可靠地分析和改进草稿的组织结构。

This chapter presents a procedure for organizing and revising your drafts so that your argument is as clear to your readers as it is to you. At first this procedure may seem a bit mechanical, but that’s its virtue. If you follow it one step at a time, you can analyze and improve the organization of your draft efficiently and reliably.

一些新的研究人员认为，一旦他们草拟出一份草稿，他们就完成了。最好的作家知道得更多。他们写初稿不是为了给读者看，而是为了发现他们实际上可以为自己的观点提出什么理由，以及它是否经得起自己的审查。然后他们修改和修改，直到他们认为他们的读者也会同意他们的论点。然而，为读者修改是很困难的，因为我们都非常了解自己的作品，无法像其他人那样去阅读它。你必须首先知道读者在寻找什么，然后确定你的草稿是否能帮助他们找到它。为此，您必须客观地分析您的草稿；否则，你只会读入你希望读者从中得到的东西。

Some new researchers think that once they’ve churned out a draft, they’re done. The best writers know better. They write a first draft not to show to readers, but to discover what case they can actually make for their point and whether it stands up to their own scrutiny. Then they revise and revise until they think their readers will agree with their argument too. Revising for readers is hard, though, because we all know our own work too well to read it as others will. You must first know what readers look for, then determine whether your draft helps them find it. To do that, you have to analyze your draft objectively; otherwise, you’ll just read into it what you want your readers to get out of it.

一些作家拒绝为读者进行任何修改，担心如果他们迎合读者，就会损害他们的完整性。他们认为他们发现的真相应该不言而喻，如果读者难以理解，那么，他们只需要更加努力。但为读者修改并不意味着迎合他们。事实上，当你想象吸引读者进入友好的对话时，你只会改进你的想法，在这种对话中，他们会在你参与他们的信仰时参与你的信仰。

Some writers resist any revising for readers, fearing that if they accommodate their readers, they compromise their integrity. They think that the truth of their discovery should speak for itself, and if readers have a hard time understanding it, well, they just have to work harder. But revising for readers doesn’t mean pandering to them. In fact, you only improve your ideas when you imagine drawing readers into an amiable conversation in which they engage your beliefs as you engage theirs.

在本章中，我们将向您展示如何诊断和修改您的组织和论点，以便读者从中得到您认为自己投入的内容。

In this chapter, we show you how to diagnose and revise your organization and argument so that readers get out of it what you think you put into it.

13.1 像读者一样思考

13.1 THINKING LIKE A READER

读者不会逐字逐句地阅读，就好像他们在串珠一样。他们想从感觉开始整体，它的结构，最重要的是，为什么他们应该首先阅读你的论文。然后他们使用整体感及其目标来解释其部分。所以当你修改时，首先要注意你的整体组织，然后是章节，然后是段落的连贯性和句子的清晰度，最后是拼写和标点符号的问题。当然，在现实中，没有人修改得如此整齐。我们一边做一边修改，在重新整理论点时纠正拼写，在修改段落时澄清证据。但是，当你系统地自上而下地修改时，从全局结构到局部句子和单词，你更有可能按照你的读者的意愿阅读，而不是从底部开始，从单词和句子开始，然后向上推进。你也会更有效率地复习，

Readers do not read word by word, sentence by sentence, as if they were adding up beads on a string. They want to begin with a sense of the whole, its structure, and, most important, why they should read your paper in the first place. Then they use that sense of the whole and its aims to interpret its parts. So when you revise, it makes sense to attend first to your overall organization, then to sections, then to the coherence of your paragraphs and the clarity of your sentences, and, finally, to matters of spelling and punctuation. In reality, of course, no one revises so neatly. We all revise as we go, correcting spelling as we rearrange our argument, clarifying evidence as we revise a paragraph. But when you systematically revise top-down, from global structure to local sentences and words, you are more likely to read as your readers will than if you start at the bottom, with words and sentences, and work up. You will also revise more efficiently, because you won’t spend time fine-tuning whole sections that you later decide to rearrange or even cut.

13.2 修改你的框架

13.2 REVISING YOUR FRAME

读者必须立即明确地认识到三件事：

Readers must recognize three things instantly and unambiguously:

• 你的介绍在哪里结束

• where your introduction ends

• 你的结论从哪里开始

• where your conclusion begins

• 哪一句或两句陈述了你的主要观点

• what sentence in one or both states your main point

为确保读者认识到这些，请执行以下操作：

To ensure that readers recognize these, do this:

1. 在你的介绍之后和你的结论之前留一个额外的空间。如果您的领域同意，请在这些关节处加上标题，这样读者就不会错过它们。

1. Put an extra space after your introduction and before your conclusion. If your field approves, put headings at those joints so that readers can’t miss them.

2. 在介绍结束时或接近结束时陈述你的主要观点。然后将这一点与你的结论中的那一点进行比较。它们至少不应相互矛盾。它们也不应该完全相同：使您的结论中的那个更加具体和有争议。

2. State your main point at or close to the end of your introduction. Then compare that point with the one in your conclusion. They should at least not contradict each other. Nor should they be identical: make the one in your conclusion more specific and contestable.

3. 在引言的中心句中加入贯穿论文的概念和主题的关键术语。不仅当你的要点句子宣布你的主要主张时这样做，而且如果它只是一个起点（见 12.1.1，16.4.2）。

3. Include in the point sentence of your introduction key terms that name concepts and themes that run through your paper. Do this not only when your point sentence announces your main claim but also if it is just a launching point (see 12.1.1, 16.4.2).

例如，考虑这个介绍性段落（缩写很多）。这对论文的要点意味着什么？

For example, consider this introductory paragraph (much abbreviated). What does it imply about the point of the paper?

十一世纪，罗马天主教会发起了几次十字军东征，以夺回圣地。1074年，格列高利七世在给亨利四世的一封信中敦促发动十字军东征，但未能实施。1095 年，他的继任教皇乌尔班二世在克莱蒙会议上发表讲话，呼吁发起十字军东征，次年，即 1096 年，他发起了第一次十字军东征。在本文中，我将讨论十字军东征的原因。

In the eleventh century, the Roman Catholic Church initiated several Crusades to recapture the Holy Land. In a letter to King Henry IV in the year 1074, Gregory VII urged a Crusade but failed to carry it out. In 1095 his successor, Pope Urban II, gave a speech at the Council of Clermont in which he also called for a Crusade, and in the next year, in 1096, he initiated the First Crusade. In this paper I will discuss the reasons for the Crusades.

最接近点句的似乎是最后一个含糊不清的句子。但它只是宣布十字军东征是一个主题。

The closest thing to a point sentence appears to be that vague last one. But it merely announces the Crusades as a topic.

这是结论第一段的前几句话（同样，缩写很多）。它的意义何在？

Here are the first few sentences from the first paragraph of the conclusion (again, much abbreviated). What is its point?

结论中的重点句似乎是第二句（“但他们的努力……分开了”）。这一点是具体的、实质性的，而且似乎有争议。我们可以在引言的末尾添加该点的简短版本，或者我们可以为引言写一个新的句子，虽然不会透露全部要点，但至少会更清楚地介绍论文的关键概念：

The point sentence in the conclusion seems to be the second one (“But their efforts . . . apart”). That point is specific, substantive, and plausibly contestable. We could add a shortened version of that point to the end of the introduction, or we could write a new sentence for the introduction that, while not revealing the full point, would at least introduce the key concepts of the paper more clearly:

在一系列文件中，教皇提议他们的十字军东征将耶路撒冷恢复为基督教世界，但他们的话暗示了其他问题，涉及在面对分裂他们的内部力量时对欧洲和基督教团结的政治担忧。

In a series of documents, the popes proposed their Crusades to restore Jerusalem to Christendom, but their words suggest other issues involving political concerns about European and Christian unity in the face of internal forces that were dividing them.

13.3 修改你的论点

13.3 REVISING YOUR ARGUMENT

一旦确定论文的外部框架适合读者，请逐节分析其论点。我们知道这似乎重复了前面的步骤，但一旦起草，你的论点可能看起来与它在故事板或大纲中的方式不同。

Once you determine that the outer frame of your paper will work for readers, analyze its argument section by section. We know this seems to repeat earlier steps, but once drafted, your argument may look different from the way it did in your storyboard or outline.

13.3.1确定论点的实质

13.3.1 Identify the Substance of Your Argument

你的论点结构与你论文的结构相匹配吗？

Does the structure of your argument match the structure of your paper?

1. 支持你的主要主张的每一个理由都是它自己的一个部分的要点吗？否则，您论文的组织要点可能会与您的论点结构发生冲突。

1. Is each reason supporting your main claim the point of a section of its own? If not, the organizing points of your paper may conflict with the structure of your argument.

2. 你在理由和证据之间取得了适当的平衡吗？在每个部分中，确定所有可作为证据的内容，所有摘要、释义、引文、事实、数字、图表、表格——无论您从主要或次要来源报告的内容。如果你认定为证据的内容及其解释不到一个部分的三分之一左右，你可能没有足够的证据来支持你的理由。如果你有很多证据但很少或没有理由，你可能只有一个数据转储。

2. Do you strike the right balance between reasons and evidence? In each section, identify everything that counts as evidence, all the summaries, paraphrases, quotations, facts, figures, graphs, tables—whatever you report from a primary or secondary source. If what you identify as evidence and its explanation are less than a third or so of a section, you may not have enough evidence to support your reasons. If you have lots of evidence but few or no reasons, you may have just a data dump.

13.3.2评估论证的质量

13.3.2 Evaluate the Quality of Your Argument

什么可能导致你的读者拒绝你的论点？

What might cause your readers to reject your argument?

1、你的证据可靠吗？在第9章中，我们说过证据应该是准确和精确的、充分的和有代表性的、具有权威性的（见9.4）。如果您接近最终草案，则可能为时已晚，无法找到更多或更好的证据。但您可以检查其他事项：

1. Is your evidence reliable? In chapter 9, we said that evidence should be accurate and precise, sufficient and representative, and authoritative (see 9.4). If you are close to a final draft, it may be too late to find more or better evidence. But you can check other matters:

• 根据您的笔记检查您的数据和报价。

• Check your data and quotations against your notes.

• 确保您的读者了解引文和数据如何与您的主张相关。

• Make sure your readers see how quotations and data relate to your claim.

• 确保您没有跳过主要原因及其支持证据之间的中间子原因。

• Be sure you haven’t skipped intermediate subreasons between a major reason and its supporting evidence.

2. 你是否适当地限定了你的论点？你能加入一些适当的对冲，比如probably、most、often、may等等吗？

2. Have you appropriately qualified your argument? Can you drop in a few appropriate hedges like probably, most, often, may, and so on?

3. 你的论文读起来是否像与同行或同事的对话，提出尖锐但友好的问题？如果它读起来像是竞争对手之间的竞赛，或者如果你没有承认其他观点或反对意见，请回顾你的论点并想象一个有同情心但持怀疑态度的读者问，你为什么相信？你真的很强调这一点吗？你能解释一下这个证据与你的观点有什么关系吗？但是关于 。. . ？（复习 10.1-2。）然后回答最重要的问题。

3. Does your paper read like a conversation with peers or colleagues asking hard but friendly questions? If it reads like a contest between competitors or if you haven’t acknowledged alternative views or objections, go back through your argument and imagine a sympathetic but skeptical reader asking, Why do you believe that? Are you really making that strong a point? Could you explain how this evidence relates to your point? But what about . . . ? (Review 10.1–2.) Then answer the most important ones.

4. 你表达了所有你应该表达的权利吗？这个问题没有简单的测试。一旦你确定了你的论点的每个部分和小节，在空白处写下它最重要的未说明的保证。然后问读者是否接受。如果不是，你必须观点并支持它。

4. Have you expressed all the warrants you should? There is no easy test for this question. Once you identify each section and subsection of your argument, write in the margin its most important unstated warrant. Then ask whether readers will accept it. If not, you have to state and support it.

13.4 修改论文的结构

13.4 REVISING THE ORGANIZATION OF YOUR PAPER

一旦您对论文的外部框架及其论点的实质有信心，请确保读者会发现整篇论文是连贯的。为确保他们这样做，请检查以下内容：

Once you are confident about the outer frame of your paper and the substance of its argument, make sure that readers will find the whole paper coherent. To ensure that they do, check the following:

1. 关键术语是否贯穿整篇论文？

1. Do key terms run through your whole paper?

• 在引言和结论的要点中圈出关键术语。

• Circle key terms in the main point in your introduction and conclusion.

• 圈出论文正文中的相同术语。

• Circle those same terms in the body of your paper.

• 在与圈出的术语命名的概念相关的其他词下划线。

• Underline other words related to concepts named by those circled terms.

这又是关于十字军东征的最后一段，其关键词被圈起来了：

Here again is that concluding paragraph about the Crusades, with its keywords circled:

如果读者在大多数段落中至少看不到其中一个关键术语，他们可能会认为您的论文漫无目的。

If readers don’t see at least one of those key terms in most paragraphs, they may think your paper wanders.

如果你发现一段缺少关键术语，你可能会塞进一些。如果这很困难，你可能已经偏离了轨道，需要重写甚至丢弃那段。

If you find a passage that lacks key terms, you might shoehorn a few in. If that’s difficult, you may have gotten off track and need to rewrite or even discard that passage.

2. 每一节和小节的开头是否都清楚地标明了？您能否快速而自信地插入标题以标记主要部分的开始位置？如果不能，您的读者可能不会认出您的组织。如果您不使用标题，请在主要关节处添加一个额外的空间。

2. Is the beginning of each section and subsection clearly signaled? Could you quickly and confidently insert headings to mark where your major sections begin? If you can’t, your readers probably won’t recognize your organization. If you don’t use headings, add an extra space at the major joints.

3. 每个主要部分是否以表明该部分与前一节的关系的词语开头？读者不仅要认清各部分的开始和结束位置，还要理解它们按原样排列的原因。您是否使用诸如“更重要”之类的短语来表明订单的逻辑。. . ，这个问题的另一面是。. . ，有人反对。. . ，一个并发症是。. . ，甚至只是首先， 。. . 第二，  。. . ？

3. Does each major section begin with words that signal how that section relates to the one before it? Readers must not only recognize where sections begin and end, but understand why they are ordered as they are. Have you signaled the logic of your order with phrases such as More important . . . , The other side of this issue is . . . , Some have objected that . . . , One complication is . . . , or even just First, . . . Second, . . . ?

4.是否清楚每个部分与整体的关系？针对每一部分提问：这部分回答什么问题？如果它没有回答构成论点（7.1）的五个问题之一，它是否创造了一个背景，解释了一个背景概念或问题，或者以其他方式帮助读者？如果您无法解释某个部分如何与您的观点相关，请考虑将其删除。

4. Is it clear how each section relates to the whole? For each section ask: What question does this section answer? If it doesn’t answer one of the five questions whose answers constitute an argument (7.1), does it create a context, explain a background concept or issue, or help readers in some other way? If you can’t explain how a section relates to your point, consider cutting it.

5. 每个部分的要点是在简介中（最好）还是在结论中说明？如果您有选择，请在介绍的末尾说明该部分的要点。永远不要把它埋在中间。如果一个部分超过四或五页，你可以通过重申你的观点和总结你的论点来结束，特别是如果你的论点是关于名字、日期或数字的事实。

5. Is the point of each section stated in a brief introduction (preferably) or in its conclusion? If you have a choice, state the point of a section at the end of its introduction. Never bury it in the middle. If a section is longer than four or five pages, you might conclude by restating your point and summarizing your argument, especially if your argument is fact-heavy with names, dates, or numbers.

6. 统一每个部分的术语是否贯穿其中？每个部分都需要自己的关键术语来统一和独特地将其与其他部分区分开来。要对此进行测试，请创建一个标题，将该部分与所有其他部分区分开来。对每个部分重复步骤 1：找到重点句子并在其中圈出该部分的关键术语（不要圈出您在要点中圈出的术语整篇论文）。检查这些术语是否贯穿该部分。如果您发现没有与贯穿整个内容的术语不同的术语，那么您的读者可能看不到该部分有什么新想法。如果你发现某些术语也贯穿于另一个部分，那么这两个部分可能只是相互重复。如果是这样，请考虑将它们结合起来。

6. Do terms that unify each section run through it? Each section needs its own key terms to unify and uniquely distinguish it from the others. To test that, create a heading that uniquely distinguishes that section from all the others. Repeat step 1 for each section: find the point sentence and circle in it the key terms for that section (do not circle terms you circled in the main point of the whole paper). Check whether those terms run through that section. If you find no terms that differ from those running through the whole, then your readers may not see what new ideas that section contributes. If you find that some of the terms also run through another section, the two sections may only repeat each another. If so, consider combining them.

13.5 检查你的段落

13.5 CHECKING YOUR PARAGRAPHS

您可能已经了解到，每个段落都应以主题句开头，并与其出现的部分直接相关。这些都是很好的经验法则，但应用得太严格会使你的写作显得生硬。重要的是结构和安排您的段落，以便它们引导您的读者完成您正在策划的对话。用一两句话打开每个段落，表明其关键概念。这样做将有助于读者更好地理解接下来的内容。如果你的开头没有说明段落的要点，那么你的最后一句话应该。永远不要把重点埋在中间。

You may have learned that every paragraph should begin with a topic sentence and be directly relevant to the section in which it appears. Those are good rules of thumb, but applied too strictly they can make your writing seem stiff. The important thing is to structure and arrange your paragraphs so that they lead your readers through the conversation you are orchestrating. Open each paragraph with a sentence or two that signal its key concepts. Doing that will help readers better understand what follows. If your opening doesn’t also state the paragraph’s point, then your last sentence should. Never bury the point in the middle.

段落的长度取决于它们出现的写作类型。例如，它们在简短的研究报告中往往较短，而在评论文章或书籍章节中则较长。段落应该足够长以阐述他们的观点，但又不能太长以至于读者失去注意力，这只是说它们应该“恰到好处”（另一个金发姑娘时刻）。如果你发现自己把只有几行的断断续续的段落串在一起，这可能意味着你的观点没有得到很好的发展。如果您发现自己展开了超过一页的很长的段落，则可能意味着您离题了。有时您可以改变段落的长度以达到效果：使用短段落来突出您想要强调的过渡或语句。

Paragraphs vary in length depending on the type of writing in which they appear. For example, they tend to be shorter in brief research reports and longer in, say, critical essays or book chapters. Paragraphs should be long enough to develop their points but not so long that readers lose focus, which is simply to say they should be “just right” (another Goldilocks moment). If you find yourself stringing together choppy paragraphs of just a few lines, it may mean your points are not well developed. If you find yourself rolling out very long paragraphs of more than a page, it may mean that you are digressing. You can sometimes vary the lengths of your paragraphs for effect: use short paragraphs to highlight transitions or statements that you want to emphasize.

一些作家发现不考虑他们的段落而是考虑他们的段落中断更自然。像对话中的停顿一样使用段落中断，例如，在你强调重点之后休息，给你的读者时间来处理复杂的段落，或者表示过渡到一个新想法。

Some writers find it more natural to think not about their paragraphs but about their paragraph breaks. Use your paragraph breaks as you would the pauses in a conversation, for example, to rest after you make a strong point, to give your reader a moment to process a complex passage, or to signal a transition to a new idea.

13.6 让你的草稿冷静下来，然后改写它

13.6 LETTING YOUR DRAFT COOL, THEN PARAPHRASING IT

如果你早点开始你的项目，你就有时间让修改后的草稿冷却下来。一天看起来不错的东西，第二天往往看起来不一样。当你回到它时，不要直接通读；浏览它的顶级部分：它的介绍、每个主要部分的第一段和它的结论。然后，根据你读过的内容，为没有读过的人解释一下。释义挂在一起吗？它是否准确地总结了你的论点？更好的是，请其他人浏览您的论文并对其进行总结：该读者对您的论点的总结程度将预测您的最终读者对它的理解程度。最后，请始终考虑读者的建议，即使您没有采纳每条建议。

If you start your project early, you’ll have time to let your revised draft cool. What seems good one day often looks different the next. When you return to it, don’t read straight through; skim its top-level parts: its introduction, the first paragraph of each major section, and its conclusion. Then, based only on what you’ve read, paraphrase it for someone who hasn’t read it. Does the paraphrase hang together? Does it accurately sum up your argument? Even better, ask someone else to skim your paper and summarize it: how well that reader summarizes your argument will predict how well your final readers will understand it. Finally, always consider your reader’s advice, even if you do not follow every suggestion.

快速提示：摘要

Quick Tip: Abstracts

摘要是一个段落，告诉读者他们将在论文、文章或报告中找到什么。它应该比介绍短，但做介绍做的三件事：

An abstract is a paragraph that tells readers what they will find in a paper, an article, or a report. It should be shorter than an introduction but do three things that an introduction does:

• 陈述研究问题

• state the research problem

• 宣布关键主题

• announce key themes

• 陈述要点或预测要点的出发点

• state the main point or a launching point that anticipates the main point

摘要因领域而异，有些领域根本不使用它们。但大多数摘要遵循三种模式之一。要确定哪个适合您的领域，请咨询您的老师或查看标准期刊。以下是这些模式的示例，改编自最近一篇政治学文章的摘要（第三篇是原文）。

Abstracts differ from field to field, and some fields don’t use them at all. But most abstracts follow one of three patterns. To determine which suits your field, ask your teacher or look in a standard journal. Here are examples of these patterns, adapted from the abstract to a recent article in political science (the third is the original).

1. 背景+问题+要点

1. Context + Problem + Main Point

这种摘要是一个简短的介绍。它以一两句话开始，以建立先前研究的背景，然后以一两句话陈述问题，并以研究的主要结果结束。

This kind of abstract is an abbreviated introduction. It begins with a sentence or two to establish the context of previous research, continues with a sentence or two to state the problem, and concludes with the main result of the research.

长期以来，学者们一直认为民主可以改善其公民的生活质量。背景但最近的研究对这种正统观念提出了质疑，表明一个国家的政权类型与其人类发展水平之间几乎没有或根本没有关系。问题在这篇文章中，我们认为民主可以促进人类发展，但前提是将其视为一种历史现象。重点

Scholars have long assumed that democracy improves the quality of life for its citizens.context But recent research has called this orthodoxy into question, suggesting that there is little or no relationship between a country’s regime type and its level of human development.problem In this article, we argue that democracy can be shown to advance human development, but only when considered as a historical phenomenon.main point

2. 背景+问题+出发点

2. Context + Problem + Launching Point

这个模式与前一个模式相同，只是抽象状态不是具体结果，只是它们的一般性质（见 12.1.1）。

This pattern is the same as the previous one, except that the abstract states not specific results, only their general nature (see 12.1.1).

长期以来，学者们一直认为民主可以改善其公民的生活质量，但最近的研究对这种正统观念提出了质疑，表明民主与民主之间几乎没有或根本没有关系国家的政权类型及其人类发展水平。问题在这篇文章中，我们回顾了这部分工作，提出了一系列民主可以改善社会福利的因果关系，并检验了两个假设：(a) 一个国家在特定年份的民主水平会影响其人类发展水平(b) 它过去一个世纪的民主存量影响着它的人类发展水平。发射点

Scholars have long assumed that democracy improves the quality of life for its citizens,context but recent research has called this orthodoxy into question, suggesting that there is little or no relationship between a country’s regime type and its level of human development.problem In this article, we review this body of work, develop a series of causal pathways through which democracy might improve social welfare, and test two hypotheses: (a) that a country’s level of democracy in a given year affects its level of human development and (b) that its stock of democracy over the past century affects its level of human development.launching point

三、总结

3. Summary

摘要还说明了上下文和问题；但在报告结果之前，它总结了其余的论点，重点放在支持结果的证据或用于实现结果的程序和方法上。这是发表时的摘要：

A summary also states the context and the problem; but before reporting the result, it summarizes the rest of the argument, focusing either on the evidence supporting the result or on the procedures and methods used to achieve it. Here is the abstract as it was published:

民主是否提高了公民的生活质量？长期以来，学者们一直认为它确实如此，但最近的研究对这种正统观念提出了质疑。问题本文回顾了这部分工作，提出了一系列民主可能改善社会福利的因果途径，并检验了两个假设：(a) 一个国家在特定年份的民主水平会影响其人类发展水平，以及 (b ) 它过去一个世纪的民主存量影响着它的人类发展水平。我们将婴儿死亡率作为衡量人类发展的核心指标，对这两个假设进行了一系列时间序列跨国统计检验。我们只发现第一个命题的证据很少，但对第二个命题有很大的支持。总结因此，我们认为，思考民主与发展之间关系的最佳方式是将其视为一种随时间变化的历史现象。重点

Does democracy improve the quality of life for its citizens? Scholars have long assumed that it does,context but recent research has called this orthodoxy into question.problem This article reviews this body of work, develops a series of causal pathways through which democracy might improve social welfare, and tests two hypotheses: (a) that a country’s level of democracy in a given year affects its level of human development and (b) that its stock of democracy over the past century affects its level of human development. Using infant mortality rates as a core measure of human development, we conduct a series of time-series—cross-national statistical tests of these two hypotheses. We find only slight evidence for the first proposition, but substantial support for the second.summary Thus, we argue that the best way to think about the relationship between democracy and development is as a time-dependent, historical phenomenon.main point

由于此版本包含摘要，因此问题的陈述略有简化。还要注意开场白。这个版本没有以标准方式陈述上下文，而是以一个似乎是反问的问题开始——“民主是否改善了公民的生活质量？”——这样它就可以推翻隐含的答案。即使像抽象一样压缩的形式也允许偶尔出现风格上的繁荣。

Since this version includes a summary, the statement of the problem is slightly abbreviated. Notice, too, the opening sentence. Rather than stating the context in standard fashion, this version begins with what seems to be a rhetorical question—“Does democracy improve the quality of life for its citizens?”—just so it can then upend the implied answer. Even as compressed a form as an abstract allows for the occasional stylistic flourish.

最后一个提示：如果您发表了您的研究，一些下线的研究人员可能希望使用搜索关键字的搜索引擎找到它。因此，想象一下自己搜索论文。你会寻找什么关键词？把它们放在你的标题和摘要的第一句话中。

A final tip: if you publish your research, some researcher down the line may want to find it, using a search engine that looks for keywords. So imagine searching for your paper yourself. What keywords would you look for? Put them in your title and the first sentence of your abstract.

14 合并来源

14  Incorporating Sources

没有什么比有效使用资源更能使有经验的研究人员与初学者区别开来了。但即使是新手研究人员也可以通过遵循一些尊重作者来源和读者的原则来表现出可信的精神。

Nothing sets the experienced researcher apart from the beginner more than the effective use of sources. But even a beginning researcher can project an ethos of credibility by following a few principles that show respect both for the writer’s sources and for readers.

14.1 适当地引用、释义和总结

14.1 QUOTING, PARAPHRASING, AND SUMMARIZING APPROPRIATELY

你必须用你自己的话来构建你的论文，反映你自己的想法。但是你会用引文、释义和总结来支持大部分的想法。正如我们所说，不同的领域使用它们的方式不同：人文学科的研究人员引用的比社会和自然科学家的引用更多，社会和自然科学家通常会进行释义和总结。但是您必须根据您使用信息的方式自行决定每个案例。这里再次强调一些原则：

You must build your paper out of your own words that reflect your own thinking. But you’ll support much of that thinking with quotations, paraphrases, and summaries. As we’ve said, different fields use them differently: researchers in the humanities quote more than do social and natural scientists, who typically paraphrase and summarize. But you must decide each case for itself, depending on how you use the information. Here again are some principles:

• 当细节无关紧要或来源不够重要以致无法占用太多篇幅时进行总结。

• Summarize when details are irrelevant or a source isn’t important enough to warrant much space.

• 当您可以更清楚或简洁地陈述来源所说的内容时，或者当您的论点取决于来源中的细节而不是其特定词语时，请改述。

• Paraphrase when you can state what a source says more clearly or concisely or when your argument depends on the details in a source but not on its specific words.

• 出于这些目的的报价：

• Quote for these purposes:

——这些话本身就是支持你的理由的证据。

—The words themselves are evidence that backs up your reasons.

——这些话来自支持你的主张的权威。

—The words are from an authority who backs up your claims.

——这些词是惊人的原创，或者如此引人注目地表达了你的关键概念，以至于引文可以构成一个扩展的讨论。

—The words are strikingly original or express your key concepts so compellingly that the quotation can frame an extended discussion.

——一篇文章陈述了你不同意的观点，公平地说，你想准确地陈述它。

—A passage states a view that you disagree with, and to be fair you want to state it exactly.

对于您使用的每个摘要、释义或引文，以适当的样式引用其书目数据（参见 14.5 和快速提示）。在任何情况下，都不要将从 Web 下载的内容与您自己的几句话拼凑在一起。老师磨牙阅读此类论文，对他们缺乏原创性思维感到沮丧。高级项目的读者会立即拒绝这种拼凑而成的作品。

For every summary, paraphrase, or quotation you use, cite its bibliographic data in the appropriate style (see 14.5 and the Quick Tip). Under no circumstances stitch together downloads from the Web with a few sentences of your own. Teachers grind their teeth reading such papers, dismayed by their lack of original thinking. Readers of advanced projects reject such patchworks out of hand.

14.2 将直接引语整合到您的文本中

14.2 INTEGRATING DIRECT QUOTATIONS INTO YOUR TEXT

以两种方式之一发出直接引述信号：

Signal direct quotations in one of two ways:

• 对于四行或更少的引用行，将它们放入您的文本中，并用引号括起来。

• For four or fewer quoted lines, run them into your text, surrounded by quotation marks.

• 对于五行或更多行，将它们设置为缩进块。

• For five or more lines, set them off as an indented block.

您可以通过三种方式在文本中插入插入引号和块引号。

You can insert run-in and block quotations in your text in three ways.

• 在引文中加入一些识别词（作者说，根据作者，作者所说等）。

• Drop in the quotation with a few identifying words (Author says, According to Author, As Author puts it, etc.).

戴蒙德说，“新月沃土和中国的历史。. . 为现代世界上一堂有益的课：环境在变，过去的首要地位并不能保证未来的首要地位”（417）。

Diamond says, “The histories of the Fertile Crescent and China . . . hold a salutary lesson for the modern world: circumstances change, and past primacy is no guarantee of future primacy” (417).

• 用解释或描述引文的句子介绍引文。

• Introduce the quotation with a sentence that interprets or characterizes it.

戴蒙德提出了我们可以从过去学到的东西：“新月沃土和中国的历史。. . 为现代世界上一堂有益的课。. ” （417）。

Diamond suggests what we can learn from the past: “The histories of the Fertile Crescent and China . . . hold a salutary lesson for the modern world . . .” (417).

• 将引文的语法融入你自己句子的语法中。

• Weave the grammar of the quotation into the grammar of your own sentence.

戴蒙德认为，新月沃土和中国历史上“给现代世界的主要教训”是“环境在变，过去的首要地位并不能保证未来的首要地位”（417）。

Diamond suggests that the chief “lesson for the modern world” in the history of the Fertile Crescent and China is that “circumstances change, and past primacy is no guarantee of future primacy” (417).

您可以修改引文，只要您不改变其含义并且用三个点（称为省略号）表示删除并用方括号表示更改。这句话原封不动地引用原文：

You can modify a quotation, so long as you don’t change its meaning and you signal deletions with three dots (called ellipses) and changes with square brackets. This sentence quotes the original intact:

波斯纳关注宗教不是因为它的灵性，而是因为它的社会功能：“美国社会的一个显着特征是宗教多元化，鉴于宗教作为此类规范的来源和执行者的历史重要性，我们应该考虑这与社会规范治理的有效性有何关系”（299）。

Posner focuses on religion not for its spirituality, but for its social functions: “A notable feature of American society is religious pluralism, and we should consider how this relates to the efficacy of governance by social norms in view of the historical importance of religion as both a source and enforcer of such norms” (299).

这个版本修改了引文以符合作者句子的语法：

This version modifies the quotation to fit the grammar of the writer’s sentence:

在讨论宗教多元主义时，波斯纳说“美国社会的一个显着特征是[我们的]宗教多元主义”，并指出社会规范如何影响“治理的效力……”。. . 鉴于宗教作为此类规范的来源和执行者的历史重要性”（299）。

In discussing religious pluralism, Posner says that “a notable feature of American society is [our] religious pluralism” and notes how social norms affect “the efficacy of governance . . . in view of the historical importance of religion as both a source and enforcer of such norms” (299).

14.3 向读者展示证据的相关性

14.3 SHOWING READERS HOW EVIDENCE IS RELEVANT

至此，您可能非常确定您的证据支持您的理由，以至于您会认为读者不会错过它的相关性。但证据永远不会说明一切，尤其是长篇大论或复杂的数字集。你必须用一句话来介绍这些证据，说明你希望读者从中得到什么。例如，这段话基于以下引文的证据得出关于哈姆雷特的主张：

By this point you may be so sure that your evidence supports your reasons that you’ll think readers can’t miss its relevance. But evidence never speaks for itself, especially not long quotations or complex sets of numbers. You must speak for such evidence by introducing it with a sentence stating what you want your readers to get out of it. For example, this passage bases a claim about Hamlet on the evidence of the following quotation:

当哈姆雷特在祈祷时遇到他的继父克劳迪斯时，他表现出冷静的理性：声称

When Hamlet comes upon his stepfather, Claudius, at prayer, he demonstrates cool rationality:claim

现在我可以这样做 [杀了他] 轻拍，现在'a 是 a-祈祷，

Now might I do it [kill him] pat, now ’a is a-praying,

现在我不会了。所以'一个去天堂，

And now I’ll do’t. And so ’a goes to heaven,

我也被报复了。. . . [哈姆雷特停下来思考]

And so am I reveng’d. . . . [Hamlet pauses to think]

[但是这个]恶棍杀了我父亲，为此，

[But this] villain kills my father, and for that,

我，他唯一的儿子，做同样的恶棍发送

I, his sole son, do this same villain send

到天堂。

To heaven.

为什么，这是雇佣和薪水，而不是报复。(3.3)证据报告

Why, this is hire and salary, not revenge. (3.3)report of evidence

目前尚不清楚该引文如何支持这一主张，因为其中没有任何内容专门提到哈姆雷特的理性。相比之下，比较一下：

It is not clear how that quotation supports the claim, because nothing in it specifically refers to Hamlet’s rationality. In contrast, compare this:

当哈姆雷特在祈祷时遇到他的继父克劳狄斯时，他表现出冷静的理性。声称 他冲动地想杀死克劳迪斯，但 停下来反思：如果他在祈祷时杀死了克劳迪斯，他会把自己的灵魂送上天堂，但他希望克劳迪斯下地狱，所以他冷静地决定稍后再杀他：原因

When Hamlet comes upon his stepfather, Claudius, at prayer, he demonstrates cool rationality.claim He impulsively wants to kill Claudius but pauses to reflect: if he kills Claudius while praying, he will send his soul to heaven, but he wants Claudius damned to hell, so he coolly decides to kill him later:reason

现在我可以这样做 [杀了他] 帕特，。. . 证据报告

Now might I do it [kill him] pat, . . .report of evidence

现在我们看到了联系。（对表格和数字做同样的事情；见 15.3.1。）

Now we see the connection. (Do the same with tables and figures; see 15.3.1.)

缺乏解释证据的理由，读者可能看不到它的意思。所以用一句话解释复杂的证据。

Lacking a reason that explains the evidence, readers may not see what it means. So introduce complex evidence with a sentence explaining it.

14.4 引用来源的社会重要性

14.4 THE SOCIAL IMPORTANCE OF CITING SOURCES

14.4.1引用对你有益

14.4.1 Citations Benefit You

引用可以保护你免受剽窃的指控，但除了狭隘的自身利益之外，正确的引用有助于你的风气。首先，读者不会相信他们找不到的来源。如果他们因为你没有充分记录他们而找不到你的消息来源，他们就不会相信你的证据；如果他们不相信你的证据，他们就不会相信你的论文——或者你。其次，许多有经验的研究人员认为，如果一个作家不能把小事做好，那么他在大事上就不会受到信任。正确获取引文的详细信息可以将可靠、经验丰富的研究人员与粗心的初学者区分开来。最后，老师布置研究论文，帮助你学习如何将别人的研究融入到自己的思考中。适当的引文表明您已经了解了该过程的一个重要部分。

Citations protect you from a charge of plagiarism, but beyond that narrow self-interest, correct citations contribute to your ethos. First, readers don’t trust sources they can’t find. If they can’t find your sources because you failed to document them adequately, they won’t trust your evidence; and if they don’t trust your evidence, they won’t trust your paper—or you. Second, many experienced researchers think that if a writer can’t get the little things right, he can’t be trusted on the big ones. Getting the details of citations right distinguishes reliable, experienced researchers from careless beginners. Finally, teachers assign research papers to help you learn how to integrate the research of others into your own thinking. Proper citations show that you have learned one important part of that process.

14.4.2引文帮助你的读者

14.4.2 Citations Help Your Readers

读者在阅读您的论文之前、期间和之后都会使用引文。以前，许多有经验的读者会通过浏览你的来源列表来预览你的论文，看看你读过和没读过谁的作品。在阅读时，读者会使用引文来决定他们对您证据的可靠性、时效性和完整性的信任程度。在 Internet 上发现过时或仅最近引用来源的论文提醒读者持怀疑态度。但是，其引用显示了引文来源的广度和深度的论文让读者放心。最后，正如您依赖来源开始您的书目追踪一样，一些读者也会依赖您的列表来开始他们的。

Readers use citations before, while, and after they read your paper. Before, many experienced readers will preview your paper by skimming your list of sources to see whose work you read and whose you didn’t. As they read, readers use citations to decide how much they can trust the reliability, currency, and completeness of your evidence. Papers with outdated or only very recent citations of sources found on the Internet alert readers to be skeptical. But papers whose citations show range and depth in engaging sources reassure readers. Finally, just as you depended on sources to start your bibliographical trail, so will some readers depend on your list to start theirs.

14.4.3引用尊重您的来源

14.4.3 Citations Honor Your Sources

最后，引文尊重你的来源。很少有学术研究人员在诸如“俄亥俄州教育，1825-1850 年”等主题上写得丰富。他们的报酬不是金钱；这是他们因出色的工作而赢得的声誉，以及当他们知道同事足够尊重并引用它时所感到的快乐——即使存在分歧。你的消息来源可能永远不知道你引用了他们，但这并不重要。当你引用来源时，你通过承认你的智力债务来尊重他们。

Finally, citations honor your sources. Few academic researchers get rich writing on topics such as “Ohio education, 1825–1850.” Their reward isn’t money; it’s the reputation they earn for doing good work and the pleasure they take in knowing that colleagues respect it enough to cite it—even in disagreement. Your sources may never know you cited them, but that doesn’t matter. When you cite sources, you honor them by acknowledging your intellectual debts.

简而言之，当你完整准确地引用资源时，你就维持并丰富了赋予书面研究学术和社会价值的社区意识。

In short, when you cite sources fully and accurately, you sustain and enrich the sense of community that gives written research both its scholarly and social value.

14.5 四种常见的引文风格

14.5 FOUR COMMON CITATION STYLES

如果我们都以相同的风格引用来源会更容易，但我们没有。对于学术研究，有两种基本模式，每种模式都有两个通用版本。风格之间的许多差异看似挑剔且无关紧要，但它们对读者很重要。所以一定要找出你应该使用哪种风格，并查阅适合你风格的指南。（您还可以找到可靠的在线指南。）

It would be easier if we all cited sources in the same style, but we don’t. For academic research, there are two basic patterns, each with two common versions. The many differences among the styles can seem picky and irrelevant, but they matter to readers. So be sure to find out which style you should use, and consult the proper guide for your style. (You can also find reliable online guides.)

如今，许多研究人员使用引文软件自动生成他们选择的风格的引文。一些老师鼓励这种做法。其他人则认为学生不应依赖此类帮助，而应了解细节。如果你不知道你的老师在这个问题上的立场，问。

Many researchers today use citation software that automatically generates citations in the style they choose. Some teachers encourage this practice. Others feel that students should not rely on such assistance, but rather learn the details. If you don’t know where your teacher stands on the issue, ask.

14.5.1两种基本模式：作者-标题和作者-日期

14.5.1 Two Basic Patterns: Author-Title and Author-Date

所有引文表格都以作者、编辑或对来源负责的任何其他人的姓名开头。我们根据作者的风格来区分风格。如果标题在作者之后，则该样式称为作者-标题。

All citation forms begin with the name of the author, editor, or whoever else is responsible for the source. We distinguish styles by what follows the author. If the title follows the author, the style is called author-title.

Anes, Lee J. 俄亥俄州的故事：它的早期。波士顿：霍布森出版社，1988 年。

Anes, Lee J. A Story of Ohio: Its Early Days. Boston: Hobson Press, 1988.

这种模式在人文学科中很常见。

This pattern is common in the humanities.

如果日期在作者之后，则该样式称为作者日期。

If the date follows the author, the style is called author-date.

阿内斯，李。1988. 俄亥俄州的故事：它的早期。波士顿：霍布森出版社。

Anes, Lee. 1988. A story of Ohio: Its early days. Boston: Hobson Press.

这种模式用于自然科学和大多数社会科学，因为在那些瞬息万变的领域中，读者希望快速了解来源的年代。当日期出现在引用的开头时，他们可以更容易地发现日期。

This pattern is used in the natural sciences and most of the social sciences, because in those rapidly changing fields, readers want to know quickly how old a source is. They can spot dates more easily when they come at the beginning of a citation.

14.5.2两种作者-题名样式

14.5.2 Two Author-Title Styles

作者标题风格有两个版本，每个版本都基于一个著名的风格手册。

There are two versions of author-title style, each based on a well-known style manual.

• Chicago Author-Title Style： 芝加哥风格手册，第 16 版。（芝加哥：芝加哥大学出版社，2010 年）。它有时被称为 Turabian 风格，基于广泛使用的浓缩手册：Kate L. Turabian，A Manual for Writers of Research Papers, Theses, and Dissertations，第 8 版。（芝加哥：芝加哥大学出版社，2013 年）。当使用这种风格时，你在参考书目中列出你的来源，并在你的文本中用脚注或尾注引用它们。

• Chicago Author-Title Style: The Chicago Manual of Style, 16th ed. (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2010). It is sometimes called Turabian style, based on a widely used condensed manual: Kate L. Turabian, A Manual for Writers of Research Papers, Theses, and Dissertations, 8th ed. (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2013). When using this style, you list your sources in a bibliography and cite them in your text with footnotes or endnotes.

• MLA 风格： MLA 研究论文作者手册，第 8 版。（纽约：现代语言协会，2016 年）。您很可能在文学或作文课程中学习 MLA（现代语言协会）风格。在这种风格中，你给出了一份被引用作品的列表，并在你的文本中用括号括起来引用你的来源。

• MLA Style: MLA Handbook for Writers of Research Papers, 8th ed. (New York: Modern Language Association, 2016). You are mostly likely to learn MLA (Modern Language Association) style in a literature or composition course. In this style, you give a list of works cited and cite your sources parenthetically in your text.

这些样式仅在次要细节上有所不同，但这些细节很重要，因此请务必查阅正确的样式指南。

These styles differ only in minor details, but those details matter, so be sure to consult the proper style guide.

14.5.3两种作者-日期样式

14.5.3 Two Author-Date Styles

作者日期风格有两个版本，每个版本都基于一个著名的风格手册。

There are two versions of author-date style, each based on a well-known style manual.

• Chicago Author-Date Style：这种风格也在《芝加哥风格手册》中有所描述，有时也称为 Turabian 风格。使用它时，你在参考书目中列出你的来源，但在你的文本中用括号引用它们。

• Chicago Author-Date Style: This style is also described in The Chicago Manual of Style and sometimes called Turabian style. When using it, you list your sources in a bibliography but cite them parenthetically in your text.

• APA 风格： 美国心理学会出版手册，第 6 版。（华盛顿特区：美国心理学会，2009 年）。这种风格也使用括号引用。

• APA Style: Publication Manual of the American Psychological Association, 6th ed. (Washington, DC: American Psychological Association, 2009). This style uses parenthetical citations as well.

与作者标题样式一样，这些样式仅在次要细节上有所不同。但同样，这些细节很重要，所以一定要遵循你使用的风格的规定，直到最后一个逗号、空格和大写字母。

Like the author-title styles, these styles differ only in minor details. But again, those details matter, so be sure to follow the prescriptions of the style you use down to the last comma, space, and capital letter.

14.6 防止无意的抄袭

14.6 GUARDING AGAINST INADVERTENT PLAGIARISM

当你起草时，你将冒着研究人员可能犯的最严重错误的风险：你让读者认为你试图冒充另一位作家的作品。如果这样做，你可能会面临剽窃的指控，如果持续下去，对于专业作家来说，这可能意味着无法挽回的声誉受损，或者对于学生作家来说，成绩不及格甚至被开除。当学生将自己的名字写在从 Internet 上购买的纸上或从兄弟会或姐妹会的文件中复制时，他们就知道他们在作弊。大多数人还知道，当他们假装自己的长篇文章直接从他们的来源中复制时，他们会作弊。对于这些情况，除了Don't之外没有什么可说的。

It will be as you draft that you risk the worst mistake a researcher can make: you lead readers to think that you’re trying to pass off as your own the work of another writer. Do that and you risk an accusation of plagiarism, a charge that, if sustained, could mean, for a professional writer, an irreparably damaged reputation or, for a student writer, a failing grade or even expulsion. Students know they cheat when they put their name on a paper purchased on the Internet or copied from a fraternity or sorority file. Most also know they cheat when they pass off as their own long passages copied directly from their sources. For those cases, there’s nothing to say beyond Don’t.

但是许多没有经验的作家并没有意识到，当他们冒着被指控剽窃的风险时，因为他们粗心大意或被误导了。当您执行以下任一操作时，您将面临该风险：

But many inexperienced writers don’t realize when they risk being charged with plagiarism because they are careless or misinformed. You run that risk when you do any of the following:

• 你引用、解释或总结了一个来源但没有引用它。

• You quote, paraphrase, or summarize a source but fail to cite it.

• 您使用来源中的想法或方法但没有引用它。

• You use ideas or methods from a source but fail to cite it.

• 您使用了来源的确切词语并确实引用了它，但是您没有将这些词语放在引号或整段引文中。

• You use the exact words of a source and you do cite it, but you fail to put those words in quotation marks or in a block quotation.

• 你解释了一个来源并引用了它，但是你使用的词语与来源的词语非常相似，以至于任何人都可以看到，当你解释时，你是逐字逐句地遵循来源。

• You paraphrase a source and cite it, but you use words so similar to those of the source that anyone can see that as you paraphrased, you followed the source word by word.

14.6.1引用每个引文、释义或摘要的出处

14.6.1 Cite the Source of Every Quotation, Paraphrase, or Summary

每次使用它的文字时，你都必须引用你的来源，即使你只是解释或总结它们。如果引文、释义或摘要来自来源的不同页面，请单独引用每一页。如果释义或摘要跨越多个段落，最后只引用一次。（有关在文本中引用来源的指导，请参阅本章末尾的快速提示。）

You must cite your source every time you use its words, even if you only paraphrase or summarize them. If the quotations, paraphrases, or summaries come from different pages of your sources, cite each one individually. If a paraphrase or summary extends over several paragraphs, cite it only once at the end. (See the Quick Tip at the end of this chapter for guidance on citing sources in your text.)

最常见的问题不是学生不知道他们应该引用来源，而是他们忘记了哪些词是他们自己的，哪些是借来的。这就是为什么我们在第 6 章中敦促你在你的笔记中区分来源的引文、释义和摘要与你自己的分析、想法和评论。添加引文后请始终包含引文，因为您以后可能不记得这样做了。在起草时要特别小心地引用释义或摘要；否则，您甚至可能不记得它起源于某个来源。

The most common problem is not that students don’t know that they should cite a source, but that they lose track of which words are theirs and which are borrowed. That’s why we urged you in chapter 6 to distinguish in your notes between quotations, paraphrases, and summaries of sources and your own analyses, thoughts, and commentary. Always include the citation as soon as you add a quotation because you may not remember to do so later. Be especially careful to cite a paraphrase or summary as you draft it; otherwise, you may not even remember that it originated with a source.

14.6.2 标记每一个引用，即使你引用了它的来源

14.6.2 Signal Every Quotation, Even When You Cite Its Source

即使你引用了出处，读者也必须准确地知道哪些词不是你的，即使它们只有一行。但是，当您复制少于一行时，它会变得复杂。读这个：

Even if you cite the source, readers must know exactly which words are not yours, even if they are as few as a single line. It gets complicated, however, when you copy less than a line. Read this:

“因为技术会产生更多的技术，所以一项发明传播的重要性可能会超过最初发明的重要性。技术的历史例证了所谓的自催化过程：即随着时间的推移而加速的过程，因为该过程会自我催化”（Diamond 1998，301）。

“Because technology begets more technology, the importance of an invention’s diffusion potentially exceeds the importance of the original invention. Technology’s history exemplifies what is termed an autocatalytic process: that is, one that speeds up at a rate that increases with time, because the process catalyzes itself” (Diamond 1998, 301).

如果你要写 Jared Diamond 的想法，你可能不得不使用他的一些词，例如发明的重要性。但是你不会把那句话放在引号里，因为它没有表现出思想或表达的独创性。

If you were writing about Jared Diamond’s ideas, you would probably have to use some of his words, such as the importance of an invention. But you wouldn’t put that phrase in quotation marks, because it shows no originality of thought or expression.

然而，他的两个短语非常引人注目，以至于它们确实需要引号：技术会产生更多的技术和自动催化过程。例如：

Two of his phrases, however, are so striking that they do require quotation marks: technology begets more technology and autocatalytic process. For example:

技术的力量超越了个人发明，因为“技术会产生更多的技术”。正如戴蒙德所说，这是一个“自催化过程”（301）。

The power of technology goes beyond individual inventions because “technology begets more technology.” It is, as Diamond puts it, an “autocatalytic process” (301).

一旦你引用了这些词，你就可以再次使用它们而无需引号或引用：

Once you cite those words, you can use them again without quotation marks or citation:

随着一项发明产生另一项发明，一项又一项发明，这一过程成为一种跨越国界传播的自我维持的催化剂。

As one invention begets another one and that one still another, the process becomes a self-sustaining catalysis that spreads across national boundaries.

这是一个灰色地带：对某些人来说似乎引人注目的词对其他人来说并不重要。如果你给太多普通的短语加上引号，读者可能会认为你很天真，但如果你在读者认为你应该使用的时候没有使用它们，他们可能会怀疑你抄袭。由于看起来天真总比不诚实好，尤其是在您职业生涯的早期，请随意使用引号。（但是，您必须遵循您所在领域的标准做法。例如，律师经常使用不带引号的法规或司法意见的确切语言。）

This is a gray area: words that seem striking to some are not to others. If you put quotation marks around too many ordinary phrases, readers might think you’re naive, but if you fail to use them when readers think you should, they may suspect you of plagiarism. Since it’s better to seem naive than dishonest, especially early in your career, use quotation marks freely. (You must, however, follow the standard practices of your field. Lawyers, for example, often use the exact language of a statute or judicial opinion with no quotation marks.)

14.6.3不要解释得太严密

14.6.3 Don’t Paraphrase Too Closely

当你用自己的话比来源更清楚或更有针对性地表达一个想法时，你就恰当地解释了。但是，如果读者能将您的文字和措辞与您的来源相匹配，他们就会认为您抄袭了。

You paraphrase appropriately when you represent an idea in your own words more clearly or pointedly than the source does. But readers will think that you plagiarize if they can match your words and phrasing with those of your source.

例如，这是马尔科姆·格拉德威尔 (Malcolm Gladwell) 的异常值：成功的故事中的一段话：

For example, here is a passage from Malcolm Gladwell’s Outliers: The Story of Success:

“成就是天赋加上准备。这种观点的问题在于，心理学家越仔细地观察天才的职业，天赋的作用似乎越小，而准备的作用似乎越大”（38）。

“Achievement is talent plus preparation. The problem with this view is that the closer psychologists look at the careers of the gifted, the smaller the role innate talent seems to play and the bigger the role preparation seems to play” (38).

这种过于接近的释义是抄袭：

This too-close paraphrase is plagiarism:

成功似乎取决于天赋和准备的结合。然而，当心理学家仔细检查有天赋的人和他们的在职业生涯中，他们发现天赋比准备发挥的作用要小得多 (Gladwell 38)。

Success seems to depend on a combination of talent and preparation. However, when psychologists closely examine the gifted and their careers, they discover that innate talent plays a much smaller role than preparation (Gladwell 38).

这段话没有抄袭：

This paraphrase does not plagiarize:

正如 Gladwell 所观察到的，总结对非常成功的研究，我们倾向于高估人才的作用而低估准备的作用 (38)。

As Gladwell observes, summarizing studies on the highly successful, we tend to overestimate the role of talent and underestimate that of preparation (38).

这种措辞与原文不相符。请注意，我们选择不将才能或准备放在引号中。我们认为这些词很常见，可以用作我们自己的词。

This phrasing is not a close match to the original. And notice that we chose not to put talent or preparation in quotes. We decided that those words are common enough to use as our own.

为避免看似抄袭，请阅读文章，将目光移开，思考片刻；然后仍然看着别处，用你自己的话来解释它。然后检查你是否可以沿着你的句子滑动手指，并在你的源代码中以相同的顺序找到相同想法的同义词。如果可以，请再试一次。

To avoid seeming to plagiarize, read the passage, look away, think about it for a moment; then still looking away, paraphrase it in your own words. Then check whether you can run your finger along your sentence and find synonyms for the same ideas in the same order in your source. If you can, try again.

14.6.4通常引用非你自己想法的来源

14.6.4 Usually Cite a Source for Ideas Not Your Own

我们的大部分想法都基于历史某处的来源。但是读者不希望你引用世界是圆的这个想法的来源。但是，他们确实希望您在 (1) 该想法与特定人相关联并且(2) 它足够新而不是该领域常识的一部分时引用该想法的来源。例如，心理学家声称我们在大脑的不同部分进行思考和感受。但是没有读者会期望你引用那个想法的来源，因为它是如此熟悉以至于没有人会认为你在暗示它是你的。另一方面，一些心理学家认为情绪对于理性决策至关重要。这个想法是如此新颖，并且与特定的研究人员联系在一起，以至于你不得不引用他们。

Most of our ideas are based on sources somewhere in history. But readers don’t expect you to cite a source for the idea that the world is round. They do, however, expect you to cite a source for an idea when (1) the idea is associated with a specific person and (2) it’s new enough not to be part of a field’s common knowledge. For example, psychologists claim that we think and feel in different parts of our brains. But no reader would expect you to cite a source for that idea, because it’s so familiar that no one would think you are implying it is yours. On the other hand, some psychologists argue that emotions are crucial to rational decision making. That idea is so new and tied to particular researchers that you’d have to cite them.

14.6.5不要以无知、误解或无意为由辩解

14.6.5 Don’t Plead Ignorance, Misunderstanding, or Innocent Intentions

一些学生真诚地认为他们不必引用从网上下载的材料，因为它是免费的并且是公开的。他们错了。其他学生通过声称为自己辩护他们无意误导。好吧，我们读的是文字，而不是思想。下面是如何思考这个问题：如果你借用的人读了你的文章，她会认出你的文字或想法是她自己的，包括释义、摘要，甚至是一般的想法或方法吗？如果是这样，您必须引用该来源并将她的任何确切单词用引号引起来或将它们放在块引号中。没有例外，没有借口。

Some students sincerely believe that they don’t have to cite material downloaded from the Web because it’s free and publicly available. They are wrong. Other students defend themselves by claiming they didn’t intend to mislead. Well, we read words, not minds. Here is how to think about this issue: If the person you borrowed from read your writing, would she recognize your words or ideas as her own, including paraphrases, summaries, or even general ideas or methods? If so, you must cite that source and enclose any of her exact words in quotation marks or set them off in a block quotation. No exceptions, no excuses.

为什么对诚实的错误大惊小怪？

Why the Fuss over Honest Mistakes?

一些学生想知道为什么老师对诚实的失误如此宽容。有什么害处？

Some students wonder why teachers are so unforgiving of honest slip-ups. What’s the harm?

首先，它们会损害您的信誉。不承认消息来源会导致读者怀疑你的诚实，这是对高年级学生的职业生涯终结判断。但它们甚至对初学者也很重要。你的老师正在准备你不是为她写作，而是为那些只会用你的话来判断你的气质的人写作。她需要看到你不仅知道如何深思熟虑地使用消息来源，而且知道如何仔细、完整地承认它们。

First, they harm your credibility. One failure to acknowledge a source can lead readers to doubt your honesty, a career-ending judgment for an advanced student. But they matter even to a beginner. Your teacher is preparing you to write not for her but for others who will have only your words to judge your ethos. She needs to see that you know not only how to use sources thoughtfully but how to acknowledge them carefully and completely.

其他学生认为剽窃是一种没有受害人的罪行。它不是。最近，两位年轻的学者以一种新的方式使用了二十年前发表的方法和思想而受到赞扬。他们顺便提到了他们的来源，但没有完全承认他们的具体债务。这样一来，他们不仅夺取了不应得的荣誉，而且还剥夺了这位年长学者应得的荣誉。更糟糕的是，通过省略导致他的作品的书目线索，他们阻止了读者重新发现它。他失去的信誉不仅使他失去了声誉，而且可能还失去了补助金、晋升和最终的更高薪水。

Other students think plagiarism is a victimless offense. It is not. Recently, two young scholars were praised when they used in a new way methods and ideas published twenty years earlier. They mentioned their source in passing but failed to acknowledge their specific debt fully. In doing so, they not only claimed undeserved credit but deprived the older scholar of credit he deserved. Worse, by omitting the bibliographical trail that led to his work, they kept readers from rediscovering it. The credit he lost cost him not only reputation but also perhaps grants, promotions, and ultimately higher pay.

快速提示：在论文中注明引用

Quick Tip: Indicating Citations in Your Paper

你必须在你的论文中指出你使用来源的每个地方。四种最常见的引文风格中的三种——芝加哥作者日期风格、MLA 风格和 APA 风格（见 14.5）——使用括号引文将读者引导至源代码中的特定页面，并提供足够的信息以在来源列表。

You must indicate in your paper every place where you use a source. The three of the four most common citation styles—Chicago author-date style, MLA style, and APA style (see 14.5)—use parenthetical citations that direct readers to specific pages in the source, with enough information to find the corresponding entry in a list of sources.

有人声称卡斯特罗将改革古巴政治 (Smith 1999, 233)。

Some have claimed that Castro would reform Cuban politics (Smith 1999, 233).

如果您使用芝加哥作者标题风格，您可以使用凸起的数字或上标，将读者引导至页面底部或论文末尾的相应编号注释。

If you use Chicago author-title style, you may instead use a raised number, or superscript, that directs readers to a correspondingly numbered note at the bottom of the page or at the end of the paper.

有人声称卡斯特罗将改革古巴政治。5个

Some have claimed that Castro would reform Cuban politics.5

5. George Smith，古巴游记（波士顿：孩之宝出版社，1999 年），233。

5. George Smith, Travels in Cuba (Boston: Hasbro Press, 1999), 233.

括号内的引用

PARENTHETICAL CITATIONS

括号内（或文内）引用仅包含读者在论文末尾的来源列表中找到来源所需的信息。根据您的领域，该列表将称为您的参考书目、参考文献或引用的作品。您在文内引用中包含的内容首先取决于您使用的是作者标题还是作者日期引用样式。例如，如果您在句子中没有提及作者并且您的来源列表中只有该作者的一部作品，那么这里是引用单一作者作品的作者标题形式：

A parenthetical (or in-text) citation includes only the information a reader needs to locate the source in a list of sources at the end of your paper. Depending on your field, that list will be called your bibliography, references, or works cited. What you include in an in-text citation depends first on whether you use author-title or author-date citation style. For example, here are the author-title forms for citing a single-author work if you do not mention the author in your sentences and you have only one work by that author in your list of sources:

芝加哥作者 - 标题（作者，页[s]）

Chicago Author-Title (Author, page[s])

只有一位作者提供了有关此事的数据 (Kay, 220)。

Only one writer provides data on this matter (Kay, 220).

MLA（作者页面[s]）

MLA (Author page[s])

只有一位作者提供了有关此事的数据 (Kay 220)。

Only one writer provides data on this matter (Kay 220).

如果在您的来源列表中，您为一位作者列出了多个出版物，您必须添加一个简短的标题，以便读者知道是哪一个您引用的出版物。在这种情况下，两种样式的格式是相同的：

If in your list of sources you list more than one publication for an author, you must add a short title so that readers will know which publication you are citing. In this case, the format in both styles is the same:

Chicago Author-Title 和 MLA（作者、简称、页码 [s]）

Chicago Author-Title and MLA (Author, Short Title, page[s])

只有一位作者提供了有关此事的数据（Kay, A Life , 220）。

Only one writer provides data on this matter (Kay, A Life, 220).

在作者日期样式中，您必须将日期添加到每个引用中：

In author-date style, you must add the date to every citation:

芝加哥作者日期（作者日期，页数 [s]）

Chicago Author-Date (Author date, page[s])

只有一位作者提供了这方面的数据 (Kay 2006, 220)。

Only one writer provides data on this matter (Kay 2006, 220).

APA（作者，日期，第 xxx 页）

APA (Author, date, p. xxx)

只有一位作者提供了这方面的数据（Kay，2006 年，第 220 页）。

Only one writer provides data on this matter (Kay, 2006, p. 220).

如果您提到了作者，请从引文中删除姓名：

If you have mentioned the author, drop the name from the citation:

Chicago Author-Date： Kay 是唯一提供有关此事数据的作家 (2006, 220)。

Chicago Author-Date: Kay is the only writer who provides data on this matter (2006, 220).

MLA：凯是唯一提供有关此事数据的作家 (220)。

MLA: Kay is the only writer who provides data on this matter (220).

APA： Kay 是唯一提供有关此事数据的作家（2006 年，第 220 页）。

APA: Kay is the only writer who provides data on this matter (2006, p. 220).

如果一部作品有多位作者，如果您引用了同一作者的多部作品，等等，则还有其他引用规则。对于这些，请查阅相应的指南。

There are additional rules for citations if a work has more than one author, if you cite more than one work by the same author, and so on. For these, consult the appropriate guide.

注释和参考书目

NOTES AND BIBLIOGRAPHY
