在芝加哥作者标题风格中，您使用注释（页面底部的脚注或论文后的尾注）来引导读者找到参考书目中的来源。注释包括与参考书目条目相同的信息，但形式在三个方面有所不同：注释列出名称而不是姓氏，名字，而是名字姓氏；注释的各个元素用逗号而不是句号分隔；和出版数据在括号中。

In Chicago author-title style, you use notes—footnotes at the bottom of the page or endnotes following the paper—to direct readers to sources in a bibliography. Notes include the same information as a bibliography entry, but the form differs in three ways: notes list names not last name, first name, but first name last name; individual elements of a note are separated by commas rather than periods; and publication data are in parentheses.

NOTE FORM: 5. George Smith, Travels in Cuba（波士顿：孩之宝出版社，1999 年），233。

NOTE FORM: 5. George Smith, Travels in Cuba (Boston: Hasbro Press, 1999), 233.

书目 形式：史密斯，乔治。在古巴旅行。波士顿：孩之宝出版社，1999 年。

BIBLIOGRAPHY FORM: Smith, George. Travels in Cuba. Boston: Hasbro Press, 1999.

有关详细信息，请参阅 Turabian 指南或The Chicago Manual of Style。

For details, consult the Turabian guide or The Chicago Manual of Style.

研究人员越来越多地使用括号引文而不是注释，因为注释重复了参考书目中列出的信息。如有疑问，请咨询您的老师。

Researchers are increasingly using parenthetical citations rather than notes, because notes duplicate the information listed in a bibliography. If in doubt, ask your teacher.

15 视觉交流证据

15  Communicating Evidence Visually

与文字相比，大多数读者在表格、图表和图形中更容易掌握定量证据。但是一些视觉形式比其他形式更适合特定的数据和消息。在本章中，我们将向您展示如何选择最能帮助读者掌握数据并理解它们如何支持您的论点的图形形式。

Most readers grasp quantitative evidence more easily in tables, charts, and graphs than they do in words. But some visual forms suit particular data and messages better than others. In this chapter, we show you how to choose the graphic form that best helps readers both grasp your data and understand how they support your argument.

15.1 选择视觉或口头表达

15.1 CHOOSING VISUAL OR VERBAL REPRESENTATIONS

当数据少且简单时，读者可以像在表格中一样轻松地在句子中掌握它们：

When the data are few and simple, readers can grasp them as easily in a sentence as in a table:

2013 年，男性平均年收入为 50,033 美元，女性为 39,157 美元，相差 10,876 美元。

In 2013, on average, men earned $50,033 a year and women $39,157, a difference of $10,876.

表 15.1。2013 年男女工资（美元）

TABLE 15.1. Male-female salaries ($), 2013

男士

Men

50,033

50,033

女性

Women

39,157

39,157

区别

Difference

10,876

10,876

但是，如果您提供的数字不止几个，读者将很难理解它们：

But if you present more than a few numbers, readers will struggle to keep them straight:

1970 年至 2010 年间，家庭结构发生了两方面的变化。1970 年，85% 的家庭有两个父母，但在 1980 年，这个数字下降到 77%，然后在 1990 年下降到 73%，在 2000 年下降到 68%，在 2010 年下降到 64%。单亲家庭的数量上升，尤其是母亲为首的家庭。1970 年，11% 的家庭由单身母亲当家。1980 年，这一数字上升到 18%，1990 年上升到 22%，2000 年上升到 23%。单亲父亲的人数略有变化（1970 年为 1% 的家庭，1980 年为 2%，1990 年为 3% , 2000 年为 4%）。无人当家的家庭稳定在 3-4%。

Between 1970 and 2010, the structure of families changed in two ways. In 1970, 85 percent of families had two parents, but in 1980 that number declined to 77 percent, then to 73 percent in 1990, to 68 percent in 2000, and to 64 percent in 2010. The number of one-parent families rose, particularly families headed by a mother. In 1970, 11 percent of families were headed by a single mother. In 1980, that number rose to 18 percent, in 1990 to 22 percent, and to 23 percent in 2000. There were some marginal changes among single fathers (headed 1 percent of the families in 1970, 2 percent in 1980, 3 percent in 1990, and 4 percent in 2000). Families headed by no adult remained stable at 3–4 percent.

关于术语的注释：我们使用术语图形来表示数据的所有视觉表示。传统上，图形分为表和图。表格是具​​有列和行的网格。图是所有其他图形形式，包括图形、图表、照片、绘图和图表。呈现定量数据的图形分为图表和图表。图表通常由条形、圆圈、点或其他形状组成；图由连续的线组成。

A note on terminology: We use the term graphics for all visual representations of data. Traditionally, graphics are divided into tables and figures. A table is a grid with columns and rows. Figures are all other graphic forms, including graphs, charts, photographs, drawings, and diagrams. Figures that present quantitative data are divided into charts and graphs. Charts typically consist of bars, circles, points, or other shapes; graphs consist of continuous lines.

15.2 选择最有效的图形

15.2 CHOOSING THE MOST EFFECTIVE GRAPHIC

当你以图形方式呈现像该段中那样复杂的数据时，最常见的选择是表格、条形图和折线图，每一种都具有独特的修辞效果。

When you graphically present data as complex as in that paragraph, the most common choices are tables, bar charts, and line graphs, each of which has a distinctive rhetorical effect.

表格看起来精确而客观。它强调离散数字，并要求读者自行推断关系或趋势（除非您在介绍性句子中说明）。

A table seems precise and objective. It emphasizes discrete numbers and requires readers to infer relationships or trends on their own (unless you state them in an introductory sentence).

表 15.2。美国家庭结构的变化，1970-2010

TABLE 15.2. Changes in U.S. family structure, 1970–2010

占家庭总数的百分比
家庭型 1970 1980 1990 2000 2010

2 父母

2 parents

85

85

77

77

73

73

68

68

64

64

母亲

Mother

11

11

18

18

22

22

23

23

27

27

父亲

Father

1个

1

2个

2

3个

3

4个

4

4个

4

没有大人

No adult

3个

3

4个

4

3个

3

4个

4

4个

4

图表和折线图提供了一种视觉图像，它传达的价值不如表格的确切数字那么精确，但具有更大的影响力。但是图表和图形也不同。条形图强调离散项目之间的对比：

Charts and line graphs present a visual image that communicates values less precisely than do the exact numbers of a table but with more impact. But charts and graphs also differ. A bar chart emphasizes contrasts among discrete items:

图 15.1。美国家庭结构的变化，1970-2000

Figure 15.1. Changes in U.S. family structure, 1970–2000

折线图表示随时间的连续变化：

A line graph suggests continuous change over time:

图 15.2。美国家庭结构的变化，1970-2000

Figure 15.2. Changes in U.S. family structure, 1970–2000

选择能够达到您想要的效果的形式，而不是第一个想到的形式。

Choose the form that achieves the effect you want, not the one that comes to mind first.

您应该考虑多少选择取决于您的经验。如果您不熟悉定量研究，请将您的选择限制在基本表格、条形图和折线图上。您的计算机软件提供了更多选择，但请忽略那些您不熟悉的选择。如果你正在进行高级研究，读者会希望你画画来自您所在领域偏爱的更大范围的图形。在这种情况下，请参阅表 15.7，它描述了其他常见形式的修辞用法。如果您在一个经常显示大型数据集中的复杂关系的领域撰写论文或文章，您可能不得不考虑更有创意的数据表示方式。（有关其他资源，请参阅参考书目。）

How many choices you should consider depends on your experience. If you’re new to quantitative research, limit your choices to basic tables, bar charts, and line graphs. Your computer software offers more choices, but ignore those that you aren’t familiar with. If you’re doing advanced research, readers will expect you to draw from a larger range of graphics favored in your field. In that case, consult table 15.7, which describes the rhetorical uses of other common forms. You may have to consider even more creative ways of representing data if you are writing a dissertation or article in a field that routinely displays complex relationships in large data sets. (See the bibliography for additional resources.)

以下是表格、图表和图形基础知识的指南。

What follows is a guide to the basics of tables, charts, and graphs.

15.3 设计表格、图表和图形

15.3 DESIGNING TABLES, CHARTS, AND GRAPHS

计算机程序创建的图形如此令人眼花缭乱，以至于许多作家让他们的软件来决定他们的设计。那是个错误。如果图形不能清楚地传达您的观点，读者就不会在意它看起来多么花哨。以下是设计有效图形的一些原则。要遵循它们，您可能必须更改图形软件中的默认设置。

Computer programs create graphics so dazzling that many writers let their software determine their design. That’s a mistake. Readers don’t care how fancy a graphic looks if it doesn’t communicate your point clearly. Here are some principles for designing effective graphics. To follow them, you may have to change default settings in your graphics software.

15.3.1将每个图形框起来以帮助读者理解它

15.3.1 Frame Each Graphic to Help Readers Understand It

代表复数的图形很少能说明问题。你必须把它框起来，向读者展示可以从中看到什么，以及如何理解它与你的论点的相关性：

A graphic representing complex numbers rarely speaks for itself. You must frame it to show readers what to see in it and how to understand its relevance to your argument:

1. 以描述其数据的方式标记每个图形。对于表格，标签称为标题，并设置在表格左上方；对于图形，标签称为图例，并设置在图形的左下方。保持标题和图例简短但具有足够的描述性以将每个图形与其他图形区分开来。

1. Label every graphic in a way that describes its data. For a table, the label is called a title and is set flush left above the table; for a figure, the label is called a legend and is set flush left below the figure. Keep titles and legends short but descriptive enough to distinguish every graphic from every other one.

• 避免使标题或图例成为笼统的话题。

• Avoid making the title or legend a general topic.

不：户主

NOT: Heads of households

但是：单亲和双亲户主的变化，1970–2010

BUT: Changes in one- and two-parent heads of households, 1970–2010

• 不要提供背景信息或描述数据所暗示的内容。

• Do not give background information or characterize what the data imply.

NOT： 1995-2004 年员工专业化之前咨询对抑郁症儿童的影响较弱

NOT: Weaker effects of counseling on depressed children before professionalization of staff, 1995–2004

但是：咨询对抑郁儿童的影响，1995-2004

BUT: Effect of counseling on depressed children, 1995–2004

• 确保标签能够区分呈现相似数据的图形。

• Be sure labels distinguish graphics presenting similar data.

NOT：高血压的危险因素

NOT: Risk factors for high blood pressure

但是：伊利诺伊州开罗男性患高血压的危险因素

BUT: Risk factors for high blood pressure among men in Cairo, Illinois

或者：密苏里州圣路易斯男性高血压的危险因素

OR: Risk factors for high blood pressure among men in St. Louis, Missouri

2. 在表格或图表中插入有助于读者了解数据如何支持你的观点的信息。例如，如果表格中的数字显示趋势并且趋势的大小很重要，请在最后一列中指出变化。如果图表上的一条线因图表上未提及的影响而发生变化，请在图像中添加文字以对其进行解释。

2. Insert into the table or figure information that helps readers see how the data support your point. For example, if numbers in a table show a trend and the size of the trend matters, indicate the change in a final column. If a line on a graph changes in response to an influence not mentioned on the graph, add text to the image to explain it.

尽管阅读和数学成绩在重新划分后下降了近 100 分，但在引入补充数学和阅读课程后，这一趋势发生了逆转。

Although reading and math scores declined by almost 100 points following redistricting, that trend reversed when supplemental math and reading programs were introduced.

3. 用解释如何解释的句子介绍表格或图形。然后在表格或图中突出显示您希望读者关注的内容，尤其是该介绍性句子中提到的任何数字或关系。例如，我们必须研究表 15.3以了解它如何支持它之前的句子：

3. Introduce the table or figure with a sentence that explains how to interpret it. Then highlight what it is in the table or figure that you want readers to focus on, particularly any number or relationship mentioned in that introductory sentence. For example, we have to study table 15.3 to understand how it supports the sentence before it:

大多数关于汽油消费量增加的预测都被证明是错误的。

Most predictions about increased gasoline consumption have proved wrong.

图 15.3。Mid-City High 的 SAT 分数，1990–2005

Figure 15.3. SAT scores for Mid-City High, 1990–2005

表 15.3。汽油消耗量

TABLE 15.3. Gasoline consumption

 1970 1980 1990 2000

年度里程 (000)

Annual miles (000)

9.5

9.5

10.3

10.3

10.5

10.5

11.7

11.7

年消费量（加仑）

Annual consumption (gal.)

760

760

760

760

520

520

533

533

我们需要一个句子来解释数字如何支持或解释观点，一个信息量更大的标题，以及突出我们应该在表格中看到的内容的视觉帮助：

We need a sentence to explain how the numbers support or explain the claim, a more informative title, and visual help that highlights what we should see in the table:

汽油消费没有像预期的那样增长。尽管美国人在 2000 年的行驶里程比 1970 年多了 23%，但他们使用的燃料却减少了 32%。

Gasoline consumption has not grown as predicted. Though Americans drove 23 percent more miles in 2000 than in 1970, they used 32 percent less fuel.

表 15.4。人均里程和汽油消耗量，1970–2000

TABLE 15.4. Per capita mileage and gasoline consumption, 1970–2000

 1970 1980 1990 2000

年度里程 (000)

Annual miles (000)

9.5

10.3

10.5

11.7

（与 1970 年相比的百分比变化）

(% change vs. 1970)

8.4%

8.4%

10.5%

10.5%

23.1%

23.1%

年消费量（加仑）

Annual consumption (gal.)

760

760

760

760

520

520

533

533

（与 1970 年相比的百分比变化）

(% change vs. 1970)

0%

0%

(31.5%)

(31.5%)

(31.6%)

(31.6%)

添加的句子告诉我们如何解读表15.4中的关键数据，阴影告诉我们在哪里可以找到它们。

The added sentence tells us how to interpret the key data in table 15.4, and the shading tells us where to find them.

15.3.2使所有图形在其内容允许的范围内尽可能简单

15.3.2 Keep All Graphics as Simple as Their Content Allows

一些指南鼓励您将尽可能多的数据塞入图形中。但读者只想看到与您的观点相关的数据，不受干扰。对于所有图形：

Some guides encourage you to cram as much data as you can into a graphic. But readers want to see only the data relevant to your point, free of distractions. For all graphics:

1. 只包括相关数据。如果您仅包含用于记录的数据，请相应地对其进行标记并将其放入附录中。

1. Include only relevant data. If you include data only for the record, label it accordingly and put it in an appendix.

2. 保持视觉冲击简单。

2. Keep the visual impact simple.

• 仅当您将两个或多个图形分组时才将图形框起来。

• Box a graphic only if you group two or more figures.

• 不要给背景上色或加阴影。

• Do not color or shade the background.

对于表

• 切勿同时使用水平和垂直暗线来划分列和行。仅当表格很复杂或您想将读者的眼睛引向一个方向以比较数据时，才使用浅灰色线条。

• Never use both horizontal and vertical dark lines to divide columns and rows. Use light gray lines only if the table is complex or you want to direct your reader’s eyes in one direction to compare data.

• 对于有很多行的表格，每隔五行轻轻涂上一层阴影。

• For tables with many rows, lightly shade every fifth row.

对于图表和图形

• 仅当图形复杂或读者需要查看精确数字时才使用背景网格线。使它们呈浅灰色。

• Use background grid lines only if the graphic is complex or readers need to see precise numbers. Make them light gray.

• 颜色或阴影线或条仅用于显示对比。仅当文本将以彩色打印而不是稍后复印时才使用彩色。（黑白复印件使许多颜色看起来很相似。）

• Color or shade lines or bars only to show a contrast. Use color only if the text will be printed in color and not photocopied later. (Black-and-white photocopies make many colors look alike.)

• 切勿使用标志性条形图（例如，汽车图像来代表汽车生产）或仅为了效果而添加三维。两者看起来都很业余，并且会扭曲读者判断价值的方式。

• Never use iconic bars (for example, images of cars to represent automobile production) or add a third dimension merely for effect. Both look amateurish and can distort how readers judge values.

• 仅当您的读者熟悉此类图表并且您不能以任何其他方式显示数据时，才在三个维度上绘制数据。

• Plot data on three dimensions only when your readers are familiar with such graphs and you cannot display the data in any other way.

3. 使用清晰的标签。

3. Use clear labels.

• 标记表格中的所有行和列以及图表和图形中的两个轴。

• Label all rows and columns in tables and both axes in charts and graphs.

• 使用刻度线和标签指示图表纵轴上的间隔。

• Use tick marks and labels to indicate intervals on the vertical axis of a graph.

• 如果可能，在图像上标记线、条形段等，而不是在侧面设置的图例中。仅当标签会使图像过于复杂而难以阅读时才使用图例。

• If possible, label lines, bar segments, and the like on the image rather than in a legend set to the side. Use a legend only if labels would make the image too complex to read.

• 当特定数字很重要时，将它们添加到图表中的条形或线段，或添加到图表中线条上的点。

• When specific numbers matter, add them to bars or segments in charts or to dots on lines in graphs.

15.4 表格、条形图和折线图的具体指南

15.4 SPECIFIC GUIDELINES FOR TABLES, BAR CHARTS, AND LINE GRAPHS

15.4.1表格

15.4.1 Tables

包含大量数据的表格可能看起来很密集，因此请组织它们以帮助读者。

Tables with lots of data can seem dense, so organize them to help readers.

• 按照让读者快速找到您希望他们看到的内容的原则对行和列进行排序。不要自动选择字母顺序。

• Order the rows and columns by a principle that lets readers quickly find what you want them to see. Do not automatically choose alphabetic order.

• 将数字舍入到相关值。如果小于 1,000 的差异无关紧要，那么 2,123,499 就是无关紧要的精确度。

• Round numbers to a relevant value. If differences of less than 1,000 don’t matter, then 2,123,499 is irrelevantly precise.

• 总计位于列的底部或行的末尾，而不是顶部或左侧。

• Sum totals at the bottom of a column or at the end of a row, not at the top or left.

比较表15.5和15.6。

Compare tables 15.5 and 15.6.

表 15.5。主要工业国家的失业率，1990-2000

TABLE 15.5. Unemployment in major industrial nations, 1990–2000

表 15.5看起来很乱，而且它的项目没有很好地组织。相比之下，表 15.6更清晰，因为它有一个信息丰富的标题、更少的视觉混乱，并且组织的项目让我们更容易看到模式。

Table 15.5 looks cluttered and its items aren’t helpfully organized. In contrast, table 15.6 is clearer because it has an informative title, less visual clutter, and items organized to let us see the pattern more easily.

表 15.6。工业国家失业率的变化，1990-2000

TABLE 15.6. Changes in unemployment rates of industrial nations, 1990–2000

3.3

15.4.2条形图

15.4.2 Bar Charts

条形图通过视觉效果和特定数字进行交流。但是没有排列的条形图意味着没有意义。如果可能，对条形图进行分组和排列以创建与您的消息相匹配的图像。例如，在图 15.4之前的解释性句子的上下文中查看图 15.4。这些项目按字母顺序列出，这种顺序无助于读者理解要点。

Bar charts communicate as much by visual impact as by specific numbers. But bars arranged in no pattern imply no point. If possible, group and arrange bars to create an image that matches your message. For example, look at figure 15.4 in the context of the explanatory sentence before it. The items are listed alphabetically, an order that doesn’t help readers see the point.

世界上大部分沙漠集中在北非和中东地区。

Most of the world’s deserts are concentrated in North Africa and the Middle East.

图 15.4。世界十大沙漠

Figure 15.4. World’s ten largest deserts

相比之下，图 15.5支持具有连贯图像的观点。

In contrast, figure 15.5 supports the claim with a coherent image.

世界上大部分沙漠集中在北非和中东地区。

Most of the world’s deserts are concentrated in North Africa and the Middle East.

图 15.5。大沙漠的世界分布

Figure 15.5. World distribution of large deserts

在标准条形图中，每个条形代表整体的 100%。但有时读者需要看到整体部分的具体数字。您可以通过两种方式做到这一点：

In standard bar charts, each bar represents 100 percent of a whole. But sometimes readers need to see specific numbers for parts of the whole. You can do that in two ways:

• 将条分成比例部分，创建一个“堆叠”条。

• Divide the bars into proportional parts, creating a “stacked” bar.

• 给整体的每个部分一个单独的条，然后将这些部分分组。

• Give each part of the whole its own bar, then group the parts into clusters.

仅当您希望读者比较不同条形图的整体值而不是它们的分割部分时才使用堆叠条形图，因为读者无法仅凭眼睛轻松比较各部分的比例。如果您确实使用堆积条，请执行以下操作：

Use stacked bars only when you want readers to compare whole values for different bars rather than their divided segments, because readers can’t easily compare the proportions of segments by eye alone. If you do use stacked bars, do this:

• 按逻辑顺序排列段。如果可能，将最大的部分放在底部最深的阴影中。

• Arrange segments in a logical order. If possible, put the largest segment at the bottom in the darkest shade.

• 用特定数字标记段并协助比较；用灰线连接相应的线段。

• Label segments with specific numbers and to assist comparisons; connect corresponding segments with gray lines.

比较图15.6和15.7：

Compare figures 15.6 and 15.7:

图 15.6。世界核能发电量，1980–1999

Figure 15.6. World generation of nuclear energy, 1980–1999

图 15.7。最大的核能发电机，1980-1999

Figure 15.7. Largest generators of nuclear energy, 1980–1999

如果因为段与整体一样重要而对条形图进行分组，请执行以下操作：

If you group bars because segments are as important as the wholes, do this:

• 按逻辑顺序排列组；如果可能的话，将大小相似的金条并排放置（所有组中的金条都以相同的方式排序）。

• Arrange groups in a logical order; if possible put bars of similar size next to one another (order bars in the same way through all the groups).

• 用整体编号标记组，在每个组上方或底部标签下方。

• Label groups with the number for the whole, either above each group or below the labels on the bottom.

大多数适合条形图的数据也可以在饼图中显示。饼图在杂志、小报和年度报告中很受欢迎。虽然引人注目，但它们比条形图更难阅读。读者必须比较大小通常难以判断的片段的比例。但饼图有其用武之地，尤其是传达关于数据比较大小的定性印象，要么显示一个部分比其他部分大得不成比例，要么表明数据被分成许多小部分。但是，请避免使用饼图来传达定量数据。请改用条形图。

Most data that fit a bar chart can also be shown in a pie chart. Pie charts are popular in magazines, tabloids, and annual reports. While splashy, they are harder to read than bar charts. Readers must compare proportions of segments whose sizes are often hard to judge. But pie charts have their place, especially to communicate qualitative impressions about the comparative size of data, either to show that one segment is disproportionately larger than the rest or that the data is divided into many small segments. Avoid using pie charts to convey quantitative data, however. Use bar charts instead.

15.4.3折线图

15.4.3 Line Graphs

因为折线图强调趋势，所以读者必须看到清晰的图像才能正确解读它。请执行下列操作：

Because a line graph emphasizes trends, readers must see a clear image to interpret it correctly. Do the following:

• 选择使直线朝支持你的观点的方向（向上或向下）移动的变量。如果好消息是高中辍学率下降（下降），您可以更有效地将相同数据表示为表示保留率增加（上升）的上升线。如果您想强调坏消息，请找到一种方法将您的数据表示为下降线。

• Choose the variable that makes the line go in the direction, up or down, that supports your point. If the good news is a reduction (down) in high school dropouts, you can more effectively represent the same data as a rising line indicating increase in retention (up). If you want to emphasize bad news, find a way to represent your data as a falling line.

• 仅当您不能以任何其他方式表达您的观点时，才在一张图上绘制多于六条线。

• Plot more than six lines on one graph only if you cannot make your point in any other way.

• 如果您的数据点少于十个左右，请用点表示它们。如果只有少数相关，请插入数字以显示它们的确切值。

• If you have fewer than ten or so data points, indicate them with dots. If only a few are relevant, insert numbers to show their exact value.

• 不要依靠不同的灰色阴影来区分线条，如图15.8 所示。

• Do not depend on different shades of gray to distinguish lines, as in figure 15.8.

比较图 15.8和图 15.9：

Compare figure 15.8 and figure 15.9:

图 15.8。1870 年至 1990 年在美国出生的外国居民

Figure 15.8. Foreign-born residents in the United States, 1870–1990

图 15.9。1870 年至 1990 年在美国出生的外国居民

Figure 15.9. Foreign-born residents in the United States, 1870–1990

图 15.8更难阅读，因为灰色阴影不能很好地将线条与背景区分开来，而且我们的眼睛必须来回移动才能将线条与图例连接起来。图 15.9使这些联系更加清晰。

Figure 15.8 is harder to read because the shades of gray do not distinguish the lines well against the background and because our eyes have to flick back and forth to connect the lines to the legend. Figure 15.9 makes those connections clearer.

这些显示相同数据的不同方式可能会造成混淆。要消除这种混淆，请测试表示相同数据的不同方式。构建替代图形；然后请不熟悉数据的人判断它们的影响和清晰度。一定要用一句话来介绍图形，说明你希望图形支持的主张。

These different ways of showing the same data can be confusing. To cut through that confusion, test different ways of representing the same data. Construct alternative graphics; then ask someone unfamiliar with the data to judge them for impact and clarity. Be sure to introduce the figures with a sentence that states the claim you want the figure to support.

15.5 合乎道德地交流数据

15.5 COMMUNICATING DATA ETHICALLY

您的图形不仅要清晰准确，而且要诚实。不要歪曲数据的形象来表达你的观点。例如，下面的两个条形图显示相同的数据，但暗示不同的消息：

Your graphic must be not only clear and accurate, but honest. Do not distort the image of the data to make your point. For example, the two bar charts below display identical data, yet imply different messages:

图 15.10。国会大厦污染指数，1982–1994

Figure 15.10. Capitol City pollution index, 1982–1994

左图中 0-100 的比例创建了一个相当平坦的斜率，这使得污染的下降看起来很小。然而，右图中的垂直刻度不是从 0 开始，而是从 80 开始。当刻度被如此截断时，它会产生更陡峭的斜率，从而夸大小的对比度。

The 0–100 scale in the figure on the left creates a fairly flat slope, which makes the drop in pollution seem small. The vertical scale in the figure on the right, however, begins not at 0 but at 80. When a scale is so truncated, it creates a sharper slope that exaggerates small contrasts.

图表也可能通过暗示错误的相关性而产生误导。有人可能会声称失业率随着工会会员人数的减少而下降，并提供图 15.11作为证据。事实上，在那张图中，工会会员资格和失业率似乎确实紧密地联系在一起，以至于读者可能会推断出一个导致另一个：

Graphs can also mislead by implying false correlations. Someone might claim that unemployment goes down as union membership goes down and offer figure 15.11 as evidence. And indeed, in that graph, union membership and the unemployment rate do seem to move together so closely that a reader might infer one causes the other:

图 15.11。工会成员和失业率，1993-1999

Figure 15.11. Union membership and unemployment rate, 1993–1999

但左轴（工会会员）的比例与右轴（失业率）的比例不同，这使得这两种趋势看起来可能存在因果关系。他们可能是，但扭曲的形象并不能证明这一点。

But the scale for the left axis (union membership) differs from the scale for the right axis (the unemployment rate), making it seem that the two trends could be causally related. They may be, but that distorted image doesn’t prove it.

当图像鼓励读者错误判断值时，图表也会产生误导。图 15.12中的两个图表表示完全相同的数据，但似乎传达了不同的信息：

Graphs can also mislead when the image encourages readers to misjudge values. The two charts in figure 15.12 represent exactly the same data but seem to communicate different messages:

图 15.12。州立大学本科生中郊区县的代表（占总数的百分比）

Figure 15.12. Representation of suburban counties in state university undergraduates (percent of total)

图 15.12中的图表都是堆积面积图。尽管它们在视觉上有所不同，但它们代表相同的数据。诸如此类的面积图表示值的变化不是通过线条的角度，而是通过之间的区域他们。在这两个图表中，南、东和西的波段宽度大致相同，表明它们所代表的值几乎没有变化。然而，北部的范围急剧扩大，表明它所代表的人数急剧增加。在左边的图表中，读者很容易误判前三个波段，因为它们位于北波段上升的顶部，使这些波段看起来也在上升。另一方面，在右侧的图表中，这三个波段没有上升，因为它们位于底部。现在只有北方的乐队升起。

The charts in figure 15.12 are both stacked area charts. Despite their visual differences, they represent the same data. Area charts such as these represent changes in values not by the angles of the lines, but by the areas between them. In both charts, the bands for south, east, and west are roughly the same width throughout, indicating little change in the values they represent. The band for the north, however, widens sharply, representing a sharp increase in the numbers it represents. In the chart on the left, readers could easily misjudge the top three bands, because they are on top of the rising north band, making those bands seem to rise as well. In the chart on the right, on the other hand, those three bands do not rise because they are on the bottom. Now only the band for the north rises.

以下是避免视觉误传的四个准则：

Here are four guidelines for avoiding visual misrepresentation:

• 不要操纵比例尺来放大或降低对比度。

• Do not manipulate a scale to magnify or reduce a contrast.

• 不要使用图像扭曲数值的图形。

• Do not use a figure whose image distorts values.

• 不要使表格或图形不必要地复杂或简单到容易引起误解。

• Do not make a table or figure unnecessarily complex or misleadingly simple.

• 如果表格或图表支持某个观点，请说明。

• If the table or figure supports a point, state it.

表 15.7。常见图形形式及其用途

Table 15.7. Common graphic forms and their uses

数据修辞用途

Data Rhetorical Uses

表 15.7。（续）

Table 15.7. (continued)

数据修辞用途

Data Rhetorical Uses

16 介绍和结论

16  Introductions and Conclusions

一个好的介绍可以鼓励读者感兴趣地阅读你的作品，并让他们做好准备更好地理解它。一个好的结论会让他们清楚地陈述你的观点，并重新认识它的重要性。在本章中，我们将向您展示如何编写两者。您花在修改引言和结论上的时间可能是您所做的最重要的修改。

A good introduction encourages readers to read your work with interest and prepares them to understand it better. A good conclusion leaves them with a clear statement of your point and renewed appreciation of its significance. In this chapter, we show you how to write both. The time you spend revising your introduction and conclusion may be the most important revision you do.

一旦您认为您的草稿可行，您就可以准备好编写您的最终介绍和结论。一些作家认为这意味着遵循标准建议：用活泼或可爱的东西吸引他们的注意力。这不是无用的建议，但读者想要的不仅仅是可爱和活泼。在第二部分中，我们向您展示了如何围绕研究问题开发项目。在这里，我们向您展示如何使用该问题来吸引您的读者。抓住他们注意力的是他们认为需要解决的问题，而抓住他们注意力的是你已经找到它的承诺。正如我们所说，您总是可以与那些说“我不同意”的读者一起工作。你无法生存的是那些耸耸肩说，我不在乎的人。

Once you think you have a draft that works, you’re ready to write your final introduction and conclusion. Some writers think that means following the standard advice: Grab their attention with something snappy or cute. That’s not useless advice, but readers want more than cute and snappy. In part II, we showed you how to develop a project around a research problem. Here, we show you how to use that problem to engage your readers. What seizes their attention is a problem they think needs a solution, and what holds it is a promise that you’ve found it. As we’ve said, you can always work with readers who say, I don’t agree. What you can’t survive are those who shrug and say, I don’t care.

16.1 引言的通用结构

16.1 THE COMMON STRUCTURE OF INTRODUCTIONS

正如我们所强调的，不同的研究团体以不同的方式做事，但这些差异在他们的介绍中似乎最大。这三个浓缩示例来自文化批评、计算机设计和法律史领域。但是，尽管它们表面上看起来不同，但它们的底层结构是相同的。

As we’ve emphasized, different research communities do things in different ways, but nowhere do those differences seem greater than in their introductions. These three condensed examples are from the fields of cultural criticism, computer design, and legal history. But while they look different on the surface, their underlying structures are identical.

(1) 为什么机器不能更像人？几乎在《星际迷航：下一代》的每一集中，机器人数据都想知道是什么让一个人成为一个人。在最初的《星际迷航》中，半火神斯波克先生提出了类似的问题，他作为一个人的地位被他机器般的逻辑和缺乏情感所破坏。事实上，数据和Spock只是最近探索人性本质的“准人”。从弗兰肯斯坦的怪物到终结者，各种生物都提出了同样的问题。但真正的问题是，为什么这些努力成为人的角色总是白人和男性。作为文化诠释者，他们是否默许地强化了对“正常”意味着什么的破坏性刻板印象？事实上，模范人物似乎是由排除世界上大多数人的西方标准定义的。

(1) Why can’t a machine be more like a man? In almost every episode of Star Trek: The Next Generation, the android Data wonders what makes a person a person. In the original Star Trek, similar questions were raised by the half-Vulcan Mr. Spock, whose status as a person was undermined by his machinelike logic and lack of emotion. In fact, Data and Spock are only the most recent “quasi-persons” who have explored the nature of humanity. The same question has been raised by and about creatures ranging from Frankenstein’s monster to the Terminator. But the real question is why these characters who struggle to be persons are always white and male. As cultural interpreters, do they tacitly reinforce destructive stereotypes of what it means to be “normal”? The model person seems in fact to be defined by Western criteria that exclude most of the people in the world.

(2) 作为其持续质量改进 (CQI) 计划的一部分，Motodyne Computers 计划重新设计其 Unidyne TM在线帮助系统的用户界面。其界面规范要求不言自明的图标，让用户无需口头标签即可识别其功能。Motodyne 拥有三年的当前图标集经验，但没有数据显示哪些图标是不言自明的。缺少此类数据，我们无法确定要重新设计哪些图标。该报告提供了 11 个图标的数据，显示其中 5 个图标不言自明。

(2) As part of its program of Continuous Quality Improvement (CQI), Motodyne Computers plans to redesign the user interface for its UnidyneTM online help system. The specifications for its interface call for self-explanatory icons that let users identify their function without verbal labels. Motodyne has three years’ experience with its current icon set, but it has no data showing which icons are self-explanatory. Lacking such data, we cannot determine which icons to redesign. This report provides data for eleven icons, showing that five of them are not self-explanatory.

(3) 在当今社会，1780年在美国后方被俘的便衣英国间谍约翰·安德烈少校会被绞死吗？虽然被认为是高尚的爱国者，但他受到了军法规定的惩罚。随着时间的推移，我们的传统发生了变化，但对间谍的惩罚却没有改变。这是唯一可以判处死刑的罪行。然而，最近最高法院驳回了对民事案件的强制性死刑判决，使其在军事案件中的适用变得模糊不清。如果最高法院的裁决适用于军队，国会是否必须修改《统一军事司法法典》？本文的结论是会的。

(3) In today’s society, would Major John André, a British spy in civilian clothes captured behind American lines in 1780, be hanged? Though considered a noble patriot, he suffered the punishment mandated by military law. Over time our traditions have changed, but the punishment for spying has not. It is the only offense that mandates death. Recently, however, the Supreme Court has rejected mandatory death sentences in civilian cases, creating an ambiguity in their application to military cases. If Supreme Court decisions apply to the military, will Congress have to revise the Uniform Code of Military Justice? This article concludes that it will.

这三个导言中提出的主题和问题与其目标读者的差异很大，但在它们背后是读者在所有导言中寻找的共同模式，无论领域如何。该通用结构由三个元素组成：

The topics and problems posed in those three introductions differ as much as their intended readers, but behind them is a shared pattern that readers look for in all introductions, regardless of field. That common structure consists of three elements:

• 情境背景

• contextualizing background

• 问题陈述

• statement of the problem

• 对问题的回应

• response to the problem

并非每个介绍都包含所有这三个要素，但大多数都有。

Not every introduction has all three elements, but most do.

以下是每个介绍中的上下文 + 问题 + 响应模式：

Here is that pattern of Context + Problem + Response in each of those introductions:

(1)背景：为什么机器不能更像人？. . . 从弗兰肯斯坦的怪物到终结者，各种生物都提出了同样的问题。

(1) CONTEXT: Why can’t a machine be more like a man? . . . The same question has been raised by and about creatures ranging from Frankenstein’s monster to the Terminator.

问题：但真正的问题是。. . 他们是否暗中强化了对“正常”意味着什么的破坏性刻板印象？

PROBLEM: But the real question is . . . do they tacitly reinforce destructive stereotypes of what it means to be “normal”?

回应：模范人物实际上似乎是由排除世界上大多数人的西方标准定义的。

RESPONSE: The model person seems in fact to be defined by Western criteria that exclude most of the people in the world.

(2)背景：作为其持续质量改进 (CQI) 计划的一部分，Motodyne Computers 计划重新设计用户界面。. . . Motodyne 拥有三年的当前图标集经验。. .

(2) CONTEXT: As part of its program of Continuous Quality Improvement (CQI), Motodyne Computers plans to redesign the user interface. . . . Motodyne has three years’ experience with its current icon set . . .

问题：但它没有数据显示哪些图标是不言自明的。缺少此类数据，我们无法确定要重新设计哪些图标。

PROBLEM: but it has no data showing which icons are self-explanatory. Lacking such data, we cannot determine which icons to redesign.

回应：这份报告提供了十一个图标的数据，表明其中五个图标不言自明。

RESPONSE: This report provides data for eleven icons, showing that five of them are not self-explanatory.

(3)背景：在当今社会，John André 少校会。. . [因为间谍]被绞死？. . . 这是唯一可以判处死刑的罪行。

(3) CONTEXT: In today’s society, would Major John André . . . be hanged [for spying]? . . . It is the only offense that mandates death.

问题：然而，最近最高法院驳回了对民事案件的强制性死刑判决，导致其在军事案件中的适用变得模棱两可。. . . 国会是否必须修改《统一军事司法法典》？

PROBLEM: Recently, however, the Supreme Court has rejected mandatory death sentences in civilian cases, creating an ambiguity in their application to military cases. . . . Will Congress have to revise the Uniform Code of Military Justice?

回应：本文的结论是它会。

RESPONSE: This article concludes that it will.

这些元素中的每一个都发挥着自己的作用，不仅在激励读者阅读你的论文方面，而且在帮助他们理解它方面。

Each of those elements plays it own role not only in motivating readers to read your paper, but in helping them understand it.

16.2 第 1 步：建立上下文

16.2 STEP 1: ESTABLISHING A CONTEXT

开场语境建立了共同点，即读者和作者之间对作者将要解决的更大问题的共同理解。但它做的更多，如童话故事的开头所示：

The opening context establishes common ground, a shared understanding between reader and writer about the larger issue the writer will address. But it does more, illustrated by the opening of a fairy tale:

一个阳光明媚的早晨，小红帽在去外婆家的路上快步穿过森林。稳定的语境 [想象蝴蝶随着长笛和小提琴在她头上翩翩起舞]

One sunny morning Little Red Riding Hood was skipping through the forest on her way to Grandmother’s house.stable context [imagine butterflies dancing around her head to flutes and violins]

就像大多数童话故事的开头一样，这个故事建立了一个没有问题的，甚至是快乐的背景，只是为了让它可以被一个问题打断：

Like the opening to most fairy tales, this one establishes an unproblematic, even happy context, just so that it can be disrupted with a problem:

. . . 突然间，饥饿的狼从一棵树后面跳了出来，破坏了环境[想象一下长号和大号]吓坏了她[而且，如果他们在故事中迷失了自己，小孩子也是如此]。成本

. . . when suddenly Hungry Wolf jumped out from behind a treedisrupting condition [imagine trombones and tubas] frightening her [and, if they’ve lost themselves in the story, little children as well].cost

故事的其余部分详细说明了这个问题，然后解决了它。

The rest of the story elaborates that problem and then resolves it.

尽管看起来不太可能，但大多数介绍都遵循相同的策略。他们以一个共同点的稳定背景开场——一些对已知研究的显然毫无问题的描述。然后作者用一个问题打断它，实际上是说：读者，你可能认为你知道一些事情， 但 你的知识是有缺陷的或不完整的。

Unlikely though it may seem, most introductions follow the same strategy. They open with the stable context of a common ground—some apparently unproblematic account of research already known. The writer then disrupts it with a problem, saying in effect: Reader, you may think you know something, but your knowledge is flawed or incomplete.

(3)稳定的 语境：在当今社会，英国间谍约翰安德烈少校会。. . 被绞死？. . . [从事间谍活动] 是唯一会判处死刑的罪行。

(3) STABLE CONTEXT: In today’s society, would Major John André, a British spy . . . be hanged? . . . [Spying] is the only offense that mandates death.

干扰性 问题：然而，最近，最高法院驳回了强制性死刑判决。. . .

DISRUPTING PROBLEM: Recently, however, the Supreme Court has rejected mandatory death sentences. . . .

并非每篇研究论文都以共同点开头。这个直接打开有问题：

Not every research paper opens with common ground. This one opens directly with a problem:

最近，人们发现使臭氧层变薄的化学过程并不像以前想象的那么好。我们可能错误地将氢氟烃标记为主要原因。

Recently the chemical processes that thin the ozone layer have been found to be less well understood than once thought. We may have labeled hydrofluorocarbons as the chief cause incorrectly.

有些读者可能会发现这个问题令人不安，足以激发他们的阅读动机，但我们可以通过将它与先前研究的看似毫无问题的背景一起介绍来加强它的冲击力，特别是这样我们就可以破坏它：

Some readers might find that problem disturbing enough to motivate their reading, but we can heighten its punch by introducing it with the seemingly unproblematic context of prior research, specifically so that we can disrupt it:

随着我们对环境威胁的调查，我们对酸雨中的化学过程和二氧化碳的积累有了更好的了解，使我们能够更好地了解它们对生物圈的影响。稳定的背景[听起来不错。]但是最近发现臭氧层变薄的过程比以前更不为人所知 想法。不稳定条件我们可能错误地将氢氟烃标记为主要原因。结果

As we have investigated environmental threats, our understanding of chemical processes in acid rain and the buildup of carbon dioxide has improved, allowing us to understand better their effects on the biosphere.stable context [Sounds good.] But recently the processes that thin the ozone layer have been found to be less well understood than once thought.destabilizing condition We may have labeled hydrofluorocarbons as the chief cause incorrectly.consequence

读者现在没有理由在问题中看到他们的自身利益，而是两个：不仅仅是问题本身，还有他们对整个问题的不完整理解。

Readers now have not one reason to see their self-interest in the problem, but two: not just the problem itself, but also their incomplete understanding of the whole matter.

你的上下文可以描述一个误解：

Your context can describe a misunderstanding:

人们普遍认为，十字军东征是出于宗教热情，旨在将圣地归还给基督教世界。稳定的背景 事实上，动机至少部分是政治性的，如果不是很大的话。

The Crusades are widely believed to have been motivated by religious zeal to restore the Holy Land to Christendom.stable context In fact, the motives were at least partly, if not largely, political.

它可以调查有缺陷的研究：

It can survey flawed research:

很少有社会学概念像天主教所谓的对自杀的保护作用一样迅速失宠。它曾经是社会学的基本信念之一，但在欧洲和北美都受到一系列研究的质疑。. . . 稳定的语境 然而，某些研究仍然发现了宗教的影响。. .

Few sociological concepts have fallen out of favor as fast as Catholicism’s alleged protective influence against suicide. Once one of sociology’s basic beliefs, it has been called into question by a series of studies in both Europe and North America. . . .stable context However, certain studies still find an effect of religion . . .

或者它可能指向对问题本身的误解：

Or it can point to a misunderstanding about the problem itself:

美国教育的重点是教孩子批判性思考、提出问题和测试答案。稳定的背景 但是批判性思维领域已经被时尚和特殊利益所接管。

American education has focused on teaching children to think critically, to ask questions and test answers.stable context But the field of critical thinking has been taken over by fads and special interests.

一些缺乏经验的研究人员在共同点上吝啬，打开他们的论文，就好像他们正在从中断的地方继续课堂对话。他们的介绍非常粗略，只有课程中的其他人才能理解：

Some inexperienced researchers skimp on common ground, opening their paper as if they were picking up a class conversation where it left off. Their introductions are so sketchy that only others in the course would understand them:

鉴于 Hofstadter 未能尊重数学、音乐和艺术之间的差异，《具身的心灵》反响如此激烈也就不足为奇了。目前尚不清楚是什么引起了争议。我会争辩说，任何关于人类思想的解释都必须是跨学科的。. . .

In view of Hofstadter’s failure to respect the differences among math, music, and art, it is not surprising that the response to The Embodied Mind would be stormy. It is less clear what caused the controversy. I will argue that any account of the human mind must be interdisciplinary. . . .

当你起草你的介绍时，想象你正在写信给一个读过一些与你相同的资源并且通常对相同问题感兴趣但不知道你班上具体发生了什么的人。

When you draft your introduction, imagine you are writing to someone who has read some of the same sources as you and is generally interested in the same issues, but does not know what specifically happened in your class.

其他人则犯了相反的错误，认为他们应该列出他们阅读的所有与他们的主题有一定距离的来源。仅调查那些您将直接修改其调查结果的来源。仅当您需要在更广泛的上下文中定位问题时才添加更多。

Others make the opposite mistake, thinking they should list every source they read that remotely touches their topic. Survey only those sources whose findings you will directly modify. Add more only if you need to locate the problem in a wider context.

16.3 第 2 步：陈述您的问题

16.3 STEP 2: STATING YOUR PROBLEM

一旦你建立了一个稳定的环境或共同点，就用一个问题来破坏它。正如我们所说，研究问题的陈述有两部分（见第 4 章）：

Once you establish a stable context or common ground, disrupt it with a problem. As we’ve said, the statement of a research problem has two parts (see chapter 4):

• 知识或理解不完整的情况，以及

• a condition of incomplete knowledge or understanding, and

• 这种情况的后果，更显着的理解差距

• the consequences of that condition, a more significant gap in understanding

你可以直接陈述条件：

You can state the condition directly:

. . . 但 Motodyne 没有数据显示哪些图标是不言自明的。

. . . but Motodyne has no data showing which icons are self-explanatory.

或者你可以在间接问题中暗示它：

Or you can imply it in an indirect question:

真正的问题是为什么这些角色总是白人和男性。

The real question is why these characters are always white and male.

只有当你想象有人问，那又如何？，然后将错误理解的后果作为答案拼写出来。您可以将该后果表述为直接成本：

You make this condition of ignorance or flawed understanding part of a full research problem only when you imagine someone asking, So what?, and then spell out as an answer the consequence of that flawed understanding. You can state that consequence as a direct cost:

缺少此类数据，我们无法确定要重新设计哪些图标。成本

Lacking such data, we cannot determine which icons to redesign.cost

或者您可以将成本转化为收益：

Or you can transform the cost into a benefit:

有了这些数据，我们就可以确定要重新设计哪些图标。益处

With such data, we could determine which icons to redesign.benefit

陈述成本和陈述收益之间的选择不仅仅是风格问题。一些研究表明，与潜在收益相比，实际成本更能激发读者的兴趣。我们的建议：在提出问题时说明成本或后果；陈述好处以加强您的解决方案。

The choice between stating a cost and stating a benefit is not just a matter of style. Some research indicates that readers are more motivated by a real cost than by a potential benefit. Our suggestion: state costs or consequences when presenting your problem; state benefits to intensify your solution.

这是陈述问题的直接版本；有变化。

That’s the straightforward version of stating a problem; there are variations.

16.3.1什么时候应该明确说明问题的情况？

16.3.1 When Should You State the Condition of a Problem Explicitly?

有时，您会解决一个如此熟悉的问题，以至于它的名字暗示了该领域的情况和后果：DNA 在人格中的作用；莎士比亚的外语知识。同样，在某些领域，如数学和自然科学，许多研究问题是众所周知的，因此只需说明条件就足以让人联想到其后果。这又是克里克和沃森对 DNA 双螺旋结构的里程碑式描述的（浓缩）介绍：

Occasionally, you tackle a problem so familiar that its name implies both its condition and consequence to those in the field: the role of DNA in personality; Shakespeare’s knowledge of foreign languages. Likewise, in some fields like mathematics and the natural sciences, many research problems are widely known, so just stating the condition is enough to bring to mind its consequence. Here again is that (condensed) introduction to Crick and Watson’s landmark account of the double-helix structure of DNA:

我们希望提出脱氧核糖核酸 (DNA) 盐的结构。这种结构具有新颖的特征，具有相当大的生物学意义。Pauling 和 Corey 已经提出了核酸的结构。他们在出版前亲切地向我们提供了他们的手稿。他们的模型由三个相互缠绕的链组成，磷酸盐靠近纤维轴，碱基在外面。我们认为，这种结构并不令人满意。. . .

We wish to suggest a structure for the salt of deoxyribose nucleic acid (D.N.A.). This structure has novel features which are of considerable biological interest. A structure for nucleic acid has already been proposed by Pauling and Corey. They kindly made their manuscript available to us in advance of publication. Their model consists of three intertwined chains, with the phosphates near the fibre axis, and the bases on the outside. In our opinion, this structure is unsatisfactory. . . .

对他们来说，仅仅“建议”一种 DNA 结构就足够了，因为他们知道每个人都想知道它是什么。（不过请注意，他们确实通过提及 Pauling 和 Corey 的错误模型提出了一个问题。）

It was enough for them merely to “suggest” a structure for DNA, because they knew everyone wanted to know what it was. (Note, though, that they do raise a problem by mentioning Pauling and Corey’s incorrect model.)

在自然科学和大多数社会科学中，研究人员通常会解决读者熟悉的问题。在这种情况下，您可能认为您不需要详细说明您的问题。但是除非你告诉他们，否则读者不会知道你的研究会纠正他们知识中的特定缺陷。

In the natural sciences and most social sciences, researchers usually address questions familiar to their readers. In that case, you might think you do not need to spell out your problem. But readers won’t know the particular flaw in their knowledge that your research will correct unless you tell them.

在人文学科和一些社会科学领域，研究人员更多地提出他们自己发现甚至发明的问题，读者会发现新的问题，而且常常会感到惊讶。在这种情况下，您必须明确描述您打算解决的知识差距或有缺陷的理解。

In the humanities and some social sciences, researchers more often pose questions that they alone have found or even invented, questions that readers find new and often surprising. In that case, you must explicitly describe the gap in knowledge or flawed understanding that you intend to resolve.

16.3.2你应该详细说明后果和好处吗？

16.3.2 Should You Spell Out Consequences and Benefits?

为了说服读者他们应该认真对待你的问题，你必须说明如果不解决他们将付出的代价或好处 如果是的话，他们会获益。有时你可以描述你的研究帮助读者避免的有形成本（见 4.1）：

To convince readers that they should take your problem seriously, you must state the cost they will pay if it is not resolved or the benefits they gain if it is. Sometimes you can describe tangible costs that your research helps your readers avoid (see 4.1):

去年，River City 主管同意 River City 应将 Bayside 开发项目纳入其税基。然而，他们的计划几乎没有基于经济分析。如果董事会在不了解这座城市将为此付出多大代价的情况下投票吞并 Bayside，董事会就有可能使 River City 本已不稳定的财政状况进一步恶化。如果将下水道和供水服务的负担纳入城市规范的分析中，吞并的成本将超过董事会的假设。

Last year the River City Supervisors agreed that River City should add the Bayside development to its tax base. Their plan, however, was based on little economic analysis. If the Board votes to annex Bayside without understanding what it will cost the city, the Board risks worsening River City’s already shaky fiscal situation. When the burden of bringing sewer and water service up to city code are included in the analysis, the annexation will cost more than the Board assumes.

这是激发应用研究的问题。无知领域（没有经济分析）会产生明显的后果（更高的成本）。

This is the kind of problem that motivates applied research. The area of ignorance (no economic analysis) has tangible consequences (higher costs).

在纯粹的研究中，当你不是用金钱来解释后果，而是解释为误解，或者，作为更好理解的可能好处时，你会提出同样的问题：

In pure research, you formulate the same kind of problem when you explain the consequence not in money, but as misunderstanding or, alternatively, as the possible benefit of better understanding:

自 1972 年以来，美国城市吞并了高档社区以支撑税基，但往往带来令人失望的经济效益。但如果他们做了基本的经济分析，这些结果是可以预测的。兼并运动是地方一级的政治决策如何未能使用专家信息的案例研究。令人费解的是，为什么城市不寻求这种专业知识。如果我们能发现为什么城市不能依赖基本的经济分析，我们可能会更好地理解为什么他们的决策在其他领域也经常失败。本文分析了三个城市在不考虑经济后果的情况下吞并周边地区的决策过程。

Since 1972 American cities have annexed upscale neighborhoods to prop up tax bases, often bringing disappointing economic benefits. But those results could have been predicted had they done basic economic analysis. The annexation movement is a case study of how political decisions at the local level fail to use expert information. What is puzzling is why cities do not seek out that expertise. If we can discover why cities fail to rely on basic economic analyses, we might better understand why their decision making fails so often in other areas as well. This paper analyzes the decision-making process of three cities that annexed surrounding areas without consideration of economic consequences.

16.3.3测试条件和后果

16.3.3 Testing Conditions and Consequences

在第 4 章中，我们建议了一种方法来测试您是否清楚地表达了不解决问题的后果：在最能说明读者无知或误解情况的句子之后，问，那又怎样？

In chapter 4 we suggested a way to test how clearly you articulate the consequences of not solving a problem: after the sentences that best state your readers’ condition of ignorance or misunderstanding, ask, So what?

Motodyne 没有数据显示哪些图标是不言自明的。【那又怎样？] 没有这些数据，它无法确定重新设计哪些图标。

Motodyne has no data showing which icons are self-explanatory. [So what?] Without such data, it cannot determine which icons to redesign.

墨西哥版和美国版关于阿拉莫的故事有明显的不同，但不同时代的美国版也不同。【那又怎样？] 出色地 。. .

Stories about the Alamo in Mexican and U.S. versions differ in obvious ways, but U.S. versions from different eras also differ. [So what?] Well . . .

回答那又怎样？可能会令人恼火，甚至令人沮丧。如果您爱上了有关阿拉莫战役的故事，您可以随心所欲地追寻它们，而不必回答除了您自己以外的任何人：我只是喜欢阅读它们。但要让其他人欣赏你的研究，你必须“推销”他们的重要性。否则，他们为什么要花时间在上面？

Answering So what? can be exasperating, even dismaying. If you fall in love with stories about the Battle of the Alamo, you can pursue them to your heart’s content, without having to answer to anyone but yourself: I just like reading about them. But for others to appreciate your research, you have to “sell” them on its significance. Otherwise, why should they spend time on it?

要说服读者关心您的作品，您必须向他们表明您的问题就是他们的问题——即使他们还不知道。你必须让他们相信，如果他们继续不知道，比如说，好莱坞如何将阿拉莫的故事变成神话，他们将无法理解关于民族认同的更重要的东西。可以肯定的是，有读者又会问了，So what？我不在乎民族认同。你只能耸耸肩思考，错误的观众。成功的研究人员知道如何发现和解决有趣的问题，但他们也知道如何找到（或创造）对他们解决的问题感兴趣的听众。

To convince readers to care about your work, you have to show them that your problem is their problem—even if they don’t know it yet. You have to convince them that if they go on not knowing, say, how Hollywood turned the Alamo story into myth, they will fail to understand something more important about national identity. To be sure, some readers will ask again, So what? I don’t care about national identity. To which you can only shrug and think, Wrong audience. Successful researchers know how to find and solve interesting problems, but they also know how to find (or create) an audience interested in the problems they solve.

如果你确定你的读者知道你的问题的后果，你可能会决定不明确说明它们。克里克和沃森没有具体说明不知道 DNA 结构的代价，因为他们知道他们的读者已经认识到，如果不了解 DNA 的结构，他们就无法理解遗传学（更重要的东西）。如果 Crick 和 Watson 阐明了这个后果，它可能看起来是多余的或居高临下的。

If you are sure your readers know the consequences of your problem, you might decide not to state them explicitly. Crick and Watson did not specify the cost of not knowing the structure of DNA, because they knew their readers already recognized that without understanding the structure of DNA, they could not understand genetics (something more important). Had Crick and Watson spelled out that consequence, it might have seemed redundant or condescending.

如果你正在处理你的第一个研究项目，没有一个通情达理的老师会期望你详细说明你的问题的后果，因为你可能还不知道为什么其他研究人员认为它很重要。但是当你能够以一种表明你致力于改进它的方式陈述你自己不完整的知识或有缺陷的理解时，你就朝着这个方向迈出了一大步。当你能通过更好的方式证明这一点时，你就迈出了更大的一步了解一件事，你就能更好地了解更重要的事情，即使只是对你而言。

If you are tackling your first research project, no reasonable teacher will expect you to state the consequences of your problem in detail, because you probably don’t yet know why other researchers think it is significant. But you take a big step in that direction when you can state your own incomplete knowledge or flawed understanding in a way that shows you are committed to improving it. You take an even bigger step when you can show that by better understanding one thing, you better understand something much more important, even if only to you.

16.4 第 3 步：陈述您的回应

16.4 STEP 3: STATING YOUR RESPONSE

一旦你用问题扰乱了读者稳定的语境，他们希望你通过以下两种方式之一解决它：通过陈述你的解决方案或要点，或者承诺你稍后会这样做。读者会在介绍的最后几句话中寻找此观点或承诺。

Once you disrupt your readers’ stable context with a problem, they expect you to resolve it in one of two ways: by stating your solution or main point or by promising that you will do so later on. Readers look for this statement or promise in the last few sentences of your introduction.

16.4.1 陈述你的解决方案的要点

16.4.1 State the Gist of Your Solution

您可以在介绍结束时明确说明您的要点/解决方案：

You can state your main point/solution explicitly toward the end of your introduction:

随着我们对环境威胁的调查，我们对酸雨中的化学过程和二氧化碳的积累有了更好的了解，使我们能够更好地了解它们对生物圈的影响。稳定的上下文[听起来不错。] 但最近人们发现，使臭氧层变薄的化学过程并不像人们想象的那么了解。条件【那又怎样？] 我们可能错误地将氢氟烃标记为主要原因。结果 我们发现碳的结合 。. . 解决方案的要点/要点

As we have investigated environmental threats, our understanding of chemical processes in acid rain and the buildup of carbon dioxide has improved, allowing us to understand better their effects on the biosphere.stable context [Sounds good.] But recently the chemical processes that thin the ozone layer have been found to be less well understood than once thought.condition [So what?] We may have labeled hydrofluorocarbons as the chief cause incorrectly.consequence We have found that the bonding of carbon . . .gist of solution/main point

16.4.2承诺一个解决方案

16.4.2 Promise a Solution

或者，你可以延迟你的主要观点，在引言的最后只说明你论文的论点，暗示你将在结论中提出这一点。这种方法提供了一个启动点并创建了一个最后一点的论文：

Alternatively, you can delay your main point by stating toward the end of your introduction only where your paper is headed, implying that you will present that point in your conclusion. This approach provides a launching point and creates a point-last paper:

当我们调查环境威胁时，我们的理解。. . 有所改善。. . . 但最近的化学过程。. . 被发现不太好理解。. . . 【那又怎样？] 我们可能错误地将氢氟烃标记为主要原因。【嗯，你发现了什么？]在本报告中，我们描述了 之间迄今为止意想不到的化学键合 。. . 未来的承诺

As we have investigated environmental threats, our understanding . . . has improved. . . . But recently the chemical processes . . . have been found to be less well understood. . . . [So what?] We may have labeled hydrofluorocarbons as the chief cause incorrectly. [Well, what have you found?] In this report we describe a hitherto unexpected chemical bonding between . . .promise of point to come

这个介绍让我们进入了这篇论文，不是它的主要观点，而是一个即将到来的承诺。

This introduction launches us into the paper, not with its main point but with a promise of one to come.

最弱的承诺是仅仅宣布一个模糊的主题：

The weakest promise is one that merely announces a vague topic:

这项研究调查了导致臭氧消耗的过程。

This study investigates processes leading to ozone depletion.

当你在论文的结尾保留你的观点时，你要求你的读者相信他们的努力是值得的。你不仅要给他们一个一般性的话题，还要给他们一个解决方案的大纲或你的论点计划（或两者），从而在你的介绍中建立这种信任。

When you save your point for the end of your paper, you ask your readers to trust that getting to it is worth their effort. You build this trust in your introduction by giving them not just a general topic but an outline of your solution or a plan for your argument (or both).

水轮机进水口和导流屏的设计有很多，但现场评估并不划算。一个更可行的选择是计算机建模。为了评估水力发电导流屏，本研究将评估三种计算机模型——Quattro、AVOC 和 Turbo-plex——以确定哪种模型在可靠性、速度和易用性方面最具成本效益。

There are many designs for hydroelectric turbine intakes and diversion screens, but on-site evaluation is not cost-effective. A more viable alternative is computer modeling. To evaluate hydroelectric diversion screens, this study will evaluate three computer models—Quattro, AVOC, and Turbo-plex—to determine which is most cost-effective in reliability, speed, and ease of use.

这种计划在社会科学中很常见，但在人文科学中并不常见，许多人认为它有点笨拙。

This kind of plan is common in social sciences, but less frequent in the humanities, where many consider it a bit heavy-handed.

16.5 设定正确的步伐

16.5 SETTING THE RIGHT PACE

在起草介绍时，您必须决定提出问题的速度。这取决于你的读者知道多少。在下一个例子中，作者用一句话来宣布消息灵通的工程师之间的共识，然后轻快地打断它：

When crafting your introduction, you must decide how quickly to raise your problem. That depends on how much your readers know. In this next example, the writer devotes one sentence to announcing a consensus among well-informed engineers and then briskly disrupts it:

压膜阻尼器 (SFD) 中的液膜力通常从经典润滑理论的雷诺方程中获得。然而，旋转机械的尺寸越来越大，需要在 SFD 的设计中考虑流体惯性效应。没有他们 。. .

Fluid-film forces in squeeze-film dampers (SFDs) are usually obtained from the Reynolds equation of classical lubrication theory. However, the increasing size of rotating machinery requires the inclusion of fluid inertia effects in the design of SFDs. Without them . . .

（我们不知道这意味着什么，但Context + Problem的结构很清楚。）

(We have no idea what any of that means, but the structure of Context + Problem is clear.)

下一位作者也谈到了技术概念，但耐心地为技术知识很少的读者展示了它们：

This next writer also addresses technical concepts but patiently lays them out for readers who have little technical knowledge:

在水力发电开发中保护洄游鱼类的一种方法是通过屏蔽涡轮机进水口进行分流。. . [另 110 字解释屏幕]。由于筛网的效率取决于鱼类行为和水力流量的相互作用，因此可以通过确定其水力性能来评估筛网设计。. . [ 40 多字解释液压]。这项研究使我们更好地了解了该技术的水力特征，这可能会指导未来的设计。

A method of protecting migrating fish at hydroelectric power developments is diversion by screening turbine intakes . . . [another 110 words explaining screens]. Since the efficiency of screens is determined by the interaction of fish behavior and hydraulic flow, screen design can be evaluated by determining its hydraulic performance . . . [40 more words explaining hydraulics]. This study provides a better understanding of the hydraulic features of this technique, which may guide future designs.

介绍的速度因领域而异。其研究社区已经熟悉其问题的研究人员可以快速开放；那些在问题没有被广泛分享的领域工作的人必须更慢地开始。但是你介绍的速度也预示着其他事情。当您快速打开时，您意味着同行的观众；当你慢慢打开时，你暗示读者比你了解的少。如果你的读者知识渊博，而你打开的很慢，他们可能会认为你知道的太少。但如果他们知之甚少而你很快就开口，他们可能会认为你没有考虑到他们的需求。

The pace of an introduction varies by field. Researchers whose problems are already familiar to their research communities can open quickly; those who work in fields where problems are not widely shared must start more slowly. But the pace of your introduction signals something else as well. When you open quickly, you imply an audience of peers; when you open slowly, you imply readers who know less than you. If your readers are knowledgeable and you open slowly, they may think you know too little. But if they know little and you open quickly, they may think you are inconsiderate of their needs.

16.6 组织整个介绍

16.6 ORGANIZING THE WHOLE INTRODUCTION

在组织你的介绍时，你有很多选择，但它们并不像看起来那么复杂。它们都遵循实际上简单的“语法”。完整的介绍仅包含三个要素：

When organizing your introduction, you have many choices, but they are not as complicated as they might seem. They all follow what is in fact a simple “grammar.” A full introduction consists of just three elements:

上下文+问题+响应

Context + Problem + Response

您不需要在每个介绍中都需要这三个：

You don’t need all three in every introduction:

• 如果问题众所周知，则省略共同点。

• If the problem is well known, omit the common ground.

• 如果问题的后果众所周知，则忽略它们。

• If the consequences of the problem are well known, omit them.

• 如果您想让读者在知道您的答案之前跟随您的想法，请在您的介绍结束时提供一个出发点，并在您的结论中陈述您的主要观点。

• If you want readers to follow your thinking before they know your answer, offer a launching point at the end of your introduction and state your main point in your conclusion.

所有这一切可能看起来公式化，但这是读者所期望的。当你掌握了这样的修辞模式时，你就不仅仅是写作的公式了。你也有一个思考的工具。来写完整陈述你们共同的背景和问题，你必须认真思考你的读者知道什么，他们不知道什么，特别是，他们应该知道什么以及为什么。

All this may seem formulaic, but it’s what readers expect. And when you master a rhetorical pattern like this, you have more than a formula for writing. You also have a tool for thinking. To write a full statement of your shared context and problem, you have to think hard about what your readers know, what they don’t, and, in particular, what they should know and why.

16.7 找到你的前几个词

16.7 FINDING YOUR FIRST FEW WORDS

许多作家发现头一两句特别难写，因此陷入陈词滥调。

Many writers find the first sentence or two especially difficult to write, and so they fall into clichés.

• 不要重复作业中的语言。如果你正在努力开始，通过解释它来启动你的泵，但是当你修改时，重写它。

• Don’t repeat the language of your assignment. If you are struggling to start, prime your pump by paraphrasing it, but when you revise, rewrite it.

• 不要从字典条目开始：“韦伯斯特将道德定义为……”。. ” 如果一个词重要到足以定义，则字典定义将不起作用。

• Don’t start with a dictionary entry: “Webster’s defines ethics as . . .” If a word is important enough to define, a dictionary definition won’t serve.

• 不要冠冕堂皇地开始：“几个世纪以来，最深刻的哲学家一直在努力解决……的重要问题。. ” 如果你的主题很宏大，它就会说明它自己的重要性。

• Don’t start grandly: “The most profound philosophers have for centuries wrestled with the important question of . . .” If your subject is grand, it will speak its own importance.

这些错误源于一个良好的冲动：它们试图与读者群体建立共享的背景或共同点。在所有情况下，问题都在于它是错误的社区。在第一个示例中，社区范围太窄：它只是学生的老师。在其他示例中，社区过于广泛：这些作者正在摸索全人类都能同意的语境。为避免这些失误，请以可能吸引您希望感兴趣的特定读者群体的方式打开。

These miscues arise from a good impulse: they are attempts to establish a shared context or common ground with a community of readers. The problem in all cases is that it is the wrong community. In that first example, the community is too narrow: it is just the student’s teacher. In the other examples, the community is too broad: those writers are groping for a context that all of humanity could agree to. To avoid these missteps, open in a way that is likely to appeal to the specific community of readers you hope to interest.

这是您的第一句话或第二句话的三个标准选择。

Here are three standard choices for your first sentence or two.

16.7.1以与你的问题相关的引人注目的事实开场

16.7.1 Open with a Striking Fact Relevant to Your Problem

那些认为为富人减税会刺激经济的人应该考虑这样一个事实，即美国最富有的 1% 控制着美国总财富的三分之一。

Those who think that tax cuts for the rich stimulate the economy should contemplate the fact that the top 1 percent of Americans control one-third of America’s total wealth.

16.7.2以醒目的引语开头

16.7.2 Open with a Striking Quotation

仅当它的文字预示着您介绍的其余部分中的关键术语时才这样做：

Do this only if its words anticipate key terms in the rest of your introduction:

“真正的扬·凡·艾克 (Jan van Eyck) 纯粹的感性之美散发出一种奇特的魅力，这与我们让自己被宝石催眠时所体验到的魅力无异。” 埃德温·潘诺夫斯基 (Edwin Panofsky) 在这里暗示了扬·范·艾克 (Jan van Eyck) 作品中的一些奇怪的魔力。他的图像具有宝石般的魅力。. . .

“From the sheer sensuous beauty of a genuine Jan van Eyck there emanates a strange fascination not unlike that which we experience when permitting ourselves to be hypnotized by precious stones.” Edwin Panofsky suggests here something strangely magical in Jan van Eyck’s works. His images hold a jewel-like fascination. . . .

16.7.3以相关轶事开篇

16.7.3 Open with a Relevant Anecdote

仅当它的语言预示了您的主题并生动地说明了您的问题时才这样做。以下是一篇讲述芝加哥街头帮派兴衰的文章的开头句子：

Do this only if its language anticipates your topic and vividly illustrates your problem. Here are the opening sentences of an article recounting the rise and fall of a Chicago street gang:

1996 年 7 月，在公园的长椅上，辛西娅、劳里和黑人姐妹联合会 (BSU) 的其他高级官员——芝加哥最大的“女孩帮派”联合会——反思了他们为维持一个可以代表并代表城里年轻的非裔美国女性。“我们太接近了！” 辛西娅痛苦地说道，她坐直了身子，环顾四周，看看有没有人听到她的声音。

On a park bench in July 1996, Cynthia, Laurie, and other senior officers of the Black Sisters United (BSU)—Chicago’s largest federation of “girl gangs”—reflected on their efforts to sustain an organization that could represent and act on behalf of young African-American women in the city. “We was so close!” Cynthia said with deep anguish, sitting upright and looking about to see if anyone had heard her.

16.8 写下你的结论

16.8 WRITING YOUR CONCLUSION

即使您的论点没有标记为结论的部分，它也会有一两段作为一个段落。你的结论是总结你的论点的机会，但同样重要的是，这是一个通过提出你的研究让你看到的新问题来扩展你的研究社区对话的机会。您可能会很高兴知道您可以使用介绍中的相同元素以相反的顺序编写结论。

Even if your argument doesn’t have a section labeled Conclusion, it will have a paragraph or two that serve as one. Your conclusion is an occasion to sum up your argument, but just as important, it is an opportunity to extend your research community’s conversation by suggesting new questions your research has allowed you to see. You may be happy to know that you can write your conclusion using the same elements in your introduction, in reverse order.

16.8.1从你的要点开始

16.8.1 Start with Your Main Point

在结论的开头陈述你的主要观点。如果您已经在介绍中陈述过，请在此处重复但更完整；不要简单地逐字重复。

State your main point near the beginning of your conclusion. If you already stated it in your introduction, repeat it here but more fully; do not simply repeat it word-for-word.

16.8.2添加新意义或应用

16.8.2 Add a New Significance or Application

在你的观点之后，说出为什么它很重要，最好是对那又怎样？例如，这个结论的作者介绍了最高法院对军人死刑判决的另一个后果是：

After your point, say why it’s significant, preferably with a new answer to So what? For example, the writer of this conclusion introduces an additional consequence of the Supreme Court’s decision on military death sentences:

鉴于最近最高法院的决定拒绝强制死刑，对叛国罪的强制死刑显然违宪，因此必须由国会修改。不过，更重要的是，如果《统一军事司法法典》发生变化，它将挑战军事文化的基本价值观，即最终的背叛需要最终的惩罚。届时国会将不得不处理军方的正义感。

In light of recent Supreme Court decisions rejecting mandatory capital punishment, the mandatory death penalty for treason is apparently unconstitutional and must therefore be revised by Congress. More significantly, though, if the Uniform Code of Military Justice is changed, it will challenge the fundamental value of military culture that ultimate betrayal requires the ultimate penalty. Congress will then have to deal with the military’s sense of what is just.

这一观察属于结论而不是引言，因为它提出了本文未涉及的进一步问题：军方将如何应对对其价值观的挑战？国会又该如何应对？就像在介绍中通过陈述问题的后果来增加问题的冲击力一样，在结论中你可以通过注意其附加含义来增加解决方案的重要性。

This observation belongs in the conclusion rather than in the introduction because it suggests further questions the article doesn’t take up: How exactly will the military respond to that challenge to its values? How should Congress respond in turn? Just as in your introduction you increase the punch of your problem by stating its consequences, so in your conclusion you can increase the significance of your solution by noting its additional implications.

16.8.3呼吁更多研究

16.8.3 Call for More Research

正如你的开放背景调查研究已经完成，所以你的结论可以要求研究仍然要做：

Just as your opening context surveys research already done, so your conclusion can call for research still to do:

新手和专家诊断医生之间的这些差异决定了他们的成熟和发展。但是，虽然我们知道新手和专家的想法有何不同，但我们不了解新手社交体验中的哪些元素有助于这种发展，以及如何促进这种发展。我们需要纵向研究指导和指导如何影响结果，以及积极的解释和批评是否有助于新手更快地成为熟练的诊断专家。

These differences between novice and expert diagnosticians define their maturation and development. But while we know how novices and experts think differently, we do not understand which elements in the social experience of novices contribute to that development and how. We need longitudinal studies on how mentoring and coaching affect outcomes and whether active explanation and critique help novices become skilled diagnosticians more quickly.

当您说明还需要做什么时，您就可以让对话保持活跃。因此，在您写下遗言之前，想象一下有人对您的作品着迷并想跟进：您还想知道什么？你会建议他们做什么研究？毕竟，这可能是您发现自己问题的方式。

When you state what remains to do, you keep the conversation alive. So before you write your last words, imagine someone fascinated by your work who wants to follow up on it: What more would you like to know? What research would you suggest they do? After all, that may have been how you found your own problem.

快速提示：标题

Quick Tip: Titles

读者阅读的第一件事——也是你应该写的最后一件事——是你的标题。初学者只需附上几句话来建议他们论文的主题。这是一个错误：当标题可以帮助读者具体了解即将发生的事情时，它就很有用。比较这三个标题：

The first thing readers read—and the last thing you should write—is your title. Beginning writers just attach a few words to suggest the topics of their papers. That’s a mistake: a title is useful when it helps readers understand specifically what is to come. Compare these three titles:

小额信贷

Microfinance

小额信贷与经济发展

Microfinance and Economic Development

小额信贷作为经济发展战略：发挥其提高妇女地位的潜力

Microfinance as a Strategy for Economic Development: Realizing Its Potential for Improving the Standing of Women

在你的标题中加入你的主要观点的关键词，即你在检查概念主题的连续性时圈出的关键词（6.6.1、8.2.1、12.1.1、12.3.2、13.4）。当读者看到这些概念再次出现在您的要点中并再次出现在您的论文正文中时，他们会觉得您的文字达到了他们的期望。（双行标题为关键术语留出更多空间。以冒号结束第一行，引入更具体的第二行。）

Put into your title the keywords in your main point, the ones you circled when you checked for the continuity of conceptual themes (6.6.1, 8.2.1, 12.1.1, 12.3.2, 13.4). When readers see those concepts turn up again in your main point and again through the body of your paper, they will feel that your text has met their expectations. (Two-line titles give you more room for key terms. End the first line with a colon that introduces a more specific second line.)

17 修改样式

17  Revising Style

清楚地讲述你的故事

Telling Your Story Clearly

到目前为止，我们一直专注于您论文的论点和组织。在本章中，我们将向您展示如何修改您的句子，以便读者认为它们清晰直接。

So far we have focused on the argument and organization of your paper. In this chapter, we show you how to revise your sentences so that readers will think they are clear and direct.

读者只有理解你的论点才会接受你的主张，但如果他们不能理解你的句子，他们就不会理解你的论点。一旦你修改了你的论文，让读者认为它的论点是合理的和有条理的，找时间做最后一遍，让你的句子在你的想法的复杂性允许的范围内尽可能容易阅读。但同样，你面临一个熟悉的问题：你不能仅仅通过阅读就知道哪些句子需要修改。既然你已经知道你想让它们表达什么意思，你就会读出你想让你的读者从中得到什么。为了确保您的句子对您的读者和您一样清晰，您需要一种方法来识别困难的句子，即使它们对您来说还不错。

Readers will accept your claim only if they understand your argument, but they won’t understand your argument if they can’t understand your sentences. Once you revise your paper so that readers will judge its argument to be sound and well organized, find time to make a last pass to make your sentences as easy to read as the complexity of your ideas allows. But again, you face a familiar problem: you can’t know which sentences need revising just by reading them. Since you already know what you want them to mean, you will read into them what you want your readers to get out of them. To ensure that your sentences will be as clear to your readers as they are to you, you need a way to identify difficult sentences even when they seem fine to you.

17.1 裁判风格

17.1 JUDGING STYLE

如果您必须阅读以下示例之一风格的文章，您会选择哪一个？

If you had to read an article in the style of one of the following examples, which would you choose?

1a. 传统的管理实践假设互动和协作通过提高员工的创造力和生产力来提高组织绩效。但是，除非协作被隔离打断，除非工作空间配置提供隔离机会，否则可能会削弱而不是提高组织效率。

1a. Conventional management practice assumes that interaction and collaboration enhance organizational performance by improving employee creativity and productivity. But unless collaboration is punctuated by isolation, and unless workspace configurations provide isolation opportunities, erosion rather than enhancement of organizational effectiveness may result.

1b. 经理们希望为他们工作的人能够互动和协作。当他们这样做时，他们会变得更有创造力和生产力。然后组织表现得更好。但人们也需要单独工作的机会，工作场所也需要提供这些机会。否则，组织的效率可能会降低。

1b. Managers want the people who work for them to interact and collaborate. When they do this, they become more creative and productive. The organization then performs better. But people also need opportunities to work alone, and workplaces need to provide these opportunities. Otherwise, the organization may become less effective.

1c. 管理者传统上认为，当员工互动和协作时，他们会变得更有创造力和生产力，从而带领整个组织表现得更好。但是，除非员工也有机会单独工作，除非工作空间被配置为提供这些机会，否则组织可能会变得不那么有效，而不是更有效。

1c. Managers conventionally assume that when employees interact and collaborate, they become more creative and productive, thus leading the whole organization to perform better. But unless employees also have opportunities to work alone, and unless workspaces are configured to provide them, the organization may become less rather than more effective.

很少有读者选择 (1a)：它听起来很密集、抽象、不透明。有些人选择（1b），但这听起来很简单，就像一个成年人对孩子慢慢说话。大多数人选择 (1c)，这听起来像是一位同事在与另一位同事交谈。当今学术写作中最严重的问题之一是太多的研究人员听起来像（1a）。

Few readers choose (1a): it sounds dense, abstract, opaque. Some choose (1b), but it sounds simpleminded, like an adult speaking slowly to a child. Most choose (1c), which sounds like one colleague speaking to another. One of the worst problems in academic writing today is that too many researchers sound like (1a).

一些研究人员更喜欢 (1a)，声称繁重的思考需要繁重的写作，当他们试图使复杂的想法变得清晰时，他们牺牲了细微差别和思想的复杂性以换取过于容易的理解。如果读者不理解，那就太糟糕了；他们应该更加努力地工作。

A few researchers prefer (1a), claiming that heavy thinking demands heavy writing, that when they try to make complicated ideas clear, they sacrifice nuances and complexity of thought for too-easy understanding. If readers don’t understand, too bad; they should work harder.

也许。每个阅读伊曼纽尔康德或弗里德里希黑格尔等哲学家的人都会为他们复杂的散文风格而苦苦挣扎，至少一开始是这样。但事实证明，他们不得不说的这些努力是值得的。问题是，我们当中很少有人能像康德或黑格尔那样思考。对我们大多数人来说，大多数时候，我们密集的写作表明的不是天才作品的不可降低的难度，而是不考虑读者的作家的草率思维。即使复杂的思想确实需要复杂的风格（这种情况比我们想象的要少），每句话都会从第二眼中获益（说实话，康德和黑格尔会从一个好的编辑那里受益）。

Perhaps. Everyone who reads philosophers like Immanuel Kant or Friedrich Hegel struggles with their complex prose style, at least at first. But what they have to say proves to be worth the effort. The problem is, few of us think as well as Kant or Hegel. For most of us most of the time, our dense writing indicates not the irreducible difficulty of a work of genius, but the sloppy thinking of writers who aren’t considering their readers. And even when complex thought does require a complex style (which is less often than we think), every sentence profits from a second look (and truth be told, Kant and Hegel would have benefited from a good editor).

有些作家在避免复杂的风格方面做得太过分了，他们使用像上面 (1b) 中的那些简单的句子。但是我们假设你们中的大多数人没有这个问题，并且您在拼写和语法方面几乎不需要帮助。（如果你认为你这样做，请与写作导师交谈。）我们在这里解决的是一种风格过于“学术”，也就是说，比它必须的更难。令人费解和间接的散文不是优秀作家的目标，而是粗心的作家所追求的。

Some writers do go too far in avoiding a complex style, using simplistic sentences like those in (1b) above. But we assume that most of you do not have that problem, and that you need little help with spelling and grammar. (If you think you do, talk to a writing tutor.) We address here the problem of a style that is too “academic,” which is to say, more difficult than it has to be. Convoluted and indirect prose is not what good writers aim for, but what thoughtless ones get away with.

这个问题尤其困扰那些刚开始高级工作的人，因为他们受到双重困扰。首先，当我们任何人写下挑战我们理解的新的和复杂的想法时，我们写得不像平时那么清晰。这个问题甚至困扰着最有经验的研究人员。但是，当新的研究人员认为复杂的风格预示着学术上的成功并且他们模仿他们阅读的错综复杂的散文时，这个问题就更加复杂了。我们可以避免。

This problem especially afflicts those just starting advanced work because they are hit by double trouble. First, when any of us writes about new and complex ideas that challenge our understanding, we write less clearly than we ordinarily can. This problem afflicts even the most experienced researchers. But new researchers compound that problem when they believe that a complex style bespeaks academic success and they imitate the tangled prose they read. That we can avoid.

17.2 清晰书写的前两个原则

17.2 THE FIRST TWO PRINCIPLES OF CLEAR WRITING

17.2.1将印象与其原因区分开来

17.2.1 Distinguishing Impressions from Their Causes

如果我们让您解释您是如何在上面的 (1a) 和 (1c) 之间做出选择的，您可能会用诸如unclear、wordy和dense之类的词来描述 (1a) ；(1c) 使用清晰、简洁和直接等词语。但这些词不是指页面上的那些句子，而是指你阅读它们时的感受。如果你说 (1a) 是dense，你真的是在说你很难通过它；如果你说 (1c) 很清楚，你是说你发现它很容易理解。

If we asked you to explain how you chose between (1a) and (1c) above, you would probably describe (1a) with words like unclear, wordy, and dense; (1c) with words like clear, concise, and direct. But those words refer not to those sentences on the page, but to how you felt as you read them. If you said that (1a) was dense, you were really saying that you had a hard time getting through it; if you said (1c) was clear, you were saying that you found it easy to understand.

使用印象主义的词语来描述你的感受并没有错，但它们不能帮助你解决像 (1a) 这样不清楚的句子，因为它们没有解释页面或屏幕上是什么让你有这样的感觉。为此，您需要一种方法来思考将令人困惑的印象与句子中让您感到困惑的内容联系起来的句子。更重要的是，你必须知道如何修改你自己的句子，当它们对你来说很清楚但对你的读者来说却不是。

There’s nothing wrong with using impressionistic words to describe your feelings, but they don’t help you fix unclear sentences like (1a), because they don’t explain what it is on the page or screen that makes you feel as you do. For that, you need a way to think about sentences that connects an impression like confusing to what it is in the sentence that confuses you. More important, you have to know how to revise your own sentences when they are clear to you but won’t be to your readers.

有一些原则可以区分 (1a) 的复杂性和 (1c) 的成熟清晰度。这些原则只关注句子的两个部分：前六七个词和后四五个词。弄清楚这些词，句子的其余部分（通常）会自行处理。但是，要使用这些原则，您必须理解五个语法术语：简单主语、整体 主语、动词、名词和从句。（如果您有一段时间没有使用这些术语，请在继续阅读之前先复习一下。）

There are a few principles that distinguish the felt complexity of (1a) from the mature clarity of (1c). These principles focus on only two parts of a sentence: the first six or seven words and the last four or five. Get those words straight, and the rest of the sentence will (usually) take care of itself. To use these principles, though, you must understand five grammatical terms: simple subject, whole subject, verb, noun, and clause. (If you haven’t used those terms for a while, review them before you read on.)

这很重要：在写新句子时不要试图应用这些原则。如果您在起草时遵循它们，您可能会陷入困境。相反，当你修改你已经写过的句子时，让他们指导你。

This is important: don’t try to apply these principles as you write new sentences. If you follow them as you draft, you may tie yourself in knots. Rather, let them guide you when you revise sentences you have already written.

17.2.2主题和人物

17.2.2 Subjects and Characters

第一个原则可能会让你想起你在文法学校学到的东西。每个句子的核心是它的主语和动词。在文法学校，您可能了解到主体是行动的“执行者”或代理人。但这并不总是正确的，因为主体可以是行动者以外的事物，甚至是行动。比较这两个句子（每个子句中的整个主题都带有下划线）：

The first principle may remind you of something you learned in grammar school. At the heart of every sentence are its subject and verb. In grammar school you probably learned that subjects are the “doers” or agents of an action. But that’s not always true, because subjects can be things other than doers, even actions. Compare these two sentences (the whole subject in each clause is underlined):

2a. 洛克经常重复自己的话，因为他不相信文字能够准确地命名事物。

2a. Locke frequently repeated himself because he did not trust the power of words to name things accurately.

2b. 洛克之所以频繁重复，是因为他不相信词的命名能力的准确性。

2b. The reason for Locke’s frequent repetition lies in his distrust of the accuracy of the naming power of words.

(2a) 中的两个主体——洛克和他——符合文法学校的定义：他们是实干家。但是 (2b) 的主题——洛克频繁重复的原因——没有，因为理性在这里并没有真正做任何事情。真正的实干家还是洛克。

The two subjects in (2a)—Locke and he—fit that grammar-school definition: they are doers. But the subject of (2b)—The reason for Locke’s frequent repetition—does not, because reason doesn’t really do anything here. The real doer is still Locke.

为了超越六年级的定义，我们不仅要考虑句子的语法——它的主语和动词——还要考虑它们讲述的故事——关于行动者和他们的行为。这是一个关于雨林和生物圈的故事：

To get beyond sixth-grade definitions, we have to think not only about the grammar of a sentence—its subjects and verbs—but also about the stories they tell—about doers and their actions. Here is a story about rain forests and the biosphere:

3a. 如果为了短期经济利益而砍伐雨林，地球的生物圈可能会遭到破坏。

3a. If rain forests are stripped to serve short-term economic interests, the earth’s biosphere may be damaged.

3b. 为短期经济利益而砍伐雨林可能会对地球生物圈造成破坏。

3b. The stripping of rain forests in the service of short-term economic interests could result in damage to the earth’s biosphere.

在更清晰的版本 (3a) 中，查看每个子句的整个主题：

In the clearer version, (3a), look at the whole subjects of each clause:

3a. 如果雨林主题被剥离动词 。. . 地球生物圈主体可能受到破坏。动词

3a. If rain forestssubject are strippedverb . . . the earth’s biospheresubject may be damaged.verb

这些主题用几个简短、具体的词来命名该故事中的主要人物：雨林和地球生物圈。比较 (3b)：

Those subjects name the main characters in that story in a few short, concrete words: rain forests and the earth’s biosphere. Compare (3b):

3b. 为短期经济利益主体而砍伐雨林可能导致地球生物圈遭到破坏。

3b. The stripping of rain forests in the service of short-term economic interestssubject could resultverb in damage to the earth’s biosphere.

在 (3b) 中，简单主语（剥离）命名的不是一个具体的角色，而是一个动作；整个主题只是冗长的抽象短语的一部分：为了 短期经济利益而砍伐雨林 。

In (3b) the simple subject (stripping) names not a concrete character but rather an action; it is only part of the long abstract phrase that is the whole subject: the stripping of rain forests in the service of short-term economic interests.

现在我们可以明白为什么文法学校的定义可能是糟糕的语言理论，但却是关于写作的好建议。清晰写作的首要原则是：

Now we can see why grammar-school definitions may be bad language theory but good advice about writing. The first principle of clear writing is this:

读者会根据你让他们的主题说出故事中的主要人物的程度来判断你的句子是否清晰易读。当你这样做时，你的主题将是简短、具体和具体的。

Readers will judge your sentences to be clear and readable to the degree that you make their subjects name the main characters in your story. When you do this, your subjects will be short, specific, and concrete.

17.2.3动词、名词和动作

17.2.3 Verbs, Nouns, and Actions

清晰散文和不清晰散文之间还有第二个区别：作家在故事中表达关键行为的方式——动词还是名词。例如，再看看下面的句子对 (2) 和 (3)。（命名动作的单词加粗；表示动词的动作加下划线；表示名词的动作加双下划线。）

There is a second difference between clear and unclear prose: it is in the way writers express the crucial actions in their stories—as verbs or as nouns. For example, look again at the pairs of sentences (2) and (3) below. (Words naming actions are boldfaced; actions that are verbs are underlined; actions that are nouns are double-underlined.)

2a. 洛克经常重复自己的话，因为他不相信文字能够准确地命名事物。

2a. Locke frequently repeated himself because he did not trust the power of words to name things accurately.

2b. 洛克之所以频繁重复，是因为他不相信词的命名能力的准确性。

2b. The reason for Locke’s frequent repetition lies in his distrust of the accuracy of the naming power of words.

3a. 如果为了短期经济利益而砍伐雨林，地球的生物圈可能会遭到破坏。

3a. If rain forests are stripped to serve short-term economic interests, the earth’s biosphere may be damaged.

3b. 为短期经济利益而砍伐雨林可能会对地球生物圈造成破坏。

3b. The stripping of rain forests in the service of short-term economic interests could result in damage to the earth’s biosphere.

句子 (2a) 和 (3a) 比 (2b) 和 (3b) 更清楚，因为它们的主语是字符，而且因为它们的动作不是用名词而是用动词表达的。

Sentences (2a) and (3a) are clearer than (2b) and (3b) because their subjects are characters, but also because their actions are expressed not as nouns but as verbs.

有一个将动词（或形容词）变成名词的技术术语：我们将其名词化。（这个术语定义了自己：当我们将动词nominalize 名词化时，我们创建了名词化nominalization。）大多数名词化都以后缀结尾，例如-tion、-ness、-ment、-ence、-ity。

There is a technical term for turning a verb (or adjective) into a noun: we nominalize it. (This term defines itself: when we nominalize the verb nominalize, we create the nominalization nominalization.) Most nominalizations end with suffixes such as -tion, -ness, -ment, -ence, -ity.

动词 → 名词化 形容词 → 名词化

决定

decide

决定

decision

精确的

precise

精确

precision

失败

fail

失败

failure

经常

frequent

频率

frequency

抵抗

resist

反抗

resistance

聪明的

intelligent

智力

intelligence

但是有些拼写像动词：change → change ; 延迟 → 延迟; 报告 → 报告。

But some are spelled like the verb: change → change; delay → delay; report → report.

（我们将在 17.4 中讨论像are stripped和be damaged这样的被动动词。）

(We’ll discuss passive verbs like are stripped and be damaged in 17.4.)

当你不是用动词而是用抽象名词来表达动作时，你也会用冠词和介词弄乱一个句子。查看 (4b) 中 (4a) 不需要的所有冠词和介词（粗体）：

When you express actions not with verbs but with abstract nouns, you also clutter a sentence with articles and prepositions. Look at all the articles and prepositions (boldfaced) in (4b) that (4a) doesn’t need:

4a. 有了衡量情绪障碍的标准化指标，我们现在可以量化患者对不同治疗的反应。

4a. Having standardized indices for measuring mood disorders, we now can quantify patients’ responses to different treatments.

4b. 情绪障碍测量指标的标准化现在使量化患者反应作为治疗差异的函数成为可能。

4b. The standardization of indices for the measurement of mood disorders has now made possible the quantification of patient response as a function of treatment differences.

句子 (4b) 添加了一个a , as , and for ; 两个s ，四个s ，都是因为四个动词变成了名词：standardize → standardization， 测量 → 测量，量化 → 量化，响应 → 响应。

Sentence (4b) adds one a, as, and for; two thes, and four ofs, all because four verbs were turned into nouns: standardize → standardization, measure → measurement, quantify → quantification, respond → response.

当你把形容词和动词变成名词时，你可以用另外两种方式把你的句子弄乱：

When you turn adjectives and verbs into nouns, you can tangle up your sentences in two more ways:

• 你必须添加比你可以使用的动词更不具体的动词。在 (4b) 中，我们使用单个模糊动词made而不是特定动词standardize、measure、quantify和respond 。

• You have to add verbs that are less specific than the verbs you could have used. In (4b), instead of the specific verbs standardize, measure, quantify, and respond, we have the single vague verb made.

• 你很可能使故事中的人物成为名词或介词宾语的修饰语，或者将它们完全从句子中删除：在 (4b) 中，人物we变成了 our，此后其余人物在行动中消失了。

• You are likely to make the characters in your story modifiers of nouns or objects of prepositions or to drop them from a sentence altogether: in (4b), the character we becomes our, and thereafter the rest of the characters are missing in action.

所以这里有两个清晰风格的原则：

So here are two principles of a clear style:

• 用动词表达关键动作。

• Express crucial actions in verbs.

• 让你的中心人物成为那些动词的主语；使这些主题简短、具体和具体。

• Make your central characters the subjects of those verbs; keep those subjects short, concrete, and specific.

17.2.4诊断与修正

17.2.4 Diagnosis and Revision

考虑到读者如何判断句子，我们可以提供诊断和修改你的句子的方法。

Given how readers judge sentences, we can offer ways to diagnose and revise yours.

诊断：

To diagnose:

1. 在每个从句的前六到七个字下划线，无论是主句还是从句。

1. Underline the first six or seven words of every clause, whether main or subordinate.

2. 执行两个测试：

2. Perform two tests:

• 划线的主题是具体人物，而不是抽象人物？

• Are the underlined subjects concrete characters, not abstractions?

• 带下划线的动词是否表示具体的动作，而不是一般的动作，如have、make、do、be等？

• Do the underlined verbs name specific actions, not general ones like have, make, do, be, and so on?

3. 如果这句话没有通过任何一项测试，你可能应该修改。

3. If the sentence fails either test, you should probably revise.

修改：

To revise:

1. 找到你想讲故事的人物。如果你不能，发明它们。

1. Find the characters you want to tell a story about. If you can’t, invent them.

2. 找出这些角色在做什么。如果他们的动作是名词，就把它们变成动词。
