2. Find what those characters are doing. If their actions are in nouns, change them into verbs.

3. 用你的主要人物作为主语，他们的行为作为动词来创建从句。

3. Create clauses with your main characters as subjects and their actions as verbs.

您可能不得不在If X, then Y的某个版本中重写您的句子；X，因为 Y；虽然 X, Y ; 当 X，则 Y；等等。

You will probably have to recast your sentence in some version of If X, then Y; X, because Y; Although X, Y; When X, then Y; and so on.

这是将密集的散文修改为更清晰的内容的简单版本。这是一个更微妙的。

That’s the simple version of revising dense prose into something clearer. Here is a more nuanced one.

17.2.5谁或什么可以成为角色？

17.2.5 Who or What Can Be a Character?

您可能想知道为什么我们通常将角色视为有血有肉的人，而我们将雨林和地球生物圈称为“角色”。就我们的目的而言，字符是可以作为一系列句子中许多动词主语的任何东西。这意味着我们也可以讲故事，其人物是雨林之类的东西，甚至是思维障碍之类的抽象事物。在您的研究中，您可能需要讲述一个关于人口变化、社会流动性、等温线或基因库的故事。

You may have wondered why we called rain forests and the earth’s biosphere “characters” when we usually think of characters as flesh-and-blood people. For our purposes, a character is anything that can be the subject of a lot of verbs in a sequence of sentences. This means that we can also tell stories whose characters are things like rain forests and even abstractions like thought disorders. In your kind of research, you may have to tell a story about demographic changes, social mobility, isotherms, or gene pools.

有时您有一个选择：经济学论文可能会讲述真实或虚拟人物的故事，例如消费者和联邦储备委员会，或者与他们相关的抽象概念，例如储蓄和货币政策。但是请注意，您仍然可以使用动作动词使这些抽象人物成为故事的一部分：

Sometimes you have a choice: a paper in economics might tell a story about real or virtual people, such as consumers and the Federal Reserve Board, or about abstractions associated with them, such as savings and monetary policy. Note, however, that you can still make those abstract characters part of a story with action verbs:

5a. 当消费者 储蓄更多时，美联储 会改变其货币政策以影响银行 放贷的方式。

5a. When consumers save more, the Federal Reserve changes its monetary policy to influence how banks lend money.

5b. 当消费者 储蓄 增加时，美联储的货币政策会 调整以影响银行贷款行为。

5b. When consumer savings rise, Federal Reserve monetary policy adapts to influence bank lending practices.

一段话可能是关于真实的人或与他们相关的抽象概念：银行与贷款实践，储户与微观经济学，或分析师与预测。不过，在所有条件都相同的情况下，读者更喜欢角色至少是具体的事物，或者更好的是，有血有肉的人。

A passage might be about real people or about abstractions associated with them: banks vs. lending practices, savers vs. microeconomics, or analysts vs. predictions. All things being equal, though, readers prefer characters to be at least concrete things or, better, flesh-and-blood people.

然而，专家们喜欢讲述抽象的故事（黑体字；主题有下划线）。

Experts, however, like to tell stories about abstractions (boldfaced; subjects are underlined).

6.衡量情绪障碍的标准化指数 有助于我们量化患者对不同治疗的反应。这些测量结果表明，对于大多数患者而言，需要长期住院治疗的治疗并不比门诊治疗更有效。

6. Standardized indices to measure mood disorders help us quantify how patients respond to different treatments. These measurements suggest that treatments requiring long-term hospitalization are no more effective than outpatient care for most patients.

第二句中的抽象名词化——测量、治疗、住院、护理——指的是其目标读者如医生和患者所熟悉的概念。有了这些读者，作者就不需要修改它们了。

The abstract nominalizations in the second sentence—measurements, treatments, hospitalization, care—refer to concepts as familiar to its intended readers as doctors and patients. Given those readers, the writer would not need to revise them.

在某种程度上，这个例子削弱了我们关于避免由动词构成名词的建议，因为现在不是将每个抽象名词修改为动词，而是必须选择哪些要更改，哪些保留为名词。例如，（6）第二句中的抽象名词与（7a）中的前三个相同：

In a way, that example undercuts our advice about avoiding nouns made out of verbs, because now instead of revising every abstract noun into a verb, you have to choose which ones to change and which ones to leave as nouns. For example, the abstract nouns in the second sentence of (6) are the same as the first three in (7a):

7a. 未经适当治疗而住院的患者会导致结果测量不可靠。

7a. The hospitalization of patients without appropriate treatment results in the unreliable measurement of outcomes.

但是，如果我们将那些抽象名词修改为动词，我们将改进该句子：

But we would improve that sentence if we revised those abstract nouns into verbs:

7b. 当患者住院但未得到适当治疗时，我们无法可靠地衡量结果。

7b. We cannot measure outcomes reliably when patients are hospitalized but not treated appropriately.

因此，我们在这里提供的不是写作的铁则，而是您必须明智地应用的诊断和修改原则。不过，一般来说，读者更喜欢主题简短、具体和具体的句子。这通常意味着有血有肉的角色。

So what we offer here is no iron rule of writing, but rather a principle of diagnosis and revision that you must apply judiciously. In general, though, readers prefer sentences whose subjects are short, specific, and concrete. And that usually means flesh-and-blood characters.

17.2.6避免过度抽象

17.2.6 Avoiding Excessive Abstraction

当你把抽象名词作为你句子的主角和主语，然后在它们周围撒上更多的抽象概念时，你会给读者带来最糟糕的问题。这是一段关于民主和制度化两个抽象特征的文章。尽管如此，这段话仍然很清楚，至少对于它的目标读者来说是这样，因为它的作者在主题和避免额外的抽象，尤其是名词化（主要字符用斜体；整个主题用下划线；动词用黑体字）：

You create the worst problems for readers when you make abstract nouns your main character and subjects of your sentences, then sprinkle more abstractions around them. Here is a passage about two abstract characters, democracy and institutionalization. Nevertheless, the passage is still clear, at least for its intended readers, because its writers focused on their characters in subjects and avoided additional abstractions, especially nominalizations (main characters are italicized; whole subjects are underlined; verbs are boldfaced):

8a. 我们 预计，较老的 民主国家 将受益于政治领域更大程度的制度化。尽管政治 制度化 很难定义，但 似乎普遍认为，制度化良好的政体 中的程序在功能上是不同的、规范化的（因此是可预测的）、专业化的（包括任人唯贤的招聘和晋升方法）、合理化的（可解释的、基于规则的） , 和非任意), 并注入具有价值。大多数长期存在的 民主国家 都符合这种描述。

8a. We expect that older democracies will benefit from greater institutionalization in the political sphere. Although political institutionalization is difficult to define, there seems to be general consensus that procedures in a well-institutionalized polity are functionally differentiated, regularized (and hence predictable), professionalized (including meritocratic methods of recruitment and promotion), rationalized (explicable, rule based, and non-arbitrary), and infused with value. Most long-standing democracies fit this description.

请注意，当这些主要人物从主题中移开时，以及当关键抽象制度化被其他抽象名词包围时，故事是如何变得不那么清晰的（主要人物是斜体；整个主题是下划线；额外的抽象是粗体）：

Note how the story becomes less clear when those main characters are displaced from subjects and when the key abstraction institutionalization is surrounded by other abstract nouns (main characters are italicized; whole subjects are underlined; the additional abstractions are boldfaced):

8b. 我们的 期望是，政治领域更大程度的 制度化将有利于老牌民主国家。尽管政治制度化的定义很困难，但似乎普遍认为职能分化、正规化（因此是可预测的）、专业化（包括任人唯贤的招聘和晋升方法）、合理化（可解释的、基于规则的和非任意的），以及注入有价值的 是制度化良好的政体中程序的特征。这种描述适合大多数长期存在的民主国家。

8b. Our expectation is that greater institutionalization in the political sphere will be of benefit to older democracies. Although definition of political institutionalization is difficult, there seems to be general consensus that functional differentiation, regularization (and hence predictable), professionalization (including meritocratic methods of recruitment and promotion), rationalization (explicable, rule based, and nonarbitrary), and the infusion of value are characteristic of procedures in a well-institutionalized polity. This description is a fit for most long-standing democracies.

我们并不是建议您将每个抽象名词都变成动词。这个关于民主和制度化的故事很难转变成一个关于像公民或你这样有血有肉的人物的故事。（如果你不相信我们，试一试。）如果你最好的主角是抽象的，使用它们。但是要避免你不需要的其他抽象。一如既往，诀窍是知道哪些是你需要的，哪些是你不需要的（通常比你想象的要少）。相互了解是一种只能来自实践和批评的技能。

We’re not suggesting that you change every abstract noun into a verb. This story about democracy and institutionalization would be difficult to transpose into one about a flesh-and-blood character like citizens or you. (If you don’t believe us, give it a try.) If your best main characters are abstractions, use them. But avoid other abstractions you don’t need. As always, the trick is knowing which ones you need and which you don’t (usually fewer than you think). Knowing one from the other is a skill that comes only from practice—and criticism.

17.2.7创建主角

17.2.7 Creating Main Characters

对我们的原则进行一次限定后，我们再次将其复杂化。如果你的句子是可读的，你的角色将成为动词的主语，动词表达这些角色所涉及的关键动作。但是大多数故事都有几个角色，你可以通过将其中任何一个变成句子的主语来变成主角. 以关于雨林的句子为例：

Having qualified our principle once, we complicate it again. If your sentences are readable, your characters will be the subjects of verbs that express the crucial actions those characters are involved in. But most stories have several characters, any one of whom you can turn into a main character by making it the subject of sentences. Take the sentence about rain forests:

9. 如果为了短期经济利益而砍伐雨林，地球的生物圈可能会遭到破坏。

9. If rain forests are stripped to serve short-term economic interests, the earth’s biosphere may be damaged.

那句话讲述了一个暗示其他人物但没有具体说明的故事：谁在剥夺森林？更重要的是，这重要吗？这个故事可以关注他们，但他们是谁？

That sentence tells a story that implies other characters but does not specify them: Who is stripping the forests? More important, does it matter? This story could focus on them, but who are they?

9a. 如果开发商为了短期经济利益而剥夺雨林，他们可能会破坏地球的生物圈。

9a. If developers strip rain forests to serve short-term economic interests, they may damage the earth’s biosphere.

9b. 如果伐木者为了短期经济利益而剥夺雨林，他们可能会破坏地球的生物圈。

9b. If loggers strip rain forests to serve short-term economic interests, they may damage the earth’s biosphere.

9c. 如果巴西为了短期经济利益而剥削雨林，可能会破坏地球的生物圈。

9c. If Brazil strips its rain forests to serve short-term economic interests, it may damage the earth’s biosphere.

哪个最好？这取决于您希望读者认为这个故事是关于谁的。当你修改句子时，尽可能把人物放在主语中，把动作放在动词中。但要确保这个角色是你的中心人物，即使只是为了那句话。

Which is best? It depends on whom you want your readers to think the story is about. As you revise sentences, put characters in subjects and actions in verbs, when you can. But be sure that the character is your central character, if only for that sentence.

17.3 第三个原则：先旧后新

17.3 A THIRD PRINCIPLE: OLD BEFORE NEW

还有第三个阅读和修改原则比前两个更重要。幸运的是，这三个原则都是相关的。比较下面的 (a) 和 (b) 版本。哪个看起来更清楚？为什么？（提示：看句子的开头，这次不仅仅是作为主语的人物，而是这些主语表达的信息是熟悉的还是新的信息，因此是意想不到的。）

There is a third principle of reading and revising even more important than the first two. Fortunately, all three principles are related. Compare the (a) and (b) versions in the following. Which seems clearer? Why? (Hint: Look at the beginnings of sentences, this time not just for characters as subjects, but whether those subjects express information that is familiar or information that is new and therefore unexpected.)

10a。由于洛克不相信词语的命名能力，他经常重复自己的话。十七世纪的语言理论，尤其是威尔金斯的通用语言计划，涉及为无数意义创造无数符号，就以这种命名权为中心。一个专注于意义和指称之间模糊关系的语言研究的新纪元始于洛克的不信任。

10a. Because the naming power of words was distrusted by Locke, he repeated himself often. Seventeenth-century theories of language, especially Wilkins’s scheme for a universal language involving the creation of countless symbols for countless meanings, had centered on this naming power. A new era in the study of language that focused on the ambiguous relationship between sense and reference begins with Locke’s distrust.

10b。洛克经常重复自己的话，因为他不相信词语的命名能力。这种命名能力一直是 17 世纪语言理论的核心，尤其是威尔金斯的通用语言计划，涉及为无数意义创造无数符号。洛克的不信任开启了语言研究的一个新纪元，一个关注意义和指称之间模糊关系的纪元。

10b. Locke often repeated himself because he distrusted the naming power of words. This naming power had been central to seventeenth-century theories of language, especially Wilkins’s scheme for a universal language involving the creation of countless symbols for countless meanings. Locke’s distrust begins a new era in the study of language, one that focused on the ambiguous relationship between sense and reference.

大多数读者更喜欢 (10b)，不仅说 (10a)太复杂或过于夸张，而且它也是脱节的；它不会流动——印象派的词语再次描述的不是我们在页面上看到的内容，而是我们对它的感受。

Most readers prefer (10b), saying not just that (10a) is too complex or inflated, but that it’s also disjointed; it doesn’t flow—impressionistic words that again describe not what we see on the page but how we feel about it.

如果我们再次应用“前六个或七个单词”测试，我们就可以解释是什么导致了这些印象。在脱节的 (a) 版本中，第一句之后的句子以读者无法预测的信息开头：

We can explain what causes those impressions if we again apply the “first six or seven words” test. In the disjointed (a) version, the sentences after the first one begin with information that a reader could not predict:

词的命名能力

the naming power of words

十七世纪的语言理论

Seventeenth-century theories of language

语言研究的新纪元

A new era in the study of language

相比之下，(10b) 中第一句之后的句子以读者会觉得熟悉的信息开头：

In contrast, the sentences after the first one in (10b) begin with information that readers would find familiar:

洛克

Locke

这种命名权[重复上一句]

This naming power [repeated from the previous sentence]

Locke's distrust [一个有用的抽象名词，因为它重复了上一句中的某些内容]

Locke’s distrust [a useful abstract noun because it repeats something from the previous sentence]

在 (10a) 中，每个句子的开头都出乎意料，因此我们无法轻易看出整篇文章的“主题”。在 (10b) 中，第一个句子之后的每个句子都以指代读者从前一句中回忆起的想法的词开始。

In (10a) each sentence begins unpredictably, so we can’t easily see the “topic” of the whole passage. In (10b) each sentence after the first opens with words referring to ideas that readers recall from the previous sentence.

如果读者能够以他们熟悉的人物或想法开始每个句子，那么他们最容易理解一个故事，因为它已经被提及或者因为它来自上下文。从这个阅读原则，我们可以推断出诊断和修改的原则。

Readers follow a story most easily if they can begin each sentence with a character or idea that is familiar to them, either because it was already mentioned or because it comes from the context. From this principle of reading, we can infer principles of diagnosis and revision.

诊断：

To diagnose:

1.在每句话的前六七个字下划线。

1. Underline the first six or seven words of every sentence.

2. 你有没有划线你的读者会觉得熟悉和容易理解的词（通常是以前用过的词）？

2. Have you underlined words that your readers will find familiar and easy to understand (usually words used before)?

3. 如果没有，修改。

3. If not, revise.

修改：

To revise:

1. 让前六七个词指的是熟悉的信息，通常是你之前提到过的东西（通常是你的主要角色）。

1. Make the first six or seven words refer to familiar information, usually something you have mentioned before (typically your main characters).

2. 在句子的末尾放置读者会觉得难以预测或复杂并因此更难理解的信息。

2. Put at the ends of sentences information that your readers will find unpredictable or complex and therefore harder to understand.

这个旧新原则与关于人物和主题的原则愉快地合作，因为较旧的信息通常会命名一个人物（在你介绍它之后，通常在前一句话的末尾）。但是，如果您不得不在以字符开头还是以旧信息开始句子之间做出选择，请始终选择先旧后新的原则。

This old-new principle happily cooperates with the ones about characters and subjects, because older information usually names a character (after you introduce it, usually at the end of a prior sentence). But should you ever have to choose between beginning a sentence with a character or with old information, always choose the principle of old before new.

17.4 在主动语态和被动语态之间进行选择

17.4 CHOOSING BETWEEN THE ACTIVE AND PASSIVE VOICE

你可能已经注意到一些更清晰的句子有被动动词。这似乎与英语教师避免使用它们的常见建议相矛盾。不加思索地听从这些建议会使你的句子不那么清晰。与其担心主动和被动，不如问一个更简单的问题：你的句子是否以熟悉的信息开头，最好是主角？如果你把熟悉的人物放在你的主题中，你就会正确地使用主动和被动。

You may have noted that some of the clearer sentences had passive verbs. This seems to contradict familiar advice from English teachers to avoid them. Followed mindlessly, that advice will make your sentences less clear. Rather than worry about active and passive, ask a simpler question: Do your sentences begin with familiar information, preferably a main character? If you put familiar characters in your subjects, you will use the active and passive properly.

例如，这两段话哪一段更容易“流动”？

For example, which of these two passages “flows” more easily?

11a. 我们的空气质量乃至世界气候都取决于亚洲、非洲和南美洲健康的雨林。但是，全世界对更多农业用地和建筑用木制品的需求不断增加，现在正威胁着这些森林的破坏。

11a. The quality of our air and even the climate of the world depend on healthy rain forests in Asia, Africa, and South America. But the increasing demand for more land for agricultural use and for wood products for construction worldwide now threatens these forests with destruction.

11b。我们的空气质量乃至世界气候都取决于亚洲、非洲和南美洲健康的雨林。但是，由于全世界对更多土地用于农业用途和用于建筑的木材产品的需求不断增加，这些热带雨林现在正面临破坏的威胁。

11b. The quality of our air and even the climate of the world depend on healthy rain forests in Asia, Africa, and South America. But these rain forests are now threatened with destruction by the increasing demand for more land for agricultural use and for wood products used in construction worldwide.

大多数读者认为 (11b) 更容易流动。为什么？请注意，(11b) 中第二句的开头采用了第一句末尾引入的字符：

Most readers think (11b) flows more easily. Why? Note that the beginning of the second sentence in (11b) picks up on the character introduced at the end of the first sentence:

11b。. . . 亚洲、非洲和南美洲的热带雨林。而是这些雨林 。. .

11b. . . . rain forests in Asia, Africa, and South America. But these rain forests . . .

另一方面，(11a) 的第二句以与第一句完全无关的信息开头：

The second sentence of (11a), on the other hand, opens with information completely unconnected to the first sentence:

11a. . . . 亚洲、非洲和南美洲的热带雨林。但对更多土地的需求越来越大。. .

11a. . . . rain forests in Asia, Africa, and South America. But the increasing demand for more land . . .

换句话说，被动语态允许我们将较旧的、更熟悉的信息从句子的末尾移动到它所属的开头。这就是被动句的主要功能：构建以旧信息开头的句子。如果我们不应该使用被动语态，我们的句子就不会流畅。

In other words, the passive allowed us to move the older, more familiar information from the end of its sentence to its beginning, where it belongs. And that’s the main function of the passive: to build sentences that begin with older information. If we don’t use the passive when we should, our sentences won’t flow as well as they could.

在英语课上，学生被告知他们应该只使用主动动词，但他们在工程、自然科学和一些社会科学中听到的恰恰相反。那里的老师要求被动，认为这样可以使写作更客观。大多数建议同样具有误导性。比较被动式 (12a) 与主动式 (12b)：

In English classes, students are told that they should use only active verbs, but they hear the opposite in engineering, the natural sciences, and some social sciences. There teachers demand the passive, thinking that it makes writing more objective. Most of that advice is equally misleading. Compare the passive (12a) with the active (12b):

12a. 以十分之一秒为间隔测量眼球运动。

12a. Eye movements were measured at tenth-of-second intervals.

12b. 我们 以十分之一秒为间隔测量眼球运动。

12b. We measured eye movements at tenth-of-second intervals.

这些句子提供了同样客观的信息，但它们的故事不同：一个是关于眼球运动，另一个是关于一个测量它们的人，而这个人恰好也是作者。第一个应该更“客观”，因为它忽略了人而专注于动作。但只是回避我或我们并不能使写作更“客观”。它只是改变了故事。

These sentences offer equally objective information, but their stories differ: one is about eye movements, the other about a person measuring them, who happens also to be the author. The first is supposed to be more “objective” because it ignores the person and focuses on the movements. But just avoiding I or we doesn’t make writing more “objective.” It simply changes the story.

其实被动的问题还是比较复杂的。当一位科学家使用被动语态来描述一个过程时，她暗示这个过程可以被任何人重复。在这种情况下，被动是正确的选择，因为任何想要重复研究的人都必须测量眼球运动。

In fact, the issue of the passive is still more complicated. When a scientist uses the passive to describe a process, she implies that the process can be repeated by anyone. In this case, the passive is the right choice, because anyone who wanted to repeat the research would have to measure eye movements.

另一方面，考虑这对句子：

On the other hand, consider this pair of sentences:

13a. 可以 得出结论，波动是由伯恩斯效应引起的。

13a. It can be concluded that the fluctuations result from the Burnes effect.

13b。我们 得出结论，波动是由伯恩斯效应引起的。

13b. We conclude that the fluctuations result from the Burnes effect.

(13b) 中的主动动词concluded及其第一人称主语we不仅在科学中很常见，而且很恰当。区别？它与动词名称的动作类型有关。当作者提到只有作者/研究人员可以执行的动作时，主动（因此是第一人称）是合适的——不仅是修辞动作，例如suggest、concluded、argue或show，而且还有那些他们作为科学家获得荣誉的动作，例如设计实验、解决问题或证明结果。每个人都可以衡量, 但只有作者/研究人员有权观点他们的研究意味着什么。

The active verb in (13b), conclude, and its first-person subject, we, are not only common in the sciences, but appropriate. The difference? It has to do with the kind of action the verb names. The active (and therefore first person) is appropriate when authors refer to actions that only the writer/researcher can perform—not only rhetorical actions, such as suggest, conclude, argue, or show, but also those for which they get credit as scientists, such as design experiments, solve problems, or prove results. Everyone can measure, but only author/researchers are entitled to claim what their research means.

科学家通常在期刊文章的开头使用第一人称和主动动词，描述他们如何发现他们的问题，并在结尾描述他们如何解决问题。在这两者之间，当他们描述任何人都可以执行的过程时，他们经常使用被动语态。

Scientists typically use the first person and active verbs at the beginning of journal articles, where they describe how they discovered their problem and at the end where they describe how they solved it. In between, when they describe processes that anyone can perform, they regularly use the passive.

17.5 最终原则：复杂性最后

17.5 A FINAL PRINCIPLE: COMPLEXITY LAST

我们关注的是子句如何开始。现在我们看看他们是如何结束的。可以预见句尾的原则：熟悉的话信息最先，最新、最复杂的信息最后。这一原则在三种情况下尤为重要：

We have focused on how clauses begin. Now we look at how they end. You can anticipate the principle for ending sentences: if familiar information goes first, the newest, most complex information goes last. This principle is particularly important in three contexts:

• 当你介绍一个新的技术术语时

• when you introduce a new technical term

• 当您提供的信息单元又长又复杂时

• when you present a unit of information that is long and complex

• 当你介绍一个你打算在接下来发展的概念时

• when you introduce a concept that you intend to develop in what follows

17.5.1技术术语介绍

17.5.1 Introducing Technical Terms

当您向读者介绍新的技术术语时，请构造您的句子，使这些术语出现在最后几个词中。比较这两个：

When you introduce technical terms that are new to your readers, construct your sentences so that those terms appear in the last few words. Compare these two:

14a. 三十多年来，单胺假说一直是抑郁症的主要生物学解释。根据这一假设，包括多巴胺、肾上腺素、去甲肾上腺素和血清素在内的单胺缺乏与抑郁症有关。不同类型的抗抑郁药以不同方式调节神经突触中的单胺浓度。

14a. The monoamine hypothesis has been the leading biological account of depression for over three decades. According to this hypothesis, deficits in monoamines including dopamine, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and serotonin are associated with depression. Monoamine concentrations in neural synapses are regulated in different ways by different types of antidepressants.

14b. 三十多年来，抑郁症的主要生物学解释一直是单胺假说。根据这一假设，抑郁症与称为单胺的神经递质缺陷有关，包括多巴胺、肾上腺素、去甲肾上腺素和血清素。不同类型的抗抑郁药以不同的方式起作用来调节神经突触中单胺的浓度。

14b. For over three decades, the leading biological account of depression has been the monoamine hypothesis. According to this hypothesis, depression is associated with deficits in neurotransmitters called monoamines, including dopamine, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. Different types of antidepressants work in different ways to regulate concentrations of monoamines in neural synapses.

在 (14a) 中，所有听起来很专业的术语都出现在句子的前面；在 (14b) 中，技术术语出现在句子的末尾。

In (14a) all the technical-sounding terms appear early in the sentences; in (14b) the technical terms appear at the end of the sentences.

17.5.2引入复杂信息

17.5.2 Introducing Complex Information

将需要长短语或从句的复杂想法放在句子的末尾，而不是放在开头。再次比较 (11a) 和 (11b)：

Put complex bundles of ideas that require long phrases or clauses at the end of a sentence, never at the beginning. Compare (11a) and (11b) again:

11a. 我们的空气质量乃至世界气候都取决于亚洲、非洲和南美洲健康的雨林。但是越来越多的全世界对更多农业用地和建筑用木制品的需求现在威胁着这些森林的破坏。

11a. The quality of our air and even the climate of the world depend on healthy rain forests in Asia, Africa, and South America. But the increasing demand for more land for agricultural use and for wood products for construction worldwide now threatens these forests with destruction.

11b。我们的空气质量乃至世界气候都取决于亚洲、非洲和南美洲健康的雨林。但是，由于全世界对更多土地用于农业用途和用于建筑的木材产品的需求不断增加，这些热带雨林现在正面临破坏的威胁。

11b. The quality of our air and even the climate of the world depend on healthy rain forests in Asia, Africa, and South America. But these rain forests are now threatened with destruction by the increasing demand for more land for agricultural use and for wood products used in construction worldwide.

在 (11a) 中，第二句以一个长而复杂的信息单元开始，这个主语不止一行。相比之下，(11b) 中第二句的主语these rain forests简短、简单且易于阅读，同样是因为被动动词 ( are now threatened ) 让我们将简短而熟悉的信息翻到开头，漫长而复杂的部分到最后。

In (11a) the second sentence begins with a long, complex unit of information, a subject that runs on for more than a line. In contrast, the subject of the second sentence in (11b), these rain forests, is short, simple, and easy to read, again because the passive verb (are now threatened) lets us flip the short and familiar information to the beginning and the long and complex part to the end.

简而言之，不要以复杂的方式开始你的句子；留到最后。不幸的是，这并不容易做到，因为您可能对自己的想法非常熟悉，以至于您无法区分对读者来说什么是旧的、简单的，什么是新的、复杂的。

In short, don’t begin your sentences with complexity; save it for the end. Unfortunately that’s not easy to do, because you may be so familiar with your ideas that you can’t distinguish what is for your readers old and simple from what’s new and complex.

17.5.3介绍以下内容

17.5.3 Introducing What Follows

当你开始一个段落时，把出现在段落其余部分的关键术语放在第一句或第二句的末尾。这两个句子中的哪一个最能介绍接下来的段落的其余部分？

When you start a paragraph, put the key terms that appear in the rest of the paragraph at the end of the first or second sentence. Which of these two sentences would best introduce the rest of the paragraph that follows?

15a。政治局势发生了变化，因为对王位继承的争论困扰着彼得大帝之后罗曼诺夫家族八次统治中的七次。

15a. The political situation changed, because disputes over succession to the throne plagued seven of the eight reigns of the Romanov line after Peter the Great.

15b。政治局势发生了变化，因为在彼得大帝之后，罗曼诺夫家族的八个统治者中有七个因王位继承争议而陷入动荡。

15b. The political situation changed, because after Peter the Great seven of the eight reigns of the Romanov line were plagued by turmoil over disputed succession to the throne.

问题始于 1722 年，当时彼得大帝通过了一项继承法，终止了遗传原则，要求君主指定继承人。但由于包括彼得在内的许多沙皇在指定继任者之前就去世了，那些渴望统治的人没有任命的权力，因此他们的继任往往是受到下层贵族的争议。甚至在任命继任者时也出现了动荡。

The problems began in 1722, when Peter the Great passed a law of succession that terminated the principle of heredity and required the sovereign to appoint a successor. But because many tsars, including Peter, died before they named successors, those who aspired to rule had no authority by appointment, and so their succession was often disputed by lower-level aristocrats. There was turmoil even when successors were appointed.

大多数读者认为 (15b) 与文章的其余部分联系更紧密。(15a) 的最后几句话对于后面的内容来说似乎并不重要（当然，在另一个上下文中，它们可能很重要）。

Most readers feel that (15b) is more closely connected to the rest of the passage. The last few words of (15a) seem unimportant in relation to what follows (in another context, of course, they might be crucial).

因此，一旦您检查了每个句子中的前六或七个单词，还要检查后五或六个单词。如果这些词不是最重要、最复杂或最重要的，请进行修改以使其成为最重要的词。尤其要注意介绍段落甚至章节的句子结尾。

So once you’ve checked the first six or seven words in every sentence, check the last five or six as well. If those words are not the most important, complex, or weighty, revise so that they are. Look especially at the ends of sentences that introduce paragraphs or even sections.

17.6 吐出并擦亮

17.6 SPIT AND POLISH

我们专注于与撰写研究论文相关的句子风格问题，以及有助于使散文尽可能可读的诊断和修改原则。还有其他原则——句子长度、正确的单词选择、简洁等等。但这些都是与各种写作相关的问题，并且在许多书中都有涉及。当然，仅可读性是不够的。修改样式后，您仍然需要检查语法、拼写和标点符号。然后你必须确保你已经遵守了代表数字、专有名称、外来词等的公认约定。这些问题虽然重要，但不在本书的讨论范围之内。

We’ve focused on those issues of sentence style relevant to writing research papers, and on principles of diagnosis and revision that help make prose as readable as possible. There are other principles—sentence length, the right choice of words, concision, and so on. But those are issues pertinent to writing of all kinds and are addressed by many books. And, of course, readability alone is not enough. After you revise your style, you still have to check your grammar, spelling, and punctuation. Then you have to make sure that you have observed the accepted conventions for representing numbers, proper names, foreign words, and so on. Though important, those matters fall outside the purview of this book.

快速提示：最快的修订策略

Quick Tip: The Quickest Revision Strategy

我们关于复习的建议可能看起来过于详细，但如果你按步骤复习，遵循起来并不难。第一步是最重要的：当你起草时，记住忘记这些步骤（除了关于记住的这一步）。您的第一份工作是起草要修改的内容。如果你一直问自己是否应该只使用动词或名词，你将永远不会这样做。如果您没有时间查看每个句子，请从您发现难以解释您的想法的段落开始。当您努力写出令人困惑的内容时，您的句子也会变得混乱。

Our advice about revision may seem overly detailed, but if you revise in steps, it’s not difficult to follow. The first step is the most important: as you draft, remember to forget these steps (except for this one about remembering). Your first job is to draft something to revise. You will never do that if you keep asking yourself whether you should have just used a verb or a noun. If you don’t have time to look at every sentence, start with passages where you found it hard to explain your ideas. When you struggle to write about confusing content, your sentences tend toward confusion as well.

为了清晰和流畅

For Clarity and Flow

诊断：

To diagnose:

1. 突出每句话的前六七个词。忽略简短的介绍性短语，例如At first，For the most part，等等。

1. Highlight the first six or seven words in every sentence. Ignore short introductory phrases such as At first, For the most part, and so on.

2. 向下浏览页面，检查是否突出显示了一组一致的相关词。一系列句子的开头词不必完全相同，但它们应该指出读者将看到的明显相关的人物或概念。如果没有，请修改。

2. Run your eye down the page, checking whether you highlighted a consistent set of related words. The words that begin a series of sentences need not be identical, but they should name people or concepts that your readers will see are clearly related. If not, revise.

3.检查每个句子中突出显示的单词。它们应该包括一个命名角色的主语和一个命名重要动作的动词。如果没有，请修改。

3. Check the highlighted words in each sentence. They should include a subject that names a character and a verb that names an important action. If not, revise.

修改：

To revise:

1. 确定你的主要角色，真实的或概念上的。使它们成为动词的主语。

1. Identify your main characters, real or conceptual. Make them the subjects of verbs.

2. 寻找以-tion、-ment、-ence等结尾的名词。如果它们是动词的主语，就把它们变成动词。

2. Look for nouns ending in -tion, -ment, -ence, and so on. If they are the subjects of verbs, turn them into verbs.

3.确保每句话都以熟悉的信息开头，最好是你之前提到过的人物。

3. Make sure that each sentence begins with familiar information, preferably a character you have mentioned before.

为了强调

For Emphasis

诊断：

To diagnose:

1.在每句话的最后五六个字下划线。

1. Underline the last five or six words in every sentence.

2.你应该有下划线

2. You should have underlined

• 您第一次使用的听起来很专业的词

• technical-sounding words that you are using for the first time

• 最新、最复杂的信息

• the newest, most complex information

• 最重要的信息

• information that is most emphatic

• 接下来几个句子将发展的概念

• concepts that the next several sentences will develop

3. 如果你没有看到那里的信息，修改：把这些词放在句子的最后。

3. If you do not see that information there, revise: put those words last in the sentence.

第五部分

PART V

最后的一些考虑

Some Last Considerations

研究伦理

The Ethics of Research

在过去的几百页中，我们提供了很多实用的建议，但也有很多关于与读者建立社会契约、投射一种鼓励他们信任的精神、在收集和报告证据时防止偏见、避免剽窃、等等。现在我们想与您分享影响我们建议的潜在道德问题，希望您在合上本书时能多加思考。

In the last few hundred pages, we’ve offered a lot of practical advice, but also much preaching about creating social contracts with your readers, projecting an ethos that will encourage their trust, guarding against biases in collecting and reporting evidence, avoiding plagiarism, and so on. Now we want to share with you the underlying ethical issues that shape our advice, hoping that when you close this book, you’ll give them more thought.

我们所说的关于研究的一切都反映了我们的信念，即它是一种深刻的社会活动，它将你与那些将使用你的研究的人以及可能从这种使用中受益或受害的人联系起来。但它也将您和您的读者与您使用其研究的每个人联系起来，并超越他们与他们使用其研究的每个人联系起来。为了理解我们现在和未来对该网络中的人的责任，我们必须超越单纯的技术来思考民间传播的伦理。

Everything we’ve said about research reflects our belief that it is a profoundly social activity that connects you both to those who will use your research and to those who might benefit—or suffer—from that use. But it also connects you and your readers to everyone whose research you used and beyond them to everyone whose research they used. To understand our responsibility to those in that network, now and in the future, we have to move beyond mere technique to think about the ethics of civil communication.

我们从道德这个词的两个广泛概念开始：建立社区的纽带和我们在该社区中行动时面临的道德选择。道德一词来自希腊精神，意思是一个社区的共同习俗或一个人的性格，好或坏。到目前为止，我们一直专注于研究的社区建设方面，我们与读者和消息来源建立的联系。但与任何社会活动​​一样，研究挑战我们定义我们的个人道德原则，然后做出尊重或违反这些原则的选择。

We start with two broad conceptions of the word ethics: the forging of bonds that create a community and the moral choices we face when we act in that community. The term ethical comes from the Greek ethos, meaning either a community’s shared customs or an individual’s character, good or bad. So far, we have focused on the community-building aspects of research, the bonds we create with our readers and our sources. But as does any social activity, research challenges us to define our individual ethical principles and then to make choices that honor or violate them.

乍一看，一个纯粹的学术研究人员似乎相对安全的道德基础——我们不太愿意为了利益而牺牲原则，比方说，华尔街分析师评估她的公司希望她推销给投资者的股票，或者制药公司付钱给科学家以“证明”产品是安全（无论它是否有效）。没有老师会付钱让你写一篇支持她观点的论文，而且你可能没有机会通过伪造结果来获得名声——就像因发现 HIV 病毒而出名（和有权势）的美国研究人员，而他实际上从法国的实验室“借”来的。

At first glance, a purely academic researcher seems on relatively safe ethical ground—we are less tempted to sacrifice principle for gain than, say, a Wall Street analyst evaluating a stock that her firm wants her to push on investors, or a scientist paid by a drug company to “prove” that a product is safe (regardless of whether it works). No teacher will pay you to write a paper supporting her views, and you probably won’t have occasion to fake results to gain fame—like the American researcher who became famous (and powerful) for discovering an HIV virus, when he had in fact “borrowed” it from a laboratory in France.

即便如此，您从项目一开始就会面临这样的选择。对于道德研究人员来说，有些是显而易见的“你不应该”：

Even so, you will face such choices from the very beginning of your project. Some are the obvious Thou shalt nots for ethical researchers:

• 他们不剽窃或声称他人的成果。

• They do not plagiarize or claim credit for the results of others.

• 他们不会误报来源、编造数据或伪造结果。

• They do not misreport sources, invent data, or fake results.

• 他们不会提交他们不信任其准确性的数据，除非他们这样说。

• They do not submit data whose accuracy they don’t trust, unless they say so.

• 他们不会隐瞒无法反驳的异议。

• They do not conceal objections that they cannot rebut.

• 他们不会讽刺或歪曲相反的观点。

• They do not caricature or distort opposing views.

• 他们不会销毁数据或隐藏对追随者重要的来源。

• They do not destroy data or conceal sources important for those who follow.

我们很容易将这些原则应用于明显的案例：使用印度墨水在他的老鼠身上伪造“遗传”标记的生物学家，安达信的安然会计师和他们的审计员粉碎了源文件，政府政治顾问擦掉了电子邮件，或提交在 Internet 上购买的论文的学生。

We apply these principles easily enough to obvious cases: the biologist who used india ink to fake “genetic” marks on his mice, the Enron accountants and their auditors at Arthur Andersen who shredded source documents, the government political advisers who erase e-mails, or the student who submits a paper purchased on the Internet.

更具挑战性的是那些道德原则使我们超越简单的“不要”到我们应该肯定地“做”的场合。当我们以这种方式思考道德选择时，我们就超越了自身利益与诚实追求真理之间的简单冲突，或者超越了我们为自己想要的与对他人有益或至少对他人无害之间的简单冲突。如果报告研究真的是读者和作者之间为寻找共同问题的最佳解决方案而进行的协作，那么挑战就是找到建立道德伙伴关系以做出道德选择的方法（我们传统上所说的性格）可以帮助建立道德社区。

More challenging are those occasions when ethical principles take us beyond a simple Do not to what we should affirmatively Do. When we think about ethical choices in that way, we move beyond simple conflicts between our own self-interest and the honest pursuit of truth, or between what we want for ourselves and what is good for or at least not harmful to others. If reporting research is genuinely a collaborative effort between readers and writers to find the best solution to shared problems, then the challenge is to find ways to create ethical partnerships to make ethical choices (what we traditionally call character) that can help build ethical communities.

这样的挑战提出了比我们在这里可以回答的更多的问题。其中一些问题的答案是我们都同意的；其他人是有争议的。我们五个人以不同的方式回答了其中一些问题。但我们同意的一件事是，研究向每位研究人员发出了道德邀请，当他们不仅尽职地接受而且接受时，可以为研究人员及其读者的最大利益服务。

Such a challenge raises more questions than we can answer here. Some of those questions have answers that we all agree on; others are controversial. The five of us answer some of them differently. But one thing we agree on is that research offers every researcher an ethical invitation that, when not just dutifully accepted but embraced, can serve the best interests of both researchers and their readers.

• 当您创建一个具有共同理解和兴趣的社区时，无论多么短暂，您都为您的工作设定了一个比您单独为自己设定的标准更高的标准。

• When you create, however briefly, a community of shared understanding and interest, you set a standard for your work higher than any you could set for yourself alone.

• 当您向他人解释为什么您的研究应该改变他们的理解和信念时，您不仅必须检查您自己的理解和兴趣，而且如果您说服他们改变他们的理解和兴趣，您还必须检查您对他们的责任。

• When you explain to others why your research should change their understanding and beliefs, you must examine not only your own understanding and interests, but your responsibility to them if you convince them to change theirs.

• 当您承认读者的不同观点（包括他们最强烈的反对意见和保留意见）时，您不仅更接近更可靠的知识、更好的理解和更健全的信念，而且更接近尊重读者的尊严和人类需求。

• When you acknowledge your readers’ alternative views, including their strongest objections and reservations, you move closer not just to more reliable knowledge, better understanding, and sounder beliefs, but to honoring the dignity and human needs of your readers.

换句话说，当你进行研究并将其报告为平等之间的对话，以求获得更多知识和更好地理解时，你对自己提出的道德要求应该有益于所有人——即使我们不能就共同利益达成一致。当你拒绝这种谈话时，你就有可能伤害自己，也可能伤害那些依赖你工作的人。

In other words, when you do research and report it as a conversation among equals working toward greater knowledge and better understanding, the ethical demands you place on yourself should redound to the benefit of all—even when we cannot all agree on a common good. When you decline that conversation, you risk harming yourself and possibly those who depend on your work.

正是这种对社区共同工作完整性的关注强调了研究人员为何如此强烈地谴责剽窃。剽窃是盗窃，但不仅仅是文字。通过不承认来源，剽窃者窃取了诚实的研究人员应该得到的适度认可，研究人员一生都在努力争取的尊重。通过降低研究对追随者的价值，这削弱了整个社区。

It is this concern for the integrity of the common work of a community that underscores why researchers condemn plagiarism so strongly. Plagiarism is theft, but of more than words. By not acknowledging a source, the plagiarist steals the modest recognition that honest researchers should receive, the respect that a researcher spends a lifetime struggling to earn. And that weakens the community as a whole, by reducing the value of research to those who follow.

这在所有研究社区都是如此，包括本科生课堂。学生剽窃者不仅从他的资源中窃取，而且从他的同事那里窃取，通过使他们的工作与购买或窃取的东西相比显得不那么重要。当这种知识窃取变得普遍时，社区会变得怀疑，然后是不信任，然后是愤世嫉俗：每个人都这样做。如果我不这样做，我就会落后。教师必须像担心教学和学习一样担心不被欺骗。更糟糕的是，剽窃者损害了她自己的教育，因此从更大的社会窃取了资源，该社会投入资源来培训她和她这一代人以后从事可靠的工作，社区将依赖的工作。

That is true in all research communities, including the undergraduate classroom. The student plagiarist steals not only from his sources, but from his colleagues by making their work seem lesser by comparison to what was bought or stolen. When such intellectual thievery becomes common, the community grows suspicious, then distrustful, then cynical: Everyone does it. I’ll fall behind if I don’t. Teachers must then worry as much about not being tricked as about teaching and learning. What’s worse, the plagiarist compromises her own education and so steals from the larger society that devotes its resources to training her and her generation to do reliable work later, work that the community will depend on.

简而言之，当您以合乎道德的方式报告您的研究时，您就加入了一个寻求共同利益的社区。当您尊重来源、保存并承认与您的结果不符的数据、仅在有保证的情况下强烈主张主张、承认您确定性的局限性并履行您作为研究人员和作家的所有其他道德义务时，您就超越了获得品级或其他物质商品——通过与读者建立联系，您可以获得更大的利益。你发现关注他人最大利益的研究也符合你自己的利益。

In short, when you report your research ethically, you join a community in a search for some common good. When you respect sources, preserve and acknowledge data that run against your results, assert claims only as strongly as warranted, acknowledge the limits of your certainty, and meet all the other ethical obligations you have as a researcher and writer, you move beyond gaining a grade or other material goods—you earn the larger benefit that comes from creating a bond with your readers. You discover that research focused on the best interests of others is also in your own.

教师后记

A Postscript for Teachers

在这篇后记中，我们想明确说明始终隐含的内容。我们希望您能参与改善国家“研究场景”的努力。太多的本科生老师说，我已经放弃教研究论文了。同事们告诉我们，他们得到的都是无聊的拼凑而成，学生们无法胜任这项任务，无论如何，死树研究论文是前数字时代的遗物，甚至只有象牙塔学者们不再做研究了。

In this postscript we want to make explicit what has been implicit throughout. We hope you will join in an effort to improve the national “research scene.” Too many teachers of undergraduates say, I’ve given up teaching the research paper. Colleagues tell us that the ones they get are boring patchworks, that students aren’t up to the task, that in any event the dead-tree research paper is a relic of pre-digital days, and even that no one but ivory-tower academics does research anymore.

当然，我们不这么认为。我们认为做研究是学习批判性阅读和思考的最佳方式。我们知道一个事实，即我们绝大多数学生的职业，如果他们不做自己的研究，他们将不得不评估并依赖他人的研究。我们还知道，大部分研究将采用书面形式，即使它恰好是在线交付的。我们想不出比自己进行研究更好地为这一责任做准备的方法了。

We think otherwise, of course. We think doing research is the best way to learn to read and think critically. And we know for a fact that the vast majority of our students will have careers in which, if they do not do their own research, they will have to evaluate and depend on the research of others. We also know that most of that research will be in written form, even if it happens to be delivered online. And we can think of no way to prepare for that responsibility better than doing research of one’s own.

我们为那些同意并相信——或至少会考虑——两个命题的人写这本书：

We wrote this book for those who agree, and believe—or will at least consider—two propositions:

• 当学生站在读者和社区的角度，他们的价值观和实践定义了胜任的研究和报告时，他们学会了做好研究并清楚地报告。

• Students learn to do research well and report it clearly when they take the perspective of their readers and of the community whose values and practices define competent research and its reporting.

• 当他们了解他们报告的一些关键正式特征如何影响他们的读者阅读和判断他们的方式时，他们学会管理该心理和社会过程的一个重要部分。

• They learn to manage an important part of that mental and social process when they understand how a few key formal features of their reports influence how their readers read and judge them.

我们认为，这两个命题是密切相关的。通过了解阅读和写作的互补过程，学生可以更好地计划、执行和报告他们的研究。他们不仅可以使用读者期望的功能来指导自己完成起草过程，还可以完成项目的所有阶段。通过了解他们的读者在报告中寻找什么，他们学会更批判性地阅读他人的报告。读和写这两个过程是相互支持的。

These two propositions, we believe, are closely related. By understanding the complementary processes of reading and writing, students plan, perform, and report their research better. They can use the features that readers expect to guide themselves through not only the process of drafting, but all the stages of their project. And by understanding what their readers look for in a report, they learn to read the reports of others more critically. The two processes, reading and writing, are mutually supporting.

实施正式规则的风险

THE RISKS OF IMPOSING FORMAL RULES

然而，强调形式特征有其风险，尤其是对于新研究人员而言。很容易将正式结构简化为空钻。那些只教舞者击中目标或教钢琴家只找到正确琴键的人剥夺了学生舞蹈或音乐的深层乐趣。那些通过数字教授研究的人，就好像它只是在学习脚注和参考书目的正确形式一样，剥夺了学生发现的乐趣，而这些学生本来可以用自己的优秀研究造福世界。

Emphasizing formal features, though, has its risks, especially with new researchers. It is easy to reduce formal structure to empty drill. Those who teach dancers only to hit their marks or pianists only to find the right keys deprive students of the deep pleasures of dance or music. Those who teach research by the numbers, as if it were merely learning the proper forms for footnotes and bibliography, deprive students of the pleasures of discovery, students who might otherwise have blessed the world with their own good research.

如果向学生展示如何以正确的精神进行研究，论证的特征就不再是空洞的形式，而是对激发和奖励认真思考的问题的回答。它们帮助学生认识到在研究人​​员、她的消息来源、她的学科同事和读者之间的关系中什么是重要的。这种认识是创造性和原创性研究的重要先决条件。

If students are shown how to approach research in the right spirit, the features of argument become not empty forms but answers to questions that stimulate and reward hard thinking. They help students recognize what is important in the relationship between a researcher, her sources, her disciplinary colleagues and readers. This recognition is a crucial prerequisite to creative and original research.

没有意义的形式鼓励空洞的模仿，尤其是当教师未能在课堂上创造一种修辞语境，使学生戏剧化他们作为研究人员的社会角色时，即使最初只是在模拟或角色扮演中。没有任何教科书能够完全创造出这种情境，因为它需要只有富有想象力的教师才能精心安排的课堂体验。

Forms empty of meaning encourage empty imitation, especially when teachers fail to create in their classrooms a rhetorical context that dramatizes for students their social role as researchers, even if at first only in simulation or role-playing. No textbook can fully create that context, because it requires a class experience that only imaginative teachers can orchestrate.

只有了解他独特的学生的老师才能设计出创造情境的作业，其社会动态为研究提供了意义和目的，并且学生可以识别和理解其期望。学生经验越少，在学生能够以富有成效的方式使用正式结构之前，教师必须提供更多的社会支持。

Only a teacher, understanding his unique students, can devise assignments that create situations whose social dynamic gives point and purpose to research and whose expectations students can recognize and understand. The less experience students have, the more social support teachers must provide before their students can use formal structures in productive ways.

关于作业场景：培养好奇心

ON ASSIGNMENT SCENARIOS: CREATING A GROUND FOR CURIOSITY

教师们已经找到了许多方法来构建研究任务，为学生提供这种必要的支持。最成功的具有以下特征：

Teachers have found many ways to construct research assignments that give students this necessary support. The most successful have these features:

1. 良好的分配建立的结果超出了要评估的产品。好的老师会要求学生提出至少他们想要解决的问题，并用可靠和相关的证据来支持该解决方案。好的研究作业要求学生将私人兴趣转化为公共兴趣，这样他们就可以体验到，或者至少可以想象，需要只有他们才能提供的理解的读者。

1. Good assignments establish outcomes beyond a product to be evaluated. Good teachers ask students to raise a question or problem that at least they want to resolve, and to support that resolution with reliable and relevant evidence. Good research assignments then ask students to translate that private interest into a public one, so that they can experience, or at least imagine, readers who need the understanding that only they can provide.

最好的作业要求学生为那些真正需要更好地了解或理解某些东西的人写作。这些读者可能是某个问题所造成的短暂的研究人员社区，就像学生在课外为客户做研究一样。例如，高级设计课程可能会解决当地公司或民间组织的问题；音乐课可能会写程序笔记；历史课可能会调查他们大学的某些部分或当地社区的机构的起源。

The best assignments ask students to write for those who actually need to know or understand something better. Those readers might be a transient community of researchers that a problem creates, as when students do their research for a client outside of class. A senior design class, for example, might address a problem of a local company or civic organization; a music class might write program notes; a history class might investigate the origins of some part of their university or an institution in their local community.

经验不足的学生可能会为他们的同学写作，但他们也可能会为另一个班级的学生写作，这些学生实际上可以使用新手研究人员可以提供的信息。他们可能会为那些高级设计专业的学生或研究生研讨会的学生做初步研究；或者他们甚至可能会写报告给还在读高中的学生。

Less experienced students might write for their classmates, but they might also write for students in another class who could actually use the information that a beginning researcher could provide. They might do preliminary research for those senior design students or for students in a graduate seminar; or they might even write reports back to students still in high school.

其次最好的是模拟这种情况的作业，在这种情况下，学生假设其他学生或客户甚至其他研究人员有学生研究人员可以解决的问题。即使在大班教学中，学生也可以分成小组工作，小组成员充当读者，他们的兴趣是初学者可以合理解决的。

Next best are assignments that simulate such situations, in which students assume that other students or a client or even other researchers have a problem that the student researcher can resolve. Even in large classes, students can work in small groups whose members serve as readers with interests that beginning researchers can reasonably address.

2. 好的作业可以帮助学生了解他们的读者。大多数学生很难想象他们从未见过的读者和他们从未经历过的读者。没有与政府机构合作的知识或经验的生物学学生不太可能写出符合州环保局管理员关注的合理报告。但是教师可以通过敦促学生想象那些遥远的读者来提供帮助。或者，他们可以让学生决定哪些问题需要解决，哪些问题需要回答，从而将班级变成自己的听众。如果学生能够定义他们感兴趣的问题，他们将成为彼此研究的最佳读者。

2. Good assignments help students learn about their readers. Most students have trouble imagining readers whom they have never met and whose situation they have never experienced. Biology students with no knowledge or experience working with a government agency will be unlikely to write a plausible report that meets the concerns of a state EPA administrator. But teachers can help by urging students to imagine those distant readers. Alternatively, they can turn the class into its own audience by letting students decide what problems need solving, what questions need answering. If students can define the problems they’re interested in, they will make the best possible readers for one another’s research.

3. 好的作业会创造出包含丰富背景信息的场景。当学生写作来解决他们已知和接触到的读者的问题时，作业会呈现一个细节丰富的场景。只要时间和创造力允许，学生就可以调查、审问和分析情况。

3. Good assignments create scenarios that are rich in contextual information. When students write to solve the problems of readers known and accessible to them, the assignment presents a scenario rich in detail. Students can investigate, interrogate, and analyze the situation for as long as time and ingenuity allow.

但是，当在真实环境中定位项目不切实际时，作业应尽可能多地创建一个想象的环境。不可能预测学生需要了解的有关此类场景的所有信息，因此将对其进行分析和讨论作为写作过程的一部分非常重要。只有当学生在社会环境中工作时，他们才会有有意义的选择和做出这些选择的充分理由。只有这样，这些选择才具有修辞意义。只有当作家能够做出具有修辞意义的选择时，他们才会明白，每一个真正的写作项目的核心都是对读者反应的预期。当学生因为他们的项目没有修辞“场景”而只是机械演练而别无选择时，

But when it’s not practical to locate the project in a real context, the assignment should create as much of an imagined context as possible. It’s impossible to predict everything students need to know about such a scenario, so it is important to make analysis and discussion of it a part of the writing process. Only when students are working in a social context do they have meaningful choices and good reasons to make them. Only then are those choices rhetorically significant. And only when writers can make rhetorically significant choices will they understand that at the heart of every real writing project is the anticipation of their readers’ responses. When students have no choices because their project has no rhetorical “scene” and so is only a mechanical drill, doing research and writing it up become merely make-work—for you as much as for them.

我们再次强调学生之间热烈讨论的重要性，无论是在课堂上，如果班级足够小，或者如果班级很大，则在小组中。

Again we stress the importance of lively discussion among the students, either in class, if the class is small enough, or in subgroups if the class is large.

4. 好的作业提供临时读者。很少有专业研究人员在征求回应之前就称报告已经完成，而学生更需要这样的回应。鼓励学生征求同事、朋友、家人甚至您的早期回应。并为作业本身创造回应的机会。其他学生可以相当好地扮演这个角色，但如果他们认为他们的任务只是“编辑”——对他们来说，这通常意味着在这里重新排列一个句子并在那里修正一个拼写错误，那就不行了。让学生回答者完成第 12-17 章中的一些步骤；您甚至可以创建响应者团队，每个响应者负责文本的特定功能。提供临时响应的人必须作为想象中的读者参与场景。

4. Good assignments provide interim readers. Few professional researchers call a report finished before they have solicited responses, something students need even more. Encourage students to solicit early responses from colleagues, friends, family, even from you. And build opportunities for response into the assignment itself. Other students can play this role reasonably well, but not if they think that their task is just “editing”—which for them often means rearranging a sentence here and fixing a misspelling there. Have student responders work through some of the steps in chapters 12–17; you can even create teams of responders, each with responsibility for specific features of the text. Those who provide interim responses must participate in the scenario as imagined readers.

5. 与任何实际项目一样，好的作业会给学生时间和临时截止日期的时间表。研究是混乱的，所以让学生循序渐进是没有好处的：（1）选择主题，（2）陈述论文，（3）写大纲，（4）收集参考书目，（5）阅读并做笔记，（6 ) 写报告。那漫画真研究。但是学生需要一些框架，一个帮助他们监控进度的任务时间表。他们需要时间来错误的开始和死胡同，进行修改和重新考虑。他们需要临时期限和阶段来分享和批评他们的进步。这些阶段可以反映本书中概述的各种顺序。

5. As with any real project, good assignments give students time and a schedule of interim deadlines. Research is messy, so it does no good to march students through it lockstep: (1) select topic, (2) state thesis, (3) write outline, (4) collect bibliography, (5) read and take notes, (6) write report. That caricatures real research. But students need some framework, a schedule of tasks that helps them monitor their progress. They need time for false starts and blind alleys, for revision and reconsideration. They need interim deadlines and stages for sharing and criticizing their progress. Those stages can reflect the various sequences outlined in this book.

承认并容忍学习不可避免的混乱

RECOGNIZING AND TOLERATING THE INEVITABLE MESSINESS OF LEARNING

学生们也认真地——有时是迫切地——需要其他类型的支持，尤其是认识到对他们的期望，以及对即使是经验丰富的研究人员可预见的失误的容忍度。初学者的行为举止笨拙，他们将建议和原则视为僵化的规则，并机械地应用。他们从一个主题到一个问题，再到他们图书馆的在线目录，再到几个网站，不断前进，得出一个微弱的结论，这不是因为他们缺乏想象力或创造力，而是因为他们正在努力获得一项对他们来说极其陌生的技能. 这种尴尬是学习任何技能都不可避免的阶段。它通过了，但往往只有在他们转到其他班级之后。

Students also seriously—sometimes desperately—need other kinds of support, especially recognition of what can be expected of them and tolerance for the predictable missteps of even experienced researchers. Beginners behave in awkward ways, taking suggestions and principles as inflexible rules that they apply mechanically. They work through a topic to a question to their library’s online catalog to a few websites, marching on and on to a feeble conclusion, not because they lack imagination or creativity, but because they are struggling to acquire a skill that to them is surpassingly strange. Such awkwardness is an inevitable stage in learning any skill. It passes, but too often only after they have moved on to other classes.

当整个班级的初学者都写出相似的报告时，我们敦促您不要感到困扰。我们必须学会对学生有耐心，因为我们等待学习者达到真正的独创性时的延迟满足——知道当我们不再在那里看到它时，它很可能会到来。

We urge you not to be troubled when a whole class of beginning students produces reports that look alike. We have had to learn to be patient with students, as we wait for the delayed gratification that comes when the learners arrive at genuine originality—knowing it will likely come when we are no longer there to see it.

我们试图向学生保证，即使他们没有解决他们的问题，如果他们能够以一种让我们相信它是新的——至少对他们来说——并且可以说需要解决方案的方式提出问题，他们就会成功。证明有一个问题需要解决通常需要比解决问题更多的研究和批判能力，当然比学生可以提出一个简单的问题并回答它要多。

We try to assure students that even if they do not solve their problem, they succeed if they can pose it in a way that convinces us that it is new—at least to them—and arguably needs a solution. Proving that there is a problem to be solved often requires more research and more critical ability than solving it, certainly more than one in which a student can ask a simple question and answer it.

我们知道有些学生使用研究作业只是为了收集关于某个主题的信息，回顾某个领域只是为了控制它。对他们来说，对重大问题的需求似乎是人为的。你只能让他们想象他们正在为一个聪明的读者写作，这个读者可能对他们的主题感兴趣但没有时间做任何研究，这个读者确实处于他们所处的环境中。

We know that some students use research assignments simply to gather information on a topic, to review a field just to gain control over it. To them, the demand for a significant problem seems artificial. You can only ask them to imagine that they are writing for a reader who is intelligent and possibly interested in their topic but does not have the time to do any research, a reader who is, indeed, in the circumstance they are in.

最后，不同的学生与你教授的研究实践有着不同的关系。高级学生应该努力实现自己的纪律实践的全部质量。但很少有初学者致力于任何研究团体或本书所有内容背后的价值观。有些人会尽早做出承诺，但大多数人不会。有些永远不会。

Finally, different students stand in different relations to the research practices you teach. Advanced students should strive toward the full quality of your own disciplinary practices. But few beginners are yet committed to any research community or to the values that underlie everything in this book. Some will make that commitment early, but most will not. Some never will.

总之，要教好研究，我们教师必须调整我们在这里概述的步骤，以适应课堂上我们面前的个人的特定情况和需求。我们只能希望各级学生学习这些步骤，学会在其他写作项目中识别它们，然后自己尝试。也许那时他们可以转向我们的社会如此迫切需要但很少得到的那种可靠的研究和合理的决策。

In sum, to teach research well, we teachers must adapt the steps we’ve outlined here to fit the particular circumstances and needs of the individuals before us in class. We can only hope that students at all levels learn these steps, learn to identify them in other writing projects, and then attempt them on their own. Maybe then they can move toward the kind of sound research and reasoned decision-making that our society so badly needs but too seldom gets.

附录

Appendix

书目资源

Bibliographical Resources

有大量关于查找和呈现信息的文献，这里只能列出其中的一部分。如需更多和更新的选择，请查阅国会图书馆目录或在线书商。此处提供了在线可用资源的 URL（作为传统印刷格式的补充或替代传统印刷格式）。其他来源也可以在线或电子书格式获得；咨询你的图书馆。本榜单划分如下：

There is a large literature on finding and presenting information, only some of which can be listed here. For a larger and more current selection, consult the Library of Congress catalog or an online bookseller. URLs are provided here for sources that are available online (in addition to or in place of traditional print formats). Other sources may also be available online or in an e-book format; consult your library. This list is divided as follows:

对于其中大部分领域，列出了六种资源：

For most of those areas, six kinds of resources are listed:

1. 专业词典，提供定义某一领域概念的短文

1. specialized dictionaries that offer short essays defining concepts in a field

2. 对某个主题提供更广泛概述的一般和专业百科全书

2. general and specialized encyclopedias that offer more extensive overviews of a topic

3. 在不同领域寻找资源和使用它们的方法的指南

3. guides to finding resources in different fields and using their methodologies

4. 列出不同领域过去和现在出版物的书目、摘要和索引

4. bibliographies, abstracts, and indexes that list past and current publications in different fields

5.编写不同领域的手册

5. writing manuals for different fields

6. 描述不同领域引文所需特征的样式手册

6. style manuals that describe required features of citations in different fields

互联网数据库（参考书目和索引）

Internet Databases (Bibliographies and Indexes)

一般的

General

ERIC. Educational Resources Information Center. Washington, DC: US Department of Education, Institute of Education Sciences, 2004–. http://www.eric.ed.gov/.

一般 OneFile。密歇根州法明顿希尔斯：Gale Cengage Learning，2006 年–。http://www.gale.cengage.com/。

General

数据的视觉表示（表格、数字、海报等）

Visual Representation of Data (Tables, Figures, Posters, etc.)

2. Harris, Robert L. Information Graphics: A Comprehensive Illustrated Reference。纽约：牛津大学出版社，2000 年。

2. Harris, Robert L. Information Graphics: A Comprehensive Illustrated Reference. New York: Oxford University Press, 2000.

3. Cleveland, William S.图形数据的元素。修订版。新泽西州萨米特：霍巴特出版社，1994 年。

3. Cleveland, William S. The Elements of Graphing Data. Rev. ed. Summit, NJ: Hobart Press, 1994.

3. Cleveland, William S.可视化数据。新泽西州萨米特：霍巴特出版社，1993 年。

3. Cleveland, William S. Visualizing Data. Summit, NJ: Hobart Press, 1993.

3. Monmonier，马克。绘制出来：人文和社会科学的说明性制图。芝加哥：芝加哥大学出版社，1993 年。

3. Monmonier, Mark. Mapping It Out: Expository Cartography for the Humanities and Social Sciences. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1993.

3. Tufte, Edward R.展望信息。康涅狄格州柴郡：图形，1990 年。

3. Tufte, Edward R. Envisioning Information. Cheshire, CT: Graphics, 1990.

3. Tufte, Edward R.定量信息的视觉显示。第二版。康涅狄格州柴郡：图形出版社，2001 年。

3. Tufte, Edward R. The Visual Display of Quantitative Information. 2nd ed. Cheshire, CT: Graphics Press, 2001.

3. Tufte, Edward R.视觉和统计思维：显示决策证据。康涅狄格州柴郡：图形出版社，1997 年。

3. Tufte, Edward R. Visual and Statistical Thinking: Displays of Evidence for Making Decisions. Cheshire, CT: Graphics Press, 1997.

3. 霍华德·韦纳。视觉启示：从拿破仑波拿巴到罗斯佩罗的命运和欺骗的图解故事。纽约：心理学出版社，2014 年。

3. Wainer, Howard. Visual Revelations: Graphical Tales of Fate and Deception from Napoleon Bonaparte to Ross Perot. New York: Psychology Press, 2014.

5. 胡同，迈克尔。科学演讲的技巧：成功的关键步骤和避免的关键错误。第二版。纽约：施普林格出版社，2013 年。

5. Alley, Michael. The Craft of Scientific Presentations: Critical Steps to Succeed and Critical Errors to Avoid. 2nd ed. New York: Springer, 2013.

5.布里斯科，玛丽海伦。准备科学插图：更好的海报、演示文稿和出版物指南。第二版。纽约：施普林格出版社，1996 年。

5. Briscoe, Mary Helen. Preparing Scientific Illustrations: A Guide to Better Posters, Presentations, and Publications. 2nd ed. New York: Springer, 1996.

5. Esposito、Mona、Kaye Marshall 和 Fredricka L. Stoller。“专家海报会议。” 在基于内容的教学的新方法中，由 Donna M. Brinton 和 Peter Master 编辑，115-18。弗吉尼亚州亚历山大市：向说其他语言的人讲英语的教师，1997 年。

5. Esposito, Mona, Kaye Marshall, and Fredricka L. Stoller. “Poster Sessions by Experts.” In New Ways in Content-Based Instruction, edited by Donna M. Brinton and Peter Master, 115–18. Alexandria, VA: Teachers of English to Speakers of Other Languages, 1997.

5. Kosslyn, Stephen M.图形设计要素。纽约：WH 弗里曼出版社，1994 年。

5. Kosslyn, Stephen M. Elements of Graph Design. New York: W. H. Freeman, 1994.

5. 格雷格·拉金。“故事板：生成有效视觉效果的具体方法。” 技术写作与交流杂志26，没有。3 (1996): 273–89。

5. Larkin, Greg. “Storyboarding: A Concrete Way to Generate Effective Visuals.” Journal of Technical Writing and Communication 26, no. 3 (1996): 273–89.

5. Nicol、Adelheid AM 和 Penny M. Pexman。展示您的发现：创建图形、海报和演示文稿的实用指南。第 6 版。华盛顿特区：美国心理学会，2010 年。

5. Nicol, Adelheid A. M., and Penny M. Pexman. Displaying Your Findings: A Practical Guide for Creating Figures, Posters, and Presentations. 6th ed. Washington, DC: American Psychological Association, 2010.

5. Nicol, Adelheid A. M., and Penny M. Pexman. Presenting Your Findings: A Practical Guide for Creating Tables. 6th ed. Washington, DC: American Psychological Association, 2010.

The Cambridge History of English and American Literature: An Encyclopedia in Eighteen Volumes. New York: G. P. Putnam’s Sons, 1907–21. Bartleby.com, 2000. At http://www.bartleby.com/cambridge/.

3. Altick、Richard Daniel 和 John J. Fenstermaker。文学研究的艺术。第 4 版。纽约：WW 诺顿出版社，1993 年。

3. Altick, Richard Daniel, and John J. Fenstermaker. The Art of Literary Research. 4th ed. New York: W. W. Norton, 1993.

3. Harner, James L. Literary Research Guide: An Annotated List of Reference Sources in English Literary Studies。第 5 版。纽约：美国现代语言协会，2008 年。

3. Harner, James L. Literary Research Guide: An Annotated Listing of Reference Sources in English Literary Studies. 5th ed. New York: Modern Language Association of America, 2008.

3. 克莱尔，马里奥。文学研究概论。第二版。伦敦：劳特利奇出版社，2004 年。

3. Klarer, Mario. An Introduction to Literary Studies. 2nd ed. London: Routledge, 2004.

3. Vitale, Philip H.研究的基本工具：英语学生注释指南。第三版，转。和英文。纽约：巴伦教育系列丛书，1975 年。

3. Vitale, Philip H. Basic Tools of Research: An Annotated Guide for Students of English. 3rd ed., rev. and enl. New York: Barron’s Educational Series, 1975.

4.英语研究文摘。科罗拉多州博尔德：全国英语教师委员会，1958-91 年。再版，纽卡斯尔，特拉华州：Oak Knoll Press，2003 年。另见 http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000521812。

4. Abstracts of English Studies. Boulder, CO: National Council of Teachers of English, 1958–91. Reprint, New Castle, DE: Oak Knoll Press, 2003. Also at http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000521812.

4. Blanck、Jacob、Virginia L. Smyers 和 Michael Winship。美国文学书目。9卷。康涅狄格州纽黑文：耶鲁大学出版社，1955-91 年。也在http://collections.chadwyck.co.uk/。

4. Blanck, Jacob, Virginia L. Smyers, and Michael Winship. Bibliography of American Literature. 9 vols. New Haven, CT: Yale University Press, 1955–91. Also at http://collections.chadwyck.co.uk/.

4.美国期刊诗歌索引。新泽西州梅图兴：稻草人出版社，1971-2006 年。

4. Index of American Periodical Verse. Metuchen, NJ: Scarecrow Press, 1971–2006.

4. MLA 国际书目。纽约：美国现代语言协会。http://www.mla.org/bibliography/。

4. MLA International Bibliography. New York: Modern Language Association of America. http://www.mla.org/bibliography/.

5. Barnet、Sylvan 和 William E. Cain。文学写作简明指南。第 12 版。纽约：Longman/Pearson，2011 年。

5. Barnet, Sylvan, and William E. Cain. A Short Guide to Writing about Literature. 12th ed. New York: Longman/Pearson, 2011.

5. 格里菲斯，凯利。文学论文写作：指南和样式表。第 9 版。波士顿：Wadsworth Cengage Learning，2014 年。

5. Griffith, Kelley. Writing Essays about Literature: A Guide and Style Sheet. 9th ed. Boston: Wadsworth Cengage Learning, 2014.

6. MLA 研究论文作者手册。第 8 版。纽约：美国现代语言协会，2016 年。

6. MLA Handbook for Writers of Research Papers. 8th ed. New York: Modern Language Association of America, 2016.

Music

1. Randel, Don Michael, ed. 哈佛音乐词典。第 4 版。马萨诸塞州剑桥市：哈佛大学出版社贝尔纳普出版社，2003 年。

1. Randel, Don Michael, ed. The Harvard Dictionary of Music. 4th ed. Cambridge, MA: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press, 2003.

1. Sadie、Stanley 和 John Tyrrell 合编。新格罗夫音乐和音乐家词典。第二版。29 卷。纽约：Grove，2001 年。也可在http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/（作为Grove Music Online的一部分）。

1. Sadie, Stanley, and John Tyrrell, eds. The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians. 2nd ed. 29 vols. New York: Grove, 2001. Also at http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/ (as part of Grove Music Online).

2. Netti、Bruno、Ruth M. Stone、James Porter 和 Timothy Rice，编。世界音乐花环百科全书。10 卷。纽约：加兰，1998-2013 年。也在http://alexanderstreet.com/。

3. Duckles, Vincent H., Ida Reed, and Michael A. Keller, eds. Music Reference and Research Materials: An Annotated Bibliography. 5th ed. New York: Schirmer Books, 1997.

5. Druesedow, John E., Jr. Library Research Guide to Music: Illustrated Search Strategy and Sources. Ann Arbor, MI: Pierian Press, 1982.

5. 赫伯特，特雷弗。文字中的音乐：音乐研究和写作指南。第二版。伦敦：ABRSM，2012 年。

5. Herbert, Trevor. Music in Words: A Guide to Researching and Writing about Music. 2nd ed. London: ABRSM, 2012.

5.温格尔，理查德。写音乐：入门指南。第 4 版。新泽西州上马鞍河：Pearson Prentice Hall，2009 年。

5. Wingell, Richard. Writing about Music: An Introductory Guide. 4th ed. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Pearson Prentice Hall, 2009.

社会科学

Social Sciences

一般的

General

1. 卡尔霍恩，克雷格，编辑。社会科学词典。纽约：牛津大学出版社，2002 年。另见http://www.oxfordreference.com/。

1. Calhoun, Craig, ed. Dictionary of the Social Sciences. New York: Oxford University Press, 2002. Also at http://www.oxfordreference.com/.

1.美国统计摘要。华盛顿特区：美国人口普查局，1878 年–。同样在http://www.census.gov/compendia/statab/。

4. Abstracts in Anthropology. Amityville, NY: Baywood Publishing, 1970–. Also at http://anthropology.metapress.com/.

4.人类学年度回顾。加利福尼亚州帕洛阿尔托：Annual Reviews Inc.，1972–。也在http://www.annualreviews.org/journal/anthro上。

4. Annual Review of Anthropology. Palo Alto, CA: Annual Reviews Inc., 1972–. Also at http://www.annualreviews.org/journal/anthro.

商业

Business

1. Nisberg, Jay N. The Random House Dictionary of Business Terms. New York: Random House, 1992.

1. Wiechmann, Jack G., and Laurence Urdang, eds. NTC’s Dictionary of Advertising. 2nd ed. Lincolnwood, IL: National Textbook, 1993.

2. Folsom、W. Davis 和 Stacia N. VanDyne，编辑。美国商业百科全书。修订版。2卷。纽约：档案事实，2004 年。

2. Warner、Malcolm 和 John P. Kotter 编着。国际商业与管理百科全书。第二版。8 卷。伦敦：汤姆森学习出版社，2002 年。

3. 布莱曼、艾伦和艾玛贝尔。商业研究方法。第 4 版。纽约：牛津大学出版社，2015 年。

3. Bryman, Alan, and Emma Bell. Business Research Methods. 4th ed. New York: Oxford University Press, 2015.

3. Daniells, Lorna M.商业信息来源。第三版。伯克利：加州大学出版社，1993 年。

3. Daniells, Lorna M. Business Information Sources. 3rd ed. Berkeley: University of California Press, 1993.

3. Moss、Rita W. 和 David G. Ernsthausen。施特劳斯商业信息手册：图书馆员、学生和研究人员指南。第三版。康涅狄格州韦斯特波特：无限图书馆，2012 年。

3. Moss, Rita W., and David G. Ernsthausen. Strauss’s Handbook of Business Information: A Guide for Librarians, Students, and Researchers. 3rd ed. Westport, CT: Libraries Unlimited, 2012.

3. Sekaran、Uma 和 Roger Bougie。商业研究方法：技能培养方法。第 6 版。纽约：约翰威利父子出版社，2013 年。

3. Sekaran, Uma, and Roger Bougie. Research Methods for Business: A Skill Building Approach. 6th ed. New York: John Wiley and Sons, 2013.

3. Woy，James B.，编辑。商业信息来源百科全书。第 32 版。2卷。底特律：Gale Cengage Learning，2015 年。

3. Woy, James B., ed. Encyclopedia of Business Information Sources. 32nd ed. 2 vols. Detroit: Gale Cengage Learning, 2015.

4.商业期刊索引。纽约：HW Wilson，1958–。同样位于http://www.ebscohost.com/academic/（作为Business Periodicals Index Retrospective）。

4. Business Periodicals Index. New York: H. W. Wilson, 1958–. Also at http://www.ebscohost.com/academic/ (as Business Periodicals Index Retrospective).

5. 法雷尔、托马斯 J. 和夏洛特多纳贝迪安。撰写商业研究论文：完整指南。北卡罗来纳州达勒姆：卡罗莱纳学术出版社，1991 年。

5. Farrell, Thomas J., and Charlotte Donabedian. Writing the Business Research Paper: A Complete Guide. Durham, NC: Carolina Academic Press, 1991.

6.维特，威廉。商法、法律研究和写作：手册。马萨诸塞州尼德姆高地：吉恩出版社，1991 年。

6. Vetter, William. Business Law, Legal Research, and Writing: Handbook. Needham Heights, MA: Ginn Press, 1991.

6. Yelin、Andrea 和 Hope Viner Samborn。法律研究和写作手册：律师助理的基本方法。纽约：阿斯彭出版社，2009 年。

6. Yelin, Andrea, and Hope Viner Samborn. The Legal Research and Writing Handbook: A Basic Approach for Paralegals. New York: Aspen Publishers, 2009.

1. Newton, Harry. Newton’s Telecom Dictionary. 26th ed. New York: Flatiron Books, 2011.

1. 沃森、詹姆斯和安妮希尔。传播与媒体研究词典。第 8 版。纽约：布卢姆斯伯里学术出版社，2012 年。

2. Jones, Steve, ed. Encyclopedia of New Media: An Essential Reference to Communication and Technology. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage, 2003.

2. 斯特恩、简和迈克尔·斯特恩。简和迈克尔·斯特恩 (Jane and Michael Stern) 的流行文化百科全书：从有氧运动和泡泡糖到娃娃谷和 Moon Unit Zappa 的名人录和内容的 A 到 Z 指南。纽约：HarperPerennial，1992 年。

2. Stern, Jane, and Michael Stern. Jane and Michael Stern’s Encyclopedia of Pop Culture: An A to Z Guide of Who’s Who and What’s What, from Aerobics and Bubble Gum to Valley of the Dolls and Moon Unit Zappa. New York: HarperPerennial, 1992.

4. Block, Eleanor S., and James K. Bracken. Communication and the Mass Media: A Guide to the Reference Literature. Englewood, CO: Libraries Unlimited, 1991.

1. Law、Jonathan 和 Elizabeth A. Martin，编辑。法律词典。第 8 版。牛津：牛津大学出版社，2015 年。

1. Law, Jonathan, and Elizabeth A. Martin, eds. A Dictionary of Law. 8th ed. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2015.

1. 理查兹、PH 和 LB Curzon。朗文法律词典。第 8 版。纽约：培生朗文出版社，2011 年。

1. Richards, P. H., and L. B. Curzon. The Longman Dictionary of Law. 8th ed. New York: Pearson Longman, 2011.

2. Baker、Brian L. 和 Patrick J. Petit 编着。法律信息来源百科全书。第二版。底特律：盖尔研究公司，1993 年。

2. Baker, Brian L., and Patrick J. Petit, eds. Encyclopedia of Legal Information Sources. 2nd ed. Detroit: Gale Research, 1993.

2.语料库 Juris Secundum。布鲁克林：美国法律书籍；明尼苏达州圣保罗：西部，1936 年–。

2. Corpus Juris Secundum. Brooklyn: American Law Book; St. Paul, MN: West, 1936–.

2. Gale 美国法律百科全书。第三版。14 卷。底特律：Gale Cengage Learning，2011 年。同样位于http://www.gale.cengage.com/。

2. Gale Encyclopedia of American Law. 3rd ed. 14 vols. Detroit: Gale Cengage Learning, 2011. Also at http://www.gale.cengage.com/.

2. Hall、Kermit 和 David Scott Clark，编辑。牛津美国法律指南。纽约：牛津大学出版社，2002 年。另见http://www.oxfordreference.com/。

2. Hall, Kermit, and David Scott Clark, eds. The Oxford Companion to American Law. New York: Oxford University Press, 2002. Also at http://www.oxfordreference.com/.

2. 帕特森，丹尼斯 M.，编辑。法哲学和法律理论的伴侣。牛津：布莱克威尔出版社，1999 年。

2. Patterson, Dennis M., ed. A Companion to Philosophy of Law and Legal Theory. Oxford: Blackwell, 1999.

3. Campbell、Enid Mona、Lee Poh-York 和 Joycey G. Tooher。法律研究：材料和方法。第 4 版。澳大利亚北莱德：LBC 信息服务，1996 年。

3. Campbell, Enid Mona, Lee Poh-York, and Joycey G. Tooher. Legal Research: Materials and Methods. 4th ed. North Ryde, Australia: LBC Information Services, 1996.

3.在线法律研究：超越 LexisNexis 和 Westlaw。洛杉矶：加州大学。http://libguides.law.ucla.edu/onlinelegalresearch。

3. Online Legal Research: Beyond LexisNexis and Westlaw. Los Angeles: University of California. http://libguides.law.ucla.edu/onlinelegalresearch.

4.现行法律期刊索引。西雅图：华盛顿大学法律图书馆，1948–。也在http://lib.law.washington.edu/cilp/cilp.html/。

4. Current Index to Legal Periodicals. Seattle: University of Washington Law Library, 1948–. Also at http://lib.law.washington.edu/cilp/cilp.html/.

4.现行法律索引。加利福尼亚州洛斯阿尔托斯：信息访问；密歇根州法明顿希尔斯：Gale Cengage Learning，1980–。

4. Current Law Index. Los Altos, CA: Information Access; Farmington Hills, MI: Gale Cengage Learning, 1980–.

4.法律期刊和书籍索引。纽约：HW Wilson，1924–。也在http://www.ebscohost.com/wilson/。

4. Index to Legal Periodicals and Books. New York: H. W. Wilson, 1924–. Also at http://www.ebscohost.com/wilson/.

5. Bast、Carol M. 和 Margie Hawkins。法律研究和写作的基础。第 5 版。纽约州克利夫顿公园：Delmar Cengage Learning，2012 年。

5. Bast, Carol M., and Margie Hawkins. Foundations of Legal Research and Writing. 5th ed. Clifton Park, NY: Delmar Cengage Learning, 2012.

5. Garner, Bryan A.法律风格的要素。第二版。纽约：牛津大学出版社，2002 年。

5. Garner, Bryan A. The Elements of Legal Style. 2nd ed. New York: Oxford University Press, 2002.

6.蓝皮书：统一的引用系统。第 19 版。马萨诸塞州剑桥市：哈佛法律评论协会，2010 年。另见 https://www.legalbluebook.com/。

6. The Bluebook: A Uniform System of Citation. 19th ed. Cambridge, MA: Harvard Law Review Association, 2010. Also at https://www.legalbluebook.com/.

6. Maroonbook：芝加哥大学法律引文手册。芝加哥：芝加哥大学，2013 年。

6. The Maroonbook: The University of Chicago Manual of Legal Citation. Chicago: University of Chicago, 2013.

3. 约翰逊、珍妮特·巴托夫和 HT 雷诺兹。政治学研究方法。第 7 版。洛杉矶：国会季刊出版社，2012 年。

4. Hardy, Gayle J., and Judith Schiek Robinson. Subject Guide to U.S. Government Reference Sources. 2nd ed. Englewood, CO: Libraries Unlimited, 1996.

4. United States Political Science Documents. Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh, University Center for International Studies, 1975–91.

4.世界政治科学文摘。马里兰州贝塞斯达：剑桥科学文摘，1976 年–。也在http://www.csa.com/。

5. Biddle、Arthur W.、Kenneth M. Holland 和 Toby Fulwiler。作家指南：政治学。马萨诸塞州列克星敦：DC Heath，1987 年。

5. Biddle, Arthur W., Kenneth M. Holland, and Toby Fulwiler. Writer’s Guide: Political Science. Lexington, MA: D. C. Heath, 1987.

5. Lovell、David W. 和 Rhonda Moore。政治和社会科学论文写作和文体指南。修订版。堪培拉：澳大利亚政治研究协会，1993 年。

5. Lovell, David W., and Rhonda Moore. Essay Writing and Style Guide for Politics and the Social Sciences. Rev. ed. Canberra: Australasian Politic Studies Association, 1993.

5. Schmidt, Diane E.政治学写作：实用指南。第 4 版。波士顿：朗文出版社，2010 年。

5. Schmidt, Diane E. Writing in Political Science: A Practical Guide. 4th ed. Boston: Longman, 2010.

5. Scott、Gregory M. 和 Stephen M. Garrison。政治学学生作家手册。第 7 版。波士顿：皮尔逊出版社，2012 年。

5. Scott, Gregory M., and Stephen M. Garrison. The Political Science Student Writer’s Manual. 7th ed. Boston: Pearson, 2012.

3. Reed, Jeffrey G., and Pam M. Baxter. Library Use: A Handbook for Psychology. 3rd ed. Washington, DC: American Psychological Association, 2003.

3. Shaughnessy、John J.、Eugene B. Zechmeister 和 Jeanne S. Zechmeister。心理学研究方法。第 10 版。波士顿：麦格劳-希尔出版社，2014 年。

3. Shaughnessy, John J., Eugene B. Zechmeister, and Jeanne S. Zechmeister. Research Methods in Psychology. 10th ed. Boston: McGraw-Hill, 2014.

3. 克里斯托弗·威尔逊。心理学研究方法：入门实验室手册。爱荷华州迪比克：肯德尔-亨特，1990 年。

3. Wilson, Christopher. Research Methods in Psychology: An Introductory Laboratory Manual. Dubuque, IA: Kendall-Hunt, 1990.

4. Science Citation Index. Philadelphia: Institute for Scientific Information, 1961–. Also at http://wokinfo.com/.

2. Smelser, Neil J., and Richard Swedberg, eds. 2nd ed. The Handbook of Economic Sociology. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 2005.

3. Aby、Stephen H.、James Nalen 和 Lori Fielding，编辑。社会学：参考资料和信息来源指南。第三版。康涅狄格州韦斯特波特：无限图书馆，2005 年。

3. Aby, Stephen H., James Nalen, and Lori Fielding, eds. Sociology: A Guide to Reference and Information Sources. 3rd ed. Westport, CT: Libraries Unlimited, 2005.

3. 斯坦利·利伯森。发挥作用：社会研究和理论的改进。伯克利：加州大学出版社，1987 年。

3. Lieberson, Stanley. Making It Count: The Improvement of Social Research and Theory. Berkeley: University of California Press, 1987.

4.社会学年度回顾。加利福尼亚州帕洛阿尔托：年度回顾，1975 年–。也在http://www.annualreviews.org/journal/soc上。

4. Annual Review of Sociology. Palo Alto, CA: Annual Reviews, 1975–. Also at http://www.annualreviews.org/journal/soc.

4.应用社会科学索引和文摘（ASSIA）。马里兰州贝塞斯达：剑桥科学文摘，1987–。也在http://www.csa.com/。

4. Applied Social Sciences Index and Abstracts (ASSIA). Bethesda, MD: Cambridge Scientific Abstracts, 1987–. Also at http://www.csa.com/.

4.社会科学研究。加利福尼亚州圣地亚哥：学术出版社，1972–。同样位于http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/0049089X/。

4. Social Science Research. San Diego, CA: Academic Press, 1972–. Also at http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/0049089X/.

4.社会学文摘。马里兰州贝塞斯达：社会学文摘，1952 年–。也在http://www.proquest.com/。

4. Sociological Abstracts. Bethesda, MD: Sociological Abstracts, 1952–. Also at http://www.proquest.com/.

5.社会学写作组。社会学论文写作指南。第 7 版。纽约：价值，2013 年。

5. Sociology Writing Group. A Guide to Writing Sociology Papers. 7th ed. New York: Worth, 2013.

5. Tomovic, Vladislav A., ed. 社会学中的定义：趋同、冲突和替代词汇；学期论文、研究报告和论文作者手册。安大略省圣凯瑟琳斯：Diliton 出版社，1979 年。

4. ScienceDirect. New York: Elsevier Science, 1999–. http://www.sciencedirect.com/.

5. Davis, Holly B., Julian F. Tyson, and Jan A. Pechenik. A Short Guide to Writing about Chemistry. Boston: Longman, 2010.

5. Ebel、Hans Friedrich、Claus Bliefert 和 William E. Russey。科学写作的艺术：从学生报告到化学及相关领域的专业出版物。第二版。德国魏因海姆：Wiley-VCH，2004 年。

5. Ebel, Hans Friedrich, Claus Bliefert, and William E. Russey. The Art of Scientific Writing: From Student Reports to Professional Publications in Chemistry and Related Fields. 2nd ed. Weinheim, Germany: Wiley-VCH, 2004.

5. 罗伯特·舍恩菲尔德。化学家的英语，“请用英语说吧！” 第三转。编辑。纽约：Wiley-VCH，2001 年。

5. Schoenfeld, Robert. The Chemist’s English, with “Say It in English, Please!” 3rd rev. ed. New York: Wiley-VCH, 2001.
